content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
You can't take the sky from me...Take Starpoint Gemini 2, Freelancer, Elite Dangerous and the worldbuilding of Starcraft 2, throw into a foodblender. Put on high for two minutes.*WHIRRR*This is the result. A gorgeous, whisky-soaked blend of a game where pilots drink greel distilled alcohol, where antimatter specks are used for deviant practices, and where combat takes place on a horizontal plane straight out of Assassins' Creed : Black Flag, on crack. All handled with the colour and panache of the original Torchlight, which exploded out of nowhere and revitalised the Dungeon Crawler genre. This promises, and mostly succeeds in doing the same for space exploration.I'm a leaf on the wind, I'm a leaf on the wind!In the time honoured tradition of all space exploration games everywhere, you are thrown into a starter ship, in this case, a dinky little corvette with a few broadside cannons, a few turrets, and a hull made of papier mache and shields made of soap suds. It is your job to find your Aunt Juno, who so very kindly left you this ship, and find out why you've been dragged out to the tail end of space, which is full of the scum of the universe, and work your way up the foodchain, blowing up said scum and villainy, and eventually become owner of a pimped up ship of doom and destruction. Depending on your playstyle this may be a top notch destroyer, with speed and agility and tons of guns, or a dreadnaught with a horrifying number of broadsides, or a heavy hauler with enough armour to qualify as having it's own gravitational pull.Or, y'know, you could buy a strike craft and try to outrun bullets, but that's for the clinically insane. Even top level shields and good guns won't allow you to toe it with the enemy dreadnaughts for -long-, but hey, whatever flicks your switch!Miner, trader, soldier, sailor...Rebel galaxy gives you a very, very diverse set of tools to work with, you can tool up for mining with lasers and fault scanners, or you can go full out commodity trader, and the economy is set up enough to actually handle that, with system averages and station histories that actually work properly and can be scanned from out of station across the system, allowing you to set up profitable trade routes back and forth. This can pay off very nicely once you have a high capacity hauler, particularly if that hauler has one of the contraband cargo expansions which means you can facilitate life as a smuggler on the side.Or you can just blow things up, because explosions are pretty. Blowing things up always work, and there's a terrifying variety of weapons, not just purchasable, but also lootable unique variants which can be discovered in the world, in loot crates or from the hulls of pirate lords, if you feel like converting them to scrap metal.The pool is wide, but not QUITE as deep as space promises...Rebel Galaxy offers a -lot- of activities, and offers enough in each activity to have you happily whiling away your time, moreso than Elite Dangerous did (and yes, I know many E;D fans who are going to burn me for that, but it's true), the mining is more sensibly handled due to the tractor beams, the combat is more visceral and less grindy, the trading makes more sense and doesn't require an excel spreadsheet to get the best out of. There's a real economy, and you don't need to be online to get the most out of the game.There are -two- buts to this rather delicious soup.One : The factions - They are present, but they're rather bland. More time and depth could have been put into them, faction exclusive ships for each faction would have been glorious, along with modules, as well as faction exclusive bases that you could dock at, along with missions and different reactions based on standing, as well as more complex interrelations between said factions. Right now you basically have only two paths you can follow. If there's anything that could exponentially increase the lifespan of this game - Faction DLC would do it. This would convert a 20-40 hour game to a 200-400 hour game. No joke.Two : Whilst the activities are good, they all tend to peter out once you get out past the destroyer mark, and the fact you can only hire gunship level mercenaries puts a hard cap on the kind of fights they can throw at you. Hiring capital level mercenaries would have solved this. Again, faction DLC for the win here.Final thoughts...Do these two issues stop this game from being anything other than excellent? No. It's still a bloody great game, and for the price point they're charging it's an absolute steal. It does however prevent me from slamming the "Essential" badge on, because I know that the devs could quite possibly get the Factions some love, and make this "the" game to beat. Hint hint. It does, however, easily merit being a game that people should look into, especially if you're someone who loved Freelancer, or similar games.Verdict : Highly RecommendedWriter and columnist for Just Reviews, where you can get similar fine reading material. Join our group, follow our curations, and throw me a like if you would like to keep up to date with our efforts!

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy... Bought it because of the soundtrack in the trailers... Took a gamble and hoped it would give me some entertainment... Man was I surprised... Sooo.... Breaking it down:1. You will feel like a frikking space cowboy.2. Music so damn good that you want the soundtrack in every possible format.3. The sheer size of this game is just shocking! Did NOT expect that when I started it.4. Broadside battles between two large spaceships might be the coolest thing ever.5. BROADSIDES!!!! (It´s so damn cool I had to mention it twice!).6. Voice actors are actually kind of good for a game thats not a AAA.7. Did I mention broadsides? 8. Simple, but complex. 9. One bug, ONE(1!), found during my entire playthrough. EA, Bethesda, Bohemian and just about everyone else, LOOK AT THESE GUYS AND LEARN!!! It was not even a gamebreaking bug! All it did was made me crash into a station after warp and my ship autodocked, which I had planned to do anyway so the bug actually made me save some time since I didn´t have to "slowboat" all the way after warp. Downsides then? Yeah a few actually, but many of them is just me being picky.1. Game gets repetetive after a while and considering how many ships there is you may just finish the story halfway through the ship line. 2. Main story line is waaay to easy. 3. Considering it´s a space game, you may actually believe there would be free flight in all directions... like up and down... but nope! ship stays leveled and all you need to think about is right, left, back and forward... However this is forgiven thanks to the awesomeness of broadside battles. 4. Soundtrack makes this game, without it (sometimes the music stops) it just feels empty. 5. Characters kind of lacked depth and you probably won´t get too attached to them. Despite the downsides I still give this game a solid 7/10. It has the right "feel" to it and It´s absolutely one of those "If this gets a sequel, the devs will get it all right" kind of game.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												This was one of the most fun space-based games I played in recent history... and I own/have played a LOT of space games.This is not exactly "space" sim as much as naval ship arcade-based action RPG, but it has the atmosphere, characters, and ship variety to keep things fresh.I clocked my 52.5 hours in a single play-through from start to finish, and yes, I did play this game for fun, so I did not rush past areas or just hop from mission to mission. I hunted for bounties, stopped raids, broke blockades, and... well... PLAY the damn game instead of just trying to get it over with.The game's unique take on broad-side combat, old-school battleship-style A la WWII, makes for a refreshing space experience that made me wonder why other space combat games did not adopt a similar format long ago.This is NOT an X3-equivalent space empire building sim, nor is it a hardcore rogue-like. It's simple a great single-player adventure with great combat mechanics and above-average story progression with TONS of polish and character. This is better than most AAA titles today.For the money, it's a steal at full price. On sale it's a MUST GET.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												This is an extraordinarily playable spaceship-piloting game. Very simple and easy to get into, whilst yet providing enough customisability and choice to justify the "open world" tag, it drew me in from the first five minutes and kept me completely immersed until the endgame. It has an easy learning curve, but it doesn't sacrifice complexity overmuch.Very pretty graphics and gratifying sound - the soundtrack, by the way, is PERFECT. And even if you don't like it, it has an amazing feature of being able to choose your own music, and assign it to different in-game scenarios. Reeeeeally nice touch.The story is quite an interesting one for sci-fi fans, and there is a surprising amount of speech/animation for a game at this price point - enough to make it a genuinely fun campaign. There is even replay value in the amount of choice in factions and weaponry.The only issue I have is that it's too short, in that the game initially hints at a large amount of content - ships; weapons; star systems, etc. and then simply makes these things very time-consuming to attain, and the end of the line- best ship; best weapons; final star system, happens a bit too soon, with the endgame lying on predictable lines from the progression set out on at the start. To sum up - extreme value for money here - just don't forget you're not playing an AAA title, like I did, and be disappointed that it ends too soon.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												To some this game will be a disaster that you hate, especially if you want a realistic space sim.Others will find it an exhilarating experience, "dumbed down" enough and arcadey enough that it's playable for the masses especially since you're locked in 2 dimensions.PLEASE RE-READ THAT AGAIN.Your ship can not move up or down, only left or right, in space. To many this will be a deal breaker.But wait!I tell you this game is a blast if you give it a chance. It will have you on the edge of your seat having a good old time as you learn the finer points of capital ship combat, and die in the process. The save system is very forgiving and you can have multiple playthroughs going at once (rename your ship to keep the saves separate is a good tip).There are mission boards with side missions and a main story line, commodities trading, tons of action and nothing a well timed deflector shield button press can't solve!  Lots of upgrades, weapons, shields, deflectors, various parts of the ship can be upgraded as well. Just enough depth in missions and main story to keep you going and the action can be intense. Also, each time you start the world you start in front seems to be based on some RNG combo as it's been different the 3 times my son and I started new games. Haven't done any comparisons for the rest of the "universe"Just make sure you are going in with the right expectations and I would expect you to find this game addicting and rewarding. Get it on sale and you won't be sorry!  Also, the music is awesome, just let the game load and the title screen run and it can be amazing on it's own!Here's a good example of an early experience: Flying an early ship with shields and deflector, trying to get a few side missions and upgrade my weapons. I pick up a dead drop and 4 fighter craft, all pirates, drop in on me and my hired Mercenary. we kick in our engines and split up, both targeting the same ship from different sides, blowing it out of.....space? Not air certainly! Anyway, it's a quick fight and we dispatch them easy, going to hyperspace and heading to take the dead drop back.Suddenly we get interdicted out of hypersace and it's pirates agian, but much worse as it's two medium sized cruisers with fighter escort.  Trying to isolate one target at a time we fight a retreating battle, luring the fighters away from the cruisers and trying to divide and conquer.The cruisers are having none of it and their thrusters flare as they quickly close the distance and open fire. Our shields are taking heavy damage and missiles are coming in (thank goodness for flak guns and deflector shields) when a militia destroyer warps in with fighter escort and opens fire on the pirate cruisers. Our 2 ships and the local constables, basically, wipe out the pirates in a fierce but ultimately one sided battle. The militia ship scans us after, tells us to move along and we head on our way to finish the mission.Phew!  Good times!Please remember this is 2 dimensional, left right only movement of your ship, but trust me it works and the game is actually quite a lot of fun!

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												This is the most fun that I've had with a spaceship-based combat game since Freelancer and, before that, X-Wing vs Tie Fighter.  I have not beaten it yet, but these are my impressions so far.The Good:  The PRICE. This game plays like a $60 AAA title.  Fast-paced combat in capital ships that actually includes you piloting instead of just giving commands.  Main storyline makes you want to learn more.  QWERTY controls are downright elegant - I own a controller but have no desire to use it.  No Z-Axis - I understand some people refuse to buy the game for this reason but, not only is it unnecessary, it would also make the game extremely awkward considering the types of ships you're flying. You won't miss it, trust me.  Young game, but so far, almost entirely bug free.  Epic blues soundtrack that changes songs depending on what you're doing in game. Fast music for fights, cruising music for, well, cruising.  The game world feels like Firefly would if it would have had a lot more in-space pewpew and also aliens. Lots of aliens.  Enough ship customization, but not so much that you feel like you need an encyclopedia. (looking at you, EVE)  Bits and pieces of humor throughout.  Graphics are pretty, if not necessarily stunning.   The galaxy is persistent, living, and breathing, and things are happening that have nothing whatsoever to do with you, which can cause interesting results.The Not-As-Good:  They're not planning on expansions or DLC or anything, last I heard, and there have been zero updates to the game since launch, though that was only 15 days ago. I'd like to think there's a big content patch in the works or something, but I have no evidence for that. The game is, however, absolutely stable, as far as I can tell, so maybe they're just considering it finished. (edit - as of 11/17/15, they have released a small patch)  Running missions to keep your ship powerful enough to take on the next story element might be too reptitive for some, though I'm enjoying it.  Escort missions are still kind of broken. I just did one where my client's destination was to a base that was aggressive to him, presumably because the base was aggressive to me. I don't know any reason a merchant would purposely go to a station whose defenses were going to shred him. On the first attempt, there was also a BIG fleet, and I didn't get credit for the mission because he got blown up. On the second attempt, no fleet, so although the station's defenses opened fire on us both, I got credit for the mission just before the merchant ship exploded. So I looted him and flew off, getting both the merchant's cargo and the pay for the escort. Amusing, but obviously not what the developers intended.Is this worth your $20? Absolutely. Zero question. Even if you don't particularly like these types of games, the lack of Z-axis might actually do it for you. It makes the game feel a lot less nauseating to those who typically can't handle the extra plane, and eliminates the circling buzzard effect that tends to plague starfighter-based games (Elite: Dangerous, looking at you).  There's something about running straight at a ship three times your size, turning and opening up your cannons and just shredding them that is immensely and uniquely gratifying while some fast-paced, hard-core electric guitar plays on queue, and the pirate-lord screams "No...no-no-no-NO!" then blows up, leaving behind a rare piece of ship equipment.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												This is easily one of the year's best games, combining the atmosphere and open "do what you like" dynamics of Freelancer, with combat similar to Starfleet Command / Black Flag (like those games your ship is restricted to the same plane, so this isn't a hardcore space sim, but it serves the gameplay well). The vibe is very much like Firefly, mostly due to the excellent grungy soundtrack, but also the look and feel of the ships, stations, and frontier-mentality characters that you meet. It works so well because the core gameplay is hugely enjoyable. Combat is dynamic and in-your-face, ships and missiles explode and shake the screen, lasers sear the side of your ship, damage is nicely modelled so that surviving a brutal encounter feels like you escaped by the skin of your teeth, your hull blackened, components shorting out, systems breaking down as you hurry to find repairs. I've spent most of my time doing missions from the bulletin boards rather than following the story, that's how much fun it all is.The universe is procedurally generated every time you start a new game, which certainly gives it legs, although to be honest the game is pretty large in scope; you'll spend at least 10 hours in the starting system, and there are many more after that. The difficulty at first is quite high, but it doesn't take long to get the hang of how combat works, and a few early upgrades will help you feel badass. Merceneries can be hired if you're still having trouble.There's more to the game than combat though, mining is actually a lot of fun (unlike Elite: Dangerous where it's sadly rather tedious), trading (legal or otherwise) is viable once you upgrade your cargo hold and find the best prices in the dynamic system, and there are plenty of things to run into out in the depths of space. Speaking of which, there's a real sense of "space" as you travel around, not enough to be tedious as you travel between planets, but enough to make it feel like a journey, watching nebulae whip by, unknown flotillas caught on the edge of your scanner, and the occasional tempting beacon to check out. The story is also a cut above the usual generic stuff, decent writing helped by the setting, and some nice voice work, plus the story missions are some of the best time to be had.I can possibly seeing it getting a bit repetitive after a while, but tell me a game that isn't. For 20 bucks you should get several days of enjoyment from this. It really depends on how much you enjoy the core gameplay loop, but for me this is the best space game released in 2015 by miles, because the developers clearly want you to have a blast. Constant updates and bug fixes show that they're committed to their customers, a great example of a two-man team showing the big boys how it's done.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												No time to read: Very pretty, but very shallow.Rebel Galaxy gives a great first impression. Great graphics, great soundtrack, great atmosphere. Different weapon types and visceral combat. No-one would blame you if you thought that this was the next Privateer or Freelancer.But delve into it a bit deeper and you begin to see the hollowness under its pretty exterior. Combat that was fun at the start becomes very repetitive the 20th time you beat the exact same group of pirates using the exact same tactics. There's not much to do in combat either, all of your weapons work on some form of autoaim so you don't even have the challenge of leading your target properly in order to hit them. The worst part of the combat is how its more attritional than based on maneuver. You'd think that because a lot of the ships' firepower is in their broadsides you can maneuver to 'cross their T' so you can take down targets much larger than you are, but all ships have omnidirectional turrets that make this very hard to do. Instead of fighters trying to get on each other's tail or ships trying to cross each others' T, Rebel Galaxy's ships are more like 2 RTS units shooting at each other: DPS and shielding are king and the effect of maneuver is minimal.This is made even worse by the way the game tiers its weapons and defenses. The tiers are set up in this game in such a way that its possible to get into a situation where you fight a ship you can never beat (i.e. their shields regenerate faster than you can ever damage them), and your only recourse is to grind money so you can buy the next higher tier of weaponry. It makes the game into one big grind. And the grind takes a LONG time. In the later stages of the game it would take upwards of 20 missions to fully upgrade your ship's weapons, shields and components to the next tier.The grind also puts the blandness of the procedurally generated universe into stark relief. Once you've seen all the types of stations in the first system, you've seen all the stations in the rest of the game. The only thing that differentiates one station from another is what tier of weapons they sell. There are no special 'capital planets' or 'story planets' like there were in Privateer or Freelancer. There's no sense of exploration as a station of one type in a system is virtually identical to a station of the same type in another system. You won't get the sense of discovery that you get when you first land in the Oxford system in the original Privateer, or when you land on a capital planet in Freelancer.The main storyline also falters at the very end. Barring the grind, the main quests are interesting enough to get you to the finale. The ending though, is bullpoo. Let's just say that someone leaves for no damn good reason, and you're dumped into the sandbox with very little fanfare. And by the time you finish it, you'd be so tired of the grind that the sandbox would no longer have any appeal.If you're looking for a Privateer or Freelancer-type game try Starpoint Gemini 2 instead. It's a lot less polished but it has a big enough universe to make discovery interesting, has a tolerable grind and more interesting combat. Or dust off the old joystick and play Independence War 2.

content:
Posted: January 28
												I'm old enough to have fond memories of playing Privateer and Freelancer.  I picked up Rebel Galaxy hoping to renew my love for those games.  While I didn't quite find what I was looking for, I found a solid game worth playing.For people who loved the aforementioned games for the open-ended exploration, the ability to build your bankroll by buying low on some planets and selling high on others, upgrading ships and weapons as you progressed, and the intriguing storyline, this game is definitely worth playing because it does all of those things well.  For those who loved those games because of the thrill of small craft in-cockpit open space dogfighting, you should probably look elsewhere. Rebel Galaxy managed to take the inherent 3D nature of space and reduce it to 2D, implementing a colonial era ship "broadside" style combat as if on the surface of invisible water.  It isn't necessarily bad, but not my cup of tea.  Essentially, you can really only do one thing, turn and fire over and over.  It gets repetitive after a while and eventually I found myself wishing I could auto-resolve battles to move on through the story.  That being said, the combat was not so off-putting as to keep me from playing until the end of the main story.  Bottom line, this game is worth what you pay for it but don't expect a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												Disclosure: I received an early Beta CopySimply put, I love the game. In essence for me it's Freelancer reborn, except with capital ships.The gameplay is fantastic, although I would strongly recommend a controller. Both the 360 one, and the Steam Controller work brilliantly with the game.One thing that separates the game from freelancer is the capital ships, and that you use Broadsides for your primary weapons. As such you need to get your sides facing the enemies.Fear not though, it's still super intense, and you have plenty of other weaponry. Ranging from Secondary fire ones such as EMP Waves, Flak cannons and plenty of turrets. Turrets are mostly A.I controlled, although you can set priorities for each and every one of them. Such as Fire at Any Craft, Target, Locked Targets only, or even Fighters only.This means that you can focus all fire on a single enemy, or you can handle the capital ships while your turrets deal with the swarms of enemy fighter and gunships.It's rather odd at first, but after a while it becomes extremely satisfying. To the point of almost feeling like you're in Battlestar Galactica fending off literal swarms of enemies.Sadly, you're unable to be a carrier and have your own fighters, although it's not too much of an issue.The story is very interesting, and it certainly is engaging. Although some story missions have very high requirements and as such you Have to go do other missions to get a better ship and equipment.This is no issue at all, and extremely fun. You can do a variety of missions, or you can just do pirate bounty hunting. Doing missions however increases or decreases your reputation with various factions. This in turn unlocking newer ship hulls, and equipment. You're also able to join some guilds, such as the Mercenaries or Merchants which give extra missions and other unique ship hulls.I would strongly encourage you to find one you like. Trading is not the most complex of systems, but very manageable, and slightly fun. I've never been much of a trader but each system and station has various prices and requirements. An impoverished station will pay a lot more for food and water than a well set up military one. While some might accept some contraband pirate items; ranging from Narco Cola, to Living Organs.Ships can also be scanned so be careful carrying contraband, the Militia will scan you and will hail you to explain yourself. If you simply ignore their Hails they will go hostile and attack you. If you want to play with those items, make sure to get a Smuggler's Cargohold; They can't be scanned ;)Graphics and performance wise the game does extremely well. It's no Star Citizen, but it looks great and runs even better. Now I might have an overkill machine with Two GTX 980Ti's, but playing at 4K with DSR I was topping out at 144FPS which is my monitor's cap, and at worst getting 80fps. The only slight complaint I have is little lag spikes when phasing in and out of a station. Although this is most likely an engine issue that'll soon be fixed for textures loading in and out.As for graphical options the game as plenty and they're all adjusted with through the game launcher. It also has 3 graphics APIs to choose from. DirectX 9, DirectX 11 and even OpenGL if you fancy using that.I unfortunately only have experience running the game in DX11, but it's done exceptionally well.The last thing I want to mention is the brilliant soundtrack. It's very similar to Borderlands, and I feel it suits the game very well. Personally it gives me a Borderlands and Cowboy Bebop feel to the game and I really enjoy having it on.In the game launcher however you can also create some custom music options so you can expand it all  if you so desire.All in all, I simply love the game. I've 40 hours into it, and I've still not finished the main story because I've been having so much fun with everything else. If you enjoyed Freelancer, I would really recommend the game; and for others it's simply a great mini sandbox open Space Action Sim with capital ships.PC Gameplay 60 FPS

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												I'm not really sure when space westerns became a thing. My secret inner weeb wants to point to Cowboy Bebop or Trigun, but it just as easily could have been Firefly or Starcraft or something else entirely. They're the logical conclusion of humanity expanding into space, really, embracing the freedom of an open universe without the unity or enlightenment of something like Star Trek. This is precisely where Rebel Galaxy lives, in a simple wild west approach to space battles and exploration.You begin the game by inheriting an old junk freighter from your aunt and running errands in it for an old alien acquaintance of hers. Following the main story missions unravels a lengthy, familiar tale of deep space intrigue and ancient artifacts. This is of course only one option of many in the vein of something like Sid Meier's Pirates! because you can just as easily haul cargo, claim bounties, or pirate convoys for as long as the game holds your attention. A fair spread of ships, weapons, and upgrades are available across several factions for you to spend your hard-earned credits on and advance in power.The moment-to-moment gameplay of Rebel Galaxy is like an arcadey version of naval combat. Capital ships in this sci-fi reality still rely on broadsides for most of their firepower, so you'll be sidling up to just about everything you want to blow away. You also get auto-targeting turrets and a secondary weapon that can fire missiles or flak, as well as shield and speed boosters to expand your tactical options. I wouldn't say there's a lot of depth to the combat but positioning and prioritizing targets can mean the difference between victory and the cold embrace of hard vacuum.Unless you get really into the mostly generic story you're going to want to spend most of your time amassing wealth for bigger ships and guns. There's a basic commodity system you can play space trader with that requires some attention to trade routes and emergent events, but most of your time will probably be spent on missions. Each station has a mission board offering bounty collections, blockades, pirate hunting, cargo hauling, and more. These missions are assigned a difficulty based on your ship's current loadout, which is terribly helpful because anything above Average carries a very real chance of annihilating you in an instant.Rebel Galaxy offers a very promising setup and world to prosper in but suffers from a few issues, the difficulty curve being chief among them. At some point you're going to hit a wall where your next story mission or the only profitable missions are High or Very High risk, and if the enemy composition is not favorable to your particular ship you're going to die very, very fast. Upgrading to a larger ship is the easiest way to climb the difficulty curve but can require a LOT of side missions and busywork if the next hull in line isn't very cheap. People who are easily distracted and habitually clear side missions will fare a lot better than most here.The further you get the more technical issues you'll see crop up as well. Late in the game I started having mission-critical items disappear and enemy ships not properly register as objectives, which led to some aggravating wastes of time. There's also a lot going on in every star system, with pirates and militia lurking everywhere. This sounds cool at first but missions don't account for or clear existing entities in the mission space, so a Low risk battle against some frigates can turn out to be instantly fatal if the game decides to spawn pirate dreadnoughts in that particular sector.I've had my fair share of frustration with this title, but most of my time in it has been a relaxing and rewarding romp around the galaxy. The systems you explore are expansive, colorful, and full of debris fields and nebulae to explore for secrets and bounties. Warping around has a great feel to it, with rich engine sounds and visual distortions through space. The twangy western feel is out in full force as well, with plenty of rough-spoken captains to deal with, junky ships to pilot and pilfer, and plenty of wailing country rock to fill the silent void.At times it feels very much like a friendlier, simpler, offline EVE Online, though it never really matches the same sense of scale or vastness. I mean that in the best and worst ways, too, because it never really aspires to be more than a basic space hauling shooting gallery. And yet, there's an undeniable draw to scraping together the credits to land a new class of vessel and taking it out for a spin in the places you feared to tread before. That's where Rebel Galaxy really succeeds, in giving you a universe to explore and plenty of reasons to see it all.

Posted: December 1, 2015
												If they tried, really tried, to make a Firefly game that nailed it...it would be this game.  It's more like Sid Meier's Pirates in space, or crossed with Freelancer/Privateer, than a traditional space sim.  This is fine because those games were all amazing.  You're piloting a capital ship, not a little fighter, which gives it a different feel.  The combat is extremely satisfying, there are a lot of choices in how you equip your ship, and the universe feels like there are really things going on in it besides what you're doing.If you liked Pirates: instabuy, the game systems are similar.  If you like the idea of capital ship scale combat and an open world, also buy.  Firefly fan and like games at all?  Buy.  This is the first space game since Freelancer that I really enjoyed straight out of the box, and it's a steal at its price.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												So here it is-my Rebel Galaxy review. Full disclosure-I'm friends with the devs and got an advanced copy of the game. That said I've done my best to be impartial.My Tl'dr opinion? I  love it and was well over 100 hours in before I took a break from it. This is so many things about space games I love rolled into one.The Setting.The game goes for a Firefly/Wing Commander:Privateer/Freelancer vibe. The solar systems in this game are on the wrong side of the galactic tracks and haven't had a bath in aeons. They're rude, crude and filled with rocks and junk. Rebel Galaxy features an interesting cast of characters. It's one of the games unfortunate downsides that you never really get to know any of them very well. It's loaded with the kind of wink/nudge humor you'd find in TV series like Farscape or Firefly-for example one of the commodities you can trade is called 'Narco-cola' and it is just that. Powerful narcotics in the form of carbonated beverage. If you're a fan of stuff like Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy you'll appreciate the humor. The Story:Length 30-40 hours (20 if you're an old hand at these kind of games).It ain't deep but it gets the job done. Like I wrote above the characters all have interesting personalities but those personalities are shallow and you won't interact with any of them very much. It's a shame because they are just interesting enough where I wanted to get to know them more. By the time I got past the 'Hello, nice to meet you, may I help you kill this troup of troublemakers?' bits their role in the story was done. This becomes even more disappointing by the end of the story. It's a great lead up but the end is a bit of a letdown. I'll give DDGames credit-despite my not liking how it ended I've played through it numerous times now. The Sound:If you're into down and dirty southern-fried blues rock this will be right up your alley. It helps add a lot to the atmosphere and makes you feel like every space station bar serves oil pan shots and barbed wire biscuits. The sound effects are another matter entirely-voiceovers can get a bit repetitive to the point of tediousness at times. Some of the audio isn't mixed well-radio chatter clips/distorts a lot and I don't recommend you use expensive speakers or a subwoofer if you plan on blasting this. Voice acting isn't bad for an indie game. This is one of the things that lends a lot of personality to the characters. It was done by the devs themselves (with the help of the always amazing Lani Minella). I dare say it's better than in most Bethesda games I've played. Even though Travis does numerous voices they sound different enough where it's not that much of a drawback. Ships:There are 21 playable ships you're able to buy throughout the game. Some of these require money and some require you to build a positive reputation with various factions (pirates, merchants guild etc). Each ship is upgradable with a wide variety of weapons and components. Lasers, missiles, shields, hulls-you can customize your ship to beef them up and match them to your playing style. This wide variety and manner of acquiring and upgrading ships means there's a lot of replay to be squeezed out of the game.I did find it unfortunate that you're not able to access all ships. Certain ships belonging to certain races seem to be inaccessible which is a real downer in a game that revolves around the very notion of collecting every ship you happen to come across. Combat:Combat takes place on a 2-D plane. That means it's more like naval combat in games like Assassin's Creed:Black Flag or Sid Meiers Pirates (the 2004 edition) or the auto combat in Mad Max. Thanks to the variety of components and weapons in game no matter what your playstyle is you can adapt your craft to it. Upgrading certain components helps with your survivability. You can also hire a merc to accompany you which is always a smart move as some of them are extremely lethal. The one down side of using a merc is that you can't upgrade their weapons or ships.It would have been cool to see something closer to the pets in Torchlight or Companions in Diablo III-especially considering all the weaponry that drops from capital ships. Being able to give my mercs better gear early on would have helped a lot as the best mercs aren't available until late in the game.The main downside to combat is that difficulty seems to be very imbalanced at the moment. It's a lot of fun don't get me wrong but some missions say they're difficult when they're not and vice versa. It's also pretty spinny. Enemies run but they never run -that- fast or far which  means there will be times when you spend  battles going in circles. That said the effects are glorious and when combat is good it's really, really good. The other stuff:Mining-It's a pretty zen-like experience. Cruise up to some rocks, scan them then go up to the ones full of ore. You can buy a fault tracker early on that paints red circles on asteroids that have more than one piece of ore in them. Blow it up that way and you get multiple ores. It's a pretty relaxing experience unfortunately unless you're very good at the market stuff, explore a LOT and very patient you won't be making a ton of credits mining. Commodities: Stations sell commodities. Buy low/sell high type stuff. Different stations have different events that effect the rest of that systems economies. You can also read the in station news boards or ask the bartenders/merchants for info. Hackable transponders that give tasty info, random cargo containers that contain nice loot (sort of like the outer space version of barrells in an rpg) and rescue missions aplenty are some of the other bits of content you'll find in this game. SUMMARY:Rebel Galaxy is a fun, arcadey naval-game-in-space that provides some of the trappings of a space-sim while ditching most of the complexity and time-investment required of more traditional space sims like EVE Online or Elite:Dangerous. It's great for drop in and play for a half hour or so sessions. If you're the kind of person who spends hours playing space games just for the sake of the atmosphere and love blowing stuff up with enough lights to build a discotechque this will scratch that itch for at least a little while. Personally I'm 100 hours in and haven't gotten bored yet.Those looking for a deeply engaging story you're not going to find one but the characters have tons of personality and give the setting a very lived in feel-just be ready for the ending to be a bit of a let down. Those into trading should be happy though the game feels like it needs a bit of tweaking since not all professions feel viable. The accent is on combat so expect to blow up a lot of ships if you're looking to be one of the galaxy's richest space truckers. Despite its flaws this is an impressive first game from Double Damage Games. The developers put a lot of heart into this and it shows. This would have been a solid deal even at $30 but at $20 it's way more than worth it.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												If you're looking for a space pew pew lazorz game, just buy it. Right now. What are you waiting for? Stop reading these words and go buy it.You're still reading? Fine I'll put more words here that might mean things about stuff. Seriously, though, this game overdelivers its $20 at release date price (or whatever you can get it for on sale). There are plenty of other reviews speaking to what's great about this game, so I won't beat a dead horse. However, I would like to speak to some of the negative comments that I've seen."Missions are repetitive." - this is true, but that hasn't reduced my enjoyment of gameplay. Sure the missions are repetitive, but each encounter does have variations within it. There are at least 3 major variations with each mission: mission type, types of friendlies, types of enemies. There are escort missions (follow a friendly around at warp speed and defend them from attacking hostiles that pull you out of warm), defend missions (move into an engagement and prevent friendlies from being destroyed), destroy missions (fly in guns blazing until everything is on fire, including you), snatch and run / fight missions (fly into an area teeming with hostiles, grab some cargo, and gtfo), delivery missions (get some cargo and deliver it to another station, while being pulled out of warp multiple times from hostiles trying to take your cargo). There are also other types that I haven't done yet (pirate missions).The other aspect that changes missions are types of friendlies/enemies. Sometimes you're fighting multiple cruisers with minor fighter support, sometimes you're fighting a dreadnaught with tons of fighter support, sometimes you're fighting waves upon waves of fighters - and yes these do require different engagement tactics. Good luck charging into waves of mine layer / bomber fighters with a cruiser and winning. I also feel like I need to point out that repetitive side missions aren't a new thing. How many times have you collected herbs as a side quest in some other RPG?"2D space combat" - When I read this before buying it, I wasn't sure how I would feel about it. After playing the game - I just don't care that it's not 3D. I don't feel like it being 3D would make it any more fun, especially with the "broadside" style gameplay (which I do enjoy). The 2D movement environment plus broadside style combat provides enough complexity without making it over-complex. You can still use tactics to use a smaller vessel to take down a larger one. I've used my quick cruiser to take down multiple dreadnaughts by getting behind them so that the only damage I'm taking is from their rear turrets and the occasional heat seeking missile, and they can't turn fast enough to broadside me. Plus with a fast vessel you have enough maneuverability to be able to zig-zag between your broadsides (shields don't depreciate as a whole - but each side is separate, for a total of 4 shields) to be able to keep your shields up, all while staying out of the main line of fire. Or you could just buy a huge ship, get ramming deflectors, AND RAMMING SPEED EVERYTHING TO DEATH. Twice."Main Storyline is [insert words]" I'm not sure why people are complaining about the main storyline. At the time of writing this I've had 26 hours in the game and still haven't finished it. Sure it's nothing especially fancy... but it is engaging, and seriously it's a $20 game. I'm not sure what you expect. I've played plenty of single player RPG-style games (ones that ONLY have a main storyline) that I've cleared in under 30 hours, and those were $50-60 at release."Soundtrack something or other" I also really enjoyed the soundtrack with it's Firefly vibe, however I would have to agree that it starts getting repetitive. I also have an easy solution. Turn off the music. Play your own if you really want music. Again, for a $20 game the soundtrack exceeds what I would expect.Final thoughts - the depth and enjoyability of the game overdelivers as a $20 price tag, making it a worthwhile purchase.  I would also like to see (and gladly pay for) some DLC/expansions to further increase the depth of the game (greater variety of missions, more ships, more weapons, more factions, expand main storyline, more musc, online co-op play)End transmission?

I grabbed the game on a small sale, and played about 80-90 hours so it worked for me. However, there's of course the bad sides, like in almost any game. Only two dimensions available for maneuvering, mundane npc-encounters, a bit grindy and relatively short + clichéd storyline.If you love hearty rock, space fluff and naval style warfare ---> Grab a copy, you won't be disappointed. Otherwise, keep that wallet in line.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												26 hours in and I'm basically in world 2.  When I play this game, I keep thinking that this is what Freelancer should have been.  When I played Freelancer, I had a "was that it?" feeling.  Contrarily, Rebel Galaxy gives off a "not JUST a space flight adventure simulator" sort of vibe.Yay:- Ignore the story, earn money, buy really big ships.- Ability to join multiple guilds without needing to quit your current one- Broadside combat in a space sim is surprisingly fun.- Very responsive devs, check the bug reports part of the forum- Prices of commodities go up and down in response to world events and planetary type- Wide variety of missions.  Escort, Pickup, Delivery, Blockade Running, Head hunting...- No speed lanes, you want to get somewhere fast just point your nose and punch the warp.- Dynamic system.  In Wing Commander: Privateer, you could watch the news and respond accordingly to major events.  Is there a famine?  Bring food.  War?  Bring weapons.  Market glut, buy low.  This system is rarely found in these space trading games.  I don't think Freelancer had it.- Good voice acting- Intuitive game design- Aliens!- Varied Nebulas.  Including the classic ones like lightning nebulas that can shatter your shields in a single flash and dark nebulas where danger and mystery lurk within.- Scanner.  A nifty halo emits from your ship and lets you know of nearby enemies, allies, and items.Nay:- Broadside combat is rather easy.  Just manuever until your side is exposed, use precise targetting, and press a button.  The lead is automatically calculated for you.  The only thing you need to decide is how much time to charge the shot.- Fighters are so annoying since they can go to the 3rd dimension.  Plus the strike craft defense options are a bit lacking due to their extremely limited range.  You're left with relying on general-purpose turrets to pick off the pesky gnats one at a time.- No speed lanes.  Most of the time, I neglect to plot a proper course before warping so I end up going through like 3 asteroid fields, 2 debris fields, and 1 planet.  That's like hitting 6 red lights when you're trying to get somewhere.Meh:- No idle radio chatter- From what I've played so far, you pass lots of planets but there is no planetary landing.  You always stop at a station in orbit.  I'm guessing the idea is that space ships should stay in space where they're designed to work.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy is a cautios recommendation. For 20€ it's a good game. It has some major flaws, but I would still call it a good game at the end of the day. I'll try this review in a different format, because this is a game that could have been a hidden gem of the year if developers had a little different focus. So:What this game should have had First and absolutely foremost: Context. That was SUCH a huge miss. The game provides no context for anything outside of the main quest.Missions and systems have zero context. They are condensed to a marker on the map. No characters to talk to, no multiple ways to complete missions, no multi-staged missions, no consequences. Even faction missions have absolutely no context. Every trader is one of two possible models, they all have exactly the same lines, regardless of where and how you meet them.All mercenaries are 5 characters that inexplicably appear in every system on random stations and can't be interacted with beyond "Hey, what ship you fly?", "What's your skills?" and "You are hired". Really really huge miss, because the mechanics of this game are very simplistic and can not justify the complete absence of context. Fast travel. 90% of the gameplay time is wasted on the annoying warp mechanic. There's no fast travel and you have to go between stations very often. During warp you have to manually aim your ship and it won't exit out of warp unless you aim it dead on point, so you can't just alt-tab and check email. You have to stare at the screen.You get pulled out of warp on every tiny object to the side of your path. And there are a LOT of meaningless tiny objects in this game. You can not engage warp again until after you are cleared from any mass, and it takes a while to accelerate enough to start warping again so travelling turns into an incredibly boring and frustrating experience that you have to endure a lot.What this game should have ditched to get the aboveScale. The game is absolutely unnecessarily large. You have something like 12 systems (don't remember exact number), each has about as many space stations. To travel through the whole map and visit every station once would require a full day of gameplay. And EACH station has like 6 contract missions, all of which are done with one of 3 main templates (fetch quest, elimination and escort), and might as well be MMORPG repeating quests. All of the stations are exactly the same. They vary only in what merc sits inside and the prices they offer on goods. The bartenders have the same dialogue, there are no interesting quests to pick up, no characters to talk to. Hell - even weapons and ships they offer are the same. Only faction stations offer different equipment. All in all it's a typical quantity over quality issue. The game could have been 10 times smaller (not exaggerating, I actually think that would be the proper reduction), but if it had actually interesting quests with dialogue, context and variety to offer it would have been much better for it.Economy. It's just uninteresting and not worth your time.The entire economy in the game could be thrown out and it wouldn't be missed. It's your basic buy low sell high economy, except fetching goods in this game, as I've explained, is tiresome and frustrating, and there's no market manipulation you can perform. The money you get out of it is rather small, overall I just don't think there's any reason to try and make money with it. It's not an MMO. There's no infinite high end equipment and clans and raids you can spend that dosh on. You can buy one of the overpriced heavy dreadnaughts, but... why? They aren't fun to use and what would you use it for anyway? Fetching more goods? It's just pointless and wasted resources IMO.Equipment could have been made into upgradable loot drops - you can't buy gear, but you can upgrade it with dosh and missions. That would have made the game far more engaging too, bring some variety in. As it stands, once I bought a full combo of guns, I just used the same set of equipment throughout the entire game, upgrading it.So as you can see there are some big issues. So what's good?What's good?Combat. It's very similar to Assassin's Creed Black Flag naval combat, just in Space. It's very cinematic, albiet not exactly difficult. It's by no means a sim, it's absolutely unrealistic and very arcady, but that doesn't really matter. It's fun. That's the main thing. Combat's difficulty comes from how the game is balanced - it is very binary. You are either not having any problems whatsoever, or you are dead. Ship's HP is very small. Your shields and armour are what protect you.  The main skill in this game is to turn your ship all the time to let the shields on another side regenerate. You must never let enemies surround you and you must maneuvre such that you take as little continuous fire as possible, while spreading the damage over all your shields. This is also a reason why you never want to fly a dreadnaught. Small ship that you can turn to spread damage across all your 4 shields and platings is more survivable than large ship which is gonna take all the damage to one side. Sountrack - amazing rock and country music, with cinematic arcade combat in a spectacle of lazers and explosions. What more could you ask for? Graphics - the game looks good obviously. Polish - the game runs well and never crashed or bugged out on me. Aliens - they look and sound cool. I think the alien languages aren't necessary, but the looks and voice modifiers are cool. Progression - there's a variety of cool ships on display and all except dreadnaughts are quite fun to use. Also there is a large variety of guns you can install, each with a specific strength and weakness. You can take control of any gun directly, through in my experience turrets are always better controlled by the AI. Usually you are better off controlling broadsides and maneuvering the ship for the most advantageous angle. Atmosphere. The game's light-hearted atmosphere with a few funny lines of text here and there blend well with combat and music.So in the end I think the game is quite good for what it is. I just think it would have been a hell of a lot better had the developers more clearly understood it's strengths and weaknesses. A cautious recommendation, but a recommendation nonetheless.

												After years and years of personally wishing for new space sims, Starpoint Gemini 2, Elite Dangerous and this game all came out within a year's time. Of the three games, this one has the glossiest presentation and best-presented story line. This is like Starpoint Gemini 2 in that the perspective is third person because you are controlling capital-ship sized vessels. There are many jobs and sidequests in addition to the story line and different factions that you can side with or against. Is this a hardcore sim? Absolutely not, but it is fun and combat heavy. Apparently in this galaxy there are hordes of pirates and alien raiders to do battle with...Recommended if you like flying around the galaxy and lots of explosions.

Posted: February 2
												Pros: - Space dogfighting. The broadside cannon system is interesting, and keeping the fighting mostly in 2D solves a lot of the problems associated with this idea. It's enjoyable for a while. - Good story. Interesting enough for the length of the game. - Great soundtrack - look for the playlist on Spotify. I love how when combat happens the music gets more aggressive. Cons:- So damn grindy. In between story missions you'll need to buy improvements on your ship. Have fun doing tons of redundant quests or flying everywhere trying to trade for money. - Speaking of trade, it's largely a waste of time. While you can certainly make money flying around and taking advantage of market conditions, there's never enough stock of anything to make large amounts of money without making the rounds of every solar system. Towards  the end of the game trade is outright worthless as any cargo drop from a ship is worth more than an entire shipload of cargo that you purchased. - Mining is worthless unless you get lucky, don't bother. I would have loved this game if there was more trade\mining options to improve your ship so that I could try different weapons configurations, but I never had enough cash, and the grind became too much for me so I just ended the game. I'm happy I played it if for no other reason than the soundtrack is so outstanding and I was introduced to a whole genre of music I've never listened to. But the game play is just meh.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Did you ever watch Firefly and think "Hey, it would be really cool with a game where I can be a space cowboy"?If no, that means you're either in the wrong place or you haven't watched Firefly. Go do that now.If yes, then look no further!Rebel Galaxy is a singleplayer open-world spaceship RPG set in distant future.As the player, you receive a message from your old aunt Juno asking you to travel to the frontier. Riddled with piracy, military conflicts, intrigues and other mysteries your arrival marks the beginning of a long journey.Aside from the story you can choose to undertake thousands (if not more) of different sidejobs, it can be anything from an escort mission to the elimination of a key pirate leader hiding in a asteroid field.Freedom is key and the player has many choices available to them, each granting you different perks but also changing the way the rest of the galaxy sees you.A player who help traders and merchants during distress calls or who actively pursue pirate fleets will be seen as friendly by the Confederate militia while a player who smuggles contraband, ambush militia patrols and disrupt authorities will be seen as a friend by the pirates.In Rebel Galaxy the systems you fly in feel very much alive, stopping at a station just to view the newsboard inside the bar is a good idea as it will provide you with all kinds of information regarding politics, bounties or good trading opportunities.Planets can go to war with eachother, raising the demand for military equipment which in turn allows you to profit from it. If you want the conflict to escalate you can destroy any treaty vessels which attempt to broke peace.Newsboard[images.akamai.steamusercontent.com]Or maybe you're more of a honest businessman? If so tech booms and market gluts will be your best friends, lowering the value of goods at certain stations so you can buy them en masse only to sell them off at a fringe world for a hefty sum of credits.Market[images.akamai.steamusercontent.com]If that doesn't sound like your type of gig you can always become a freelancing bountyhunter or mercenary, tracking down pirate lords or escorting merchants through rough space.The choice is yours.GameplayGameplay-wise Rebel Galaxy is pretty straightforward, with easy-to-understand mechanics, helpful tutorial prompts and simple controls.CombatIn Rebel Galaxy the combat relies on three things: turrets, broadside ports and secondary ports.When not controlled by the player, turrets will act independently and target any hostile craft within the range or specific craft (you can choose). Broadsides are your main weapons and are used to obliterate enemy capital ships, broadsides can be anything from lasers to cannons.Finally, secondary ports are used for equipping fixed weapons and launchers such as flak guns, dumbfire missile launchers or mine catapults.Overall it's a very straightforward system even though it does get a bit repetitive after a certain point.Controls & UIThe controls for Rebel Galaxy are simple and easy to understand, the player has access to full control mapping.As for the UI, it's very clean and elegant. It shows exactly what you need without cluttering up the screen.UI[images.akamai.steamusercontent.com]All in all Rebel Galaxy is a fun game. While it might suffer from being repetitive at a certain point it's stilla solid game which I highly recommend.Also, the soundtrack is amazing. Look it up.Fly safe.

Rebel Galaxy


Rebel Galaxy 
A Screenshot of Rebel Galaxy
By: 𝓝𝓪𝓪𝓻𝓲𝓼




At the moment of this review I have played for 38 hours. Do I think this game is good and can I recommend it? Yes but... but if you are looking for a combat/ship/free space game  this is NOT it. A few words about this game? Firefly+Freelancer+Blues= Rebel Galaxy Are you comparing this one with Elite Dangerous? I did too and I chose this one. In fact, they are not the same kind of game, except both are in space. You don't know what's Firefly? Really?!  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firefly_(TV_series) What's Freelancer? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freelancer_(video_game) Now i feel old... thanks.


Rebel Galaxy 
A Screenshot of Rebel Galaxy
By: 𝓝𝓪𝓪𝓻𝓲𝓼




Graphics:  I have been playing with downsampling at 4K -30Fps with my mid computer.  You can look at the screenshots included to see the graphics. The ships are well constructed: engines,  turrets, lateral cannons. The planets are good enough, you can't land anyway so...  The hyperspace effect is nicely done, and all the combat weapons, missiles, defense, shield effect are perfect. Now... the npcs are almost clones, you will find the same face over and over although you travel to the far corner of the galaxy. This is really a mess because you speak with a lot of merchants to trade/ rob them, with pirates, guards etc etc. If you are civilizan neutral (at least) you can acces to the cantina, and the bartender has his (i sadly didn't find even one woman bartender...) clone face, you say ok... I won't look at you more than 20 seconds. BUT when you are pirate neutral and go inside the cantina, you expect to find a different cantina with a different cloned bartender but in pirate rol... big mistake. It's the same civilian cantina, with the same bartender (really?)So, graphics approved but very repetitive. Edit: I found at last on my second run a Bartender "woman"!!! In one of the last starbases of the farthest system... but there she is! (at least for my random generated game). Music: The game ost is really good. The compositor is Christopher Robert Adams and besides the good of his work, the game allows you to customize the directory of each kind of music (exploration,combat...) and you can put there your own ost. I, for exemple, have been listening  Cowboy Beebop.if you want to listen the ost take a look at this link https://www.reddit.com/r/RebelGalaxy/comments/3pe3xg/rebel_galaxy_soundtrack_double_damage_games_a/


Rebel Galaxy 
A Screenshot of Rebel Galaxy
By: 𝓝𝓪𝓪𝓻𝓲𝓼




Story: It's... simple but enought to do your way through the system, exploring, fighting, trading, and improving over and over your ship. From a little old carrier to the most powerfull destructor... don't expect much more.Take a look at the ships  http://rebelgalaxy.gamepedia.com/ShipsGameplay:I recommend to use a gamepad. And here comes the controversial point... Rebel Galaxy is a 2D space game. Besides, is single player and always in 3rd person (ship) view.   I could compare it to a naval ship combat, with cannons and lateral combat, where you have to change your flank because your enemy will sunk you if you continue on that side. It could be nasty, even an insult for those who think on space games like Elite or Star Citizen but damn... it's fun! I really enjoyed it, it has it's strategic point and you can be quickly destroyed if you rush into an enemy formation that you think that are weak. So, if you can look forward beyond games like ED or SC, you will enjoy it. One interesting thing. The entire game is redone each time you play, the connections of each system with another, the planets each system has, the type of planet, well, everything. You will play into a new universe each time you start a game. Space: The way you travel through system is using jumpgates, and it's instant travel. You can only navigate and explore each system, and to balance that, each system is really alive. Each time you travel from A point to B point, you will find something, let's say: traders convoys, pirates, milita ships, emergency beacons, space trash, nebulas, asteroid field, ice field, debris from older battles, a lot of stations from the different factions and planets, satellites which you can hack to get information... and more. In this game, space is old. Humanity has spread all over the place and thousands of years of races activity, has changed it and let their legacy. while you navigate you will see little pieces of  trash around your ship and if you destroy a big ship and you come back days later, you will find the debris.  Mods http://steamcommunity.com/app/290300/discussions/2/405691491120297253/ This mod will change some important things, add new ships to be able to use and rebalance others. Please read the description to be sure if you want to use it. Thanks to Timberrino for the link to this mod. Negative point: The cloned faces There are few mods. The repetitive missions.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a bit of a strange bird. It is a spaceship game with a serviceable story told within a pseudo-sandbox game world. The game itself seems polished on initial inspection, but after hours of play certain odd design choices and rough edges start to show themselves.But is it fun?After accumulating 24 hours in the game and just now finishing up the main quest line, I have to say that it IS definitely fun. While the game has a tendency to force you to grind procedurally generated missions, a common issue in open world sandbox games, I have to say that this is one of the few games where the grind did not bother me! Rather fun combat, decent mission variety, and a plethora of (somewhat) profitable side activities keep the game fresh and the amazing looks that the ships have make you want to keep going until you've got that one last shiny battleship. Another thing to note is that this game absolutely BLEEDS Firefly (a fairly popular short TV series) and really captures the feeling of flying around the galaxy in a trusty ship while smuggling goods and blasting other pilots to space bits in a way I, personally, haven't experienced before.Before I get into the nitty gritty details of the game, here's a TL;DR score: 7/10 (I'd say drop it down to a 6/10 if you don't really love spaceships or Firefly).Sound:If you overlook the fact that there really shouldn't be any sound in space, the sound is, in general, pretty good! Lasers sound like lasers, cannons go boom, and explosions seems appropriate! They can get a bit repetitive after a while, but that's to be expected in a longer game like this.Music:The music is awesome! If you've seen Firefly the music will really give you some flashbacks to the show. However, the selection in the game seems rather similar and you start to hear the same thing over and over again. Got to the point where I had to mute the music at times.Voice:The voice work in this is passable, but nothing special. While there weren't really any cringe-worthy moments, I never felt like the actors' performance or the script really pulled me in. The aliens and robots sound pretty neat though!Graphics:The game is pretty freaking gorgeous in my opinion. While not the most graphically impressive game out there, the galaxy looks pretty vibrant and the graphical effects that surround your ship when you are warping around the map is pretty great. The ships themselves look awesome and there are a couple of different ship lines in the game that offer varied ship aesthetics! The UI looks decent but is nothing special.Gameplay:The gameplay in this title is a bit of a mixed bag. The combat is a blast, however little things about it can start to bother you. For instance, the game is played on a flat plane, however at times when ships get close to you they tend to leave that plane to fly around you and at times this makes hitting them with your broadsides feel like a total crapshoot. Unfortunately, if you don't like the combat in this game, you might want to look elsewhere as the other activities in the game such as mining and trading are somewhat underdeveloped and are in general nowhere near as profitable as combat missions which will result in the currency grind becoming much more difficult than I believe it should be. One other huge issue I had with the game was that the UI is very unfriendly for mouse and keyboard users. Everything else in the game works fine with a mouse and keyboard, but the UI is clunky and is not mouse friendly at all, in many cases requiring you to use WASD to navigate. Lastly, certain weapon types in the game seem rather underpowered, in some cases to the point of being completely useless, and there is very little meaningful change-ups in terms of the gameplay as the game progresses.Final Verdict:I think this game is a lot of fun. While it is definitely rough around the edges and features a noticeable grind, it kept me playing for a full 24 hours and I am not the kind of person who typically enjoys grinds in games. Would I buy it at full price? Probably not. However, I think the game is worth a play despite all of its flaws and I would certainly recommend it to anyone looking to pick it up during a sale or in a bundle. Rebel Galaxy gets a thumbs up from me!

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy is a fun, arcadey space game that feels like a mix between Sid Meier's Pirates, Freelancer/WC:Privateer, and Assassin Creed: Black Flag naval boardsides combat combined with a cheesy/awesome Western-Rock soundtrack.There is a main storyline but you don't really have to follow it that much, you can just go around trading/mining/fighting/exploring, but the meat of the game is in the fighting. Thankfully the fighting is pretty fun. Instead of playing as a fighter or small freighter/gunship like many of these types of open-ended/sandbox space games, you start out in a Corvette and eventually work your way up to larger ships, I believe there is roughly 20 playable ships in all. As has been mentioned, the combat plays something like Assassin's Creed Black Flag ship battles, maneuvering on a 2D plane, with a heavy emphasis on broadsides and positioning. Your ship is outfitted with a main battery of broadside cannons as well as some turrets and secondary weapons (like missile launchers). You can customize the weapons of your ship with stuff like long/short range guns, beam lasers, missile turrets, anti-fighter/missile flak guns, etc etc.The game is surprisingly colorful and ships explode into big bright fireballs when they die. Its fun. The music, as I've mentioned is cheesey western butt-rock and, IMO, quite nice. However if its not your thing, or if you just get bored of it, the game has an option to put your own music into the game (alongside or replacing the soundtrack). I haven't progressed too far into the main plot, but this doesn't seem like the kind of game most would play for a gripping plot, as its pretty basic so far. Basically your aunt, an (in)famous smuggler and overall space Rogue, sends you a package containing a weird alien artifact and the access codes to one of her old ships and tells you to meet up with her and you go off to get into cool space battles and track her down.The game is only $20 and so far it seems like a lot of fun for that price.

Posted: April 11, 2016
												I had a hard time getting into this at first, because it doesn't hold your hand, and I'm a carebear. Then I watched a tutorial on suggestions to get started, what to spend your money on, and that I should rent a mercenary. Then I absolutely started trashing other ships and it was hella fun. The soundtrack is fantastic, the combat is really satisfying, and I love that you can customize your weapon loadouts and ships, depending on what you want to do. I thought the galaxy was ENORMOUS- zooming out to the map and back into your ship a-la Eve Online gives you a really good perspective of how tiny you are compared to everything else. Then I realized there are like 15 other galaxies and I haven't even gone to the second one yet. I like the characters so far, particularly aunt Juno. I like that you can work for other factions, and end up being an as$hole pirate, an as$hole military agent, an as$hole smuggler, or an as$hole nice guy. It's very quest based, so if that's not for you, then you may not like it, but I dig doing quests/bounties and getting money and upgrading my weapons and ship, I find it satisfying. Really enjoying this game, I feel like the marketing fell through and it hasn't gotten as much attention as it should have.

												Wow. I'll admit, I went into this game without much knowledge of it at all... and after the time I've spent with it, I can only say... Rebel Galaxy is totally badass!However, allow me to explain the basics of the game. Simply, you're a Space Cowboy, living on the edge of the law and banditry. You explore the vastness of space, blasting away pirates or helping them incinerate innocent traders while completing missions and getting rich. You get your own equipment customizable spaceship where you can fire broadsides, flak, missiles and all sorts of vaporizing goodness. There are even quite a few ships that you can purchase should you gain enough money. The concept is simple, the gameplay is addicting.Gameplay Footage:

			This game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome! I've always wanted to be a Space Cowboy!		

The game also has an epic sound track of catchy guitar twangs as you blow Space Pirates into nonexistence. The voice acting is also very solid. As if that wasn't good enough, the gameplay is fluid and the controls make sense. While the control isn't as indepth as Space flight sims like Elite: Dangerous, it's more than enough to keep players interested while also keeping the gameplay fast-paced.All in all, I definitely recommended this game!

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
Product received for free
												Rebel Galaxy is an indie space game with a variety of star systems to explore and endless number of procedurally generated missions to complete. It shares some similarities with Freelancer, but the core gameplay is rather different.While the game does feature trading and mining, the main draw is clearly the space battles. Unfortunately the combat itself is a rather shallow experience. All ships apart from enemy/allied fighters are restricted to a 2D plane and all your main weapons are fired as a single broadside, so in practice the game often feels more like a naval game than a proper space game. It's fun in small sessions, but gets repetitive really quickly.This isn't helped by an extremely poor item system and ridiculous economy. Both seem to be lifted straight from a bad MMO, which doesn't make any sense in a single player game. Overall you spend way too much time traveling through empty space and grinding pointless side missions to earn enough cash for the next tier of upgrades so you can actually continue with the main game.The setting is quite generic but has enough of a Firefly vibe to keep things somewhat interesting. Unfortunately the main story is not that memorable either and there's not enough variety with the side missions. There's also a faction system, but this didn't seem to add much to the overall game.While I found Rebel Galaxy enjoyable in short sessions, overall I'd consider it too flawed to recommend. Between the shallow combat and the repetitive missions the game got boring well before I finished it.The good:- Combat can be fun in small dozes- Bigger space battles can be impressive and quite hectic- Nice soundtrackThe bad:- Shallow combat mainly restricted to a 2D plane- Repetitive missions and random encounters- Grindy with extremely lazy item design- Story is forgottable and the ending is extremely lackluster- Trading and mining felt somewhat pointlessThe ugly:- Some graphics issues in DX9 mode, switching to DX11 fixed these- Overuse of shader effects and some of the weapons look downright terrible- Even the small space rocks inhibiting your warp drives- Warp pairing with friendly targets is a broken mess
