Posted: March 12
												Cowboy Bebop: The GameI wont lie, this game has blown my expectations out of the metaphorical water. I haven't played long enough yet to give a full review but after 5 hours I have to say this is like a lovechild of Elite Dangerous and Red Dead Redemption (gameplay wise) and also Starcraft and Cowboy Bebop theme wise. It also feels like it could be an extension of the Mass Effect universe.The developers have really focused on perfecting the basic core mechanics that are both simple and have a lot of longevity. I think this is the kind of game you could enjoy for a long time.I've owned this game for quite a while and I never touched it until now and I'm really glad I did. If you're out there and you're on the fence about this game I promise you it is very easy to start. You wont be looking up tutorials unless you want to.Update: After 26 hours I'm finally putting the game down. It was a great journey and whilst the story was nothing special, if you enjoy building up a character from scratch then you'll love this game. As I progressed I felt stronger and stronger but some of that was lost because as you progress to further and further areas the enemies get stronger with you. Whenever I visited earlier systems I was always reminded of my progress though.I think if you were to play this strategically and focused on min-maxing your ship, you could easily get 100+ hours out of this game.Overall a fantastic SCI-FI game and a must buy for people who enjoy starting with nothing and earning a spot at the top.

YouTube™ Video:

Rebel Galaxy is a story driven space exploration and battle game with a unque style and a firefly-esque feel. Above is a short video of me running through th first half hour or so of the game, below are my thoughts on Rebel Galaxy. TheHiddenLevels.com was provided a review copy by Double Damage Games and for that we thank them.The opening soundtrack and just the music in general really gave that space junker, firefly, out in the verse where there is little law and less integrity vibe.. The following gameplay did not let this notion slip away. This is a fantastic western style space traveler and battle game. I was hooked pretty quickly by amazing music and voice acting, the graphics are impressive as well.I engaged my first enemy and honestly thought I was about to lose my ship when I shot them down just in time, the battles feel tense and while manuvering isn't the focus, you've still got to be crafty. The only thing that was a slight turn off was that other ships I was fighting were able to move on a 3D axis, but of course our ship is not capable of 3D flight. It is a game mechanic so that is the last I'll mention it, becuase the game is supremely fun even without that facet involved. The ship building and upgrade possibilities are relatively deep, and offer a real variance in experience and gameplay. I really enjoyed the feeling of landing on new planets, talking to folks in smoky dive bars, and running errand / bounties for unsavory space characters. It's a great adventure game and I'll likely be coming back to it often to see what's next in the story.I'd reccomend this one to any fans of space games, especially those where players can outfit ships and fly around a massive galaxy. Thanks for wathcing and reading, check out www.thehiddenlevels.com for news and reviews!

												I came in to this game with the idea that "If you liked freelancer, you'll like this".  I liked Freelancer, I didn't like Rebel Galaxy.I felt like the camera was always way zoomed in and at a weird angle, and during combat it's pretty much always facing at a right angle to the direction you're moving (because of broadside combat) so I run in to asteroids a lot.  My second time out in a combat zone I ran into an asteroid that had something else next to it, and my ship got stuck such that it couldn't turn, and you can't go backwards, so I had to reload to get my ship free.It feels like you're flying through something far more viscous than water.  I can forgive constant thrust = constant velocity in space games if they at least let you cruise along for a while without slowing down super fast when you disable thrusters.  This game feels like a naval combat engine with space combat art resources.  I think the ship in assassin's creed black flag has less resistance from the water than your spaceship does in the vacuum of space in this game.I also didn't like the weapons.  They auto aim at stuff, and you do broadside combat where you don't really have to lead or even aim close, your weapons all just kind of pick stuff and shoot at it.  The combat is very non engaging and easy, and if it were hard I'm not sure it would be anything but frustrating since there doesn't seem to be any strategy or skill involved.The UI and the controls on keyboard and mouse are also not too great.  It seems like it might feel better on a console, but that's not much of a "consolation" on PC.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												"You can't take the sky from me"I've only just begun, but I can say that the combat is very fun, the game plays like a 2D version of FREELANCER or PRIVATEER. Graphically, it's got a lot in common with Freelancer, the color-pallet is even similar.It has a 2D combat that's easy to get into with a heavy influence of naval broadside combat.The game has a wonderful FIREFLY flavor to it. It's got a rockin almost honkeytonk soundtrack that never feels out of place.The universe is DIRTY, it's ORNERY, and it really doesn't like you.The only thing I can think of that would add to the game, is a crew aspect. If you had to find and hire good gunners, or missile loaders, or navigator, I think it would have added a bit of depth. It's not poorer for not having those things, but perhaps a sequel later on can explore that aspect.This is very satisfying game in this genre, and should keep the appetite sated until the Persistent Universe for Star Citizen[robertsspaceindustries.com] (also by the guy who did Freelancer, Privateer, and Wing Commander) comes out. Which will have a similar trading system, but a 3d environment.I'm having a ton of fun with Rebel Galaxy, and I can't wait to play some more.

												A very good space RPG game. A very good one for those who don't have the $$ to spend for Elite:Dangerous, EVE Online or Star Citizen.The map per star system is quite big with many enemies or allies roaming around.There are many types of ships to choose on different Stars but they cost quite a lot.Combat is for me, hard as I have yet to master the shield system.You can trade with merchants and different station and read the news to see where is the cheapest and highest market.You can also mine though you will have to sacrifice some of you ships combat parts.There are plenty of enemies that they mostly travel in groups especially if you bump into a Flagship or a Pirate Lord which basically murdered you.Music is awesome all the way.Graphics is beautiful, stunning effects and pretty display on the combat.You can customize you ship from weapons to armor to system though you can't colour it. You can hire mercenaries though only 1 and they can really help take away some of the enemies focus from you.

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
REBEL GALAXYDamn! This is such a nice discovery that I made with this little gem of a game. I had bought it, uh, long ago but finally managed to find the time and see what the hell is up with Rebel Galaxy. Oh boy, why have I waited so long? Close to 47 Hours in playtime, I think this is the longest I've played an Indie game!So what is Rebel Galaxy?If you're familiar with FREELANCER, STAR LANCER, FREESPACE, then you will feel right at home in Rebel Galaxy! The main difference is in RG, you pilot a "BIG" Capital ship... well, not the starter Corvette ship but there are many ships to choose from as you progress further till the untouchable ENORMOUS Dreadnought BLACKGATE! Took me forever to get it but once I did, game is just too easy...  Anyhoo... let's see the pros and cons!PROS:+SOUNDTRACK! That Dark Country musical genre is so damn good from the composers known as Blue Saraceno, The Dirty Diary and others!+Simple yet really fun and addicting gameplay.+Controlling a HUGE ship is quite satisfying! You ain't a tiny fighter here but a Capital Ship!+The progress system is taxing but rewarding each time you buy a new ship!+Freedom of progress. Want to farm/grind some more credits to have better gear/ship, do so!+Randomly generated "universe" so the solar systems aren't the same in each playthrough. Doesn't really matter I'd say as trading is rather pointless in RG!+21:9 UltraWide Monitor support! Visuals are pretty simple which makes RG not a demanding game!+CHEAP! For a 20$ game, I got more than my money's worth out of RG!CONS:-Average story. Hopefully Double Damage Games can improve upon that in a sequel!-Highly repetitive: Lots... LOTS of grinding. You are warned! To make it easier, focus on the "DEAD DROPS" side missions, they don't take long to complete and you can repeat them at will.-Ally/Enemy factions doesn't have any territories. You see them everywhere in all Solar Systems... would love a fixed territory setting like in Freelancer!-Would love more variety of missions, mostly all "dead drops, escorting, go kill Mr X".OVERALL:For the first game developed by Double Damage Games, I'd say they started amazingly! Sure there's some irks and quirks to work around so hopefully on an RG2, things would be polished and more meat be added too!RECOMMENDATION:Love space games? You'll love this! I just want to warn you that if grinding in a game annoys the sh!t out of you, play RG in quick daily sessions, that way you won't feel it too badly! At first, I felt the annoying grind but as you progress and get a better ship, the grind is less significant as the rewards are much bigger... so is the drops from killed enemies!I truly recommend this game especially at this low price of 20$, you'll get your money's worth!

content:
Posted: February 10
												I would buy it again and Rebel Galaxy 2 if it would be there.This kind of game was there once or trice with only a few pixels trading and fighting. Now it's here fully 2.95D with beautiful visual effects. Easy and fun to play (with a controller) after investing a tiny bit of time.This game is not 100% for the hardcore space gamer that's needs to have everything perfect (and boringly slow). For example space is just not as empty as it would be irl,.. but I like that.  It misses i tiny bit of immersion (like a few more different faces or discussion options or some side stories or a bit more rare cool stuff or safe stuff for your retirement). But it is finished and as good as bug free (which is rare).On the other hand there is not as much time consuming todo list management. you can actually "play" a lot in less time.There is a lot of action per hour combined with the enjoyment of cruising through well ambianced space... not too long... just enough to enjoy the quiet lovely star rays, while in a warp bubble, or meteor belts before an adrenaline rush when going after some fleet of pirates or when they come after you ;-). Not being bothered with loosing track of everything in fully 3D (for die hards). I simply enjoy playing this for fun. Well balanced between trade, fight, travel, progression. Good interface. Good controls. Still room for a better version or dlc ;-)I vote for version 2

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												This game is fun, but don't expect it to be a game you will play for 100+ hours.  It'll last the hardcore main story mission runners about 15-20 hours.  The main storyline seems short.  Most side missions are faction based, but pay well for the time involvement.  Side missions have some variety and are easy to find the location of and execute.  If you like doing side missions and answering every distress call, you can expect 50+ hours of gameplay.There is a variety of ships each with their own specific stats, but you are more defined by your ship's equipment.  Multiple options for defenses, weapons, and components.  Once you get the largest ship with almost all of the best weapons, the enemies don't really pose a threat and the large dreadnoughts can be melted in under 10 seconds.  Looting is easy and your cargo capacity is upgradable, to a limit.Controls are easy to use and doesn't require you to learn and use 100 different keys.The soundtrack is great and is a mix of Rock, country, and blues.  It includes music primarily from guitarist Blues Saraceno (Poison, albeit briefly) and others.Achievements are easily attainable.  I finished them in 60 hours(all but one at 56), but I probably could have done it much faster if I wasn't meandering.Graphics are good and have plenty of good effects.  You have many options you can turn off.Minimum HW requirements are low, so it'll be playable on most people's gaming computers.There are some things that could be improved if you analyze every aspect of the game.  This is not a sim, expect it to be somewhat arcade like.  The game appears to be aimed at combat and having a good time.  Don't get hung up on the trade system because it needs an overhaul.Overall, it is a well polished game with good graphics and a good soundtrack.  Buy it for $19.99 and enjoy it.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												IntroductionRebel Galaxy is the space swashbuckling brainchild of Double Damage, reminiscing of arcade space games like Freelancer, and is supported by an excellent Firefly-like soundtrack. Unlike most space arcade shooters, the game has no pitch movement, instead opting for travel along a single plane. The main game is set inside a galaxy, although it does feature multiple maps, relatively large in size. Despite its similarities, it does a whole lot of thing in a slightly different manner, from combat style all the way down to the way you travel. What you see is basically a new breed of space arcade gameplay, and very much feels like its own brand of shiny new original IP. Prepare yourself for broadside battles and inter-faction negotiations, along with a whole lot of lighting effects to blind you mid-mining.StorylineThis game actually has a rather interesting story line, which is something I didn’t expect. Basically I was expecting it to be like Freelancer in most ways, but be lacking in some department or other. Despite my previous disposition, Rebel Galaxy follows a decent storyline. Basically you’ve been sent a message from your old crazy Aunt, who actually turns out to be a swashbuckling badass space-pirate at the age of late 50’s early 60’s. You’re trying to find out where she is, and make some sense of this weird AI you’ve gotten a hold of. Needless to say you get backstabbed and used like no tomorrow, and very often end up murdering the people you started out helping. It’s all a bit up and down, but heavily broken up by side quests and random world events. It’s similar to Freelancer in that you really need to do side quests and random events in order to upgrade your ship between main missions.GameplayLearning Rebel Galaxy initially can be a bit odd. I went in expecting one thing, and discovered it was something different. The key problem is I was expecting something akin to most space arcade titles. I wasn’t far off, but I was enough for the game’s management to throw me a bit. From scanning areas to turrets with AI, that and the fact that despite manual aim there’s still an aim assist – don’t walk into this expecting Freelancer/Freespace/X-Wing. Take portions of a number of space arcade games, and you’ll eventually have a recipe for Rebel Galaxy. The mystification lasted only a short while in fairness, it’s just something new you have to get used to, but once you do it becomes second nature. To clarify, this is a good thing. What we have in Rebel Galaxy is something that feels at least a little bit unique, unique enough for us to be learning something new, while enjoying ourselves at the same time.I’d like to go on about how much I love this game, so let’s first get the crap out of the way. Two things disappointed me most. First and foremost is the aiming system. AI turrets are awesome, configurable, and there’s a whole bunch of them and they do their job. Manual aim however, felt consistently interrupted. When engaging in broadside battles the game is constantly doing what it thinks is best. I aim the broadsides at a ship, but there’s another smaller ship closer which the game’s AI thinks is a more important target. The catch is my broadside weapons are slow velocity projectiles, and quite frankly I don’t give a damn about that tiny piece of crap. My lasers will take care of it. Instead of simply aiming at the ship I want to kill (which is usually fine in most cases I might add), the auto-aim kicks in and starts shooting broadsides in a direction that is not where you’re pointing. I hate it when a game thinks it knows better than me, and is flat out causing issues for me in intense combat situations. This doesn’t happen all that often, but it’s enough to annoy me a bit. Freelancer had it right. Allow full manual aim, but add aim assist circles to shoot for to shoot ahead of an enemy’s flight path. Auto-aim is just plain interference, because if you want to adjust the game’s target, you have to go into scan mode and switch targets.This auto-assist comes in a second form, with the game’s speed and travel system. I cannot abide it. I’m sorry, but throttling my sublight speeds and dropping me out of warp at the hint of a sparrow’s fart gets extremely irritating throughout the game. Basically warp can only be engaged when the game says so. Sublight can only be sped up to cruise speeds when the game says so. Give me control of my damn ship’s navigation, and stop farting about like my mother. Nothing has been more infuriating so far than travelling 6000 game-lengths and getting stopped three times between A and B because you skirted around an asteroid field. Freelancer solved it, but adding AI auto-avoidance around objects. You’d occasionally hit stuff and lose some shield, but no problem. Slowing me down, and then further slowing me down to the lowest sublight speeds, forcing me to turn ninety degrees and boost out of an asteroid field is immersion breaking.Rant over. The rest of the game rocks. This game is not Freelancer. Stop right there. Take all those predispositions out of your head, and prepare to play an all new type of game. Movement is entirely on one plane, but that’s cool. It means you can focus more on your tactical (or woefully haphazard) combat with those big♥♥♥♥♥broadsides. Turrets have varying types of AI that can be programmed to fire at certain types of targets, and there’s so much variation in weapons it tickles me in all the right places. Combat feels punchy, it looks pretty, and quite frankly simulating space-pirates is an excellent idea. The easiest way to make money is to pick a mission and then do all the randomised events that happen on the way there. There’s tonnes to do, and an enormous solar system to do it in. You might think to yourself that after the first solar system you’re halfway done, but you’re wrong, there’s a tonne more, and each map is as big as the next. Quite simply put there’s an awful lot of content and a lot of sights to see.Unfortunately I can't fit my entire review in this section.To read the full review, go to: http://www.nextpowerup.com/articles/rebel-galaxy-review/To read the performance analysis, go to: http://www.nextpowerup.com/articles/rebel-galaxy-performance-analysis/

Posted: October 22, 2015
												Highly recommended for space pilots, space pirates, and especially, space pilot pirates.tl;dr:  Firefly with capital ships by a well-credentialed indie developer (i.e, Torchlight).   Elite Dangerous in an arcade, but still mature, setting.Pros:+ Great polish in graphics.   Crunchy, but colorful.   Just the right amount of JJ lensflare.+ Excellent, excellent, excellent sound design.   Audio feedback is excellent.   Soundtrack fits perfectly.+ Varied ship customization.   Even the starter ship can be outfitted for very, very different roles.+ Thank you for on-screen button reminders!   For a casual, "old fart" gamer... that's huge!   (It's not memory loss... not yet... it's only playing 20 minutes a night)+ Broadside combat maneuvering is great!   Many "Age of Sail" ship games don't do broadside maneuvering as well as Rebel Galaxy does it. Cons:+ Minor Nit:  Some odd UX choices.   Radial menu has most of what you need, scan button has others, and yet the start menu has even others.+ No multiplayer.  Wow, would this be fun in a team!  I get that it would be out of scope for this sorte, ala Torchlight 1.+ Another minor nit:  Who are the factions?  Are they important?  Not sure.  A few brief pop-ups when you gain/lose standing might help.For <$20, I highly recommended buy for spaceship fans and browncoats alike.    A nice hybrid of space sim and space shooter.

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												SUMMARY: A simple to play, but surprisingly deep space adventure sim with a lot of personality and style that gives you a solid "Space Western" adventure where you can carve your own path.It took me awhile to get into Rebel Galaxy as, early on, the directions weren't that clear and the difficulty was erratic.  That's when I realized Rebel Galaxy, for all its great graphics and soundtrack, really is a throwback to the old "drop 'em in space and good luck" games of the past.  Once you realize you are on your own in just about every way, it all comes together.In Rebel Galaxy you come to a distant set of stars to find out what happened to your Aunt Juno.  And from there you can do anything you want, from following her legacy, to trading, to piracy, to naming your ship "Cosmic Bannanahammer" and doing donuts in space.  It's pretty much up to you.Basic gameplay involves piloting your ship to different locations and pursuing different tasks - trading goods, fighting enemies, raiding ships, mining asteroids.  From firing broadsides to talking to people everything can be done with a standard game controller, which makes it extremely easy to play.  Though controls can get complex, the layout and design makes it very easy to get into the game.So let's break down the usual parts of these games:PILOTING: Space is 2D here.  Sorry, 3D is just for display.  This may seem limiting, but it fits the easy-to-control method and keeps the game from getting insanely complex.  See, battles are done by . . .NAVAL BATTLE TACTICS: This may take a bit of getting used to, but the game emphasizes a mix of broadside weapons, turrets, and specailized items.  Learning to juggle when to attack, maneuver, and fire takes a bit of work, but is rewarding to get right.  Also some of your weapons are AI controlled, making life much easier.  Speaking of ship components . . .PLENTY OF SHIP OPTIONS: Equipment really matters in Rebel Galaxy and has tradeoffs.   Once you get your playstyle down you can buy and customize ships that fit you.  Little changes mean a lot, which is good because . . .PLENTY OF MISSIONS: Sure they're often find, kill, or trade, but they're fun and more importantly they have impact with your standing of various groups.  Pirates, Militia, Citizens, and more will come to regard you differentlly depending on what you do.  This gives you quite a few ways to play the game.LOTS OF LITTLE BITS: There's also a delightful amount of extras.  Trade advice and data that appears to help you trade.  Guilds to join. Bits of humor.  Random events that pop up to keep the game rich, from ambushes to data transponders.  The more you play the more you find.A STORY THAT SEEMS INTERESTING: At first I wasn't sure about the story, but a few missions in it actually got my attention.  You don't have to play the story, but still.A SENSE OF ATMOPSHERE: Finally the game really manages to create a great "Space Western" atmosphere, somewhere between Firefly, Cowboy Bebop, and its own thing.  This is helped by . . .A COWBOY BUTTROCK SOUNDTRACK: Really, the soundtrack is the icing on the cake, a bunch of country-rock hard-edged western type songs that complete the experience.  The details in this game really make it.Is the game perfect?  No.  Some of it's very standard game-play, if well-implemented.  The combat can be a bit twitchy and confusing.  Some of the data and info layouts could have been better done.  The thing is with Rebel Galaxy, most issues are really minor.  The game is fun, obviously made by people who love games, and has a clear, well-defined identity.  It delivers.So if you like a good space adventure game, want one that's challenging but you can pick up with realtive ease, then buy the game, get on board the Cosmic Bannanahammer, and head on out to find Aunt Juno.

number of helpful: 13 of 19 people (68%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Basically AssCreed Black flag in Space, including the grindy and repetative nature that BF had.It has a great charm and flare and perfectly nails the space western vibe that it wants to set up. All the ships are dinged up and rusty buckets, your warp drive sounds like it needs a crank start half the time, everyone including the aliens sound like rednecks while vibrant nebulas full of warm yellows and purples makes the dreary backwater system you're in look cozy despite the absolute zero conditions. Combat is fine if pretty shallow, it emulates Black flag almost completely. Combat is mainly through the use of broadside cannons of which there are three main types for your preffered engagement range as well as a slew of secondary weapons that can either be AI or manually controlled. The main unique spin in all ships have shields as their main defesne and these are set up in quadrents with their own independant health pools giving a bit more importance to positioning than Ubisoft's pirate game. Ultimately that is the crux of the entire game, what is has works well but there is very little variety. You'll find one or two setups that are effective and then proceed to grind away doing randomly generated missions or trades to generate the cash needed to buy the next tier of upgrades to survive the later systems and missions, progression is purely numerical. The story itself while not offensively bad won't offer any suprises but gives a good enough incentive to have you roam around the game world.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
Pros of the game:Easy to learn - the controls are simple yet still allow for strategic tactics.It plays similar to Freelancer.Decent variety of ships and weapons to try out.An okay faction system. Not as bad as the faction systems you see in other games.Both the "good" and "bad" factions have their own set of ships, weapons, and components to try out.None of that "selling items for a lower price than you bought it" crap. Everything you sell is for the exact price you bought it. So if you don't like one certain thing, you can trade it for something else with no downsides.There are lots of ways to make money. Even if you're just on your way to a mission, you can end up making some decent cash just from distress calls and bounties.It's very easy to tell if you are well or under equipped for missions with the dynamic mission difficulty system.It has a feature where you can add your own soundtracks to the game to listen to.The graphics are pretty nice even on low settings.The difficulty is dependant on what sector of the system you're in. That way you can choose how easy/hard you wish to play.The rewards you get from missions is also dependant on the sector of the system you're in. So completing harder/longer missions yields much better rewards.Cons of the game:Most of the game's settings can only be changed from a separate launcher. If you want to change a setting, you have to quit and re-launch the game.The main story is very short. Can be completed in less than 24 hours.This is debatable, but the story is not really that interesting.Once you beat the game both as a "good guy" and a "bad guy", there's not much else to do.There's no real reason to use any other ship other than the "Blackgate" once you are able to afford it. It's by far the most powerful ship in the game.There is a certain type of mission where you have to "warp pair" with an NPC and escort them to their destination. Don't even bother taking these types of missions. The NPC AI during these missions is very bad, often times they'll fly in random directions or just despawn all together and give you an automatic "mission failed". And the time it takes to complete these missions is very long as well, so it would be an enormous waste of time if they despawn on you.There are only 4 factions in the game that serve a real purpose. The rest are just for cannon fodder. There is no way to gain reputation with them, which is a shame because they all have their own set of ships that you cannot access or unlock in any way.Rating:Buy it for you and your friendsWorth the full price>>Buy it when it's on sale<<Aim for a free copyNot worth it

												Great game, incredible music, super easy controls, the ships look like something out of Cowboy Bebop (kinda) mixed with Star Wars frieghters (more so). The 2d plane you fly and fight on just works, attacks just like a naval battle, and is really easy to track enemies. Heres hoping we get a second Rebel Galaxy, cheers!

Don't even bother taking these types of missions. The NPC AI during these missions is very bad, often times they'll fly in random directions or just despawn all together and give you an automatic "mission failed". And the time it takes to complete these missions is very long as well, so it would be an enormous waste of time if they despawn on you.There are only 4 factions in the game that serve a real purpose. The rest are just for cannon fodder. There is no way to gain reputation with them, which is a shame because they all have their own set of ships that you cannot access or unlock in any way.Rating:Buy it for you and your friendsWorth the full price>>Buy it when it's on sale<<Aim for a free copyNot worth it

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
This is a review discussing specific points about the game as a comparison for veterans of the genre.An excellent free roaming space game. Very much a Freelancer for the new generation, featuring Capital class vessels!THIS GAME IS JUST FINE WITH A KEYBOARD AND MOUSE, DONT LET OTHER REVIEWERS TURN YOU OFF OF IT BECAUSE YOU DONT HAVE A GAMEPAD!So, in Rebel Galaxy, the value of ALL of the parts you buy for your ship is fully refundable. Including ship chassis. You're free to experiment with new types of loadout at will. No charge for resale at all.There's a stat in the pause menu that shows your Net Worth, including your ship and all of the parts you have on it, what's in your cargo hold, etc. It's a great way to do a single-player space exploration game.People complain a LOT about warping taking too long, but I don't find it a problem at all. You can get upgrades to your warp drive that increase the speed dramatically. As for hitting asteroid belts during a warp, you can and SHOULD watch for oncoming nebulae and asteroid fields. You can literally see them coming from a million miles away, and just steer out of the way. Snake around space for a better paralax view, so you can tell whether you're coming up on something big.Combat is on a 2d plane for capital class vessels, and a 3d plane for fighters and bombers. So, your turrets can hit stuff above and below you depending on their placement, and your side-guns are primarily for hitting the bigger stuff.There is a surprisingly large number of ships in the game, I'd put my currently seen number at about 20. Each faction has their own set of ships on offer. I particularly like the trade faction's GIGANTIC verticall wall of shipping containers, bristling with turrets and cannons.When considering your loadout, you spend a lot of time trying to strike a good balance between equipping anti-fighter, anti-cap, anti-shield, or anti-armor. Each turret and cannon has it's own set of attributes, and the jack-of-all-trades stuff is lacking a little in the numbers department. Over all, weapons feel good and balanced between types, with a slight leaning toward Mining Lasers at the start. I found them good for the first system, and switched out to specialized guns later.The cowboy music aesthetic is nice, very firefly. I ended up turning it off after a few hours of hearing the same four or five tracks, and loaded up a playlist with all the Star Wars music from the original trilogy. Definitely a good choice.Bounties are very easy to get in to. You can find them at random when flying about by using your PULSE scanner, and waiting for the "Bounty Detected!" notice, then flying to the nearest enemy group. You can get map icons and waypoints to them by paying a small fee to bartenders at any station. While flying about, you'll come across lots of other stuff too. Message terminals that you can hack with a simple timed button-puzzle put waypoints on your map marking weapons caches and asteroid belts uncommonly rich in minerals. You can find distress beacons, traders or military who are fighting a losing battle and pay you VERY well to save them! You can also find "Pirate Lords" floating around out there. They are elusive and unusually powerful enemies with huge bounties on them.Missions are the same old cookie cutter, go here, kill stuff, gather items, come back. But! You can take three at a time, and bang them out really quick. Every station has missions, you can see the relative difficulty of each one as a color-coded mission title, green being easy, red being hard. It's actually quite accurate so far, hard missions definitely require some interesting strategies. The missions pay out as SOON as you complete the objective, so if it's just a kill order, you don't need to return for the reward. Super handy!Some of the later trade-faction missions are super lucrative, but require you to actually go find minerals on your own time. I got a mission to gather Pure Water that took me an hour or so due to NONE of the local stations having any, but that could be why I got the mission in the first place! I ended up mining out a few ice asteroids for the loot, and the reward was over $300,000.Trade itself in the game is very simple. Go to station, find merchandise that is selling low, travel around until you find a place to sell high. Each station you visit will book the sale price of each item FOR YOU, and then map them on a really clever line graph showing maximum price, minimum price, and the average price. This means you can do everything at a glance, and don't need to worry about note keeping on paper. Cargo upgrades are pretty cheap, so most any ship can do some hauling. Obviously, gigantic hauling ships do have a lot more to offer that way though.Some ships concentrate much more heavily on rotating turrets, too. So if you don't like the whole "Broadside" dynamic, you really don't have to do it at all. I had a little cruiser with 7 turret slots and only 3 side guns, it was just perfect! The downside to a turret-ship is primarily cost. Turrets cost as much as the entire battery of your broadside guns. They lack a little in pure DPS as well, but you can easily make up for it with proper tactical positioning. Broadsiding is hard to line up against faster enemies, and makes you extremely vulerable to flanking by other enemy ships. It does have a pretty devestating hit if you nail another ship with the whole volley, though!You can blast fighters to smithereens with a well-placed cannon volley, too. That's a little tough, but super satisfying.Over all, I rate this game very highly. Each of it's features feel polished to a mirror sheen. It's very, VERY well thought out, and plays like a dream. I've run the gamut of space-freedom games from EVE to Freelancer to EV-Nova, and I feel like this game is a shining star in the genre!

												It's a *very* well put together game.  I run it with a steady 60 FPS on my potato without having to reduce the settings hardly at all which makes for a rather pretty playing experience.  Well optimized and fun to play and it has a killer soundtrack.  There's definately a Borderlands + Firefly vibe going on and I love it!! number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Think Elite Dangerous, but with naval combat and a good story.The naval-style combat deters a lot of people, but it actually works quite nicely with the single-plane orbit everything has in every solar system.  That means you can't fly up or down, only left or right.  However, smaller fighter planes and asteroids can fly beneath or above you, requiring your ship's turret placements to be more strategic.You can trade, mine, steal, join factions, make factions hate you, help people in distress, escort ships, fight every time, flee every time (depending on ship speed).  You can play as good, neutral, or evil, or jump around and do whatever pays the most.The game allows you to easily put your own music into it. You can resell every ship or item for 100% retail value.  This means you can test out ships, weapons, defenses, etc. without fear of wasting money.  This is a nice way of getting around the fact that you can only own one ship at a time.I think this game is definitely worth the price.  As of writing this I have played 32 hours.  I'm not done with the main story line, and I don't think I will be for a while.  There is too much money to be made, and too many ships and ship upgrades to buy.

												This is the most surprising fun game I've ever played. It has me so hooked that I took a break from Fallout 4 to go back to it. If you read the description, you're likely to tilt your head and say "really?", but I swear, they got the formula right. The fights are frantic and intense, but very fun. number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Its a cool lightweight space sim. Its got good graphics, and the alien voices are pretty cool, especially when they say words you recognize in the subtitles. The music isnt your typical space game ambient or electronica, its a kind of bluesy rock that reminds me of Pandora (Borderlands). Its great.The weird thing about this game is it looks 3d, but its actually on a 2d plane (no Y-axis). Think a top down space sim like Escape Velocity, Ring Runner, Trancendence or any of those, where you are moving on a 2d plane. But imagine the game has a similar POV as the X series. Its really weird and disorienting to be in front of a station and not be able to dive under it.Again, let me state that the game is *lightweight*. Not casual, just not as deep as a game like X3. If you love incredibly in-depth games like X3, Eve, or any of those, you will probably find this a bit too shallow.People just breaking into the space sim genre, or those of you who prefer lighter weight or 2d space sims will probably like this one. For what it is, its done very well. That lack of a y-axis  is hard to get over though, especially if you've come from a full 3d space sim.

												I was really curious how they implemented the broadside-combat in a space game. It seems like they found out that for the broadside-combat mechanic to work, the game had to be in 2D space instead of 3D space. So essentially, a pirate game with the looks of a space game. That would have been fine, if it wasn't for every other ship in the game being able to fly three-dimensionally and you only being able to fly and aim two-dimensionally. So, basically, auto-vertical-aiming, like in the original Doom. But then again not like Doom, as you just have to aim directly at something for your guns to auto-correct the trajectory of your projectiles so they hit a moving target. Makes combat increadibly un-exciting. As combat is an integral part of the game, this just completely turned me off.

												Interesting concept that gets old really fast. If this had been done better it'd feel a lot more like actually being a space bounty hunter or bandit but after like 6 hours it just turns into doing random missions and running supplies around to get more ship upgrades to do more of the same. The combat never changes the enemies just do more damage, so it just feels like a grind as you do missions to get upgrades to... do more difficult missions... For a world as big as it tries to be, the hubs are extremely generic, the bartenders are almost all the same, and your 'random encounters' all play out idententically with recycled voice overs. The soundtrack gets old af after like the first hour. We get it, the final frontier is an allegory for the western frontier, you don't need to dial that theme to 11. This game had a lot of potential I feel like but ultimately didn't meet it at all, just feels like the project funding got cut as soon as they had something that looked like they could sell. I wouldn't pay more than five or ten dollars. It's fun for an afternoon but aimless after that.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8
												Of all the Space sci-fi games I've played, this is easily one of the most satisfying ones I've played in a long time. It delivers on a great Firefly-esque atmosphere, making you feel like some outlaw merc on the fringes of space, saving or sacrificing whomever you choose. The soundtrack is great, the graphics are quite good, and the gameplay feels incredibly satisfying. From the "float like a butterfly, sting like a scorpion" action of the smaller, faster ships, to the bulky and powerful dreadnoughts, each ship class has a great feel to it.The story, while not groundbreaking, does it's job well. And the voice acting, while limited, is more than tolerable at the very least.If you're looking for a super-realistic, newtonian physics based spaceflight simulator, you're at the wrong galaxy. Rebel Galaxy delivers on an incredibly satisfying space cowboy feel, and at a great price too.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												I must say that at almost 50hr's into the game, I love every moment of it.  Honestly, at this point the only thing that I dont particularly care for is the fact that there isn't any kind of co-op/multiplayer mode to it.  The story line was compelling to the point that (aside from getting the distress call or unknown signal source) that i found myself wanting to know what would happen next about midway thru it.The soundtrack is very nice, but as with other games, when i want to listen to something else, i mute the music in game and play my own play list.The Broadside combat i throughly enjoy as i enjoy other games such as Black Flag (console), World of Warships, and back in the day Starfleet Command.  To many space sim games that do give you the whole 3D still even lack the simple ability to do a loop.  So why bother calling it a 3d game? (yes i pointing my finger at you STO and EVE)The missions will get repetive, but honestly, what game doesn't make your grind once you reach that certain point?  And there are enough different ships in the game to let you find the "one" that fits your play style.  I would love to see more ships added eventually.  (i want to fly that Proteus (red devil cruiser/dread (has the look of the Galactica to it))).   I would pay a little more for a DLC with the ability to fly the Alien/Pirate faction ships.As one other person mentioned, there is no cookie cutter build to deal with all missions.  The only ship that will come close to that is the End game Dreadnaught, but all that does is make you a Jack of all trades and Master of none.  (small spoiler below)(small spoiler below)The only constant you can get is the Broadsides destroying everything in 1-3 volleys unless your doing certain Heroic mission.I hope this game continues to add more to it, but if it don't, i've gotten a great game for less than $20.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												If this was being marketed as some $50 triple-A title, it would be disappointing, but as they say in the ad, it's 20 friggin' dollars (and that's when it's not on sale). Rebel Galaxy is a very simple game, and that is its strength and its weakness. If you're looking for a game with a deep story, complex controls, or a fully realized universe with a vibrant dynamic economy, then this ain't it.  Rebel Galaxy is just a fun way to pass the time. It's a nice looking space game with simple controls and a good cowboy rock soundtrack. Incidentally, if you don't like the soundtrack, or you just want a little more variety there is a way to replace or add to the playlist in the game's launcher. I like that it lets you add different folders for different parts of the game. You want honky-tonk piano in the stations, smooth jazz while exploring and speed metal during combat? You can do that.The game is easy to learn and easy to play so long as you understand that running is often a better option than fighting. A fast ship lets you choose your battles and outrun those nasty pirate ambushes that some players seem to have trouble with. It's also a fun way to play. I especially enjoyed the dead drop missions in which I warped into the middle of an enemy formation, grabbed the loot, and hightailed it out of there before they could say, "Prepare to die!"Are there better games in this genre? Of course. But sometimes I don't feel like firing up an Egosoft title and micro-managing a fleet of traders. Sometimes I just want to have a little fun. Rebel Galaxy was made for those times.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												Early impression is very good. It's a casual game which is a good thing for me considering how time consuming many space based games are. Rebel Galaxy just lets you jump straight in and start having fun.The attention to detail is one of the most impressive things, most noticably the sound effects and music. Firefly was clearly an inspiration here. Full voice acting is a refreshing change from walls of text in many new space games have used.If I had any complaints it would be that being 2D does feel a little restrictive, but I get why they did it. This could have been something really special if they made it with PC's in mind instead of consoles (but thats just me still hoping for the utimate PC space game to arrive). Dont let that put you off, it's good fun and well worth the price.Something to add - I've noticed people complain about being dropped out of warp due to asteroids and debris. That happened to me the first time I played, but then I realized you can steer around them while in warp. It's very easy to see objects coming up in the distance and it hasn't happened since.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												After reading reviews about this game being successor to the freelancer classic, I bought the game. The first few hours of game was quite disappointing as the 2D flight mode and the lukeworm story can hardly convince me that this game is even comparable to freelancer. After 5 hours, however, the game became a little more interesting as weapons and ships are unlocked and some of the missions are quite interesting. I have to admit the graphics are good, not superb, but comparable to the freelance --- a shame on its own as the freelancer was a game almost two decades old. The combat system was not inspiring but acceptable and admittedly quite fun to play. Just as I thought the game is getting better, it quickly revealed to me that this is no more than a freelancer game in its core repacked with better graphics and a toned down 2D flight mode. The game soon degenerates into a struggling effort to complete repetitive missions to gain enough money to upgrade ships and components that are ridiculously expensive and are so for no other apparent reasons than to compel the player to complete those stupid missions. So far I think it is unrealistic to make enough money to buy any of those higher level weapons and ships with trade alone. The difficulty associated with some of these missions are also questionable as some missions would see you quickly swarmed by a horde of overpowered enemies ships while other missions give ridiculously high reward for the simpler tasks.In conclusions, I believe this is a game suitable, in fact I would use the word ideal, for killing your excessive pastime at a moderate price. However, to comment that this game may even aspire to be of the equal to freelancer is a severe overstatement.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												Overall this game is amazing. As other reviewers have mentioined this game plays like Freelancer and the Assassins Creed sailing mechanic had a baby.  One issue for me: I did not find the soundtrack to be as wonderful as most do. There are moments where this game genuinely feels like a space western in the vein of Firefly, with moody slide guitar and banjo cues.  At other times, the music drifts into the realm of nickelback clones and pop country (even worse than Whedon's godawful song at the beginning of Firefly).  Personally, I'd ilke to see some of those lound country and blues songs toned down or replaced with a wider variety of background/atmosphere-building music.  Other than this particular issue of taste, I wholeheartedly suggest you buy this. Best space sim I've played in recent years.  Combat is very satisfying and upgrades come quicker than you think if you go about your purchases the right way.   A small tip: don't constantly strive for a new ship. Instead work at upgrading your defenses and weapons. Once I figured this out, it was much easier to complete those high-paying missions needed to finance the next vessel.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												this game totally exceeded my expectations: every other indie space sim of similar price point just doesn't have this level of polish. the UI looks amazing, gameplay is challenging and sensible, the characters and the plot are engaging, there's even some amount of post-story gameplay (grinding for dreadnaughts and rare alien weapons, working for faction reps, killing pirate lords, etc).the music is amazing, but it does get a little repetitive, since the game seems play the same short rock song (with actual singing) for the same scenes. regardless, the songs are pretty cool and firefly-esque, and would be nice to own as a soundtrack.there's even that little bit of modding possible - basically, opening the game's ini files and modifying the values to unlock certain assets for players to buy. flying a greel ship is just so awesome.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												I'm a fan of the old-school get your mission from some weirdo in the bar of a space station style of space combat sims. My all-time favorite game would have to be Wing Commander: Privateer. This game does a really great job of coming close to that experience.Pros:The soundtrack is fantastic. All the music tracks are well chosen. I only wish they would release the soundtrack as an option to buy.The choices of ships and equipment are not vast, but just right to keep things fun and keep me working to get more cash so I can try different combinations of builds.The environment is really beautiful. The game is fun to play. I would find myself warping to random spots on the map just to see what was there.Meh:The lack of a 3rd axis took some getting used to. If you put it in your brain that it is a sailing ships game with space textures instead of water it will be easier to wrap your mind around it. Once you do that you will stop noticing the inability to fly up.Besides. "Up is just where you are looking" -EnderCons:Some of the pirate encounters feel very RNG. I'll be flying along doing great and defending myself to suddenly find myself in overwhelming odds for no reason what-so-ever and go boom. Mining is boring as hell. And this is from someone who enjoys mining in Eve Online. Overall: This game is worth the price of admission. 7/10

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												I had been looking for a single player space based game that included missions, mining, exploration and ship to ship combat for a long time before I came across Rebel Galaxy. I picked this game up on sale hoping it would provide me with what I had been looking for and was happily satisfied. You start Rebel Galaxy off in a tiny ship and are quickly thrown into this massive galaxy head first with no real direction and plentiful choices on what to do first, an amazing first impression. After a few hours I found that some of the missions were kind of repetitive so I moved on to a different sector to try a new guild. While the missions did vary there are a lot of fetch quest style side missions that unfortunately did not change as the game progressed. Rebel Galaxy shows you straight from the start these giant dreadnaught class ships worth $15m+ while you are making a measly $10k a mission. This while great, also lead to a desire to acquire better ships and gear as quickly as possible. The problem with this choice is due to the games difficulty system, which  is never explained. Rebel Galaxy seems to use four mechanics to set difficulty; system rating, mission difficulty and the last two are based on what hull class and gear type you are using. The game only considers your highest individual type of gear to set the difficulty which can lead to some annoying situations where you are severely outclassed by the enemy ships . These two points should not dissuade you from this game, however. Almost every other aspect was fantastic. The music, while I found not suited to space exploration, was great and has been well received by the community . The ship types and styles all were unique and looked great while offering a variety of build possibilities and attack styles. The weight and feel of the ships during combat and the combat itself. The battles at the core of the game can be amazingly chaotic, the large varieties of ships / builds with different amounts of each in a fleet can lead to some of the biggest fights you have ever been in. I went into a great number of battles ridiculously outnumbered and when surviving in the final moments after a tense and carefully executed fight,  let out a profanity or cheer due to the satisfaction of these sometimes epic encounters. Overall this game scratched an itch that I've had for years that nothing has come close to. For the price and the amount of time you can get out of this game I couldn't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												From the first riffs of the soundtrack, to the thundering broadsides in your first battle, Rebel Galaxy grabs hold of your inner "space cowboy" and never lets go.Honestly, not many games give you the full experience of being an outlaw like Rebel Galaxy. Sure, other games has the long arm of the law chase you around, have you be loathed by the locals, and generally make life less than pleasant as it should be. So, what was missing? The soundtrack. This is hands down one in the top 20 game soundtracks I have had the pleasure of listening to while I played a game.As for the game itself, it is pretty straightforward. Take missions, get credits, earn/lose reputation, and along the way solve the mystery of what happened to your Aunt. While it can get grindy, especially for those wanting to be outlaws and getting that initial "bad reputation" you need, there is a fair amount of variety to the missions, as well as stuff to find, kill, mine, trade, etc. You can also customize your ship in a plethora of ways, from weapons and armor, to ship class itself. From gunship to dreadnought, there's a ship for just about everyone.Combat is pretty straightforward, you use devastating broadsides on larger ships to tear them apart, while using your turrets to add to the carnage, or use them to pop pesky fighters. With the customized loadouts, you can make your ship a straight up brawler, or make it a long range ship that deals damage from afar without having to worry about heavy plating. There are also support abilities that can further refine your battle plan, or round out a particular weakness.The map is pretty expansive, and the economy reacts to events, so raiding a convoy or breaking a siege will also affect prices of goods that can be traded. This affords you the player lots of ways to play, from being a miner to a no guts no glory pirate.My only gripes are that it can get grindy, but I really don't mind. The soundtrack and visuals clearly make the downtime less unpleasant, and the long warps around the map have given me lots of places to visit along the way. For someone that enjoys being a space privateer, Rebel Galaxy is a game I am glad that I did not miss out on.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												So... Rebel Galaxy...Rebel Galaxy is a game with a space setting that locks you in a 2D plane. You can steer right, you can steer left and that's it. No up, no down, in a game with a space setting, one of the only settings in which you expect full freedom of movement and you're stuck in a 2D plane. This just doesn't make sense to me, why would you make a space game but then handle it as if the player was a ship in the ocean.This was such a disappointment. I bought this game after I watched the trailers, had a loock at the screenshots, which do look good, and read some of the user reviews. These reviews described this game as a mix of Freelance and Sid Meier's Pirates, games I absolutely love and I go back to play them regularly.What else can i say about this game?The graphics are okay, the music is... well I am not a fan of country music, so it's not for me, but that's something you need to decide yourself.I can't say much about the quests you get or the universe itself, as I only played about 20 minutes and then shut the game down in disappointment.So in conclusion if you want a very good space game with lots of freedom get Freelancer and if you want a game with naval combat on a 2D plane get Sid Meier's Prates (it's on Steam).I will refund this game and I hope that if you buy it you will have a better time with it than I did.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												I bought Rebel Galaxy on a whim, and thus far it has been the best impulse buy I've ever made on Steam.  You control a space cruiser flying around the galaxy trading and fighting.  Make money from trading at space stations buying low, selling high, and use the money to upgrade your ship with new weaons, armor, and equipment.  This will allow you to take on pirates (or become a pirate) and loot your fallen enemies.  Trade, fight, loot, upgrade, repeat until you have enough for a bigger ship and repeat the process.  This is much what I imagine Han Solo and Chewbacca did before running into Luke and Ben in Mos Eisley.  Do you want a Han Solo simulator or a Firefly simulator?  This is pretty much it.  I also enjoy the amount of choices the devs chose to throw at the player.  For almost every mission you have multiple options of how to proceed, be it violently or non-violently.  I have yet to see how many of these choices play out, but Rebel Galaxy has made a very good impression in my first few hours of gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 15
I like it, but...As a fan of Firefly, I like this game for both the whole living-on-the-edge vibe, and for the slide-guitar soundtrack. It's cool.But as an astronomer and lover of science fiction, I'm disappointed.First, in space a real spaceship does NOT slow down just because you kill the engines. There is this thing in physics called "momentum". You know, the whole thing about an object in motion tending to stay in motion unless acted upon by an outside force? In space there are very few outside forces that would cause a spaceship to slow to a stop just because the engines are off. At the bottom of a gravity well, like, say, on the surface of the Earth, a vehicle like a car will slow when you take your foot off the gas because of friction. Silly programmers... If you're gonna make a game set in space, at least pay attention to how things BEHAVE in space.Second, even though the POV can be moved around in 3 dimensions the actual game play is 2-dimensional. You can go right & left (port & starboard), but not up or down. Remember Star Trek II, the Wrath of Khan? How did Kirk beat Kahn? Because Khan was operating in only 2 dimensions, whereas space is 3-dimensional.I mean, c'mon, guys! If you're gonna go to all the trouble of programming a game that is smart enough to have you colliding with ice chunks, asteroids and planetary objects, can't you figure out how to deal with 3 dimensions?The last item is that, like so many other games, once you’ve got the basics down it’s “lather, rinse, repeat.” It would be nice to have more different kinds of missions - medical rescues, something that involves landing on some of the worlds instead of just flying by, I dunno. Something other than just blasting things to smithereens.Ah, well. Given the limitations, I'm gonna have to give this game 3.5 stars on a 1-5 scale.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												This game is amazing!  It has great gameplay, from zooming around killing dirty ol space pirates, to mining for riches, or delivering cargo to and fro.  The visuals on it are breathtaking, and the amount you can customize your ship is awesome too.  I just made it out of the first sector, and I'm finding new enemies, a new guild to join and do quests for and new parts of the storyline.  The one thing that I find the coolest is the amount and difference in ships.  I started off with the basic little ship, it has like 4 broadside cannons and 2 turret placements.  I saved up enough to buy the next one that had one more turret placement and thought "holy crap, I am way stronger now".  Before I jumped sectors I had saved up for a half million dollar ship "the barracuda", because it had very fast speed and manuverability, along with 5 turret slots.  I thought I was the boss... and then I saw the ships in the next sector.  This one I just saw costs 17 MILLION and has 13(!) broadside ports and 13(!) turret placements and is HUGE!  Holy crap, time to do some more missions and save up to get one of those beasts.  I have played for 16 hours as of this review, and I can see myself playing for many more hours to come.  So worth the money!

content:
Posted: February 13
												This game is definitely worth it on sale. The gameplay is repetitive but fun. I recommend playing as a pirate for maximum fun. There is just something so satisfying about flying up to a trader asking for help because he is bring attacked by pirates and joining in on the kill. The life of an outlaw is fun, running from or destroying the militia as they chase you around each system. The music is great. I created a playlist of the songs and have listed to it hundreds of times. The space western theme is well flushed out. Mining and trade are boring. It's much more fun to just take from others. The missions are repetitive but are fun if you like blowing stuff up. There are a decent number of ships and some are faction specific. I enjoy the 2D combat. I fully admit that I find 3D space combat to be too difficult to enjoy. This game is more like eve online in that sense. I definitely recommend you get this on sale. A few dollars for a solid 30-50 hours of fun is well worth it.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												I bought this game because of the trailer set to "Evil Ways: Justice Mix," and I have no regrets. Whether intended or not, the title is a loving tribute to all "Cowboy Movie In Space" stories, from Star Wars to Firefly. As with any other similar offering, the startlingly addictive travel-fight-upgrade loop is crafted to keep you hooked, and hooked I was."Rebel Galaxy," at the pick-up-n-play level, offers a nifty sort of subversive, stripped-down take on maneuvering and shooting. This isn't a game about twisting and turning in every possible direction. Instead, you're locked on a 2D plane, with your abilities to both manage your loadout and hop into manual fire-control being of paramount importance. This is not to say that maneuvering and mobility aren't influential. Rather, it's to say that the approach to those aspects is much more focused; The "domain" is restricted to a relatively simple mechanic that's easy for the player to recognize and iterate upon.What's very interesting to me is how this connects to the overall backdrop of the experience. Especially with the "broadsides" element, the way the ship-combat works makes that part of the game a "Tall Ships In Space" sort of activity, which is usually mutually exclusive from the "Cowboy Movie In Space" genre. An odd sort of outcome, though, is that for all the emphasis on the broadsides, the game ends up subverting them. Matching speed and hammering away at an enemy is fine if you outclass them, but you're far better off getting on their tail and letting your turrets do the work. A smaller ship can really beat up on bigger adversaries that way, because the truly frightening firepower can't hit you."Rebel Galaxy" doesn't quite hit a perfect mark. The way the interaction is broken up into three modes is strange and clunky, with two kinds of scanning (the pulse and detail scans) being strangely divorced from each other in both where they are found and how they work. Also, the "loot" value/ mission value/ mission difficulty/ equipment cost curves start off being very nicely tuned, but then seem to diverge as the game gets into the late stages. Particularly frustrating were missions labeled as being relatively safe, where that label apparently pertained only to the very beginning of the mission. A few moments into the actual meat of the encounter, and you might find yourself surrounded by a large number of very dangerous opponents.The problems are very small, though. "Rebel Galaxy" is a truly worthy effort that is fun to play and manages to have its own identity. I hope there are more like it over the horizon.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												Great space action RPG. As a low priced space game I didn't expect much, but have found this game fun and satisfying.The world is full with a great variety of things to do. Everywhere you go are distress beacons, asteroid fields, ships to fight. Even while on a mission you constantly run into things to distract and entertain you. There are a huge variety of quests to suit any play style.The combat is interesting and challenging. The world is 2d and the ships feature big broadside guns, naval combat style.There are a variety of upgrades that will change the way you play. Broadsides cannons, turrets, missiles, different shield and engine styles.If I have a single complaint it's the difficulty curve of the main quest. The missions ramp up very steeply and require doing tons of side missions to earn cash for upgrades. While I'm still enjoying myself, it does get a bit grindy.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10
												I have to say, I love the style and presentation of this game, and the gameplay is superb. There is a balance in every type of play style and it feels fantastic to lay waste to your enemies in whatever fashion you choose, be it ramming into the hull of enemy ships, overwhelming them with a superior arsenal, or quick strikes that topple your alien foes with mosquito bites. The base soundtrack is limited but manageable with the option to extend the playlists with your own tracks. If you want to blow up♥♥♥♥♥♥while listening to Drake, you can do it! My biggest gripe with this game however... Is the repition. You will be destroying bandits, evil alien factions, the lawmen and women of the galaxy... but thats all the game has to offer. Even into my 20th hour of gameplay I was in love with the combat system, but as the dust settled and the story came to mind, I couldn't find it in me to play past a certain point. I love this game and I believe with a little love and attention for the story or making the economic elements more accessible it could be great.

If there is a mod support, this game will be even more awesomeIt's on sale now and I reccomend you to buy this especially if you are a fan of space battles.

												Remember Wing Commander Privateer? This is that game taken to the next level.Cool space battles akin to the naval battles of Assassin's Creed Black Flag? content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												This game is great! You'll be able to find a lot of reviews listing its general qualities, so I'll just talk about my experiences with its combat.Note: This is not a 3D movement dogfight space combat sim,  combat in this game is closer to what you might find in old naval battlesCombat against a mixed enemy fleet is truly a multitasking excercise. You'll be using your boosters to keep yourself alongside larger enemy ships so you can use your broadside cannons, timing your deflector shield uses to block their incoming broadsides/missles, and spamming X button to fire EMP flak at the smaller ships so you can focus on the big target.I find myself having to think about positioning alot, and having to boost away from larger ships or swarms of small craft while i swing my own ship around because the big hole in my leftside hull cant take it anymore, so i reorient and come in from a new angle. So far about 50% of my combat has been outside of mission running. You'll often find distress beacons, get tips from bartenders on bounty locations, or just plain run smack into an enemy fleet while warping somewhere else. Certain missions seem really unbalanced at first, but after refitting to the right weapons or adopting new tactics, suddenly theyre totally manageable.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												As a fan in general of the larger and more complex space sims such as the old X games I can say I had a lot of fun with this game despite it being "simpler". If you're looking for a game that is very deep and has fully fleshed out trading, reputation, 3d flight you may want to look elsewhere (X3 or Starpoint Gemini 2 come to mind). I don't think that's what the developers were trying to accomplish here. I think they wanted the fun and engaging nature of a naval pirate game with some light-weight trading mechanics, where the focus is kept on the combat with the loot system basically for rewarding the player and enabling progression. In that I think they succeeded and did a great job in bringing that feel to a space setting while adding a distinctive feel with the music and pace. I will say that I did have a minor issue with the game where once I found the right setup it became pretty easy to cheese my way through the fights, but it was still a blast.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy....Probably the most fun I've ever had with a space game like this ever. The soundtrack alone attracted me to this wonderful game, only because it's such a perfect match. Though I must say, at the time of writing this, I have roughly 60 hours set in right now into Rebel Galaxy, but it does not match the potential amount of hours I COULD be spending playing this game. With it's randomly generated "Systems" or whatnot, it provides a relatively fresh experience with every new playthrough. The only downside with this model, is there is a general process that is the same, and it goes with the advancement in tech vs. the contracts price in every system. Right out of the start cutscene, I could spend maaaybe 2-5 hours building up enough money for a new drive that allows for Solar System Gate use, and start working easy contracts in the furthest system. Run into no conflict, and in the matter of hours attempting at getting high tier gear relatively early on in the story breaks the immersion a little bit. Even if you were to stay true to the story aspect, you can get to a specific point and still go do side quests and contracts for money. There are many directions that you could take with every playthrough, and thats what I'm getting at exactly. No matter how hard or easy you make it for yourself, it's still amazing what one could do in this game.I will have to say, it does break a little bit of realism/immersion at times, when Juno talks  about "your small ship and how it may be time for an upgrade", and you already maxed everything out. It just seems weird to me. Little prompts like that. Another thing that concerns me is the difficulty overall, it goes from baby steps to smacks in the face pretty quick, and the overall progression seems a little awkward when moving up in tech. I found that the only way I could survive going up in difficulty for the next system was to earn a ridiculous amount of money, go over there, and buy the highest tech because that would be the only way I could even survive there. The whole concept of Mining or Trading seems a bit awkward to me, because if you want to mine, you have to go at it for a long time to make any real profit. It feels almost useless to me (Mining), unless you find that golden nugget in a desert, the Antimatter Specks, which I have yet to find. The only way you can even make trading profitable is if you attack convoys or traders due to the large amount of items they have that are super profitable OR fighting Pirate lords with high end ship systems, though, they are insanely hard sometimes.PROS:1. The whole badass atmosphere (with music) gives the player confidence and has a really good feeling while flying through space in my awesome ship with big weapons2. Optimization and level of content allow the highest graphics even on lower end machines3. Ship designs seem really well thought out and allow for a multitude of playing stylesNEUTRAL:1. Combat feels tasteful and well done, though lack of ways to end your enemies in your travels feels saddening at times. When I'm flying past, I feel the only way to really do damage is broadsides or lots and lots of turrets. If only there were more ways, it would feel just perfect.CONS:1. Mining is tacky and has a useless feeling. One could be mining for hours, but unless they are mining the right materials that usually scarce in most astroid fields, so it doesn't feel fulfilling2. Solar Systems never really feel unique, a few system is a new system. It may have labels that some places are better for trade or mining, but I haven't really noticed a difference anywhere.3. Factions seem pointless sometimes - because I could be super friends with the militia and citizens, but NOBODY else would like me, and it wouldn't matter because I wouldnt gain anything from them anyways. The only other faction that matters to some degree is the Red Devil Raiders, but they offer mid-game gear from my current understanding. If the other factions had more purpose and personality, I'd be more inclined to try improving relations with them, IF there was a way besides surrendering all of my cargo whenever they see me.Rebel Galaxy is definitely a fun game and I highly suggest you give it a try!---NOTE---The game is not far from its release date, so I expect a lot of changes in the games further history, but for now, this is what I see :)

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I've only gotten a few hours into this game, but I'm already loving it. It appears to have the full range of activities in the Freelancer tradition: exploration, trading, mining, and loads of combat. You have faction relations that can go up or down depending on who you do missions for, and there seem to be space ports all over the place to dock at for missions and equipment. I've only barely scratched the surface of the main story, but it's intriguing so far.Combat seems to be the focal point of the game, and it's really well done. I'm not sure how much more layered it can get, but it's nicely varied so far. You control a capital ship rather than just a fighter, and you seem to have two primary classes of weapons: broadsides and turrets. Broadsides do massive damage, but are slow and can't track fast moving ships. They're great against other capital ships though. Turrets can lock onto targets and tear up small fighters, but they can overheat if you don't give them a break from firing. And the cool thing is, they will automatically fire while you're controlling the broadsides. In addition, you have a thruster boost mechanism that can increase you speed, but which can also be depleted from over use, such that it needs a rest to recharge. On top of that, you can get a deflector add-on which is something like an extra shield that absorbs essentially all incoming damage. When it's up, you can't fire your weapons, and it has limited energy which drains over time or rapidly when it's taking hits.What all this means in practice is that you've got a lot of systems and energy bars to keep track of, which keeps combat really engaging. It was a tiny bit overwhelming or frustrating initially, but I felt like I got the hang of the essentials within maybe half an hour. At that point, combat was a blast.I can't say much about the main story, since I've only gotten a couple missions into it, but it seems to revolve around some form of advanced technology and finding a lost relative. Interesting enough that I want to see where it goes. The world feels large and full of activity. Visually, the game is gorgeous, with great effects for all the weaponry, and the music is awesome, a dustry, countrified rock soundtrack that really adds a lot of character to the experience. I love me some electronic music, but this is a nice change of pace that gives the game a distinct personality. In summary, if you ever played the old Wing Commander games, or Freelancer, or anything similar, you will love this game. It even more closely resembles another game call Nexus: The Jupiter Incident that came out about a decade ago, which had an equally interesting story. I'd say the primary difference with that game is that combat is much more refined and well done here. If you're like me and aren't sure, but crave space adventures, get this game.
