number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 9
												It has a firefly theme to it (the music especially). Which is awesome.Game plays on a 2D plane. You basically fly around doing missions (basically kill missions, or fly into a bunch of guys and take something and leave while they try to kill you missions). As you fly around you get blockaded by enemies who you have to fly through/around to get back to warp. As you fly around you also run into distress beacons you can go to and either fall into a trap or come to someone's aid while they are getting killed.Basically killing is the only real solution to anything in this game. I think that's it's major weakness.The commodities market is pretty lame. You can only put a few things in your holds and most stores never sell enough of anything to fill your holds to do proper buy/sell trading. And even if they did, it's almost never going to be all of the good stuff with a good price. Otherwise this system could be pretty fun if it was balanced and actually changed with supply/demand. All in all it's fun for a while. Then it gets grindy. Then it gets really grindy. Then you use cheats and give yourself all the money you want. Then you go out and realize there's nothing else to the game and you quit. If you can get this for $5, I'd buy it for some over simplified naval combat in space with the firefly theme to it. But while this game engine is good enough for some pretty awesome gameplay....sadly, it is pretty void of good content.Almost great.

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 12
												THE GOOD:This is a game that is visually beautiful, with great graphics and sound.  For instance, the details on damage your hull takes is, for lack of a better word, gorgeous.  High production values all around.THE BAD:Wow, I just can't get into the gameplay at ALL.  Take all the parts that aren't fun about World of Warcraft, and combine them with all the parts that aren't fun about X3: Reunion.  -Shallow RPG elements.  Shallow dialogue choices.  Shallow, linear plotline buried in a sandbox game.-An "open world sandbox" that is mostly empty, and is in TWO dimensions.  (This is a space game.)  -Grinding the same bounty quests over and over for money for upgrades.   -Combat is similar to space battles in Star Trek Online, but shallower, with less strategy and fewer options.  I kept wishing for the officer abilities of STO to give it some variance.-3/4th of the enemy you face are starfighters, which you have to bat away with your turrets. Fighters move in three dimensions; you do not.  To help you hit them, your reticule locks onto them and follows them around.  So you're pretty much just flying in a circle and holding down the fire button.  Against 3/4 of the enemies you face.-Oh, and by the way, you know that cool "Evil Ways" song in the preview movie on the store page?  Well, you'll think it's alot less cool when you start playing because that song (in rotation with perhaps two others) is your constant companion as you amble around the universe looking for mobs to grind. THE VERDICT:Dull.  There isn't much more to this game than the combat, and I can tell the combat is supposed to feel a lot more exciting than it does.  When you streamline something to a certain degree, it moves past "stream-lined" and ventures into the dangerous realm of "dumbed-down."  The combat feels dumbed-down, the trading feels dumbed-down, and the RPG elements feel dumbed-down. After playing for about an hour and a half, all I want to do is reinstall X3 so I can play a game that does all of these elements correctly.  Glad I got this at a discount, but I still wish I could take this purchase back.

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												Good game for the money with some major drawbacks.Pros:- Great atmosphere- Enjoyable Costumization- Enjoyable Fights but (see cons)- Good difficulty balance- Nice random events but (see cons)- Great soundtrack- Beautiful universe and ship design Cons:-Fights get stale fast and are in terms of tactical depthness pretty bleak after a short while. Enemys get spawned in around you which is a huge letdown. The fighst needed features like e.x. Take cover behind asteroids to avoid incoming fire from enemy, Take cover behind enemy ships to avoid fire. Maybe features like cloaking (you can detect every ship with a simples can, th game needs a system like world of warships), sideway boosts or big space battles with way more ships but a tactical feature to command and order friendly ships to win battles. (stop the game like the scannermode give us a overview and command features)- Market system is to simple after a while and it should add new goods if you get to new systems or have individual goods that you can sell in different systems and more economical possibilitys.- Random events like distress calls or bountys are great but two features get boring pretty fast- Events on planets have a good impact on the econemy features but some events don't effect the prices as much as they should in my opinion. - Rewards for e.x. destroying big battleships or pirate kings are inconsistent and don't scale properly- And last but not least my most important complain:The missions are too similar and there are only a handful of Story missions. The pretext of the Mainstory is good but it feels like the WHOLE CAMPAIGN should be only the FIRST CHAPTER of the whole story unfolding. Everything feels impersonal. You are traveling space for years and you have interaction with 4 notacible Characters in the whole game if you count all mercenarys as one character of interest.I'm aware that this is a fairly small project from a very small developer team but the wasted potential on this game is making my head spin. So for now, as regrettable as it is, I can't wholeheartly recommend for you to buy this game.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												The brief review:What did I do?It took me 27 hours to complete the storyline, and then I took another 2 hours to get into a dreadnought, just to see what it felt like. I played it to complete it, and not to just fly around and experience the "universe". The story is bland at best, but it serves as a waypoint reference to guide you. I went the way of the mercenary and did fighting missions almost exclusively. This got.. bland after awhile. I found a method of fighting and stuck to it, simply upgrading the same types of weapons from Mk1, Mk2, Mk3 etc... blandWhat didn't I do?trade. Boring.. How was it?I guess it was SORTA worth the time? I mean it feels like fleet combat with broadsides, and certain weapons are more fun than others. If you like grinding reputation, killing pirates and stuff, this is not a bad game. The soundtrack is brilliant, the graphics are nice, and the overall aesthetic is worth your viewing pleasure. But it is NOT an epic space opera. It's the 2d platforming brother of something like Elite. But that just makes it a good place to start if you're not sure if you're going to like that type of game, since this one does away with all the tedious "realistic" parts :)It's a tentative recommendation. Go into this if you want an arcadey space sim with great music.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Well, just finished my first game of this, so I figured it was time for a review. So, where to start?Well, I'll start basic. This game is basically what it looks like: a space trucker sim with combat that is similar to the ship-to-ship combat in Assassins Creed: Black Flag, with the primary weapons being broadside cannons and turrets. If you've heard that this game starts out kinda crappy, you heard right. The starting ship (a Hammerhead called the "Rasputin") is exactly what the intro cinematic says it is: a near-derelict ship with lousy hull & shielding, and the cannons are more akin to pop guns than actual weapons.But that's the whole point, isn't it? You build yourself up by killing baddies, taking quests, maybe mining some, although I personally avoided mining as much as I could in this game. (Too boring.) The idea is to earn enough cash so you can spend it on upgrading your ship's weapons, shields and armor to the point that enemies that once gave you a mountain of trouble will now regret ever♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off... right before their ships explode and you suck up whatever cargo they dropped.[As an extra note, some games may think it's cool to have increased prices for purchases, lowered prices for sales. Not this one! Here, if you purchase a turret for 5,000 credits and then decide to sell it later (possibly because you'd just picked up a better version), you'll still receive 5,000 credits back. Same goes for hull, shield, and engine upgrades.]And of course you'll want to swap out your starting ship for a better one as quickly as possible. One with more turret slots, more broadside cannons, more cargo space, and a better hull. You'll also want to purchase some special components for your ship, like Heat Management which reduces the amount of heat your turrets generate when firing, allowing them to fire more often.Which brings me to weapon setups. When it comes to setting up your strategy, your first perrogative will be to find a setup which works for you. Personally, I ran with Tachyon broadsides for their fast rate of fire, Heatseekers for secondary weapons, and my turret of choice was the Pulse variant for their range & damage per shot, although I do recommend equipping a Korian Viridian laser cannon if you happen to find one. (I managed to find two, one a Mrk 2, the other a Mrk 5 late in the game.)Your second concern will be learning how best to maneuver in a high-tension battle. This is a 2D arena, so you won't have to worry about capital ships hitting you from above or below. But fighters will swarm around you, attempting to knock out your shields so their bigger cousins can finish you off. And by the way, your shields deplete based on which side gets hit, meaning that if you take too many hits to starboard, your starboard hull will be exposed and vulnerable; take too many hits to starboard after that, you're a goner. Oh yeah, I've had a couple of deaths where the shields were still strong on everywhere except where the enemy was currently hitting me en masse.Here's my pro strategy though: when engaged in a pitched battle, move out to the sidelines to draw the fighters away and have your turrets take those out first. After which, you'll want to position yourself so the capital ships will be on only one side at a time. Then throttle down so that you can turn faster as needed. Just keep fire broadsides at them while your turrets provide backup, and when your shields on that side start to lose their charge, turn around so the other side will be facing them and then repeat the procedure.However, there is something I should mention: up until the third star system, your main obstacle is pirates who fire nothing but regular rounds and missiles at you. Once you get to the third system, however, you'll meet the Greel. These guys (both their fighters and their capital ships) feature Leech weapons which fire EMP missiles at you. And these things  not only do a good amount of damage to your shields, but they do a number on your engines as well. So your best bet is to get the EMP Ablation component (what the hell kind of word is that?) so that EMP weapons won't cause quite as much trouble.Nevertheless, a well-upgraded ship can handle just about anything. Just find the style and setup that works best for you and get out there. Just remember if things start to go♥♥♥♥♥♥up, there ain't no shame in making a run for it. All the money in the galaxy won't comfort you if you're dead.As the game itself, it's single player only and can be played offline if you please. Although you won't be able to make progress on achievements without being online, I found out. Also, the musical tracks they used in this game, while good, can get really repetitive; I ended up muting it. And if there's one gameplay feature I'm iffy about, it's that the best lasers in the game (the Korian Viridians) are random drops, no way to purchase them in a spaceport.There's also the issue with communications with the npcs in the game: they're pretty limited. Not to mention that the pirates seem to have trouble realizing when they're outmatched and that surrender would be in their best interest. Like I'll be flying an Arcturus-class Destroyer (which is strongly reminiscent of the Imperial Star Destroyer from Star Wars) armed to the teeth with top-notch weapons and they'll still be talking♥♥♥♥♥♥.. right up until I blow them to smithereens.And speaking of the AI, there's the escort missions. Now, the way it works is that you fly to a location, approach the client, and hold down E to Pair Warp. What that does is that the AI takes full control of your ship, keeping it alongside the ship even as you two go into warp. Noble in itself but it can lead to some annoying results. For one, when two ships are alongside each other, a human would say that the best course of action is to throttle down and turn right to line up with the client; the AI meanwhile turns your ship left, causing your back section to collide with the client's. And why is it that every escort mission has to start in an asteroid field or a ice field? Because just now I had a mission start in an ice field, I was flying a dreadnaught and it took 5-10 minutes just to get started! The AI kept maneuvering us around the ice field, taking me one direction him another. And just when I thought we were getting out of this mess, it had the client move back into the field, prolonging this mess. I had to break warp pairing, and move my ship out of the ice field myself just to get us going.Was I annoyed by all of this? Yeah, I'd say it goes without saying that I was.Then there are the missions where you fly in and save someone from enroaching hostiles. There's a good chance they'll get themselves blown up because they decided to fly into the middle of a pack of hostiles. And as Harrison Ford said in The Last Crusade "Are you crazy?!? Don't go between 'em!!"All in all though, it's a good game, well-worth the asking price. Combat can get a little challenging at times (especially with the Greel I mentioned above) but it's easy to learn & of moderate difficulty to master, just the way I like it. And if all that wasn't enough, the developers also made sure to include a risk analysis for each mission that adjusts based upon anticipated enemy strength against that of your own. And while not all the ship designs are prize-winners, there are some really good ones.So yes, I definitely recommend this game. It's cheap, it's challenging, and it'll last a long time. Hell, there're some triple-A titles that won't last as long as this game will! [cough, cough... Star Wars Battlefront: EA... cough, cough]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												This is yet another game where I wish I could give a middle rank, neither a yes or a no, but a "meh" rating too, however since the game is cheap, and has very good production values, and is fun for a little while, Ill give it the up vote.Anyway, you can watch some videos to see what kind of game this is about, however, Ill just get into some of my gripes with the game design.Some minor issues that annoy me:1.  Missions are over scripted and in a way are not realistic.  For example, every time you have do a trade-guild mission to ship some specific cagro from point A to B, you will ALWAYS be intercepted.  There is ALWAYs trouble.   Now if this were the only problem, I could overlook this.  The actual problem is that the REAL trade mission is to actually destroy the guys who intercept you.  Case and point, I took a very lucrative delivery mission that took place in  the same system.  It was rated as HIGH risk.   I figued I could run away.  My mission is to deliver something, not kill things?  RIght?  Oh no, quite wrong.   So I am getting close to the station I need to make my delivery to, and as usual, the trap is sprung and a bunch of ships appear from all directions and they pull you out of "warp".    So what do I do? I escape, I use my after burners and get enough distance and jump back into warp.  I make it like 5 clicks and the same trap happens again.  I do this 2 more times and each time the trap is reset and sprung again which is just terrible game design.  The only solution is to kill the ambush.  All mission types that are not supposed to be directly about combat workout the same way.2.  You can have missles as weapons, the problem with them is that you do not have a lot of ammo, which makes sense.  However, if you are an NPC, then you have infinite ammo.  I once had a ship that shot waves of missiles the killed my engines.  The didn't do any damage to my ship or shields, but I couldn't move.  It just sat there for like 10 minutes keeping me pinned.  I had to Alt-F4 to recover because if you exit normally, it would save your game and I would have been stuck forever.3.  No quick save.Ok, enough of the small sutff.  Why did I stop playing this game without finishing the main story?  What is the big thing that is wrong with the game design?Basically it is repetivie and boring.  Combat is boring.  Flying around in space warping everwhere is boring.  Each star system is randomly generated, but they are all very generic and you can't really tell the difference other than this sone might have a yellow sun and the other one has a blue sun.   There is nothing to explore or find.  Its all the same, everywhere.Now maybe if you LOVE space games you may get a lot more milage out of it then I did, but after about 20 hours the game felt more like work then fun.

												Purchased on a lark and was suprised by the game's quality. Broadside space combat, mining & trading all take place with an overall "western" theme. The soundtrack is catchy and sounds great. The game can get repetitve but the core conecepts are fun enough to have anyone coming back for more. content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Open world Space Pirate/Trader RPG! Which will you chose? You can be a trader, fighter or a mix. The music is fantastic and dead on for this type of game. The voice acting, graphics and game play are all great and help deliver a fun and entertaining game play experience. It's linear and has no up or down movement, but it works and in a time when the industry is all about freedom of movement in games it is not needed in this game and is not missed. You can tell the game has heavily drawn from TV show Firefly. Shiny!

												I bought this on a whim yesterday after seeing it available, probably one of the better purchases I've made recently. The gameplay is simple but feels rewarding and the challenges scale well when upgrading and buying new ships and equipment. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a thoroughly enjoyable space RPG-style game.  The game page and other reviews do a good job of providing more detail on the gameplay, so I won't waste too much time covering that.  Basically, it's a naval combat game in space (movement is in 2D only).  That being said, this style in no way detracts from the game's value.  You spend your time doing missions, mining, trading, and/or hunting bounties to make money which goes toward upgrading your ship.  There is also a "main campaign" that takes you through a simple yet adequately interesting story.  On the downside, the factions are a bit bland (as is mentioned in several other reviews) and there really doesn't seem to be much replayability (at least I personally have no desire to replay now that I've beaten the game).If you want to pew-pew other spaceships in a beautifully rendered, decent sized "universe" while listening to an admittedly catchy soundtrack (seemingly ranging in influence from CCR to Pearl Jam at times) then this game is worth looking into.  It runs smoothly with no bugs or glitches (for me, anyway).  Ultimately, I found the game experience to be well worth the cost.8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy is a light hearted space sim, borrowing ideas from games such as Sid Mier's Pirates! and others. Graphically styled like Galaxy on Fire and Torchlight, it's a pretty game that runs smoothly other than when using the warp gate (no big issue really, they're used infrequently). Controls work nicely with both mouse/KB or controller. The game offers plenty of ship customisation, do you want to be a ship of the line with massive broadsides? Or perhaps a gunboat bristling with turrets? Maybe you want to long-haul goods across the system? Heaps of options for you to try out.My only real negatives so far;1) Not enough music, the music in the game is AMAZING, but the sound track needs to be a little longer I think2) Stop dropping me out of super-cruise etc when near asteroids etc, if I can visually plot a safe way through a field, then let me. :DSeriously though, this game is amazing value for $18, if you like space sim-lite, this is your game, or just want to blow up ships across the galaxy, look no futher.9/10, definately recomend.

When it comes to setting up your strategy, your first perrogative will be to find a setup which works for you. Personally, I ran with Tachyon broadsides for their fast rate of fire, Heatseekers for secondary weapons, and my turret of choice was the Pulse variant for their range & damage per shot, although I do recommend equipping a Korian Viridian laser cannon if you happen to find one. (I managed to find two, one a Mrk 2, the other a Mrk 5 late in the game.)Your second concern will be learning how best to maneuver in a high-tension battle. This is a 2D arena, so you won't have to worry about capital ships hitting you from above or below. But fighters will swarm around you, attempting to knock out your shields so their bigger cousins can finish you off. And by the way, your shields deplete based on which side gets hit, meaning that if you take too many hits to starboard, your starboard hull will be exposed and vulnerable; take too many hits to starboard after that, you're a goner. Oh yeah, I've had a couple of deaths where the shields were still strong on everywhere except where the enemy was currently hitting me en masse.Here's my pro strategy though: when engaged in a pitched battle, move out to the sidelines to draw the fighters away and have your turrets take those out first. After which, you'll want to position yourself so the capital ships will be on only one side at a time. Then throttle down so that you can turn faster as needed. Just keep fire broadsides at them while your turrets provide backup, and when your shields on that side start to lose their charge, turn around so the other side will be facing them and then repeat the procedure.However, there is something I should mention: up until the third star system, your main obstacle is pirates who fire nothing but regular rounds and missiles at you. Once you get to the third system, however, you'll meet the Greel. These guys (both their fighters and their capital ships) feature Leech weapons which fire EMP missiles at you. And these things  not only do a good amount of damage to your shields, but they do a number on your engines as well. So your best bet is to get the EMP Ablation component (what the hell kind of word is that?) so that EMP weapons won't cause quite as much trouble.Nevertheless, a well-upgraded ship can handle just about anything. Just find the style and setup that works best for you and get out there. Just remember if things start to go♥♥♥♥♥♥up, there ain't no shame in making a run for it. All the money in the galaxy won't comfort you if you're dead.As the game itself, it's single player only and can be played offline if you please. Although you won't be able to make progress on achievements without being online, I found out. Also, the musical tracks they used in this game, while good, can get really repetitive; I ended up muting it. And if there's one gameplay feature I'm iffy about, it's that the best lasers in the game (the Korian Viridians) are random drops, no way to purchase them in a spaceport.There's also the issue with communications with the npcs in the game: they're pretty limited. Not to mention that the pirates seem to have trouble realizing when they're outmatched and that surrender would be in their best interest. Like I'll be flying an Arcturus-class Destroyer (which is strongly reminiscent of the Imperial Star Destroyer from Star Wars) armed to the teeth with top-notch weapons and they'll still be talking♥♥♥♥♥♥.. right up until I blow them to smithereens.And speaking of the AI, there's the escort missions. Now, the way it works is that you fly to a location, approach the client, and hold down E to Pair Warp. What that does is that the AI takes full control of your ship, keeping it alongside the ship even as you two go into warp. Noble in itself but it can lead to some annoying results. For one, when two ships are alongside each other, a human would say that the best course of action is to throttle down and turn right to line up with the client; the AI meanwhile turns your ship left, causing your back section to collide with the client's. And why is it that every escort mission has to start in an asteroid field or a ice field? Because just now I had a mission start in an ice field, I was flying a dreadnaught and it took 5-10 minutes just to get started! The AI kept maneuvering us around the ice field, taking me one direction him another. And just when I thought we were getting out of this mess, it had the client move back into the field, prolonging this mess. I had to break warp pairing, and move my ship out of the ice field myself just to get us going.Was I annoyed by all of this? Yeah, I'd say it goes without saying that I was.Then there are the missions where you fly in and save someone from enroaching hostiles. There's a good chance they'll get themselves blown up because they decided to fly into the middle of a pack of hostiles. And as Harrison Ford said in The Last Crusade "Are you crazy?!? Don't go between 'em!!"All in all though, it's a good game, well-worth the asking price. Combat can get a little challenging at times (especially with the Greel I mentioned above) but it's easy to learn & of moderate difficulty to master, just the way I like it. And if all that wasn't enough, the developers also made sure to include a risk analysis for each mission that adjusts based upon anticipated enemy strength against that of your own. And while not all the ship designs are prize-winners, there are some really good ones.So yes, I definitely recommend this game. It's cheap, it's challenging, and it'll last a long time. Hell, there're some triple-A titles that won't last as long as this game will! [cough, cough... Star Wars Battlefront: EA... cough, cough]

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												The brief review:What did I do?It took me 27 hours to complete the storyline, and then I took another 2 hours to get into a dreadnought, just to see what it felt like. I played it to complete it, and not to just fly around and experience the "universe". The story is bland at best, but it serves as a waypoint reference to guide you. I went the way of the mercenary and did fighting missions almost exclusively. This got.. bland after awhile. I found a method of fighting and stuck to it, simply upgrading the same types of weapons from Mk1, Mk2, Mk3 etc... blandWhat didn't I do?trade. Boring.. How was it?I guess it was SORTA worth the time? I mean it feels like fleet combat with broadsides, and certain weapons are more fun than others. If you like grinding reputation, killing pirates and stuff, this is not a bad game. The soundtrack is brilliant, the graphics are nice, and the overall aesthetic is worth your viewing pleasure. But it is NOT an epic space opera. It's the 2d platforming brother of something like Elite. But that just makes it a good place to start if you're not sure if you're going to like that type of game, since this one does away with all the tedious "realistic" parts :)It's a tentative recommendation. Go into this if you want an arcadey space sim with great music.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												After playing several hours of this game I can say without a doubt, Rebel Galaxy is AMAZING. *It's the perfect blend of action packed navel combat with dynamic trade economy. If you thought X was an interesting concept, but though that the gameplay felt like doing spread sheets in a 3D shooting gallery, then look no further, Rebel Galaxy is your game. *The combat is fun and easy to pick up, with its Black Flag style broadside combat, but has alot of depth and strategy aswell. I found that a fast frigate could out do a powerful, lumbering dreadknoght with speed and manuverability, or that using your ship's suppior broadside's range could keep you out of harms way. *The economy is dynamic and interesting but not overly complicated "cough cough X!" and scoping out trade roughts in the games massive, proceduraly generated universe was alot of fun.*The style was another big draw with it's awesome southern rock/blues/country soundtrack and it's wild west, bad-side of town vibe. Not to mention, the ship models are fantastic!*The game also has alot of choice for missions and encounters. Do you help the pirates take down the merchant for a haul of loot, or do you take a stand and protect the merchant to increase your reputation with the citizens?*And finnaly, the devs are great. They're helpful and dedicated and constantly patching the game and listening to the communityIn the end, Rebel Galaxy is a terrific, deep space, swashbuckling adventure sure to keep you flyin' for along time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Love being a space cowboy in Rebel Galaxy, it just feels good to fly around and fight other ships! Graphics are amazing even on my mid-level system, my jaw dropped when I first loaded up the game. My laptop has a hard time running it though.Great pacing, lots of things to do; explore the solar systems, smuggle cargo between space stations, start fights with space pirates and steal their cargo, sell loot and upgrade your weapons...buy a new ship once you've saved up enough.I also like how you can customize your ship to fit different playstyles, there's no wrong answer, combat always feels intense and rewarding. Outfit long range cannons and missles to snipe opponents from afar, for medium range fightfights use blaster turrets and rockets, or cover your ship in lasers to cut ships apart up close! You also get to pick whether you prefer a huge tank-like ship or a sleek corvette, customize your speed and durability based on your play style. There are no levels, the more money you make the better ships and equipment you can afford, so buy trade items low, stock your hold with valuables, and sell to the buyers offering the most at the commodity markets at the space stations.One other thing I love is the music. Not only does it come with great music by default, you can use your own MP3 collection, and it will change songs for Ambient, Combat, Idle, Menu, and Space Station. So I made folders for each music type, copied songs that fit the mood into the folders, and added those folders to the game's music library. So when I'm cruising through space I can enjoy some low key Beck and Radiohead, but when a fight breaks out the game will start blasting Green Day or the Klaxons!Buy it! Don't even hesitate, don't even worry, don't even give it a second thought.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												I've only put a few hours into this game so far, and I'm enjoying it immensely. Broadly, Rebel Galaxy reminds me of a mashup of the Assassin's Creed series, World of Warships, and good old Freelancer. The former because the way that the map and locations work (markers and missions within the system map), the second because of the similar broadside naval combat mechanic (which, given the lack of a traversable Z axis [for simplicity's sake] in the game, works surprisingly well), and the latter because...well, you fly around in space and do whatever you want for a career.Rebel Galaxy is very smooth. Everything looks wonderful, the theme music and some of the game's feel are obvious homages to Firefly and Serenity, but the overall experience is pretty fresh. While the exploration and side mission elements of gameplay can get redundant (see Assassin's Creed), the constantly evolving state of your own ship keep things fairly interesting. The difficulty curve can be a little intense. Like AC, this is forgiven somewhat because the game autosaves every time you leave dock, but there are a number of bloody lessons to be learned early on while you learn how to poke around the galaxy without dying with some frequency.Combat mechanics are very nifty. In addition to hired help and the already highlighted broadside combat system, turrets, auxiliary weapons, and various modules help keep combat pretty fresh and interesting. Plus it all looks very pretty, and blowing up pirate capital ships is viscerally satisfying in a way that Eve never accomplished.Very, very recommendable to fans of any of the above listed titles (disparate though they may seem), as long as you dig things in space. A great, sandboxy capital ship combat game that really WORKS, unlike so many halfhearted efforts.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a thoroughly enjoyable space RPG-style game.  The game page and other reviews do a good job of providing more detail on the gameplay, so I won't waste too much time covering that.  Basically, it's a naval combat game in space (movement is in 2D only).  That being said, this style in no way detracts from the game's value.  You spend your time doing missions, mining, trading, and/or hunting bounties to make money which goes toward upgrading your ship.  There is also a "main campaign" that takes you through a simple yet adequately interesting story.  On the downside, the factions are a bit bland (as is mentioned in several other reviews) and there really doesn't seem to be much replayability (at least I personally have no desire to replay now that I've beaten the game).If you want to pew-pew other spaceships in a beautifully rendered, decent sized "universe" while listening to an admittedly catchy soundtrack (seemingly ranging in influence from CCR to Pearl Jam at times) then this game is worth looking into.  It runs smoothly with no bugs or glitches (for me, anyway).  Ultimately, I found the game experience to be well worth the cost.8.5/10

												Rebel Galaxy is a light hearted space sim, borrowing ideas from games such as Sid Mier's Pirates! and others. Graphically styled like Galaxy on Fire and Torchlight, it's a pretty game that runs smoothly other than when using the warp gate (no big issue really, they're used infrequently). Controls work nicely with both mouse/KB or controller. The game offers plenty of ship customisation, do you want to be a ship of the line with massive broadsides? Or perhaps a gunboat bristling with turrets? Maybe you want to long-haul goods across the system? Heaps of options for you to try out.My only real negatives so far;1) Not enough music, the music in the game is AMAZING, but the sound track needs to be a little longer I think2) Stop dropping me out of super-cruise etc when near asteroids etc, if I can visually plot a safe way through a field, then let me. :DSeriously though, this game is amazing value for $18, if you like space sim-lite, this is your game, or just want to blow up ships across the galaxy, look no futher.9/10, definately recomend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												I never write reviews, and I only do so for games that I think are that much fun, that I need to tell everyone!Rebel Galaxy is a weird thing, it combines "naval" combat with space ships and quite some options to (role) play the game.The combat, is in one word, different. You fly in 2D space, as the rest of the capital ships do, and only the lighter fighters are able to fly everywhere, but you only fly capital ships.If you want someone to explain on how you should tackle the combat in this game, then dont read this, I think you should totally find that out yourself. There are some really powerfull combinations but almost everything works together if you set it up logically.In ways how to play the game, there are different factions. the Citizens are what the name says, these people just want to live and inhabit most of the stations.The Militia are a military 'police' faction, taking down pirates but also stopping illegal trading.The Merchant Guild and Mercenaries Guild are a thing of their own. The Merchants are traders and specialize in getting cargo through the system. You can join them if you want to focus on trading with stations, because the trading and goods system in this game is quite fleshed out!The Mercenaries supply contracts to you if you join them, also giving you access to better equipment, like most factions do in the game when you join them. They work with and against everyone, its up to you what you choose.Then there are quite alot of Pirate and Raider factions, you'll meet the Red Devils and Double Jack's first, and you can join them if you play your missions right and work against their enemies, though all of them start out hostile to you.There is alot more to tell, but you can find it out for yourself. I still havent beat the main story, as i'm to busy working for my chosen faction, which is alot of fun.If you can get this on sale, defenitely get it, otherwise its still a pretty good deal!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22
Product received for free
												Basically, my few complaints with this game are the same as those for Interplanetary: Everything is pretty much restricted to the 2D ecliptic, even the fighter-class craft don't wander very far above or below that, certainly not outside of a good weapon's range. I mean, what if I don't feel like having to fly around three planets just so I don't get kicked out of warp? Why shouldn't we be able to run a few hundred thousand kliks above or below the orbital plane? Also, the time scale is apparently vastly inflated, but none of the orbital objects in any system move in relation to anything else. I understand the necessity of keeping the jumpgates in specific places, but planets should move. The perfectly circular assumed orbits are unrealistic and unnecessary. Lastly, I would love to be able to hail a militia vessel to actively turn over contraband cargo I may have picked up, in exchange for a +1 to Militia relations instead of having them discover it on your ship and attempting to confiscate it for -4 to relations.   That said, the game really is a treat to play. The light effects I thought were especially good, the control scheme is nicely ergonomic, and the space combat is pretty exciting. The campaign missions had a  rather interesting plot, but I went through them in fewer than fifty hours, and I did A LOT of side missions so I had really good equipment. I would really like to see more missions in the story. If you remember Privateer fondly, you might also like Rebel Galaxy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I was on the fence about a 2D space combat game, but having played it it's a fun game.It has some problems, the control system seems to be based around a gamepad so there are a few limitations on the UI that wouldn't otherwise be there. There are also some curious design decisions like being unable to access your cargohold/factions list/tactical menu etc while docked.There is no RPGesque character development, the only limitation on what ship/equipment you can use seems to be money and to a lesser extent faction.The combat in the game is fun. There is a large variety of equipment available to outfit your ship in order to compliment your playstyle. For instance you can gear your ship up for long range sniping, close range, and even fitting special deflector shields in order to cause extra damage ramming into other ships. In general the combat seems very well thought out.On the other hand the trading and mining feel a bit lacklustre. Mining, even with the "perfect" mining setup is haphazard and rarely nets you anywhere near the amount of money combat would in the same amount of time. Trading seems too random in that it's very hard to charge what good will be worth more at any given station. I freely admit though I haven't spent a lot of time trading, so it's very possible that if I invested more time in it I'd understand the system more.I've read complaints about the save system. It's a standard autosave only game, and the autosave only takes place when you dock. This means that if you pick up 3 missions, complete 2 and then die in the 3rd one you'll lose all that progress. However, that's not necessarily a bad thing as you just weigh up the risk and dock if necessary to save.The soundtrack in the game is...interesting. I kind of liked it at first, but it becomes very repetitive after a couple of hours. However, using the launcher you can easily add your own music.In summary this game is definately worth picking up if you enjoy space action games.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Over all I like this game. It is a fun combat focused game. the brodside style is great but can make it a little challenging in the belts with all the rocks you can run into while looking to the side. The voice acting is ok and sounds like your dealing with folk living in the backside of creation, does remind one alittle of Firefly. Though there could be more of it and more variety.  That said the game feels a little flat for an open world style game. Some things are missing that other open world games have, ie the Elder Scrolls series.   Other than the main story line there is nothing to do except the mission boards and get credits for your next upgrade. You can join the guilds but the only reason to is for the gear that only they have. There should be guild specific storylines, as in other open world games, with thier own consequences and rewards (not just creds but uniqe gear as well) to make it worth your time to join.  I enjoy playing this game. But would like to see some DLC's or mod's come out to fix these little flaws. All in all thumbs up.   I have now finished the game and got all achivements. The torpedo's shot down took the longest (killed the little guy's then circled the leviathon just out of gun range in projectile turet mode for ever).   I still like this game but I'm sad it is so short.

Posted: November 18, 2016
												If you liked Freelancer and/or Privateer then Rebel Galaxy will feel very familiar, but be warned: this isn't a massive game. There are only a dozen or so (mostly identical) systems to explore, and the campaign is relatively short and uninspired. The crucial elements are all there  - a trading market with fluctuating demand, factions, ship upgrading, space combat - and are competently done even if they are relatively shallow. I hope the interest generated by RG will convince the devs to create the much larger, much more ambitious game that RG could be if given the time and resources.

Posted: January 23, 2016
												Over all I like this game. It is a fun combat focused game. the brodside style is great but can make it a little challenging in the belts with all the rocks you can run into while looking to the side. The voice acting is ok and sounds like your dealing with folk living in the backside of creation, does remind one alittle of Firefly. Though there could be more of it and more variety.  That said the game feels a little flat for an open world style game. Some things are missing that other open world games have, ie the Elder Scrolls series.   Other than the main story line there is nothing to do except the mission boards and get credits for your next upgrade. You can join the guilds but the only reason to is for the gear that only they have. There should be guild specific storylines, as in other open world games, with thier own consequences and rewards (not just creds but uniqe gear as well) to make it worth your time to join.  I enjoy playing this game. But would like to see some DLC's or mod's come out to fix these little flaws. All in all thumbs up.   I have now finished the game and got all achivements. The torpedo's shot down took the longest (killed the little guy's then circled the leviathon just out of gun range in projectile turet mode for ever).   I still like this game but I'm sad it is so short.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Summary: This is a nice, action-ladden space opera. Decent presentation, virtually bug-free and quite a lot of fun for many hours.Further Info:Think of Starpoint Gemini 2 done right. It has nice (albeit cheesy) music, pretty nebulas and explosions and Laser Beams. Like, a lot of beams. And missiles. There are a lot of spaceships that you can customize with different type of weapons to accomodate your game style. Whether you prefer to attack from afar or get in melee (including ramming), there is the right equipment for you.So if you like to blow up spaceships of all kinds, this is your game. However, if you like a realistic space sim, stay away from it. There is nothing realistic in Rebel Galaxy. Flight physics are very basic and very forgiving. Space in the game is only 2D, at least for you. There are objects and enemy fighters that can fly above or below you, but you cannot. To me, this is a great design choice. But this means that you will not really do any dog fighting. Instead, combat feels like seaships battling with the sea removed. This impression is supported by the fact that ships in Rebel Galaxy have their most powerful weapons mounted at their sides and not the front.And by the way. While you can mine in this game and trade, you will likely spend most of your time blowing up spaceships. Mainly because mining and trading is very rougly implemented. I guess, if you make a space opera, you have to allow people to mine and trade. Because people expect it to be there. Even if it is boring as♥♥♥♥♥♥There are a couple of negative points I would like to mention: the loot system is very basic. There are a few weapons you can only get from destroying other ships, but these are very rare and not really special. So upgrading your ship is mainly done through spending credits you earn through missions. And while the ship customization options are fine, I would have preferred still more options. Like putting extra power into weapons by sacrificing shield strength. Or installing an extra tower while giving up a support module. Also, the story is sort of generic. No big surprises there.Still, this is another game that revives the space opera genre, which was believed dead long enough. And if you are actually still expecting Star Citizin to be great, this might be a game that shortens the long wait.8.5/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												I never write reviews, and I only do so for games that I think are that much fun, that I need to tell everyone!Rebel Galaxy is a weird thing, it combines "naval" combat with space ships and quite some options to (role) play the game.The combat, is in one word, different. You fly in 2D space, as the rest of the capital ships do, and only the lighter fighters are able to fly everywhere, but you only fly capital ships.If you want someone to explain on how you should tackle the combat in this game, then dont read this, I think you should totally find that out yourself. There are some really powerfull combinations but almost everything works together if you set it up logically.In ways how to play the game, there are different factions. the Citizens are what the name says, these people just want to live and inhabit most of the stations.The Militia are a military 'police' faction, taking down pirates but also stopping illegal trading.The Merchant Guild and Mercenaries Guild are a thing of their own. The Merchants are traders and specialize in getting cargo through the system. You can join them if you want to focus on trading with stations, because the trading and goods system in this game is quite fleshed out!The Mercenaries supply contracts to you if you join them, also giving you access to better equipment, like most factions do in the game when you join them. They work with and against everyone, its up to you what you choose.Then there are quite alot of Pirate and Raider factions, you'll meet the Red Devils and Double Jack's first, and you can join them if you play your missions right and work against their enemies, though all of them start out hostile to you.There is alot more to tell, but you can find it out for yourself. I still havent beat the main story, as i'm to busy working for my chosen faction, which is alot of fun.If you can get this on sale, defenitely get it, otherwise its still a pretty good deal!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												I've only put a few hours into this game so far, and I'm enjoying it immensely. Broadly, Rebel Galaxy reminds me of a mashup of the Assassin's Creed series, World of Warships, and good old Freelancer. The former because the way that the map and locations work (markers and missions within the system map), the second because of the similar broadside naval combat mechanic (which, given the lack of a traversable Z axis [for simplicity's sake] in the game, works surprisingly well), and the latter because...well, you fly around in space and do whatever you want for a career.Rebel Galaxy is very smooth. Everything looks wonderful, the theme music and some of the game's feel are obvious homages to Firefly and Serenity, but the overall experience is pretty fresh. While the exploration and side mission elements of gameplay can get redundant (see Assassin's Creed), the constantly evolving state of your own ship keep things fairly interesting. The difficulty curve can be a little intense. Like AC, this is forgiven somewhat because the game autosaves every time you leave dock, but there are a number of bloody lessons to be learned early on while you learn how to poke around the galaxy without dying with some frequency.Combat mechanics are very nifty. In addition to hired help and the already highlighted broadside combat system, turrets, auxiliary weapons, and various modules help keep combat pretty fresh and interesting. Plus it all looks very pretty, and blowing up pirate capital ships is viscerally satisfying in a way that Eve never accomplished.Very, very recommendable to fans of any of the above listed titles (disparate though they may seem), as long as you dig things in space. A great, sandboxy capital ship combat game that really WORKS, unlike so many halfhearted efforts.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												The brief review:What did I do?It took me 27 hours to complete the storyline, and then I took another 2 hours to get into a dreadnought, just to see what it felt like. I played it to complete it, and not to just fly around and experience the "universe". The story is bland at best, but it serves as a waypoint reference to guide you. I went the way of the mercenary and did fighting missions almost exclusively. This got.. bland after awhile. I found a method of fighting and stuck to it, simply upgrading the same types of weapons from Mk1, Mk2, Mk3 etc... blandWhat didn't I do?trade. Boring.. How was it?I guess it was SORTA worth the time? I mean it feels like fleet combat with broadsides, and certain weapons are more fun than others. If you like grinding reputation, killing pirates and stuff, this is not a bad game. The soundtrack is brilliant, the graphics are nice, and the overall aesthetic is worth your viewing pleasure. But it is NOT an epic space opera. It's the 2d platforming brother of something like Elite. But that just makes it a good place to start if you're not sure if you're going to like that type of game, since this one does away with all the tedious "realistic" parts :)It's a tentative recommendation. Go into this if you want an arcadey space sim with great music.

Posted: October 26, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy is a light hearted space sim, borrowing ideas from games such as Sid Mier's Pirates! and others. Graphically styled like Galaxy on Fire and Torchlight, it's a pretty game that runs smoothly other than when using the warp gate (no big issue really, they're used infrequently). Controls work nicely with both mouse/KB or controller. The game offers plenty of ship customisation, do you want to be a ship of the line with massive broadsides? Or perhaps a gunboat bristling with turrets? Maybe you want to long-haul goods across the system? Heaps of options for you to try out.My only real negatives so far;1) Not enough music, the music in the game is AMAZING, but the sound track needs to be a little longer I think2) Stop dropping me out of super-cruise etc when near asteroids etc, if I can visually plot a safe way through a field, then let me. :DSeriously though, this game is amazing value for $18, if you like space sim-lite, this is your game, or just want to blow up ships across the galaxy, look no futher.9/10, definately recomend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Well, just finished my first game of this, so I figured it was time for a review. So, where to start?Well, I'll start basic. This game is basically what it looks like: a space trucker sim with combat that is similar to the ship-to-ship combat in Assassins Creed: Black Flag, with the primary weapons being broadside cannons and turrets. If you've heard that this game starts out kinda crappy, you heard right. The starting ship (a Hammerhead called the "Rasputin") is exactly what the intro cinematic says it is: a near-derelict ship with lousy hull & shielding, and the cannons are more akin to pop guns than actual weapons.But that's the whole point, isn't it? You build yourself up by killing baddies, taking quests, maybe mining some, although I personally avoided mining as much as I could in this game. (Too boring.) The idea is to earn enough cash so you can spend it on upgrading your ship's weapons, shields and armor to the point that enemies that once gave you a mountain of trouble will now regret ever♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off... right before their ships explode and you suck up whatever cargo they dropped.[As an extra note, some games may think it's cool to have increased prices for purchases, lowered prices for sales. Not this one! Here, if you purchase a turret for 5,000 credits and then decide to sell it later (possibly because you'd just picked up a better version), you'll still receive 5,000 credits back. Same goes for hull, shield, and engine upgrades.]And of course you'll want to swap out your starting ship for a better one as quickly as possible. One with more turret slots, more broadside cannons, more cargo space, and a better hull. You'll also want to purchase some special components for your ship, like Heat Management which reduces the amount of heat your turrets generate when firing, allowing them to fire more often.Which brings me to weapon setups. When it comes to setting up your strategy, your first perrogative will be to find a setup which works for you. Personally, I ran with Tachyon broadsides for their fast rate of fire, Heatseekers for secondary weapons, and my turret of choice was the Pulse variant for their range & damage per shot, although I do recommend equipping a Korian Viridian laser cannon if you happen to find one. (I managed to find two, one a Mrk 2, the other a Mrk 5 late in the game.)Your second concern will be learning how best to maneuver in a high-tension battle. This is a 2D arena, so you won't have to worry about capital ships hitting you from above or below. But fighters will swarm around you, attempting to knock out your shields so their bigger cousins can finish you off. And by the way, your shields deplete based on which side gets hit, meaning that if you take too many hits to starboard, your starboard hull will be exposed and vulnerable; take too many hits to starboard after that, you're a goner. Oh yeah, I've had a couple of deaths where the shields were still strong on everywhere except where the enemy was currently hitting me en masse.Here's my pro strategy though: when engaged in a pitched battle, move out to the sidelines to draw the fighters away and have your turrets take those out first. After which, you'll want to position yourself so the capital ships will be on only one side at a time. Then throttle down so that you can turn faster as needed. Just keep fire broadsides at them while your turrets provide backup, and when your shields on that side start to lose their charge, turn around so the other side will be facing them and then repeat the procedure.However, there is something I should mention: up until the third star system, your main obstacle is pirates who fire nothing but regular rounds and missiles at you. Once you get to the third system, however, you'll meet the Greel. These guys (both their fighters and their capital ships) feature Leech weapons which fire EMP missiles at you. And these things  not only do a good amount of damage to your shields, but they do a number on your engines as well. So your best bet is to get the EMP Ablation component (what the hell kind of word is that?) so that EMP weapons won't cause quite as much trouble.Nevertheless, a well-upgraded ship can handle just about anything. Just find the style and setup that works best for you and get out there. Just remember if things start to go♥♥♥♥♥♥up, there ain't no shame in making a run for it. All the money in the galaxy won't comfort you if you're dead.As the game itself, it's single player only and can be played offline if you please. Although you won't be able to make progress on achievements without being online, I found out. Also, the musical tracks they used in this game, while good, can get really repetitive; I ended up muting it. And if there's one gameplay feature I'm iffy about, it's that the best lasers in the game (the Korian Viridians) are random drops, no way to purchase them in a spaceport.There's also the issue with communications with the npcs in the game: they're pretty limited. Not to mention that the pirates seem to have trouble realizing when they're outmatched and that surrender would be in their best interest. Like I'll be flying an Arcturus-class Destroyer (which is strongly reminiscent of the Imperial Star Destroyer from Star Wars) armed to the teeth with top-notch weapons and they'll still be talking♥♥♥♥♥♥.. right up until I blow them to smithereens.And speaking of the AI, there's the escort missions. Now, the way it works is that you fly to a location, approach the client, and hold down E to Pair Warp. What that does is that the AI takes full control of your ship, keeping it alongside the ship even as you two go into warp. Noble in itself but it can lead to some annoying results. For one, when two ships are alongside each other, a human would say that the best course of action is to throttle down and turn right to line up with the client; the AI meanwhile turns your ship left, causing your back section to collide with the client's. And why is it that every escort mission has to start in an asteroid field or a ice field? Because just now I had a mission start in an ice field, I was flying a dreadnaught and it took 5-10 minutes just to get started! The AI kept maneuvering us around the ice field, taking me one direction him another. And just when I thought we were getting out of this mess, it had the client move back into the field, prolonging this mess. I had to break warp pairing, and move my ship out of the ice field myself just to get us going.Was I annoyed by all of this? Yeah, I'd say it goes without saying that I was.Then there are the missions where you fly in and save someone from enroaching hostiles. There's a good chance they'll get themselves blown up because they decided to fly into the middle of a pack of hostiles. And as Harrison Ford said in The Last Crusade "Are you crazy?!? Don't go between 'em!!"All in all though, it's a good game, well-worth the asking price. Combat can get a little challenging at times (especially with the Greel I mentioned above) but it's easy to learn & of moderate difficulty to master, just the way I like it. And if all that wasn't enough, the developers also made sure to include a risk analysis for each mission that adjusts based upon anticipated enemy strength against that of your own. And while not all the ship designs are prize-winners, there are some really good ones.So yes, I definitely recommend this game. It's cheap, it's challenging, and it'll last a long time. Hell, there're some triple-A titles that won't last as long as this game will! [cough, cough... Star Wars Battlefront: EA... cough, cough]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Love being a space cowboy in Rebel Galaxy, it just feels good to fly around and fight other ships! Graphics are amazing even on my mid-level system, my jaw dropped when I first loaded up the game. My laptop has a hard time running it though.Great pacing, lots of things to do; explore the solar systems, smuggle cargo between space stations, start fights with space pirates and steal their cargo, sell loot and upgrade your weapons...buy a new ship once you've saved up enough.I also like how you can customize your ship to fit different playstyles, there's no wrong answer, combat always feels intense and rewarding. Outfit long range cannons and missles to snipe opponents from afar, for medium range fightfights use blaster turrets and rockets, or cover your ship in lasers to cut ships apart up close! You also get to pick whether you prefer a huge tank-like ship or a sleek corvette, customize your speed and durability based on your play style. There are no levels, the more money you make the better ships and equipment you can afford, so buy trade items low, stock your hold with valuables, and sell to the buyers offering the most at the commodity markets at the space stations.One other thing I love is the music. Not only does it come with great music by default, you can use your own MP3 collection, and it will change songs for Ambient, Combat, Idle, Menu, and Space Station. So I made folders for each music type, copied songs that fit the mood into the folders, and added those folders to the game's music library. So when I'm cruising through space I can enjoy some low key Beck and Radiohead, but when a fight breaks out the game will start blasting Green Day or the Klaxons!Buy it! Don't even hesitate, don't even worry, don't even give it a second thought.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a thoroughly enjoyable space RPG-style game.  The game page and other reviews do a good job of providing more detail on the gameplay, so I won't waste too much time covering that.  Basically, it's a naval combat game in space (movement is in 2D only).  That being said, this style in no way detracts from the game's value.  You spend your time doing missions, mining, trading, and/or hunting bounties to make money which goes toward upgrading your ship.  There is also a "main campaign" that takes you through a simple yet adequately interesting story.  On the downside, the factions are a bit bland (as is mentioned in several other reviews) and there really doesn't seem to be much replayability (at least I personally have no desire to replay now that I've beaten the game).If you want to pew-pew other spaceships in a beautifully rendered, decent sized "universe" while listening to an admittedly catchy soundtrack (seemingly ranging in influence from CCR to Pearl Jam at times) then this game is worth looking into.  It runs smoothly with no bugs or glitches (for me, anyway).  Ultimately, I found the game experience to be well worth the cost.8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												If you liked Freelancer and/or Privateer then Rebel Galaxy will feel very familiar, but be warned: this isn't a massive game. There are only a dozen or so (mostly identical) systems to explore, and the campaign is relatively short and uninspired. The crucial elements are all there  - a trading market with fluctuating demand, factions, ship upgrading, space combat - and are competently done even if they are relatively shallow. I hope the interest generated by RG will convince the devs to create the much larger, much more ambitious game that RG could be if given the time and resources.

												If you like space trader style games then get this.Pros-Amazing Delta blues sound track. -The combat is well done.-The market is active and even responsive to events(I've seen a lot space trader style games mess this up)-Good core story that gives you a good intro then let's you wander around.Cons-I haven't found a difficulty slider, I feel a little overpowered in combat.-Ui is a bit of a console port shoehorn.-Kind of shy's away from detail in the UI; eg markets it gives you the info but doesn't let you page through it you have to wait for it to scroll by, no actual speed numbers just feel, menu layout is a bit cludgy. -Camera feels a bit off while aiming broadsides.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												It's not awfully deep, the story and dialogue is flat, you'll have to decide between better ship and better guns, better guns and better engines, better engines and better shields. You'll never feel like mining is worth the time, you'll feel like merchant jobs are all about punishing you for taking merchant jobs, you'll take one escort job before you decide you should NEVER do escort jobs. There are many things about this game you'll wish were better, you'll wish they were better because even though they aren't, you're having a really really really hard time stopping yourself from playing. So much is just good enough in this game to keep you glued start to finish. You will get your $20 worth and more out of this game and you will write a laundry list of suggestions for RG 2 because you really want RG 2 and you will weep because there never will be an RG 2 because 6 of your friends *want* but have not *bought* Rebel Galaxy. BUY REBEL GALAXY. DO IT NOW. IT'S WORTH IT. HONEST!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												If you were ever a fan of the Escape Velocity franchise you'll fall in love with this game. While it is missing some key elements from games like Escape Velocity such as being able to board and capture vessels to build a small fleet of escort ships it definitely fits the classic bill of running missions out of seedy bars on backwater stations and running those luxery goods from place to place to rake in the dough hand over fist.Soundtrack is heavily influenced by the dark and outlaw country genres of music, predominately by guitarist Blues Saraceno and acts such as The Blue News whichs adds a very heavy credit to it being a premier Space Western. Spend more than five minutes in the game and you'll be wishing you were raiding Space Trains belonging to Space Yankees who sacked the Space South after Sherman's Jump through the Orion Spur.Graphicly it is a decently impressive game that doesn't really fail to impress when it concerns ship, station or other object design and detail... also love burning up in atmospheres of planetary bodies, so gotta watch that hahah... seriously don't fly too close or you'll melt yourself six ways from STS-107.Overall if you want to jump into something that'll suck you in for a couple dozen hours its well worth the purchase for the sound track alone, which you can stand alone play from the game's data files (if you have anything that converts .ogg format)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												WOW for a $1.49 on sale this game was well worth the price i paid.Honestly I would of paid full price after playing this game for over 30 hours and I am no where near done yet.The number of turret and broad side weapons is staggering. If your willing to huntdown Pirates and Alien groups to see diffrent wepons or Join Diffrent faction to get them its very rewarding. This game lets you be a complete @$$ if you want to be.Want to go and slaughter Milita and Civilians? Go Ahead.Need to be the hero and save everyone? Feel free.Money your motovation? Become a Trader or Mercenary.Or you can Kill everyone and make EVERY faction mad at you.The quests in game or "missions" all pretty much involve some sort of combat even if it is nothing more than you survive long enuff to run away.Combat is the bread and butter of the game with diffrent firing arcs for every ship. Armor, Sheilds, Deflectors, Special comps, Engines, Jumpdrives, there are alot of items in game to modify and change to your liking.I dont want to go into to much detail as exploring and finding out what you like is a big part of the game as well as finding your own play style.With all that being said the one gripe I have is the "Risk" lv of each mission can be VERY misleading. I can say Low or very low risk and out of nowhere 4 Dreadnaughts that outgun you so bad that if they look at you youed die can appear.Good Luck.

content:
Posted: April 16
												This is a pretty mellow recommendation. It's a pleasant game for wandering around being the most brutally murderous good samaritan, but doesn't really have much in the way of great exciting moments. The combat is pretty unique, but lacks skillshots or headshot-analogues. The economy (with the mark 1-6 versions of items) is set up such that you can throw down a huge number of credits on upgrading your ship to feel pretty much the same as it did before.It's mostly an improvement on Freelancer though I think, with more nuanced combat, a more lively world, and less time spent docking with trade lanes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												You got problems captain.You just came out of warp. Your screen fills with red icons as criscrossing missile trails and cannon fill your vision. Seems this station is under attack by a rather nasty group of pirates. You can see your turrets taking aim and firing as you aim for the station itself. The system militia seems to be doing well, but the pirates just got reinforcements. Torpedo bombers and enemy frigates are starting to get real close. Too close for your liking. You activate your flak cannons and watch the fighters pull away from you. Unleashing a broadside into a passing enemy frigate, you idly wonder if maybe you should just take that mining laser off of your rear turret. Maybe get another tachyon turret? Your ship shakes violently as a mine slams into your hull, and with growing concern you hear your ship calmly relay the fact that your engines are slowing down. Hitting your deflectors you absorb a few torpedo hits as your shields try their best to recharge with the brief respite you have given them.Best shields in the sytem you had thought to yourself as you happily pressed the buy button after trading all that juicy ore you mined. This situation probably wouldn't have been a big deal, if you hadn't of been ambushed on the way here. Apparently when the mission board said 'deadly ore delivery' they had meant it. That fight with two massive heavy frigates had ripped most of the armor off of your hull. Then your hull had been beaten something fierce. Emerging from that fight with a mere 20% hull integrity had been rough.That was before the distress call. Sure, you could have ignored it, after all in your experience sometimes it was a trap. Yet sometimes it was a trader in need of help. You had come out of warp with all of your weapons singing. The friendly trader barely expressed his grattitude before handing over a handful of credits and jumping to warp. Sure, you could have ignored them and kept on trucking, but that aint you, is it outlaw? Frontier folks gotta stick together.You sigh as you realize you just fired on a militia ship. It was gonna be a while before you could build that rep up. Luckily, the station was in full view, and you hit your boosters and your deflectors to make up the remaining distance.As you dock, you smile as 31,900c goes into your account, and the repair costs of your ship are covered by those alien artifacts you scooped up coming in.You have heard rumors of other galaxies. Starpoint Gemini 2, X3 Terran Conflict, Evochron Mercenary, Freelancer, but word in the space bars is that all of those where missing something. As you replace your flak cannon arrays with EMP grids, you can't help but smile once more.Yeah, you got problems captain, but that's the way you like it.

Posted: October 22, 2015
												I really enjoy playing this game. I loved watching the streams on YouTube before release. I was having a hard time waiting for the release date thou to tell you the truth. Watching an awesome game is great but playing the game yourself is even better. I will have hundreds of hours on this game. I just know it. Be friends with the Militia, a pirate, or anything in between. You can also do your best to remain neutral so you can go everywhere. There is no set path you must follow to finish the game. You can abandon the storyline or play after you finished it, it's your game. Have fun everyone and enjoy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												English is not my primary language, so please, be patient :)Man, I'm not one to write reviews, but hell, this game is FUN !It was a very welcome surprise for me. I've played elite dangerous and other space games around, but nothing as fun as this one. The game awsome, good graphics, fast combat (even inside a capital ship, belive me), great learning curve, easy to play, not a insane number of commands, keyboard/mouse or joystick, great music, you really get the feeling of a space cowboy and pause: Yes PAUSE ! hit esc and everything stops ! You can get a soda, got take a leak, eat some pizza and the game will wait for you ! Want to snan some ships for cargo ? No problem, hit TAB and the game stops letting you scan ships without worring abou hitting something. The progression is also good, the game will give you bether missions based on the configuration of your ship. Bether ships, bether credits for your time. The side missions may seen repetitive, but, as long I'm blasting stuff up, I don't care, ehe. The game has many ships to fly, and even more as NPCs. Also, a good amount of gear for your ship. Main gus, sub guns, turrets, engines, warp drives are just some to name. HINT: A good defence IS A GOOD DEFENCE ! Don't neglect shields, or you will find yourself blowing up more than you like.Final words. Game is solid, for the price, it's a bargain. 8/10 If you're looking for a fun game to pass time, without the big worries of other space sims, go ahead, you will not regret it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Okay, so as I write this I am currently only at eleven hours of playtime, not a whole lot really. And in the grand scheme of things? I've barely scratched the surface of this game. You're dumped into a solar system, with a few planets and maybe ten-ish? stations to visit and get some random missions from. Cool, great, awesome. Did I mention this is only one solar system out of a galaxy? Sure it's in space, the game isn't really going to be absolutely teeming with life or a huge population, but whenever you find a landmark there's usually some miners, pirates, the Militia, or some traders that are around, and it's up to you how to interpret who is friend, who is foe, and who is prey.Can you be a pirate in this? Absolutely. Can you trade and smuggle illegal materials from different stations? Of course, just be careful of Militia patrols - they're in bigger, and meaner ships than you are to start out with, and they tend to shoot first and ask questions later if you're on the wrong side of the law. And of course you can also play the role of a bounty hunter, chasing after Pirate heads to fuel your bank account and taking up odd jobs to buy a few new guns along the way.You can also be a trader, taking supplies from one station, then going and selling them at another station to make a huge profit. There's a news-feed option in there to let you know what the latest prices are for each station, if you're patient enough. Just look out for the pirates. Or, if you're a wuss, you can just be a miner and shred through astroids with mining lasers, selling the metal ore for profit, and running the hell away from the Pirates who like your cargo, but don't like the work.As far as the combat goes, there's nothing really all that complex about it. You've got Broadside weapons, Turrets, and Secondaries. Broadsides are pretty self explanitory - they're guns mounted in the port and starboard sides of your ship (Left and Right) that are your main ship-killing weapons. What's neat is you can just spray-and-pray with them if you want, or you can charge them up, take aim, and have a well-timed barrage that leads your target so it lands right into their hull. Although if you're point blank, sometimes the spray-and-pray is better for use as a DPS race.Then you have turrets. You can have some pretty simple stuff... missile turrets, laser turrets, beam weaponry, and even some flak guns to take down those pesky fighters and bombers swarming around your poopdeck.And lastly there's Secondaries. Secondaries are essentially up to you, and effect certain places where your craft will be effective. You can put... bigger flak guns, you can put mine launchers, dumb-fire missile launchers, heat-seeker missile launchers, and so on. As far as the story goes? I haven't really gotten that far into it yet, but from what I can tell it's super simple and not really anything that you're gonna get lost on. Find some alien-tech doohickey and then go on an adventure to find out what the heck it is and what it does.Bottom line is this: If you like Starpoint Gemini, but thought the combat and world was exceptionally boring (like I found it to be...)? You'll like this. If you like pretending you're piloting Serenity or the Outlaw Star, you'll like this.You can't take the sky from me.
