content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												OK, So I know I dont have a whole lot of time in this game but my favorite genre of games is space flight/simulators. As far as a single player space simulator this is by far my favorite. You are not limited to just fighting all the time you can MINE and TRADE as well!!!! So if you feel like taking a break from all of the Multiplayer space games (Eve online, Star Citizen, Elite Dangerous, ect.....) this is the game for you. This game is a simplified, single player version of Elite Dangerous. Also the graphics for such a small game are quite AMAZING!!!! They show hull damage significantly better than most space games out right now. So in short great game probably gonna put in an easy 100 hours into it. Wish I could give it more thumbs up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Call me utterly surprised. This game came out of no where from me, and if not for a reccomendation from someone I trust I would have never even heard of it. This is a game by a series of devs that know their stuff. The controls are very slick and accessible, the ship piloting is fantastic, and it's the kind of thing that could have had a waffly, generic scifi electronica or trumpet track and instead has some of the most radical rock/country (yes, I am advocating something that is at least in part country, but I mean listen to the trailer people) I've ever heard backing it pretty solidly. That tangles with the interesting strategies for space battles, the system for navigating faction trust and how you can play out numerous missions without even touching the main story. This is an excellent example of emergent gameplay and, while the story to me is really just so much background noise, even the little things characters do and say add to the setting's charm. This is AAA+ to me, amazing and simply made me a fan of this dev in whatever they do.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												This is my review, the game is great, love it quite abit. Being a Former EVE Online player, and multitude of other games I got in my own collection, The controls for this is very simple... for I will admit, I am no pilot! I am the only person in the world whom can crash an aircraft on takeoff!But the controls are easy, and I love it.Okay so here are the pros that I can safely say: for one, 19 bucks for the game is a bargin compared to other games, such as Elite: Dangerious (I tried it, cant fly), I like the trade system in the game, cause lets face it... repairs can suck at times, and drains the living hell out of your coffers. It doesnt hurt to dabble in it afterall, suppliment your income to ensure your vessle is in combat shape? why not right?Another is the combat system, The turrets, the Turrets! Oh how wonderful it is to be able to set the turrets how you wish. Leaving you to focus on defence, Sub Weapon systems (EMP Flak for the win), and the broadsides! while the turrets can rip the little fighters apart (they suck at times). the Manuvering is very smooth if your comfortable with the standard Keymotions from MMOs, you know the ASDW.Okay, time for the Nitpicking;the Cons;Ship content; I was told by a Dev (Thank you by the way) They will adjust ships to better suit how each is to stack up, so no one size fits all vessle... But still, we could use more ship types. even have Fighter Crafts of our own, even Bombers (For you batshit crazy aces out there, you know who you are), And maybe JUST Maybe, look into adding Multiplayer content, like conversion option for Single or Online version. Some people wanna rub other peoples faces into their afterburners afterall, and some are lone wolves in a sense.Mercinaries: Well not really judging, but would be nice if there was more of them to choose from, its like... each part of the space you go to, its sometimes the same pilot sitting at the bar (Stalker much?), So be kinda nice to have to hunt down your fav merc, and make them worthwhile to hang onto (rather than rehire them later in the game just to keep up with the enemies in the area)Factions: Needs a hint more love, maybe more factions?, and of course adding stuff for the factions to do (stuff that can affect each galaxy?) So Devs if your reading this and not vomiting from my pretty sad review. Take a moment from giving yourselves a far well deserved pat on the back, and look into Factions. Then Add and Fluff (and polish them out), it would give you ALOT more stuff to do, and would (hopefully) get alot more people to buy itSo all and all in a Nutshell (if your still sane after reading this, grats, if not... I heard the Jello in the institutes is nice),The Game is great with next to no complaints, great soundtrack (be better if you can change the channel at times), Good content, and player control. I highly recommend getting this game...Oh by the by, for you new players out there... hire a merc, they are a real help!-----Spoiler alert!-----THE CAKE IS A LIE!!

Cowboy Bebop EditionI have been waiting for this game since I stopped playing FreelancerAt the time of this review I have 14.7 hrs and I have only just made it into the second sectorPros Large sectors with the freedom and range to do whatever you choose (mining, trading, pirate, mercenary) Multiple ships and upgrades, further diversified by guild specific upgrades Universe feels alive, randomly intercepting a pirate attack or being ambushed Interesting combat (naval style), broadside attacks being the main weapon usedCons Gets a bit grindy at times in order to progress, although it's realistic and makes you appreciate your ship as you upgrade it 2D plane playstyle, so no nifty barrel rolls to evade attacks Story isn't amazing  Buying and selling is weird, assuming because gui is made for both keyboard and controller Auto stop on cruise control, sometimes good, most of the time tediousRecommendations Fleet building, I get it's a primarily lone ranger feel but I would love to build an AI fleet to really wreck havoc Being able to have multiple gui windows, again I know it's made for conrollers but I'd like to have that space captain feel, being able to monitor my cargo bay, knowing what's contraband or not. Monitoring a locked on enemy whether or not it's in view.  Damaging ships like ftl, I wish I could exstensively damage an enemy thrusters or target their missile launchers with my turret to temporarily disable them, nothing major just would make fights a bit more interesting and not just bigger guns and better ship wins Overall though it's a great game especially for $20, if you love sci-fi and want that star trek style  battle where you both slowly move hitting each other balancing your power usage between thrusters, shields and weapons then definitely buy this game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Okay, so as I write this I am currently only at eleven hours of playtime, not a whole lot really. And in the grand scheme of things? I've barely scratched the surface of this game. You're dumped into a solar system, with a few planets and maybe ten-ish? stations to visit and get some random missions from. Cool, great, awesome. Did I mention this is only one solar system out of a galaxy? Sure it's in space, the game isn't really going to be absolutely teeming with life or a huge population, but whenever you find a landmark there's usually some miners, pirates, the Militia, or some traders that are around, and it's up to you how to interpret who is friend, who is foe, and who is prey.Can you be a pirate in this? Absolutely. Can you trade and smuggle illegal materials from different stations? Of course, just be careful of Militia patrols - they're in bigger, and meaner ships than you are to start out with, and they tend to shoot first and ask questions later if you're on the wrong side of the law. And of course you can also play the role of a bounty hunter, chasing after Pirate heads to fuel your bank account and taking up odd jobs to buy a few new guns along the way.You can also be a trader, taking supplies from one station, then going and selling them at another station to make a huge profit. There's a news-feed option in there to let you know what the latest prices are for each station, if you're patient enough. Just look out for the pirates. Or, if you're a wuss, you can just be a miner and shred through astroids with mining lasers, selling the metal ore for profit, and running the hell away from the Pirates who like your cargo, but don't like the work.As far as the combat goes, there's nothing really all that complex about it. You've got Broadside weapons, Turrets, and Secondaries. Broadsides are pretty self explanitory - they're guns mounted in the port and starboard sides of your ship (Left and Right) that are your main ship-killing weapons. What's neat is you can just spray-and-pray with them if you want, or you can charge them up, take aim, and have a well-timed barrage that leads your target so it lands right into their hull. Although if you're point blank, sometimes the spray-and-pray is better for use as a DPS race.Then you have turrets. You can have some pretty simple stuff... missile turrets, laser turrets, beam weaponry, and even some flak guns to take down those pesky fighters and bombers swarming around your poopdeck.And lastly there's Secondaries. Secondaries are essentially up to you, and effect certain places where your craft will be effective. You can put... bigger flak guns, you can put mine launchers, dumb-fire missile launchers, heat-seeker missile launchers, and so on. As far as the story goes? I haven't really gotten that far into it yet, but from what I can tell it's super simple and not really anything that you're gonna get lost on. Find some alien-tech doohickey and then go on an adventure to find out what the heck it is and what it does.Bottom line is this: If you like Starpoint Gemini, but thought the combat and world was exceptionally boring (like I found it to be...)? You'll like this. If you like pretending you're piloting Serenity or the Outlaw Star, you'll like this.You can't take the sky from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												 Rebel Galaxy is the first “space sim” I've ever played to completion. I've tried getting into a few others (Elite: Dangerous and Dark Star One come to mind), but after the initially overwhelming but ultimately satisfying learning curve of those games had been conquered I got bored and dropped off once they devolved into tedious job simulators. Rebel Galaxy includes all of the main features of those more complex games, but streamlines them into something more digestible. It takes a hit on it's sense of “realism” and scale, but it's engaging and simplified loop of progress is enough to make up for that.  Did you know space is actually a flat plane? It's a silly concept and not really a complaint, I know, but Rebel Galaxy's one dimensional representation of open space is a good example of what you're in for. You never have to worry about vertical thrust or rolling your ship, just 360 degrees of activity. This feels like literal, ocean-based ship-to-ship combat and navigation with a space backdrop. And it works if you're willing to accept it. What you're losing in freedom you're gaining in ease of use. Most extraneous, technical fiddlings are stripped out: just point your ship where you want to go and hit the warp drive. Hold “A” to dock. There are four speeds to pick from, but just go full throttle and if you want to slow down or stop hold back on the left stick. You know it's a casual sim when the game's launcher recommends you use a gamepad. Again, none of this is inherently bad, it just is what it is. It's an arcade representation of a notoriously complicated genre.  Also unconventional is the personal story that is the driving force of the game. You inherit a ship from your aunt that contains some fragment of something or other that a number of local scumbags seem interested in acquiring. It's pretty clear that there's more to the fragment than meets the eye, and sure enough it soon awakens as an AI. The AI, Trell, directs you to other fragments scattered around increasingly dangerous sectors of the galaxy, which she uses to upgrade your ship to make it feasible to travel to even more dangerous parts of space. She also warns you that there are bad space guys after her, and if they get her it's bad news for everybody. This is all told through really nice looking close up conversations with Cortana's cousin Trell and other characters you meet in seedy space bars. You have some options for responses, but they're pretty limited and don't seem to matter too much. While the story starts off strong and shows promise, it ends up falling apart and fizzling out toward the end. It's the most disappointing aspect of Rebel Galaxy; it had the potential to be a grimy, emotional space opera but doesn't know how to progress or wrap up. It ends so abruptly I actually had to back out of the game and check my achievements to make sure the story was actually over. It was...  While it's a shame the fantastic but rather shallow characters are underutilized, the story is just a jumping off point for the familiar loop of space truckin'. Earn money by any means to upgrade your ship to make it easier to earn even more money in order to buy even better ships to make more money faster. It's a grind at it's core, but the ships look cool and the job simulator repetition is painless enough. You pick missions up from job boards at any space station. These range from delivering cargo to other stations, hunting (space) pirates with bounties on their head, picking up data at dead drops, etc. The higher the difficulty the more money you receive. You could also buy and sell goods for profit, but I didn't find the investment worth it if you're not nuts; you regularly pick up salable cargo from defeated enemies that you can exchange for pure profit so don't bother. You'll also run into distress signals in your travels where you can assist for some easy cash, or take out random bounties. Basically: play the game to earn money.  Almost any path you take will involve combat. Thankfully, like the rest of the game, getting into scraps is simple and enjoyable. You maneuver your ship as you would in naval warfare, with your main means of attack being your broadside cannons. The longer you wait to fire the more focused and accurate your shots become, so you can pinpoint a distant enemy for devastating damage or spam a barrage of wild shots to keep a ship's shields down or harass smaller swarms closer to you. You're also outfitted with a secondary weapon you can use with the “X” button. I went with flak cannons to destroy incoming missiles and smaller vessels, but you have options like homing missiles as well (which you need to buy ordinance for). Depending on how large of a ship you're piloting you can equip a number of turrets like shield destroying missiles, long range lasers, or mining lasers. You can control these manually, but I found the simpler my approach to combat the better the results. After experimenting with using the secondary lasers to take out smaller ships and targeting individual modules on capital ships, it took me an embarrassingly long time to realize I was overplaying the game. Just focus on your broadsides, spam your secondaries, and let the auto turrets do their work and you're playing optimally.  Rebel Galaxy offers a custom soundtrack option, and it's a small feature that goes a long way. The included soundtrack is decent, twangy Space Western tunes that sell the premise, and the ability to add your own songs is invaluable. You have several pathways to store the music, so you can divide your list to play only while at space stations, at the title screen, while traveling, during combat, etc. If you don't have Deep Purple's “Space Truckin'” on there you ♥♥♥♥ed up, but other than that it's great to inject your own mark onto the game and it makes travels through deep space feel like a road trip. This was a standard feature of the Xbox 360 but has sadly dropped off, and having it fully integrated here is fantastic and certainly welcome.  If you're looking for a deep simulation that requires every button on your keyboard for knobs and dials and subsystems Rebel Galaxy might not be the game for you. If you've come to the realization that those games are for crazy people and want to relax to some Johnny Cash as you cause some space wars and marvel at how such visual chaos can be distilled into simple arcade controls, Rebel Galaxy delivers. The promising story ends up being kind of crap and there's a definite grind to endure, but the game has heart and personality and delivers what I value most: fun.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Quick Summary: Rebel Galaxy is an open-universe space combat/exploration/trading/mining/pirating game.Quick Score: 8/10 - Great gameplay, graphics and sound, can get grindy and repetitive.Full Review:I'll talk about, in order of relevance to me personally, Gameplay, Graphics, and Sound.Gameplay-If you liked the ship combat in Assassins Creed Black Flag, then you'll find something to love here. The game takes place on a flat plane, which means no z-axis navigation. You're solely on the X-Y Plane. And that's a good thing, once you see the competition you're up against. But don't worry, only the smaller craft go up and down, the larger ones don't. You can individually man a selection of turrets or your broadsides in combat. There's a variety of each type to choose to suit your playstyle. If you like to get up close and personal, or keep your distance, there's a weapon for you. When you are not controlling the turrets directly, they are controlled by the AI, which you can configure. You can set them to lock onto specific targets, fire at will, or be completely manual. It's up to you. Even navigation is largely the same as Black Flag. Accelerate in stages, decelerate in stages with optional braking, and turn from side to side.Aside from that, there's things like factions you can side with, an economy to exploit, mining activities, and so on. A story is present, but can go largely ignored. Feel free to blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up and rack up the credits to the next ship upgrade. Speaking of, aside from aforementioned weaponry, defenses such as shields and armor and subsystems, which run specialised tasks as additions to your ship, can be upgraded. In a refreshing change of norm, you don't lose any credits when buying and selling items for your ship, so you're free to experiment until you find something that works. Even the ships you purchase come in a variety of sizes, from meek little frigates to massive and lumbering dreadnaughts and destroyers. There's plenty of ways to find a loadout more to your playstyle.One complaint I often see in space games is the sheer lack of things to do between travels. Fortunately, Rebel Galaxy keeps you on your toes. What may seem like a routine flight to another station may result in attending to a distress signal, getting ambushed by the enemy, or crashing into a nebula, with rocks (sorry, unsure what it's actually called) to dodge, mine or destroy. You can't expect to set your target and make some tea. There's also significant strategy in taking down opponents. Firing at the left side of the ship reduces the shielding for that side only, and not all the way round. Same goes for armor. So do you take an all-sides approach, or focus on one side of the ship? It's not so easy to just fire away, as you need to consider these things when attacking.Should you wish to make some dough, you can take on side missions or perform things like trading, mining, bounty hunting, and so on. It shouldn't be too hard to get the credits required for your next purchase.Graphics-I'm not one to stress on how pretty a game looks. I'm more for graphics. But my oh my is this game pretty. I'm more the person who feels Mirror's Edge looks better than Crysis 3, and the same goes here. Not the Crysis 3 thing. Space is beautiful. Instead of making it a black cosmos, with little white dots, it's colourful. Distant nebulae pepper the view with dashes of red, green, blue, purple, etc. Ships look worn but strong. Damage modelling is pretty impressive. ou can see scorch marks and chunks missing, embers glowing with some of the inner components revealed if you suffer significant damage. Weapons look beautiful when fired. They glow brightly, be it lasers or missiles. Speaking of, there's a flare effect from oncoming missiles fired from afar. Gives it a very cinematic feeling. There's also enough lens flare to make JJ Abrams happy, but it's done tastefully. Rest assured you won't have your view blocked by it. The UI is clean and uncluttered, letting you really soak in the surroundings. Rocket trails, when at warp, leave long blue lines behind you, and they each have a different layout depending on the thrusters of your ship. The Pulse effect looks good, akin to sonar visualised. When braking your ship, the thrusters turn red, as though they were brake lights. I considered it a nice touch.Sound-Best soundtrack so far. The game comes with a preloaded country/western soundtrack, that actually fits really well with the game. Should it not be your thing, feel free to add your own music collection, with the ability to set specific folders to different moments in the game, ie Combat, Travel, and so on. I personally set some dubstep for combat. As for sound effects, they're powerful. Flak cannons properly deafen, missiles have their own distinct sound, and everything comes together without sounding deafening. Even the AI which reports on your ship's status is plucked straight outta Sci-Fi stereotype, but hey, it works! Voice acting for the other characters you meet along the way is decent, but some of the quips from your enemies will begin to repeat fairly early.There's variety in language too. Different species may speak different languages, but in a way that sounds realistic. All in all, pretty good.Conclusion: The game gets repetitive, sure, so its longevity  really depends on how much fun you can have. I personally see this as the kind of game I can invest quite some time it, but your mileage may vary.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												This is my review, the game is great, love it quite abit. Being a Former EVE Online player, and multitude of other games I got in my own collection, The controls for this is very simple... for I will admit, I am no pilot! I am the only person in the world whom can crash an aircraft on takeoff!But the controls are easy, and I love it.Okay so here are the pros that I can safely say: for one, 19 bucks for the game is a bargin compared to other games, such as Elite: Dangerious (I tried it, cant fly), I like the trade system in the game, cause lets face it... repairs can suck at times, and drains the living hell out of your coffers. It doesnt hurt to dabble in it afterall, suppliment your income to ensure your vessle is in combat shape? why not right?Another is the combat system, The turrets, the Turrets! Oh how wonderful it is to be able to set the turrets how you wish. Leaving you to focus on defence, Sub Weapon systems (EMP Flak for the win), and the broadsides! while the turrets can rip the little fighters apart (they suck at times). the Manuvering is very smooth if your comfortable with the standard Keymotions from MMOs, you know the ASDW.Okay, time for the Nitpicking;the Cons;Ship content; I was told by a Dev (Thank you by the way) They will adjust ships to better suit how each is to stack up, so no one size fits all vessle... But still, we could use more ship types. even have Fighter Crafts of our own, even Bombers (For you batshit crazy aces out there, you know who you are), And maybe JUST Maybe, look into adding Multiplayer content, like conversion option for Single or Online version. Some people wanna rub other peoples faces into their afterburners afterall, and some are lone wolves in a sense.Mercinaries: Well not really judging, but would be nice if there was more of them to choose from, its like... each part of the space you go to, its sometimes the same pilot sitting at the bar (Stalker much?), So be kinda nice to have to hunt down your fav merc, and make them worthwhile to hang onto (rather than rehire them later in the game just to keep up with the enemies in the area)Factions: Needs a hint more love, maybe more factions?, and of course adding stuff for the factions to do (stuff that can affect each galaxy?) So Devs if your reading this and not vomiting from my pretty sad review. Take a moment from giving yourselves a far well deserved pat on the back, and look into Factions. Then Add and Fluff (and polish them out), it would give you ALOT more stuff to do, and would (hopefully) get alot more people to buy itSo all and all in a Nutshell (if your still sane after reading this, grats, if not... I heard the Jello in the institutes is nice),The Game is great with next to no complaints, great soundtrack (be better if you can change the channel at times), Good content, and player control. I highly recommend getting this game...Oh by the by, for you new players out there... hire a merc, they are a real help!-----Spoiler alert!-----THE CAKE IS A LIE!!

												If you like space trader style games then get this.Pros-Amazing Delta blues sound track. -The combat is well done.-The market is active and even responsive to events(I've seen a lot space trader style games mess this up)-Good core story that gives you a good intro then let's you wander around.Cons-I haven't found a difficulty slider, I feel a little overpowered in combat.-Ui is a bit of a console port shoehorn.-Kind of shy's away from detail in the UI; eg markets it gives you the info but doesn't let you page through it you have to wait for it to scroll by, no actual speed numbers just feel, menu layout is a bit cludgy. -Camera feels a bit off while aiming broadsides.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
Cowboy Bebop EditionI have been waiting for this game since I stopped playing FreelancerAt the time of this review I have 14.7 hrs and I have only just made it into the second sectorPros Large sectors with the freedom and range to do whatever you choose (mining, trading, pirate, mercenary) Multiple ships and upgrades, further diversified by guild specific upgrades Universe feels alive, randomly intercepting a pirate attack or being ambushed Interesting combat (naval style), broadside attacks being the main weapon usedCons Gets a bit grindy at times in order to progress, although it's realistic and makes you appreciate your ship as you upgrade it 2D plane playstyle, so no nifty barrel rolls to evade attacks Story isn't amazing  Buying and selling is weird, assuming because gui is made for both keyboard and controller Auto stop on cruise control, sometimes good, most of the time tediousRecommendations Fleet building, I get it's a primarily lone ranger feel but I would love to build an AI fleet to really wreck havoc Being able to have multiple gui windows, again I know it's made for conrollers but I'd like to have that space captain feel, being able to monitor my cargo bay, knowing what's contraband or not. Monitoring a locked on enemy whether or not it's in view.  Damaging ships like ftl, I wish I could exstensively damage an enemy thrusters or target their missile launchers with my turret to temporarily disable them, nothing major just would make fights a bit more interesting and not just bigger guns and better ship wins Overall though it's a great game especially for $20, if you love sci-fi and want that star trek style  battle where you both slowly move hitting each other balancing your power usage between thrusters, shields and weapons then definitely buy this game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												If you remember games like Freelancer and Freespace 2 and wish there was a modern game like them, then this is the game for you. It's a single player space adventure with naval style combat, complete with broadside attacks. Upgrade your weapons, shields and more or save up to buy a whole new ship - anything from a nippy little corvette to a huge and powerful dreadnought.[PROS]* The soundtrack is immense. It's sort of bluesy and grungy, with a definite western feel (think Firefly). The heavy guitar riffs brought a smile to my face more than once during a pitched battle.* The story. Engaging and fun, with just the right amount of grinding side-quests in between.* Active developers. The game is post-launch, but they're still working on it and perfecting things, which is always nice to see.* The graphics. The ships are very detailed in perticular, with artistic and individual designs for each one. None of the 'stock blocky ship 1a' nonsense you get in some games of this ilk. They all have their own distinc look and feel.* Firefly. A lot has been made of the similarities and they are there. Mostly in the asthetic rather than the actual gameplay, but it really feels like that's the universe you are playing in. What's not to love about that!* Freedom. Choose to stay in a fast ship with high maneuverability, or spring for a lumbering dreadnought, armed to the teeth. Looks like a fish, moves like a fish, steers like a cow. There really is no perfect choice. You can switch between ships you have bought with no penalty too, which is a great touch.[CONS]* Campaign could be longer. A mid-level ship is more than sufficient to complete the whole thing, so the awesome but expensive top-tier ships don't get a proper airing. However  The campaign ends on a cliff-hanger, so a sequel or expansion might be in the works. * Navigating can get a bit irritating. You drop out of FTL travel when you get close to an asteroid, or any other obstacle and they are everywhere. This would be okay, but you can never see them coming in advance. I got used to it though, since travel times really aren't that long anyway.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												English is not my primary language, so please, be patient :)Man, I'm not one to write reviews, but hell, this game is FUN !It was a very welcome surprise for me. I've played elite dangerous and other space games around, but nothing as fun as this one. The game awsome, good graphics, fast combat (even inside a capital ship, belive me), great learning curve, easy to play, not a insane number of commands, keyboard/mouse or joystick, great music, you really get the feeling of a space cowboy and pause: Yes PAUSE ! hit esc and everything stops ! You can get a soda, got take a leak, eat some pizza and the game will wait for you ! Want to snan some ships for cargo ? No problem, hit TAB and the game stops letting you scan ships without worring abou hitting something. The progression is also good, the game will give you bether missions based on the configuration of your ship. Bether ships, bether credits for your time. The side missions may seen repetitive, but, as long I'm blasting stuff up, I don't care, ehe. The game has many ships to fly, and even more as NPCs. Also, a good amount of gear for your ship. Main gus, sub guns, turrets, engines, warp drives are just some to name. HINT: A good defence IS A GOOD DEFENCE ! Don't neglect shields, or you will find yourself blowing up more than you like.Final words. Game is solid, for the price, it's a bargain. 8/10 If you're looking for a fun game to pass time, without the big worries of other space sims, go ahead, you will not regret it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												If you're looking for elitist  3D space combat with twitchy impossible combat and hardcore navigation and think it's fun to die trying to dock your ship, don't waste your money.If you want a fun game that's rewarding in small doses or good for an epic gaming weekend, this is it.  But warn your friends and family that they will be seeing less of you for a while....It's a beautifully done space combat/trading/questing game.  You can be a trader, you can be a miner, you can be a pirate, you can be a quester, or most likely you'll find yourself doing a little bit of all of it.  Or a LOT of all of it.I will suggest playing with a controller...I'm a longtime keyboard and mouse guy and I never use a controller for anything.  Thats a big part of why my Nintendo was gifted to my nephew and my xbox hasnt been plugged in for 2 years, but with this game the controller just feels right and works perfectly.Pros: *  It looks 3D, but it's mostly a 2D game, so it simplifies the navigation and combat *  Its very open.  There is a story line to progress through , but you're free to ignore it, or progress at your own pace*  You can fire it up, do a couple of quick quests, and feel like you accomplished something.  * And then a couple more, and then just one more, and then another one.....and 8 hours later you've played a quick game* It autosaves every time you visit a station.  So if your next quest goes horribly wrong, and you die a fiery death, then reload and try again. * If an objective is too hard, there are plenty of options to go make a little money, buy some better armor and weapons, and try it again.  Yet somehow it doesnt feel grindy, it's fun.* After over 30 hours, I still have the music turned on.  I saw one review call it "Cowboy butt-rock" - I'm not sure if they meant that as a compliment or an insult, but it kind of fits.  Either way, I like it.* The one time I had a problem, I posted a question on the support forum and got a response in 15 minutesCons* If you're not a fan of the "Cowboy butt-rock", turn it off.  The game is still worth it.* The game is so awesome it will inspire you to take time out to write a review, which takes time away from playing the awesome game.* I can't think of any other cons to put here* Really, why are you still reading?  Buy the game already

content:
Posted: February 12
												Was looking forward to this game since I used to play Privateer as a kid and this game might bring back some of those memories.From a technical perspective I can't recommend this game. Sorry.In 4k it's unplayable with a mouse. The mouse does not work correctly. In 1440p it's better, but the mouse still does not work correctly. Basically the issue is that even though the cursor is visually on a selection the game does not recognize it being there. That means you have to move the mouse around until you find the area of the screen where the game thinks the cursor is in the correct spot. They should just remove the 4k and 1440p options from the settings until this is fixed. If you don't mind playing in 1080p I'm sure you won't have to worry about the mouse issue. I see some people saying how nice the graphics are, but I don't see it. The textures are very "muddy" and blurry. Yes, I was in 4k and max settings. Easily was over 100fps so you know it's not a graphic intensive game. Which is probably a good thing for many people. Sound and music seem top notch the little I played the game though. Had to ask for a refund because of the technical issues.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Spent around 50+ hours in this game, finished it after obtaining MK6 equipment and being able to get the more expensive ships and guild ships.Having played through this with a good friend watching it live on Stream for the majority of the playthough i can say i enjoyed this title a lot.But i have gripes, gripes that comes from that it's meant to be played with a controller.There is a distinct snapping with aim assist in this game, this paired with no pitch control (Y axis for your spacecraft doesnt exist, but exists for other smaller crafts and various world objects/projectiles)The game felt huge at the beginning but the main storyline skips through sectors mid story, which leaves you just going through sectors without a reason to stay (unless you are doing trading, mining or hunting).It feels like this game was ported over from a Console, but that could also be good.. hear me out.In 50+ hours i have not had a single crash or bug, nor any weird software issues at all.This could very well be thanks to that the game is polished in that sense, framerate feels solid aswell.Game is beautiful (even if nebulas are tiny dust clouds compared to real life), the game allows custom music for: Idle, Combat, Space stations, ambient & main title.This is a very nice addition and lets you (once you get bored of the ingame music) put your own tracks for various interactions in game.Game plays well, no stutter or dips in general performance.I highly recommend playing this with a controller, as with a mouse the snapping / aim assist gets very frustrating once you wanna have more of a freelook aiming.Story should be made longer, or added with DLC as it felt short and kinda rushed, especially compared to the amount of sectors you dont even do any type of missions in at all. (you mainly just go find npc for mission->go and talk to npc->gate->gate->mission->gate back->gate back->find npc who gave mission->talk to npc.It does have some issues in those areas i mentioned earlier, but because it performs so well, and compensates with positives i can only give this a thumbs up.Improvements for a sequel in my mind would be:Expansive story, more side quests (not just mission board money makers), get rid of aim assist/snapping and give us Y axis / Pitch.

												I've seen some reviews that the battles aren't in three dimensions and that is slightly annoying, but I get why they did it.  Plus, it becomes a non-issue very quickly, as your mercenary (get one ASAP, they last until they die) takes care of a lot of the 3D fighters and the bigger battles have so much going on, the 2D actually helps.  That being said, this is like you're a young Han Solo in the Firefly world.  I'm barely fans of either universe, but this game is a fun ride and for the price, I feel like I got my money's worth.

												What a fantastic experience this is being.This game is what EVE Online never was. Action packed combat, that requires ACTUAL strategy, ACTUAL aiming, not just idiotic "Point and click". Requires skill. My computer is very old. I'm running this game on a GTX 260m, and it runs flawlessly, with everything turned ON. It's incredible.Stop wasting time. Just freaking buy this thing. Just buy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Short : its like elite-freelancer with more soul (firefly like) on 2D plane with different combat mechanics.Overall i realy like the game, below in points:1-Very nice mood. Its really got that Firefly mood. Teh galaxy is alive, plenty of events that affect the game (for example a holiday wiht gifts custom on a planet means certain items will have very high price etc ), you can get tips from bartendes, hire mercenraies, help traders under attack and get rewards from them etc. I liked Elite but tough beatifull, it felt a bit sterile and souless to me. Here i love it,The music is quite unusual for this type of game, inmstead of electronic trance-ambient you got hard rocking blues. I love it, tough if you dont dig rock/blues might a problem.2- Open end game. Follow the story or just take missions, bounty hunt trade, whatever you like. Plenty of ships and upgrades.3-Ship control is unusual. It looks 3d but in truth is a 2d plane.You got a third person view , Eve online like, but you must aim in combat.4-Combat: its quite unusual and initially i was disspointed by it , i yearned for full 3d and standard cockpit view. But at some point something clicked  and i began to really like it.Its broadside based,  you can aslo control turrets.5- The graphics are nice, and i ahvent run into many bugs (i think i crashed once)If you are past Privateer/Elite/Freelancer fan, i think you should enjoy it very much, tough i recommend wathing vids to see the unusual ship control/combat in action.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Spent around 50+ hours in this game, finished it after obtaining MK6 equipment and being able to get the more expensive ships and guild ships.Having played through this with a good friend watching it live on Stream for the majority of the playthough i can say i enjoyed this title a lot.But i have gripes, gripes that comes from that it's meant to be played with a controller.There is a distinct snapping with aim assist in this game, this paired with no pitch control (Y axis for your spacecraft doesnt exist, but exists for other smaller crafts and various world objects/projectiles)The game felt huge at the beginning but the main storyline skips through sectors mid story, which leaves you just going through sectors without a reason to stay (unless you are doing trading, mining or hunting).It feels like this game was ported over from a Console, but that could also be good.. hear me out.In 50+ hours i have not had a single crash or bug, nor any weird software issues at all.This could very well be thanks to that the game is polished in that sense, framerate feels solid aswell.Game is beautiful (even if nebulas are tiny dust clouds compared to real life), the game allows custom music for: Idle, Combat, Space stations, ambient & main title.This is a very nice addition and lets you (once you get bored of the ingame music) put your own tracks for various interactions in game.Game plays well, no stutter or dips in general performance.I highly recommend playing this with a controller, as with a mouse the snapping / aim assist gets very frustrating once you wanna have more of a freelook aiming.Story should be made longer, or added with DLC as it felt short and kinda rushed, especially compared to the amount of sectors you dont even do any type of missions in at all. (you mainly just go find npc for mission->go and talk to npc->gate->gate->mission->gate back->gate back->find npc who gave mission->talk to npc.It does have some issues in those areas i mentioned earlier, but because it performs so well, and compensates with positives i can only give this a thumbs up.Improvements for a sequel in my mind would be:Expansive story, more side quests (not just mission board money makers), get rid of aim assist/snapping and give us Y axis / Pitch.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												I was suprised. I really like this game. Being both a story driven and, sandbox game that blends very nicely. (IE:Your not forced to do anything, and have all the tools and oportunities of every other AI player from the start.) *almost, there are some races that have improved weaponry and such, but these can be "obtained" in various ways. I'm not sure about all unique crafts, but they are not OP so not a real worry.It gives me all the excitment and fun stuff that Elite Dangerous promised(lied about), and has never delilvered.Your actions have an impact in the game in a way that doesn't seem grindy.It feels fun and less like having a second job. *See Elite DangerousI don't have to pay $60.00 a year to play the full game.The controls took me a few mins to figure out, but then I'm using a keyboard and mouse, but after a few mins I was having a blast.I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes space-flight, open-world, scripted or sandbox type play.You can choose to play as the "good-guys", "bad-guys" or anything in between, or any type of character you want really, AND change your play-style at any point. Various missions give you the oportunity to improve your relations with the different factions regardless of past history.The graphics are terrific.My rating 9.0 out of 10.Having finnished the game; the rating stands. I should lower it a bit due to the unfinished feeling the game leaves you with as pertains to the interface, contant speed bumps, other factions, and weaponry and such. Still I had fun. The modding community has tried to keep this game fresh and fun for those of us who have finnished it. But, without real modding tools, this list is short and creating your own mod is way too much work to be worth the effort atm.Hopefully, the Devs will create something to make the process a bit simplified or the replayability of this game may suffer in the long run.

												Okay, so i've bought this game because i was incredibly bored and wanted something to be able to wait for Fallout 4 with i am glad i did.I have not played for long, yet i am having a lot of fun with this game. content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Starts to become repetative towards the end, but still a great game.+GREAT soundtrack+Good visuals+Engaging gameplay+Fairly well designed trade system+VERY engaging and fun combat~Story is meh, not great, not bad.~Random pirate encounters are really neat at first, but become common after the first 5 or so that happen.  One of the best ways to farm cash though, bounty from enemy ships.-Once youve figured out the games combat and the best loadouts, you can fairly easily 1v1 any ship in the game, and take on fairly heafty fleets on your own.  As said, makes the game become a bit repetative toawards the end.-If you want to get the largest ships in the game, it will take a LOT of farming/grinding for cash.-Missions become repetative pretty quickly, not a lot of variance beyond 5-10 types.Overall, I consider this a great game.  I purchased it for 10$, and easily got my moneys worth.  Soundtrack alone is worth the purchase lol.  I even boot it up for other space games.8.5/10

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												2.5D game with good looks and great gameplay. Even though you can skip the story completely it guarantees you at least 20 hours of gameplay just to finish the story mode, thus the ships and upgrades you can work your way to buy.As many other "space sims" out there you can spend time mining, trading, doing mercenary work and questing. It's all about finding what's best for you. There are ships to fit your needs and you can always improve them. Reminds me a lot of Endless Sky and Freelancer but with better graphics and fancy effects.The soundtrack leaves me speechless and the game gives you the ability to add your own songs into the soundtrack so you can listen to your own music while playing. Realism is not the main factor here but this game sure is really fun! 10/10, waiting for a faction revamp DLC.

content:
Posted: January 7
												So I bought this game on a drunken whim because I really really really liked the music, here's me first couple hours with it:>Start out as a humble smuggler, mostly sticking to commodities and mining, money is flowing, the booze does too.>No Idea what the heck is happening around me, explosions and lasers bloody everywhere, but I somehow keep coming out more or less unscathed. Must be Liquor Luck.>Getting a taste for higher-tier ships, need more money badly, but don't wanna resort to illegal activites.>Couple more hours of drinking and smuggling.>Regular goods just don't cut it anymore, so out the window morals go, let's become a drug trafficking, war-mongering space slaver. Heck yeah.>Am I flying two ships now or is it the booze?>Feeling invincible with my new bomb♥♥♥♥♥combate frigate.>Haven't died so far, game seems to always just create the illusion of danger.>Keeping that in mind, I tell a milia warship with heavy escort to go suck some cold space, anticipating nothing to happen because of comfort zone game design.>Getting blown to smithereens before I can say "Skazzer".10/10 Traded my Live Organs for some more Greel Whiskey.Side note: As of this review I've been playing this game without break (13.5 hrs).Thanks Double Damage.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												This is a great space battle and trading game, but it does leave some things to be desired. The main storyline is quite short and I imagine that most people get to the ending without knowing it - its very sudden. The storyline is too short to make saving up for better ships and weapons worthwhile. It's cool to have the biggest, badest ship and tearing enemy's apart with waves of munitions is quite fun, but it's a side mission grind that gets you to that point. If you follow the storyline's natural progression, you wont even get close to obtaining the best ships. All in all, time worth spent and I enjoyed most things about this game. If you can get it on sale, I'd say go for it.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												Made by two guys, and you can really see where that is obvious. Lots of cutbacks. For example a male cruiser pilot will suddenly turn female on the comms and ai is shared a lot, meaning a pirate will get interdicted by friendly merchants guild ships who have the exact same ships and exact same all-female captains as the miltia does. Lots of shared and samey stuff.Nevertheless, you can also see where those savings went. Very few bugs, cool aesthetic and with the awesome feature to add your own music even for different situations. This is a super easy to learn, fun space shmup where all to a surprisingly kicking vanilla soundtrack (seriously, check it out on YT if you like space westerns) The gameplay is a little repetitive, but getting bigger and bigger ships is just so satisfying.For this price? I haven't had this much fun in ages. Hope for an improved sequel someday. 7/10.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a rather 2D depiction of space travel and combat with limited gameplay options. However, the game is nice looking and the slow grind to earn money makes upgrading your ship feel great. Getting larger and larger ships as the game progresses feels good but the grind is almost too repetitive. There is also a market that seems a little out of place for the "space cowboy" vibe this game usually has. The main campaign is short lived and feels rather pointless by the end. All in all this is a good game to play if you just want to play something mindlessly. A good pick up if its on sale. Fun but not memorable.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												There is something incredibly satisfying in aligning your ship alongside another and unleashing every single broadside cannon you have. In combination with the incredible music giving every fight you take a Wild West spin; you truly are on the lawless outskirts of space. You start with nothing and climb all the way to the top in any way you want. Trader, Miner, Mercenary, Pirate. Just be careful who you make enemies with, anything goes in this game.On the subject of trading, Rebel Galaxy contains a simple yet effective trading system with market values that will change in response to local events. Discover trade routes from station to station, capitalise on resource shortages, a station currently being blockaded will be in desperate need of supplies.When you feel strong enough, use a jump gate to travel to one of the many other systems. Make sure you are prepared though; higher risk brings higher reward but you won’t be smiling facing a Dreadnought class ship armed to the teeth. This game stands out as one of its quirks is that it is locked on a 2D plane, honestly I think this brings its benefits. You're at the helm of a capital ship, you wouldn't be doing amazing tricks. It also simplifies the controls, meaning you can focus less on keeping the ship level and more on the actual fight. Just listen to the soundtrack, it completes this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												In rebel galaxy you will find yourself on the edges of civilised space, space stations placed anywhere from the hollowed out husk of a mighty asteroid to in orbit around colossal gas giants will be a sight for sore eyes as you pilot your ship into the awaiting docks, the repair bay will offer you a chance to repair the fractured hull, weapons ranging from ionised bursts of plasma to mighty missle batteries having punched through the shield and torn through the hull damaging systems as well as your own weapons, handing over an adequate sum of currency to the shipwright. You may choose to offload cargo, either acquired via the mission board (cargo needs to get around somehow), trade with a cargo vessel you pulled out of the fire as pirates attempted to 'appropriate' its cargo or from the ruined husks of the pirate vessels themselves (maybe even the trader too if you're so inclined)Maybe you're looking for a job? or perhaps to finish one, handing over the agreed upon cargo for a sum of credits, hitting up the mission board to pick out a slew of quests to keep yourself busy as you trek across the system taking on a notorious pirate here, guarding a mining outpost there or perhaps assisting the militia forces take on a pirate convoy, headed by a mighty command ship; there are no shortage of things people want done.And after all that there's the bar, where you could chat up the tender, asking for news he might be partial to, whether it be as simple as an excalation of pirate activity in the sector, or perhaps that one of the stations in the system are going through some rough times, that being said no one pays more for food than those who need it and where there is demand, there is supply, but whether or not you're the one to supply said goods is up to you.Or perhaps you're looking for bounties? Slip the barkeep a couple hunded credits and suddenly you've got the locations to a few people someone out there wants dead, and are willing to pay for it.At the bar you might also meet a merc, spend a couple thousand on a good pilot to watch your back, this section of the galaxy is after all 'mostly' lawless space.Your visit done, you return to your ship, maybe spend a few thousand credits on an enhanced engine, thicker hull plating or better weapons, maybe even a few new tools to help you along the way, making your weapons deadlier, your aim sharper and those pirate scum a little less threatening.Whether you want to take to the stars as space trader extraordinare, feared bounty hunter, humble asteroid miner or parhaps cutthroat pirate, (Perhaps a mix of all four?) Rebel Galaxy can certainly accomodate.{Serious stuff out of the way, I caught a pirate group harassing a salvage crew harvesting the wreck of a giant (at least 12 times the size of my current ship) capital vessel (which you can TOTALLY get later) caught in the midst of a minefield, I noticed a cluster of mines near the enemy vessel on and ended up taking a shot at the explosives, which like a chain reaction of epic preportions exploded (As 'explosives' tend to do) taking out the pirate in a single shot, moments like that is what this game provides, if any of this review sounds like something you'd enjoy than I wholeheartedly recommend Rebel Galaxy.}

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Classic Naval Broadside Cannon Combat IN SPACE!This game is a ton of fun, from the moment you start you literally can do anything you want. Whether it be bounty hunting, mining, protecting, exploring. Everything is right there, right away. It's simple with it being on a flat plane (meaning you can't fly up and down, instead you go left, right, and straight). Surprisingly it doesn't take to much away from the game. Combat is fast paced and their is a varity of ships to face, from small fighters to capital ships. Some of your weapons crush small fighters but won't even scratch the paint job against the capital ships. There is plenty of upgrades for your ships and the best part is when you buy a new ship, you don't have to rebuy everything as it swaps out the ship but keeps the equipment and automatically sells the old ship (so if you're a tad short on money it'll do an exchange where it sells your ship first then buys the new ship making it pretty seemless to purchase new things). The sounds are pretty good in the game, I really can't complain. Especially when you hit warp. The voice acting is above average for a game of this production size.All in all, if you like space, I'd have to recommend this game. I got this game when it was $9.99 and to be honest, it would be worth it at $20.00 hands down.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Classic Naval Broadside Cannon Combat IN SPACE!This game is a ton of fun, from the moment you start you literally can do anything you want. Whether it be bounty hunting, mining, protecting, exploring. Everything is right there, right away. It's simple with it being on a flat plane (meaning you can't fly up and down, instead you go left, right, and straight). Surprisingly it doesn't take to much away from the game. Combat is fast paced and their is a varity of ships to face, from small fighters to capital ships. Some of your weapons crush small fighters but won't even scratch the paint job against the capital ships. There is plenty of upgrades for your ships and the best part is when you buy a new ship, you don't have to rebuy everything as it swaps out the ship but keeps the equipment and automatically sells the old ship (so if you're a tad short on money it'll do an exchange where it sells your ship first then buys the new ship making it pretty seemless to purchase new things). The sounds are pretty good in the game, I really can't complain. Especially when you hit warp. The voice acting is above average for a game of this production size.All in all, if you like space, I'd have to recommend this game. I got this game when it was $9.99 and to be honest, it would be worth it at $20.00 hands down.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												This game fills a void in the market: accessible (arcadey) freelancer-esque open-world space game. That was a mouthful.I'm completely enamoured with this game right now. It has fun naval-style combat (complete with broadside cannons), upgrades to buy, ships to save up for, and space pirates to blow up. It feels good, it looks good, and it's a boat load of fun.However, I'm worried that the game's content will come up a bit thin. The missions can get repetitive very quickly, and there is a lot of repetitive action going on with a very thin reward and upgrade structure. I'm only 7 or so hours in, so time will tell if the depth opens up later on.I hope the devs continue to build on to this and flesh it out in the future. As it is, it's a good game. But It could be a lot better too.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												Disclosure: I received the key from the devs a few days before release.Pros:-Amazing interface that works perfectly with both Mouse+Keyboard and gamepads.-Easy to follow Video+text tutorials simmilar to those in Deus Ex Human revolution.-Addictive combat on a 2D plane but with a twist: fighters and gunships evade fire in 3D, which opens up more room for specialized weapons. (and the developers capitalized on that fact)-Everything is voiceacted. And it's good :)-Progression is slow but steady. It will take you dozens of hours to get the best ship & gear but since you constantly advance a weapon turret here and a subsystem there it will feel a lot less grindy.-Progression is completely open and the campaign reacts to your behaviour (so, if you choose to be a pirate it just works!)-You can mix your on audio files to the soundtrack collection and even differentiate Combat, Station, Ambient and other types of music usage.Cons:-I would have really loved this to be a $40+ title with even more ships, factions and better skyboxes. (then again, I was convinced this game would be $30 AT LEAST, so it's still amazing)-I wish it had multiplayer

content:
Posted: February 21
												Combat is shallow, boring, repetitive and easy. The progression for the equipment curve is bizarre, everything almost doubles with the upgraded versions (weapon damage, shields etc.) Feels weird equipping your first next level equipment that basically obseletes your other weaponryTrading UI is a pain to use to find the information you want. Tractoring specific items is also an issue.The trading is made more interesting with random events affecting prices one way or the other. It was fun for a while running embargo blockades for the big $$.In this game an asteroid field is 5 rocks and a tin can, a nebula is a few puffs of smoke. All that really changes is the system backgrounds.All the stations are basically the same. There's not much personality in this game.Hailing system is half-done e.g. hail someone emitting a distress signal, and they'll tell you they don't need any help with anything, until you close your distance a certain amount.Someone offers to give up in a fight, and you reject it? Can't push them for more credits, or even take their original offer.You are free to warp in any direction, but you will be pulled out of warp near any object and don't have any direct control over your speed (fields and other environments are probably so small in size and barebones, so you don't get caught in them warping)This leaves all the systems without much structure. If you want to go to a station across the map, just point your ship and go. Maybe you'll warp right through a miniature junk field without hitting anything and get a 20 credit exploration bonus (equipment is in the thousands, I don't know why this is a thing?)Another fun feature with warp is occasionally you'll want to catch a special ship/s that comes up on the system map. You warp to them, and the game will match your warps so you're in formation, instead of letting you blast past and cancel their warp.Also, game says "warp cancelled by stellar mass" every time you're pulled out of warp, regardless of what caused it. Come on guys.If you're after something like Freelancer or even something like Pirates! I wouldn't bother

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Fresh and simple, this game manages to create the feeling of an enormous, dynamic Freelancer-style sandbox with fantastically simple arcade-style controls.  Easily one of the most intuitive games I've ever played, and one of the prettiest (and in light of that, one of the best optimised too - running far better than games with lower requirements and looking better than some with higher requirements too).  This game feels a lot like Diablo II, perhaps unsurprisingly since those games are amongst the staggering pedigree of the team of TWO core developers.   The two games on Steam that seem closest to it in aesthetics and playstyle would be, I think, Starpoint Gemini 2 and Drifter.  I've got both and after 1 hour on Rebel Galaxy I already know I'm going to spend much more time on this than the other two.  It is far simpler to pick up and have fun with than Starpoint Gemini 2 - a real sense of instant fun and adventure - and it's significantly more polished and deep than Drifter, as well as being much prettier.My only gripe with the game is that all the action takes place in a plane as opposed to having real 3D movement.  You can't pitch your ship up or down.  Hardly game-breaking, and I suppose it's true that the vast majority of real star systems are organised in a plane, but they are far from 2-dimensional from the point of view of a human space-ship!Don't expect an X-series experience.  This game is much closer to classics like Freelancer and Tachyon: The Fringe.  It's not shallow, but it's certainly not "spreadsheets in space" either.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												I bought this in a previous 50% sale and would say that at this price it is definitely worth it, however after having now played it for 30+ hours (and finding it hard to put it down each time) I think I would have paid full price too!As many reviews have already stated this game is like the love child of Sid Meier's Pirates and Freelancer, it's neither one or the other but has emulated some of the features from both games and merged these into an interesting hybrid. The 2D naval style fighting makes it less complicated than a 3D counterpart but don\'t let that fool you that it's less of a challenge. The variety of ships, weapons and modules give it enough diversity to keep you playing for that next upgrade but without bombarding you with sheets of complicated stats. The soundtrack isn't going to be everyone\'s taste but I think it's awesome and really suits the pace of the game.Yes it's a bit clichéd, the main story is short and it's quite simplified compared to others in the genre but that's the beauty of it - it isn't trying to copy a successful franchise and then failing miserably; it has it's own spin on space rpg that's different whilst being familiar at the same time.Edit: Removed typos caused by mobile app

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												A short learning curve, but the games throws you into the action fast in a universe where you can't count on everthing you run into to be 'in your league'. After getting smoked A LOT, I learned how to judge fights quickly and get away if I stepped in something too deep. Looking forward to seeing if the trade system gets deep, but just as a shooter it's great.First, it's 2D space, if that isn't obvious from the videos- but there's good reason for it. INstead of traditional 'chase them and try to shoot their♥♥♥♥♥ style dogfighting, it's battleship style broadside combat with an interesting fighter/gunnery system where your turrets can be set to auto or manually controlled as needed.Loving this game. Recommend a gamepad, I use an Xbox 360 controller. Tons of fun with it, and the controls are well mapped (although I find myself constantly forgetting about where to find what I need between the Start menu and Y meu)

												The simplest way to describe it is Naval Space Western Game.You travel around in outer space, doing missions, fighting space pirates, buying and selling stuffs from planet to planet. But I won't call this space sim in the sense of freelancer or X series! You actually only travel in one plane. there's no vertical movement. And you're not flying a dinky fighter. You're flying something bigger than that, a frigate or gunship at least. Which fight with broadsides. Why? Because space is an ocean. It's Naval Space.Why western? Because it's a space western game as well. Just check the trailer and absorb the music and aesthetics.In other word, weird but cool game.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												Wasn't paid for my review.  Let's get that out there in the open.  *pushes beer under his bed with his feet, all slick-like*AHEMThe game is a prettier, more entertaining version of Space Rangers.  You can choose to slay pirates, trade comodities, or mine your way into a larger, faster, more powerful ship all pimped out with the latest murder gadgets ranging from flak guns to missle turrets.  Broadside firing is a nice plus in the middle of battle while all the other guns are auto targeting.  Lots and lots of fun.Pros:+Lots of upgrades+Lots of stuff to explore/hack/kill+Space is beautiful and makes me wee nips perky+Tons of missions+Lots of ship variations (Though I'm limited on what I can see this early in)+Battles need finger dex and quick reflexes when against more powerful ships (I'm assuming controller is easier)+Character models are pretty cool+Warp auto disables when you get to target, so no need for timed disengages+Customize firing/targeting for auto-turrets as you move into a good firing position for broadside+Battles can be rather long, but hella enjoyable when you beat out capital ships with crappy weapons/armor+Love the western-rock music vibeCons:-Missions are the samethings over and over-Autosaving only kicks in when you dock, so DOCK OFTEN or exit to force autosave-Warps disengaging due to pirate ambushes are no bueno early in game-Warps disengaging in mine fields is no bueno-Warps disengaging in electrical storms is no bueno-Warps disengaging in astroid belts is no bueno-Auto plotting courses would be nifty-Dev is buying reviews with early access codes all illuminati-like-Didn't come with beerI give the game 5 Landsharks out of a 6 pack

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												Charming, if limited, arcade game written by the creator of Torchlight.Whilst it really isn't anything special, Rebel Galaxy enjoys a level of charm not often seen in the modern gaming world. From the sci-fi western setting to the naval-esque space combat, Rebel Galaxy takes a lot of smart-but-simple game mechanics and throws them together in one thoroughly enjoyable and deceptivel moreish space romp.Whilst it will feel familiar to both fans of games such as the X series as well as hardened ARPG players, both will see where the limits shine: from the limited dimensions of space combat to the under-developed item metagame, Rebel Galaxy is very much a jack of many (if not all) trades, but a master of none.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												I really want to like this game because I love the whole Firefly thing it has going on. There are definitely things to like about it, but it ultimately is just a very boring space sim with a kinda lousy battle system IMO.Turn-ons:+Firefly!+Soundtrack is great!+NPCs are marvelous!Turn-offs:--The broadside combat. I played the game for 3+ hours and fought a fair number of battles against pirates in that time. I even upgraded to better weapons and different types of weapons. But the combat just never started to feel good. Broadside combat is great with sea vessels because they are both sea vessels. But in this game your ship is confined to a flat plane while enemy ships are flying loops over you and under you as you try to lock onto them. It's more like trying to use a sluggish wooden sailing ship to engage in broadside combat with a bunch of airplanes and submarines. I'm not saying that it's impossible or anything, but I did find it really irritating and it did not start to get better.--It is very empty and boring. It has all of the things that space sims normally have, such as trading and merc missions and ships parts that can be upgraded and so on. But I put in several hours into this game and I spent most of that time staring at the butt of a ship flying in a straight line toward a mission destination. I seriously just set the controller down on my desk, folded my hands, and watched a picture of a space ship. For minutes. MINUTES ON END. I found out that I could upgrade all of my engines and boosters etc to get some more speed out of the ship, and I was feeling very positive about that at first, but then I realized I was STILL pretty much spending most of my time staring at the butt of a ship flying in a straight line. So much yawn.--The game seems heavily skewed toward playing as muscle. If you tend to lean a little more pacifist/trader in space sims, then this game does not seem very friendly towards those types. When I first started running missions, I initially was only accepting missions that the game explicitly labeled as VERY LOW RISK, which were usually just trading missions that asked me to go pick something up and bring it back or transport some cargo from A to B. But EVERY SINGLE ONE of these missions resulted in a scripted ambush attack from multiple pirate ships. Literally every time. So there's not really any point accepting the missions that pass themselves off as the pacifist types because this game shoves you into combat literally every time. Every mission is a combat mission. Always. Without fail. Or so this was my experience.--But did I mention how incredibly boring it is? This was really the thing that made me stop playing the most. Most of my time spent playing this game I did not feel like I was playing a game. I felt like I was staring at the butt of a ship that was doing nothing.And then it occurred to me that I could be playing a game that felt like doing things. So I'm done with it.I love the whole Firefly thing, and apparently lots of people think the game is just great, but man... I could not stay awake while playing this thing.

content:
Posted: April 7
Product received for free
												Rebel Galaxy is a very casual space pilot "simulator", all combat is really handled in 2D and mostly resembles sea battles (broadside artillery, all ships except fighters manouver on the same "height") so if you're looking for a serious space-sim it's not for you.Gameplay consists of main storyline broken up by (a lot) of generated sidequests which get a bit boring after a while since there's only a few types (search and destroy, delivery, defend target, pick up object). Since main story quickly ramps up in difficulty you'll be grinding these quite a lot. Apart from sidequests you can also play as a trader, buying low and selling high, a miner selling resources found in asteroids, pirate hunter looking for bounties or a pirate hunting civillian ships.As you progress you will upgrade your ship with new weapons, shields and additional equipment, every once in a while buying a new ship.Pros:+ Enjoyable space combat (if you dont mind the sea battles feel).+ Plenty of ships/upgrades to work towards.+ Decent voice-acting (somewhat repetetive lines from enemies).+ Multiple ways to progress.+ Great musicCons:- Requires a lot of grinding sidequests to progress.- Not much depth or variety beyond the basics.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												Grindfest 10/10Gameplay 2/10Story 1/10Graphics 10/10Sound 10/10I love everything about what this game SHOULD HAVE been. It feels like a rushed college project where the devs just wanted to get it turned in and get their passing grade.The lack of content, the lack of everything in this game makes it a grindfest and a pretty boring one at that. Seriously you could buy this game, play the 3 hours and 59min and get your refund, because the next 25+ hours are the exact same thing.Missions are "Go here and kill everything" - No real strategy involved other than don't get overrun. You can kite for days.Ship upgrades lack diversity.There's nothing else to do. You fly around galaxies that all feel the same, going from point A to point B, mining and trade are simplistic time wasters that try to add complexity but fails.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												This is a pretty good space RPG. In addition to the main campaign quest, you pretty much go around the galaxy accepting different bounties so that you can upgrade your ship and complete the harder quests in the campaign. Almost all the bounties are combat-type bounties. You can also acquire money through trade on the commodities market, but it can be very time-consuming. The key to commodities trading is finding out what outposts will pay the highest for various products. For instance, a scientific oytposts will pay higher for intellectual property and tech stuff, but a rogue or outlaw outposts will pay more for illicit drugs and whatnot. You can also gain trading info by reading news boards and speaking to bartenders. Traveling between space stations and various parts of the galaxy can be boring. It can take several minutes to travel between points on opposite sides of the galaxy.The graphics are nice and the music is awesome, but it gets a little monotonous after awhile since it plays constantly on a loop throughout the entire game. The combat is interesting. It is "naval-style" combat, which means your primary guns fire from the side. This imposes a significant learning curve to combat since you have to fight sideways, which makes it harder to see incoming missiles. There are secondary weapons that you can switch to that don't require sideways combat, but then you have to constantly adjust your ship angle if you switch weapons a lot. It is challenging but rewarding when you finally get it all down.Rebel Galaxy is a fun and nice alternative to most space sims that require a lot of management and alliance building over a long period of time. Rebel Galaxy commences with all that by giving you a campaign and a ship. The rest is up to you.
