number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												I like this game.  A LOT!  I bought it because I was looking for something similar to EVE, but without the malicious player base that EVE is notorious for.  This game filled that nitch nicely.  PROS:This is one of the few games I've played recently, where the keyboard/mouse control scheme is every bit as good as the Console Controller scheme.    Intuitive and effective keyboard control make this a joy to play without a controller.The Graphics are Very nice, and Don't require a Monster video card to run.  (I'm running it on an old nvidia 9800 gt with 512mb of Vram and it runs just fine.  Framerate rarely drops below 60fps, unless I turn on depth of field and motion blur.  Then it still plays fine until I get into a nebula, where my framerate starts to crawl with certain effects, so I would recommend playing with those two settings turned off if you are using a lower end video card.The story is interesting enough and the voice acting is well done.The combat is where this Game really really shines.  It's very well executed, with controls that feel natural and fluid, and the explosions when enemy ships pop are extremely satisfying.    The 'Missions' section of the game  is well set up and fun to play.  Mining works fine, and trading is functional enough.You can hire a mercenary (only one at a time) to fly with you and help you fight, and early in the game, they are quite strong.This game has a really cool feature called 'warp pairing' where you escort a ship by moving up in a flanking position and select the 'enable warp pairing' feature, that basicly causes you to follow the lead ship through warp while staying in formation  (sort of like gang warping in EVE online)  It works well most of the time, however, asteroid fields and such can cause the ship you're escorting to get a little confused sometimes.  It's still fun to do though and is a nice change from the typical; "Go here and kill everything." type missions. Cons:One of the biggest Cons for me is the difficutly system.  It is based on a number of factors, (Star system, equipment grade, ship type, etc) and it works well early on.  However around the later part of the second system and beyond, the difficulty gets a bit unstable.  You will run into large difficulty spikes that seem to come out of nowhere.  It leaves the game feeling a little unpolished, and can be frustrating.  (in the second system, I was using all Mark III equipment and weapons, and I got a Mark IV mining laser from an enemy drop so I popped it on... and promptly got blown up over and over again until I took that little booger back off again.  Adding that one cheesy mining laser pushed me up into a higher difficulty bracket and made doing even simple missions very difficult or even impossible.  My advice?  Don't upgrade weapons one at a time.  Save your money and do them all at once so you actually have the firepower to take on that next difficulty bracket.)Trading can be profitable, but is a bit clunky.  There is no realtime feed telling you what prices are in various stations/systems so the only way to see if you will make a profit is to physically go there and look for yourself.  A live feed (or at the very least a price list that updates once a day or so, would be a huge help, and would save the player from making tons of wasted trips to stations.)One of the few things I dislike about the keyboard/mouse setup is what I call; "the-one-press-wonder-key".  The 'E' key does various things depending what is available at the moment.  The problem lies with the fact that if several options are open at the same time, the key starts popping from one option to another as you fly close to them.  I've been caught trying to 'tractor beam' some loot into my hold and had the prompt switch as I'm pressing the key so that instead of getting the loot, I warp away.  Same thing when trying to loot while close to a station.  You end up docking instead of looting.  This happens alot and is pretty frustrating sometimes.Enemies tend to spam really annoying weapons at you when you move beyond the first area.  Leach missles and mines that screw up your engines and shields are used constantly in the later game and they are quite irritating.  There are ways to protect yourself to an extent, but they require precious component slots to equip, and most ships don't have enough space for all the systems you will need. Verdict:Even with the Cons mentioned above, I find this game very fun (I've spent over 300 hours on Rebel Galaxy at the time of this writing) and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a Space ship game based around Capital ship combat and broadside bombardments!  There's nothing as satisfying as scraping hulls with an enemy ship and unleashing your Broadsides into it!  Amazing!

												I love this game! I do most of my playing when I'm on duty and have some down time, so please, don't let my in game time fool you. I have played this game A LOT! I also like the fact that if you don't like the music, you can change it to whatever you like. Sure, there is some repetition here and there. Seems every bartender in the galaxy is the same person. It really doesn't bother me that bad. This works great with the Steam controller. Controlls are intuitive and eas to learn. It'll be no time at all before you are out and about fiding the best prices for the goods you have, or out hunting bounties for killing local thugs. Be warned though, tis game can get brutal really fast. Where you might dominate in one system, you can get totally owned in the next system.I will say this, while it doesn't have the free flying 3D movement, this game does take me back to my love for Freelancer. They do manage to make it feel natural.If your shy about the price, catch it on sale.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Really good and fun game. Played almost non stop for 2 weeks straight and beat it with 37 hrs on record, probably could have gone quicker but I enjoyed taking on side quests and building up my ship. I finished the game with a Manticore destroyer, mk6 shields/armor/broadsides, mk5 everything else. The campaign could likely be finished with an even smaller ship as long as you can deal some high damage. There's still some game left for me to play after beating it, the game goes right back normal just without the campaign mission.  I haven't had the chance to play with a cuiser or dreadnaught yet, and some of the side quest missions are still pretty challenging with my destroyer.Technically the game runs smooth as butter, and looks pretty decent. The game only crashed on me a single time while playing. I did have a problem where if I left the game paused for 10-20 minutes my computer would restart? Never happened while playing though. I played with a KB/M and thought it was fairly easy to get into, it definitely appears setup for easy controller play though.For a budget game it just feels really polished and well thought out. I LOVE the music selections, even if they can get a bit repetitive.  Worth the normal $20 price, but a great buy when on sale!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												This game is really fun. I bought it and I played it for a hundred+ hours. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes sandbox / space exploration / shoot em up's.... well... .....I'd recomend it to nearly everyone.    I WOULDN'T recommend it to anyone who was involved with the creation of a game called Freelancer that came out nearly ten years ago.... they'd probably wonder why these game developers stole every single idea they had in their game... slapped some differnet names on the characters 'n races .... and started charging people money for it like it was their own original idea.Don't get me wrong.... I really like this game (probably because it's practically identical to freelancer... which I loved ten years ago). I would, and do, recommend it to all who like this genre. But I'm left wondering...... did the developers buy the rights to the original Freelancer game? ...did they just steal EVERY idea they used in their game from it thinking nobody would notice???  ... or did they think that gamers inevitably forget about the games they love and play for hundreds upon hundreds of hours as the years pass. I haven't forgotten about Freelancer.... and in my opinion.... even for a ten year old game.... it's still better than this one.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												I think it's hard for me to express how much I'm in love with this game. The unique style of 'flat' space combat allows for combat to be focused on broadside cannons. The lack of a "Z" axis of movement allows focus for more tactical real time decision making in combat instead of focusing on keeping your nose pointed at a lead indicator like most space games. The music and theme are amazing as well! This is the frontier of space, so naturally theres an old west theme throughout The music consists of driving rock & metal rooted in the old west. It evokes fond memories of the T.V. show Firefly during some chords. It's worth mentioning that if you're looking for a space exploration game along the lines of the X series or Elite, that's not really what this is. This is a space adventure with exploration elements. On sale this game is an absolute must buy imo, but it's worth the current full price as well.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												I'm addicted.........That being said. This game is AWESOME. I'd of reviewed it sooner cause I instantly fell in love, but I've been unable to peel my eyes away. Every free minute I get on the PC, I'm playing this.It's a great semi-casual game that compares a lot to FTL in it's rougeness, and as far as combat and missions go it seems to take a lot away from EVE Online. There are other comparisons but these stand out the most. The missions and combat have managed to keep me just on my toes enough every time I start to open my mouth to say "This is getting repetitive." I get put in my place by some new tactic a higher level enemy is using. There is a bit of story line to the game, but It's there more to keep your compass from spinning as you progress than it to make the game linear. You could play for hours and hours and never touch the main mission and not get bored.I really can't think of much bad to say about this game. One downside that comes to mind is warp times can seem a bit long after you've been doing a lot of hopping around, but it's really not so bad as there are ways to negate it. Also, aiming with turrets at small targets can be a nuisance if they start maneuvering above or below you.Other than, a well spent 20 bucks. I've paid $40+ for a lot less entertaining crapware. If you enjoy Spacey, shiny thing. Get this damn game! You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Boring and buggy as hell. You are going to die a lot, and it's not because the little fighters have more firepower than you, but because of atmosphere that will destroy your ship in the middle of space, or some 20 clicks from a moon, yes a moon, smaller than your ship, and destroys you with its atmosphere. Or because of Militia suddenly turning on you and killing you with 20 ships as soon as you've completed the mission to help them rid of pirates, etc... etc...It is a nicely presented game with noobish bugs and ideas. Also the game was designed for a console and it plays like this on the PC too. Pretty annoying! The camera which is changing view randomly as it feels the need, and not letting you decide what you want to see on the screen is a hell to work with. The story is boring, the missions are repetitive, and all of the same sort. You basically almost have to fight or run, no matter what mission is it. The guilds are just an extension of the mission system, and nothing else. All in all, this game, if expanded upon, would be great, but it looks like it's unfinished, with development cut short before major features were added.

												It looked fun at first, but I got sick of it very quickly. The manually targeted weapon that your ship has is utterly useless compared to the autoaiming laser turrets you can get - or even the mining laser. Missiles are completely useless. It is really annoying to have to dock all the time instead of doing 4-5 missions at once, just because of the risk that some encouter would be too hard. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												The best way to describe this game, I think, is to imagine a simplified Freelancer that doesn't take itself nearly as seriously. It has this sort of disjointed western-slash-Caribbean pirate theme to it that works brilliantly in its favor, lending a much needed injection of comic-book stylization to the genre of space trade & combat sim. The voice acting is good enough not to be grating or distracting, which is great. What's a little less great (but maybe not by a lot) is the two-dimensional flight. Again, simplified. A 6DOF shooter, this is not. If you can do naval combat, you will probably do fine here. To me, this makes the game feel a little strange, not being able to fly up or down in space. But not a deal breaker. The soundtrack is very fun and unique, but some of the tracks end up sounding a little same-y after a few hours. Gameplay pacing moves about the same as Freelancer, so if you enjoyed that title, you will probably feel justified in spending full price on this one. If you're expecting a fast-paced space shooter, maybe wait until it goes on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27
												Rebel Galaxy: Ah what a fine Adventure made by 2x Developers :) Imagine a Firefly Space Adventure with Mass Effect's space flight bits and the naval combat from AC: Black Flag. You can trade, mine or fight & each one has it's affect from Rp point of view. For example, let's say you are bringing food to a station in famine: you can increase your profit by blowing up relief ships heading to the station (or not). You can negotiate your way out of fights by dropping cargo, bribe officials to smuggle illegal goodies out of a station :P Definitely Worth a buy at full price for ppl who enjoy this Genre & why not for newcomers heh. Pirates & Aliens fighting with the player in the mid. Add a bit of mining & different upgrades for ship & there's decent Low Budget Space Flight Boom Boom :) Liked the sideways navy-like battles. Your actions affect your reputation with the citizenry, the militia & various Pirate Factions. Series of story missions take you from one side of the sector to another & each mission, main or side is marked with its "risk level". That Allows you to judge whether to take it & do right away or take some time to upgrade your equipment first. Soundtrack in Rebel Galaxy is Atmospheric, Real gritty & includes world country rock tunes. Soundtrack had big impact on my decision whether to buy RG when watched the Trailer :) Paid full price at Steam & happy for supporting Devs :) Only 2x Negative things to say are: Can't Look Map inside Station & Can't use "Engage Warp" Keybind separated from Interact Key. For ex: Using Tractor Beam to take items. Frustrating as need to wait to pass some item(s) floating in space or take them before can activate Warp. Also sometimes "Engage Warp" Pops to screen with delay. Not good when in rush to catch Pirate Lord or in a hurry to save some Ally. Minor things ofc so didn't ruin Goodiness lvl :) Ppl who look for a well engaging story aren't going to find one, but the characters have tons of personality & story is ok :) This is good work as 1st adventure from Double Damage games. Devs put a lot of heart into this & can be seen. RG's Fine Tunes: http://rebel-galaxy.com/the-rebel-galaxy-soundtrack/My High School Review 8.5 / 10Enjoy the Flights :)

												I know it isn't technically a RPG but it feels like a RPG. And it is a short RPG at that. This is a good thing. If you don’t want 100+h RPGish game this is a good game for you. The gameplay loop, trade/do missions -> buy new/better gear -> repeat, sustains the game for the duration.  At the last main story mission, I felt satisfied. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												This game is both oddly addictive and frustrating.  Hours of play go by without me noticing, but every time something annoys - combat mechanics, navigation, etc.  The good:Right out of the gate, you can do stuff.  You’re not limping around with crappy, starter equipment very long. The first couple missions are just challenging enough, and give you a decent reward to do some upgrades.  There’s no dishonor in running away from fights until you get good enough equipment to fight back.It’s really is immersive, and I love that you can play your own custom soundtrack which enhances that. I haven’t done much with the main story yet, having too much fun tooling around the galaxy doing side missions and exploring stuff.  Equipment upgrades don’t depreciate, so you can sell them back for the same as the purchase price.  This is great when you’re starting out and just figuring out the game mechanics.  It eliminates those costly newbie mistakes that handicap you as you advance.The annoying:Some of the mechanics clunky.  For example: When mining, you blow up the asteroid then have to go hunting for what pops out using the pulse feature, boost your way to the loot (being careful not to overshoot it), then painstakingly angle into the sweet spot that will auto trigger your tractor beam. I’d really like to be able to target stuff manually and then grab it. I have to agree with other reviews about the lack of Y axis. It is really frustrating, particularly in a big firefight when you have a swarm of nimble enemy fighters attacking you at all angles, disappearing along the vertical just as you go to nail them and all you can do swing from side to side, waiting for them to get back to the horizontalDifficulty ratings are a crap shoot as far as accuracy.  I’ve gotten my tail kicked on a “low” risk mission and blown right through a “high” risk mission.Misc:The game doesn’t recognize my Xbox 360 wireless controller (which works with other Steam games), but does recognize my old Logitech F310 USB gamepad.  I find that handles the game better than K&M.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												The Good:*Combat, while limited by the "age of sail" mentality and 3rd person view, is quite entertaining.*Piracy, through force or "persuasion". Nothing more entertaining or profitable than stealing from the trader you are escorting.*Exploration can be quite captivating thanks to being set in space.The Bad:*Obvious console port with minimal mouse utility in menus.*Nausiating edge scroll turret aiming and disorienting auto tracking.*Semi-fixed distance 3rd person view which can only be changed in menu, not on the fly.*3D mining from a 2D plane can be frustrating as nodes can be difficult to aim at depending on turret configuration.*RPG elements are minimal involving buying upgrades for one's ship, mostly linear, and fulfilling quests to receive mutually exclusive bonuses.*Inability to scroll through one's weapons, can only select weapon groups be it ballistic, flak, laser, or the various missile types, making it impossible to see beneath one's ship to personally aim at fighters.The Ugly:*Trading, I swear the comerce AI is programed to to drop the prices wherever you go making it nearly impossible to make money through trading outside of special events such as Famine.*Diplomacy, nearly non-existant beyound scaring off weaker enemies (kinda pointless) or dumping one's cargo to appease pirates (rarely worth it), and no way to improve relations beyound fulfilling quests for the five main factions (takes too long) or responding to distress signals (can be risky early on), and no way to improve relations with the minor factions.*The Grell, ugly♥♥♥♥♥fish ♥♥♥♥ers with frankly overpowered ships who swim in schools, avoid at all costs until very late game.Despite the overwhelming negativity presented above, I still enjoy the game and would recommend it, so long as it's on sale.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												While the story is pretty barebones, the combat and the music is where this game is at. I've now spent 18 hours roaming the galaxy, and while I can understand people saying it's repetitive, I really enjoy the space-trucking, Jim-Raynor-space-combow feel to this game. Some people compare it to Assassins Creed 4's naval combat (that games single strengh, IMO), and while this is certainly a obvious comparison, I actually think that the combat in this game is better, as there are multiple types of weapons for different situations.I got this on a 33% sale, but I would easily recommend this game at full price.EDIT: after 34 hours, I feel I can say with certainty that I'm done with the game. I finished the last mission, and while I still could max out the biggest, most badass ship out there, I'm not compelled to do so. All in all a good game by it's own, and when you factor in the relatively low entry price, it's a no-brainer.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												This game represents everything that's right about games.A couple of guys named Erich Schaefer and Travis Baldree put this thing together. Between the two of them, they've had a hand in Fate, Mythos, Diablo II, and Torchlight. If you liked those games, and have played Freelancer or the little known Escape Velocity, this game should be an instant buy. Even if you haven't played space based ARPGs, you should buy this game.Why? It feels good to play, and everything in the game is secondary to it feeling good to play. That's how it represents everything that's right about games: it focuses on playing as being the critical element. The controls, sounds, and looks of the game come together to make it feel like you're playing something that's meant, designed, and created to be played, above all else. What really drives the game is the desire to kill things and become space rich, so you can kill stronger things and become even more space rich. It's the drive to kill, loot, and kill and loot even more that keeps the player going.If you're into narrative heavy games, then you probably should pass on this. The story is campy, and not something that you'll remember for crazy plot twists or complex drama. But it's just interesting enough to keep you moving forward.Rebel Galaxy has some sim-lite features, though not especially fleshed out. A player can disrupt a trade convoy, which keeps supplies low and prices high at a station. Or they can break through a blockade, and exploit the need for supplies to work towards becoming space rich.Looking forward, this game provides a solid foundation for further features to be developed. I think this has a lot of potential to become an even better game, with deeper complexities driving the sim-lite features.Really though, if you played and loved kill & loot driven games like Diablo II & Torchlight, or especially if you have played Freelancer or Escape Velocity... you need to buy this.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												TL;DRIf you like economics / 2D naval style combat / challenge, get this game.It's worth more than you're paying.Pros:This game feels highly polished for the ~$20 price tag.Economics function quite well, are not random, and you can earn Credits fairly quickly once you see the patterns. (i.e. if there's a Militia Embargo on an outpost, bring it military style products for a nice profit)The ships are interesting and specialized. You feel accomplished when you get the next awesome ship and throw some killer components on it.Computer requirements are well within reach for most PC gamers.^>It feels very optimized and lag is infrequent.The graphics aren't comparable to BF4 but, it's a very pretty game.The story, though not entirely compelling at first, is well written as are the characters for their minimalistic impact on the game.There's been ZERO glitching. That's just fantastic.Cons:Difficulty may seem overwhelming at first but, you'll quickly understand the importance of picking your battles and what upgrades are needed. Until you learn to broadside properly, high-range turrets will be your best friend.I can't really think of any others at the moment. I've been having a really good time. :)Suggestions:Co-op Play would be EPIC in larger scale confrontations.When on the Commodity Window make a sortable LIST of the other outposts you've visited and their pricing instead of the slow "here's the price at this location" rotation. I've spent far too much time just sitting in my chair waiting for the outpost i want to see prices for pop up without having to go back into space and look at it on my map.The distance between the sides of your ship and stellar masses when trying to warp is too great. Front space is wonderful but, if i can turn my Radovich completely sideways and not hit what made my warp stop that's a problem.Also, a question to the Devs;Did a few members of your team REALLY enjoy "Armada" for the Dreamcast? Because this feels like what that game should have been. I loved that game when it came out and put far too much time into it and this feels heavily influenced by it.Comp specs:AMD FX-6300 OC'd to 4.5GHzRadeon R9 280 OC'd to 280x specsUltra setting, Full Screen, 1080p = 140FPS most of the time.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Followed this game during it's development and was intrigued by it's take on a navel-style broad side combat. I know some might want verticle access for combat but honestly, this game doesn't need it. If you're familiar with the ship combat in Assassin's Creed: Black Flag then you'll know exactly how this game plays. The game is packed full of side quests, your classic fetch, eliminate, gather and escort. Several factions exist and many are joinable, some at war with one another so there is a sense of choice but it's not very deep. There's plenty of freedom, being a pirate is entirely possible but expect resistence.The sound for this game is great, from the mechanical vibrations, rising whurrs and powerful sounding blasts, it all feels very appropriate to the space exploration theme. With a very firefly esque feel to the music, you get that space-cowboy feeling right off the bat. There's an option to add your own easily, if you prefer as well.People looking for an extremely rich story and lore, incredibly complex combat mechanics and deep reputation based faction reputation systems might be a little disappointed, Rebel Galaxy certainly has these things but they're light. Overall, this a great 20 hour game with outstanding sound, combat and just enough exploration and progress to keep you going to the end. I wish there was a little more to story and lore but overall, I can't explain. If you can grab it on sale, totally worth it.

content:
Posted: February 18
												After careful consideration, I can't recommend this game as it stands. It has a lot of potential, but due to various bugs and imbalances it fails to live up to that potential. The system it uses to classify mission difficulties is spotty (some very high risk missions are easy, while some low risk missions are very difficult). Escort missions are extremely buggy: escorts path back and forth regularly, they have almost no armor and NPCs don't have aggro tables AFAIK, if you engage personal warp for even a moment you immediately fail the escort. Some missions have you kill another faction's ships with no warning, so it's tricky to farm faction rep when a mercenary guild mission for 15 rep might have you killing merchant guild ships and losing 30 rep with them. On top this, it's extremely grindy. Get to a system, buy modules that are ~50% stronger than the ones you entered the system with, move to the next system since all the content in that system is obsolete now. Aside from the story, it's the same missions grinded over and over. "Go here and kill these two groups of enemies" "Escort this trade prince to that station" "Take this cargo from point A to point B". Honestly, this feels like a game that someone worked long and hard on, but then 80% of the way in they decided they needed to wrap it up ASAP and filled the last 20% with hollow, paper mache content. For the first 10 hours or so it was fun, but once you realize that it's just going to be the same recycled grind over and over it leaves you with a sinking feeling of "why am I still doing this?"

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Shallow.On the surface this game is fantastic. I want to love it. The soundtrack makes you feel like a space cowboy right at the main menu. The designs manage to sell you on this gritty space society without feeling messy or cluttered. The gameplay premiss seems like a fresh twist on a working concept... and here things fall apart.It has an interesting idea of broadside combat in a freelancer type space sim, but it fails to achieve either. Whatever there is to master in this game is mastered in under an hour, and it basically comes down to "have bigger guns and better shields". Any fancy manouvers will only give the enemy time to recharge their shields or let them turn their undamaged sides towards you. Just fly up and hammer them harder while your turrets autoshoot any fighters. After that you just repeat the same interactions over and over to earn cash towards upgrades that add +stat% . You can feel safe taking any mission that has a danger rating you've dealt with before, because they scale with you and nothing ever changes.Even more dissapointing is the fact that there is virtually no point or reason to fight or do missions as it's slow and tedious, forcing you to cover large distances of empty space. Just find the trade route that is currently most profitable per minute and fly it back and forth until it drains to make atleast 10x in an hour what you could have gotten from missions during the same time. This way you'll never make enemies either!Also, dont buy anything but cargo or cargospace boosts.♥♥♥♥♥♥is super expensive and serves no point. You basically don't have to fight ever if your goal is to become the biggest bad♥♥♥♥♥in space. Some light shields and an engine will do fine! Any investments in your ship will just take money away from buying up expensive cargo. Then, when you made all the money there is to make from trade runs where you interact with absolutely no one... buy the most expensive♥♥♥♥♥♥you can find. Voila! You are now the best at this game and nothing can hurt you!The best part? Maybe you got a bit eager and there was more money to be made? Bigger ships to be found? Better guns? And now all you trading captial is gone? NO PROBLEM! Just sell all your ship parts AT COST and become a peacful trader again. You could just do this at any point when you wanted to actually kill something. You never have to feel invested in anything! Choices have no consequence or impact. Life is great in space! Except for all that emptyness and boredom you will feel. They really captured that part...

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												This is a FUN game. Very Fun!   I keep looking for the single ultimate magic answer for my space game hunger.  The more games I try, the more clear it becomes: there is no answer - there are many different answers, each answering in a slightly different way.. and some answer better than others.  Rebel Galaxy is one Very Good answer!  I may not yet have spent quite as much time in this game as in some of my other favorites (X3AP, Rebirth, Evochron, Starsector, Endless Sky, SPG2, Freelancer, iWar2) - but I have enjoyed every single minute of it!  Its fun and refreshing and easy to sink your teeth into, and has a great space swashbuckler feel to it.  Rebel Galaxy is a great game and I happily recommend it.  There's also something to be said for the modesty of it - a great value that kinda flies under the radar, and doesn't seem to get the applause it deserves.  Other reviews and the description will give you a pretty good idea what it's about.  I just wanted to give a quick thumbs-up, as I've been meaning to for about a year.  The idea of Freelancer + Firefly gives a good general sense of gameplay and theme.  At first I was reluctant due to the 'flat space' nature of it, but it turns out it just feels right - and fresh, and fun.  Anyway - if there's (hopefully!) any DLC or a RG2, I'll be all over it, instantly, no questions asked.  Not many games have earned that kind of trust!  Well done Dev's, thanks for a Fun game - and I really hope you have more of this yet to come in the not too distant future!

												So far from my limited playtime, I can already tell it will be one of those "I'm only playing it because I am bored" type of games. Right from the get-go the menu does not use the mouse (it has some in-game menu use, but it is very buggy)...obvious console port. Overall I would say just wait for a sale or don't buy it at all.Gunplay: 4/10It is very annoying to shoot enemies with your broadside cannons because they lock on to targets, so you are not really aiming. Same with the turret and missiles. Sometimes the aiming redicle will lock up when trying to aim due to it trying to stick on to a different enemy. The gunplay just isn't fun.Graphics: 8/10The game looks nice, but at first glance it seems much older than 2015. Still, good or bad graphics don't determine a game's quality. Story: 7/10The story line is neat, but right from the start it gets predictable. Also, most missions are "Hey, you! Go run over there and shoot something for me, thanks." You go do the mission, return, and then do it all over again. Also, all stations are the same (not externally or main characters, but the generic character models and interior is all the same).

												Definitely the best space game since Freelancer. I've been waiting years for something similar to Freelancer and this does not disappoint. It has broadside combat for the most part, which is pretty fun once you get used to it. My only complaints so far are that there are not a wide array of ships to choose from. I think I've seen 5 so far. There are also huge ships that the enemies have with smaller fighter ships that surround them in combat but you cannot use one of these ships. Other than that the game is pretty awesome. I'm really enjoying it and look forward to finishing up a gameplay as the good guy so I can be a pirate in the next round.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												A space fighter/flight game is an itch that has gone unscratched for a very long time and for a very simple reason; They’re not terribly user friendly to start with. They're mostly varying flavors of spreadsheets and menus.Rebel Galaxy avoids this problem by... not being a very complicated game. It’s stuck on a single flight platform which completely omits the need for severe flight tactics, and is instead comparable to Assassin’s Creed: Black Flag’s style of naval combat, down to the similarly used “Broadside” cannons. After that, it’s a matter of strategically placing some of your turrets as they autofire at your enemies while you control one, usually some type of rapidfire thing to cut through your enemies.Enemy ships, usually the small fighters, tend to have access to the 3D plane which is not as much of a problem as you might expect as it usually just means you need to plan your position to open fire. Again, your guns can shoot them depending on placement.Meanwhile it has a sort of MMO-like questing style of clearing enemies, shipping goods, defending traders, as well as a story mode. I actually have a lot of fun just ignoring the main quest (As you do), running around making ALL the money, upgrading my ship, and having a giggle when my main quest’s risk rating reads “Very Low”.As an aside; The music is wonderful and it took considerable resistance not to name my ship “Serenity”. It’s got a couple hours of full length (~3 minute) songs that will change in space stations or open battles which helps mix it up a bit.If I had a complaint, it’s probably that there’s not too much to do mid flight. Mid transit, there’s not a lot of popups when you’re fighting thousands of whatever-unit-of-distance it’s using. It amounts to three things interrupting your warp speed: Distress Signals, Ambushes, and Asteroid Fields/Nebulas. Beyond those, you might want to stop to play some piracy and raid trading convoys that go between space stations, which manipulates the market for you to take advantage of. I just wish there was more to do when I'm aiming for an objective that's tens of thousands of whatever-unit-of-distances away.Ultimately, it’s nice to find a space game that I can be moderately good at. Everything is put together pretty well, and while some may call it too simple; I find it works in the game's favor. Space games these days feel the need to overcomplicate themselves, and Rebel Galaxy avoids that.

												As much as I wish there were more ships and  verticle maneuverability, I have a hard time not loving this game. It's almost everything I was looking for in Elite Dangerous. With Increasing difficulty as you progress and scaling rewards from missions, this game scratches an itch that no other game could reach.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												This game brings to mind a delicious combination of Battlestar Galactica, Star Trek, Spaghetti Westerns, Wild West Novels, the Imperial Navy from Warhammer 40,000, and Battlefleet Gothic. But I'll be sure to be more cohesive at this point. Firstly, the music is great. As in, bloody fantastic, perfect, chill-inducingly delectable. It makes me so happy to hear a westernized form of country again, even if it is more modern. It practically makes me weep with joy and happiness. The music guides you along a beautiful path of twisted flaming wreckage and bloody gorepiles in space of the helpless rended limb from limb by a cascade from your turret networks. Truly, it makes me nearly froth with inarticulate rage and glory, my blood flowing in great cascades from my eyelids to hear this music. I would rate it a 7/10 or even 8/10 if I am particularly in the moment.Next we have the gameplay, an enormous bulky monster that growls across the scarred membranes of your cerebral cortex. First of all, it is weighty. I feel as if I am a space marine interred in a mighty dreadnaught of the God Emperor of the Mandkind whenever I go into warp, barreling on to my inevitable destination and perhaps description. Secondly, the combat makes my eyes burn with the dancing hatred of a thousand devils, shewn from the eternal Blood War by a great swathe of undead demons lead by Orcus himself. I revel in the heinous and most deliciously extensive.  The pound of my ordnance and turretry as I combat the vile hordes of heretics and pirate scum makes me giggle as a mentally deranged serial killer escaped from Alcatraz. Truly, this game excels in its gameplay.Finally, as I must say, the westernized feel bleeds over heavily into the characters, making for interesting dialogue and contact with either unknown xeno scum or unwashed and mangy of hide baffoons. As the clink of aged coin, illicit goods, or untold amounts of credits flow from my scabrous hands as we exchange evil pleasantries and oafish camaraderie. I can do nothing but appreciate this.I recommend this game highly my battle brothers, my dark souled companions, my vicious murderers and my fellow hiver scum.  You will do no better on this day if you seek endless battle, horrific suffering, and countless bouts of larcency, lies, and lack of litigious action. “The past shall consume the future, the dead shall consume the living, and chaos shall reign supreme!”--- Unicron

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Love it.I've played it for quite a while now, and I love what they have done with the atmosphere and the battles. If there was an expansion, I would definitely buy it, as I just completed the main story. I am going to play more, try other storylines, perhaps try a bit of trading and even a bit of piracy.So, the parts with potential for improvements:I wish there were more setting for the stupid mercenary ship, such as "protect me, don't go running off on your own to die". That's not really a big deal though, I can always get more mercenaries, they don't seem to understand that it is certain death to sign up with me.The missions have no deadline, such as there is in Elite Dangerous, and that means there is also no real rush. If you have accepted a mission, you can probably wait until next year before you complete it, no matter what the description says.So, I would like more rush, and more stories to complete. And perhaps a reason to get out of my destroyer and into something bigger.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												Freelancer with badass capital ships.   Absolutely spectacular experience crafted predominantly by two (!!) geniuses.  Trade, pirate, mine, bounty hunt and complete various types of missions in a procedurally generated universe for cash.  Use that cash to buy a bigger and meaner ship and/or choose from tons of interesting and tactical diverse upgrades.   Topped with very deep and visceral combat that has juuust the right balance of automated and skill based systems.  Bottom line:  No game has ever captured capital spaceship combat quite like Rebel Galaxy and I can't wait to see where the devs take the series.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												I didn't know quite what to expect. But from the trailer it looked like it would be an absolute wild ride.It is.I don't know what pulled me in more: The incredible soundtrack, which while somewhat short, never ever got old and always pumped me up for taking on a whole enemy flotilla single-handedly while being completely out-classed and out-gunned. Or the visuals which are stunning from the very beginning. This game has hit a perfect spot of being scifi and western: a playable Firefly. It keeps you enthralled even after you finish the story. The developers really hit spot on on the idea of purely enjoyable gameplay. It's not complex and convoluted. It's not necessarily simple either. you have to think about how you approach your enemy. What weapons are best, do you go with massive firepower or shield and hull strength? A middle ground? How can a small cruiser take on a dreadnought 5 times it's size without getting obliterated? There are a couple pseudo-downsides, other than the (epic) short soundtrack, The first somewhat downside to this game is that because it's their first one (as far as i can tell), they weren't able to make it bigger, or the story longer. There isn't much character development, however they put a LOT of thought into what was there, such as if you listen to the alien languages, you can actually pick up what words mean what in the translations. I'm a language nerd and that scored MAJOR points for me.The other downside is that you have to get used to it not being a 'realistic' space game, since you are playing on a flat plane, you cannot do spins or attack from above or below as you would imagine being able to in theoretical 'real' space combat.But the gameplay is so fun that, at least for myself, i completely discarded that particular misgiving and simply had fun with it.This is quite honestly one of the best games i've played in YEARS, i can't recommend it more.This is one of the few games where not only do i WANT more, i NEED more.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Such a fun game. Compared to other space titles around at the time, Elite, Star Citizen, Star Conflict, No Man's Sky, and a host of others surfacing and submerging, this game stands out first to me the fact that it's single player. Shock horror. If you can get over that, it's fantastic.     I can't stress enough what a masterpiece the devs have done as far as software goes. Produced in a ridiculously short time, by the guys that brought us diablo, and then torchlight. Install's 2Gb, and run's so smooth even on a low end laptop. Has controller support, also (personally i love the controller controls on this title, well thought out, the commands are simple enough to just get stuck in). The controls overall aren't gratuitously complex. There aren't as many menus to cycle through as other games, and this doesn't feel like a bad thing, or that you're missing things. The combat is great fun. Winning or losing, it just FEELS good, with an awesome soundtrack to accompany it. Basically, in my view, while i enjoy say, elite, for a long term, "sim", this is arcade. It's pick up and play, blast a few minutes out and achieve something. It doesn't have so much replayability for me personally, but for the 1 playthrough alone, it was worth every penny. While writing this i genuinely am getting a hankering to play it again some time, so, i guess it has some replayability factor afterall. I'm not sure what else is important in a review.... it's smooth as hell to play, bug free (i'm aware that of course there'll be bugs these days in most titles, but i haven't found any thing i'd call a bug. The forums are well maintained and there's few bug reports from people with competant brain cells, if any, that haven't been addressed and long fixed. There will always be a vocal few that want to run across a open room in a shooter, towards an enemy sniper, head on, without jinking, get shot in the head, and complain that the sniper rifle is OP, and game breaking. Welcome to the internet. It's bug free, fun to play, great soundtrack, cheap game even when not on offer, looks great on not so great machines. Cons? Can't play with friends. Oh well, they'd only mess things up.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												The game is basically meditation (flying) punctuated by spur of the moment naval-broadside combat (your capital ship versus pirates). The core narrative and the bartenders (talk to them at each station) breathe life into the game. The music while flying around at warp speed has been a really relaxing experience (something I rarely want from a game, but it works here).Also: I\'ve seen a lot of people trying to make Firefly references and I can tell you this game has nothing to do with Firefly aside from the space cowboy music and that you happen to be a captain of your own ship. There\'s nothing in the galaxy or story that is similar and you won\'t have a big crew of interesting people (which is what made Firefly the show that it is).Play the game for what it is: space trading with naval broadside combat. If that sounds interesting, I think you\'ll find your money well spent (especially if you pick it up on sale).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Oh my, what fun!So I read the reviews with people saying this game is like a mix of Freelancer, Firefly and Assassins Creed IV (the naval combat sections) and I guess those are pretty good comparison.The game certainly has the Freelancer vibe, with an open universe, optional story-line, combat, trading, rep/guild affiliation etc.The Firefly comparisons I think stem mainly from the music, but given you are flying a large vessel (not a smaller fighter) you do feel like you are captaining a ship with crew. and yes, you can 'aim to misbehave'Combat and travel is strictly 2D, but before you judge that too harshly, it plays our like ship combat from AC IV, with broadside combat being the order of the day. And it WORKS!It actually reminds me of the animated movie Treasure Planet a bit. Oh yeah, I am totally now a space pirate! Controller support is well implemented and I don't need to touch my keyboard to play (other than to hit 'play').Just shy of 2 hours in and barely scratched the surface, but based on what I have seen so far, this game could charge at least double the current price and still be good value.Recommended.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												If you're gonna get this game you should really know what you're getting in to. The combat could be fun for some, but to me it's dull, unintuitive and lacks depth of any kind. It's not about skill it's all about your gear.The missions are uninspiring and feel like quests in MMOs, that would've been fine if not for the fact that this is a single player gane and I expect more from it.The story wasn't too gripping at first but there might be some people who are really interested by it.The travelling is boring and takes waaaaaaay too long.The soundtrack is good though so I give it a plus there, the voice acting is also good and there seems to be put in a lot of effort there.Do your research before buying the game, this is a very unique game... For good or bad (With my taste it's bad bu tI can see where others find the appeal).All in all I'd say this is a very niche game, but if you're looking for a star citizen or elite dangerous type of game this is not it.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												You've played Freelancer, right? That's the comparison you'll hear the most often. Take Freelancer, make it prettier, remove actual free flying and exploration, muddy the PC port waters with a UI that isn't really comfortable away from a gamepad, and tack on an atrocious blues/country rock soundtrack choking on its own distortion. That's Rebel Galaxy. I get the feeling they wanted to make a naval combat game, but decided spaceships were cooler than boats, and set it in space instead. It helps to imagine the entire gameplay area as a giant, flat, invisible ocean, and you're just floating on the surface -- planets and bases are nothing but islands to stop at or maneuver around. Other ships can go above or below or around you, but you're stuck on the surface, plunking away with broadside guns and the occasional turret. Homeworld's map screen alone has more maneuverability options than this entire game.Gameplay-wise, you just do the typical Freelancer things: Visit space stations, accept jobs to improve/diminish faction reputation, occasionally pick up a plot-related mission, collect resources, trade commodities, earn money, upgrade your ship, wash, rinse, repeat.Mercifully, the music can be disabled.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
 20€ for some dry bones As far as i know, it was the devs first game ever, developed by a single guy. So i guess 99% of development time was spent into the graphics.The game has a big world. Big and really empty. Rarely you´l find a convoy or pirates, thats it.Trading system is basic. VERY basic.Battles are 2D. In Space. No joke. And basic. Lock target, charge shot for some seconds, fire. Assasins Creed 4 made more fun.Theres no boarding. No killing shields or engines. You can only target the ship directly or some additional turrets, if its one of the bigger ones.Story is also basic. Nothing impressive. Found someone on the forums who finished it in 13 hours.All in all, the game is nothing but grinding the same missions all over again until you can afford gear for the next area, then its grinding again.As you can figure, once the short story is done, thats it. Nothing more to do. Not that you need to, but you also couldnt even be a pirate afterwards, cause theres no booty in empty universe. Just very rare miners or freighters, whic you cant board, that drop one or two units of cargo after getting destroyed.And during all that time you hear nothing but that sh*tty rock-soundtrack. Thank god you can replace it with custom sounds. CONCLUSION: Nice foundation made out of expensive, snow-white marble. Too bad construction stopped right here and the house was never build.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												First and foremost I'm not a paid reviewer/streamer/critic or any of that. I was blessed enough to receive a key for free eventhough I will buy multiple copies of this for my family/friends. Just being upfront about it but I played in the beta and pre-release so my review is coming from all my experience with the game. Now onto the review. Ever since the rlease of Freelancer on PC way back in 2000, I have been aching for a new space sim experience. If your like me and also have that itch then look no further. This game has pirating/trading/looting/mining/space battles.... a whole slew of things you can do in the sandbox that they have created for you. There are several systems or galaxies in which you traverse and have jump gates to connect them. Each system has its own factions with which to either befriend or destroy. You have a main story but also space stations with side missions along with the included Trading/Mining/Mercenary guilds which also provide missions. These three factions also provide unique ships, weapons, shields, and other things to outfit your ship. The combat is likened to naval style (think Assassins Creed Black Flag ship battles) and its set on a 2d plane. The art style, ship design, space backdrops are all top notch. The audio is also one thing that is a step above. The soundtrack alone warrants a look at this game. It gives the feel of a space fairing outlaw lol. Think Firefly, Han Solo, Cowboy Bebop, Outlaw Star vibe. The sounds of the weapons firing gives a sense of real power and gurth behind each barrage launched from your broadside cannons. The best sound to me is when your FTL drive spools up and then hits warp.This game has been on my radar for some time now as my top 5 most anticipated games of 2015. I knew that Travis and Erich who left Runic Games to establish Double Damage wouldn't let me down. If you have any interest, what are you waiting for help these two Devs out by purchasing this amazing experience! I know I will be purchasing copies for my friends and family and for only 20$ US you can't beat that deal. The price for value is one of the best of 2015 alone. Do your self a favor and play it.

Posted: July 12, 2016
												Hours 0-2: What's with this ridiculous 2D battle system?Hours 3-4: Okay, I'm getting the hang of it, but the music is really repetitive.Hours 5-6: This is pretty fun. Controls take some getting used to. Odd design choice, but I can dig it. Gorgeous!Hours 7-8: Alright, now we're getting somewhere. Guild membership, a couple new ships, winning tougher battles. Let's hit that next star system. Can't wait to see what it looks like. Hopefully some new tunes too.Hour 9: Every mission available in second star system rated as "Very Difficult" and higher; every mission available in first star system rated as easy. Same repetitive butt-rock sountrack in the second star system, and one star system looks the same as the next.Verdict: Never played a space game that felt less like space than this one. Really sorry I bought it.

												I really wanted to like this game, it is almost good. I got this after reading the Freelancer comparisons, but this game is not even close to it, it doesnt have the combat dynamism as it is naval based combat instead of fighter ships, nor the story pacing which helps improve your vessel before main missions, its more of go on playing until you get into a snafu.I specially don't like the combat, to me it feels grindy instead of tense and fun, there's no going up or down, it is a 2D flight system while some enemies have the freedom to move into the third dimension and even though it may fit the naval combat system, it feels weird.It has to be said that it is a great game to have been developed by a two man team, but it falls short of what one may expect after a Freelancer comparison, sadly it is kind of misleading and a video about the combat system would help clear things up.If you like Freelacer type games and think you may like the naval combat system a la ACIII+ ship combats, you should at least try this. content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												A non-biased quick look @ the Game:


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Rebel Galaxy' (GeForce GT 640, Win 10) 

			Views: 190		

			This game is available here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/290300 MASSIVE THANKS TO THE DEV'S FOR THE STEAM REVIEW COPY!		

One of the best space adventures I've played in 2015.... don't miss this gem of a game. Rebel Galaxy is a swashbuckling space adventure, with action-packed combat, exploration, discovery, trade, and “negotiation” with the outlandish denizens at the edge of the known universe. As the commander of an immensely powerful star destroyer, you’ll battle pirates, explore anomalies, befriend aliens, scavenge battle wreckage, mine asteroids, and discover artifacts. Choose your path as a roguish do-gooder, crafty space-trader or power-hungry privateer – or maybe a little of each! Buy larger and more powerful craft with your hard-earned credits, and outfit them with a variety of wicked weapons and defenses. Set in a galaxy of fantastic sights, and secrets to be found, Rebel Galaxy is above all a space epic of adventure, exploration, and combat. The edge of the universe is a pretty dangerous place, so watch your back. - Highly Recommended!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												I've had more fun in the first five hours of playing this game than I have had in a long time. Combining elements from many beloved titels across genres, Rebel Galaxy is what you're looking for. It's 2D approach to space combat leaves your focusing on tactical options and attacks instead of trying to orient yourself constantly like in other games such as Elite: Dangerous. Thatisn't to be said that movement can't be still be a challenge. When you add in the need to manage weapon types against mixed engagements -- which are almost always the case. In these clashes you will face one or several other capital ships and a wide variety of fighter and gunship craft. The former come in a nice mix -- you don't know if the next capital ship you are going to run into will be an up close brawler or a ranged homing missle boat. The sub-capital ships although substatially lower defenses still provide pressure on the player. In swarms fighters can effectively dodge in and out of turret arcs if they aren't focused on. Gunships, on the other hand, pack a punch in a small size. A group of these gunships can be as dangerous as some campital ships.I speak of the wide range of encounters the player can have but the variety doesn't end there. Consider the different armerments that any one ship can use. Will you use a long range anti-captial ship guns paired with swarm missle launchers or will you choose some beefy in-your-face anti-capitals paired with several flak turrets? The number of combinations doens't end there. Each turret location on your ship can be outfitted with a different type of turret. If you sesired, you could put to gether a kitchen-sink styple ship!Beyond the mechanics of combat Rebel Galaxy also gives you the freedom to choose the type of contracts you take on. If you are able to plan ahead you can take several missions and set up a somewhat efficent flight path. The mission types tend to fall into a few different catagories; courier, defense, elimitatie, dead drop (recovery), or collection. Although mission fall into these catagories as a rule, the way each unfolds is randomly generated to keep you on your toes. If jumping mission to mission isn't your thing or you just want a break, you can also do some margin trading or mining.The tradeing consists of transporting goods between locations in hopes of turning a profit. This seems simple, but a host of factors will influence your success or failure. The way time works in Rebel Galaxy has what seem like short warps between locations to having passed several days. This leads to a an amount of uncertainy of a fluctuating market shortly after you've left. Random events will also add a little spice to the mix. These events allow you to swoop in and pick up goods when they are over-saturated or drop your goods into a starving market. Ships in Rebel Galaxy also have a fairly limited cargo hold. So, no running around the system with vast amounts of cargo in your hold just waiting for the opportunity to offload it onto a waitting market.The difficulty that Rebel Galaxy provides is a welcome change to the modern status quo. Rather than needing to set a arbitrary difficulty setting you need simply get yourself in hot water by approaching a mission or location that's rated "Risk: High". This nice little warning suggests what you'll find will be a distinct challenge no matter your tactics or fit. At noumerous times during my play, I found myself feeling quite the force to be rekoned with. After rolling through enimies and dispatching them in a short time I presumred I was the big man in the system. Then I was ambushed in mid warp. I thought to myself, 'I've been killing everything iwth no problem; this area is probably too easy for my current skill." I was so wrong. The three capital ships and a  few squadrons of gunships ensured that my growing ego was quite deflated. Although I could have, after being ppulled from warp, turned and ran to safety, I instead engaged foolishly and committed to a fight I couldn't win.To sum it up, if you enjoy space combat sims like Freespace, Elite:Dangerous, ando thers this game will provide a refreshing spin on the favorite genre. As you challenge yourself with different play styles and different engagements you will be rewarded with the uncertainty of your success while being excited to try again after your ship explodes. For a standard price of $20, I would buy this game twice. Enjoy.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												I was really looking forward to playing this game. The first time I saw it, I thought "This looks so cool, must be hell of a lot of fun". The atmosphere, the particals, the spaceship battles, etc. When I bought it during the summer sale, it was one of the first game (of the 10 that I bought) that I installed, just to get disappointed. The game didn't launch for me. So I uninstalled it. I later upgraded my OSX (yes, I am on Mac) for Smite and decided, why don't give it a second try? So I reinstalled it, and launched the game again. It froze on the Titlescreen. I had to restart my PC, then it finally worked and I dove right into it...The first thing I noticed was the music. It fits the game/theme perfectly, some sort of "Space Rock". It's the kind of music you would expect Han Solo to listen to whilest flying. The rythem is good, quality is good and the feeling is even better. I think the best thing in this game is the music (@Devs why don't publish the Soundtrack?).My first 30mins with the game where not enjoyable. My camera was moving around like a drunk guy on a unicycle. I couldn't get ride of the feeling that mouse accelerations was on. I looked under controles, and the only option I saw was to turn down mouse sensitivity. After that it worked a bit better, was still frustrating though. I enjoyed the dialogues a lot too, the characters where what you expected, a bit clichée but still really fitting into the game. Your choices concerning responses are not amazing, but they give you a bit of choices, which added a nice little touch, which isn't useful, but I still considere well placed in the game.And finaly, I came to the combat. Hell did it look cool, and hell did it play♥♥♥♥♥♥ After I died the first time, not knowing how to use my weapons properly, I closed the game and played something else. I was so frustrated. I later tryed again, giving the game 3 trys to convince me that the combat was fun. For me it never felt fun.The biggest problems I encountered where the camera. The placement is awkward at best, and it can ruin everything. I sometimes couldn't even see where I shot because the camera backed down behind the ship, whilst I was aiming. And moving it back up again, well, now it goes way overbord and I ca't see the enemy ship properly.Another aspect is the free movement in combat. You and other heavy ships are limited to a 2D combat field, whilst small fighters can fly all around you. That wouldn't be a problem, if you didn't have to fly, fight and try not to ram something at the same time.To break it down: You will ram into things if you focuse on the combat aspect, and you will not fight well if you focuse on the flying aspect. The auto aiming of your beta canons it terrible. It locks you onto someone and you shoot. But if you have locked onto someone, you won't be able to aim at someone else. I would have liked to get a fonction where I can aim freely, and then press a button and that locks my aim onto that target I'm aiming at currently. Another problem with that auto-lockon is that your camera moves with the target. I had small fighters circleing around me, spinning my camera like crazy, making it impossible to fly properly.My last, but not unimportant problem with combat is, that enemies fly away. But you are in free space, so they can fly where they want. So you have to concentrate on fighting them, and following them around, which to me, somebody uncapable of multitasking is too much of a challenge.To summe it up, I really liked the music, fantastic. The dialogue is not really useful, but a nice touch. However, the combat system ruined it for me, to such an extend that I don't feel the need to continue. I know I didn't even play 3hs, but the combat is so frustrating to me, that I will probably not continue, as I play for fun, not to be more♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off after then before (and yes, I'm not one of those oldschool elitsts that have to play every game for the challenge, I play them for fun).So do I recommend this game. No, not really. I do recomment the soundtrack. And if you can multitask, otherwise, stay away. But who am I kidding, I'm a stranger on the internet, that hasn't even finished the game.If you can, and have a friend who has the game, try it, see if it's for you, and then buy. For me this game was really disappointing, not because it's beyond bad, just because I came in with expectations that where not reached.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												I loved this game but it has very little replay value. I pretty much tried all the various strategic setups possible in my one play through. It has me wishing there were crew, boarding, and other characteristics similar to FTL. Planetside or more technical mining would have been cool too. The game felt a little empty like there were other things that could have, or should have happened. The main story was also a bit too short and there's nothing really existing outside of that. Once I hit the end there was also no reason to further continue because I already had one of the biggest and baddest ships with most of the weapons being the top-line. There was very little that could stop me at that point so to max out every thing would have been redundant.There's also lots of glitchy bits. Still I recommend this game because it's more about the music and the feel. It had a very cinematic aspect to it and I thoroughly enjoyed cruising through the stars and exploring. In tribute to my ships:Rasputin - HammerheadFish Face McGee - Barracuda (The one I had the hardest time giving up cause it's agility made it dominant against all but the absolute biggest mothers)Free Loader -  RadovichLazy Jane - BlackGate

												Arcadey spacesim with bluesy cowboy bebop/firefly jams.   You fly your ship around on one axis, but there are tons of weapons, components and ships to buy.  The game has 5-6 different factions that range from bandits, to the law, whom you can either side, or fight against.   There is an in-game economy where different outposts want different things, so you can spend your time just smuggling narco-cola, or live organs if you'd like to amass a fortune.I've only gotten a few hours on it, but I'm quite hooked!After giving it some thought. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Ok there's enough reviews about the games content and what you can do. This game is fun, initially. That's it. The fights, the graphics, the soundtrack, everything, it's all fun.........initially. After 30 hours of gameplay I am bored witless. In fact if I had the soundtrack seperately I would be disinclined to play the game at all. It is just repetitive in the extreme now. There's not many ships, there's not many factions. There's no real diversity in missions. There's no immersion or roleplay element with which to amuse yourself. It's just become one long dullfest. I think even the developers are bored of it. There have been no real changes to this game since release. Aprt from a few bug fixes they haven't added anything new or worthwhile.Let's also trounce the myth that this is some kind of successor to Freelancer. Absolute BS. I still play Freelancer now, albeit in a modded form. 16 years after it was released. This game, I was bored of in 16 hours. It has no depth and nothing to drive you on and keep you playing or just exploring. Freelancer systems were unique and atmospheric. Systems in RG are sterile, empy, uninteresting and so similar in appearance that you are never entirely sure which you are in.Combat is 2 dimensional, there's no up or down. Freelancer combat is tactical, intense and challenging. Not flat, predictable and too easy. Save you money, find an old copy of Freelancer. Install the Discovery Mod, and never look at this game again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												3rd person view of what is essentially a tabletop game.  (You can steer left or right, but not up or down.  It's not "space," the whole game exists on one flat disc surrounded by  a space background.)Text flash tutorials don't really do a good job of explaining what you need to do, or what you should expect from combat.  That being said, combat (once you get the hang of it) is really well done despite being on the previously mentioned flat surface.Extremely imbalanced difficulty levels may discourage some players.  Each solar system, including the first one, starts off very difficult.  Avoid fights, do some cargo hauling missions to upgrade your ship before attempting combat or progressing the story.The story starts pretty shallow, towards the middle it stays shallow, and it ends shallow.Once you get the hang of the combat in this game, and if you're ok grinding cargo hauling missions from place to place - it's a lot of fun.  Objectively I don't think it's a very well polished game, but it's definitely worth the ten bucks on Steam Sale if you're a big sci-fi fan, and only if you're a big sci fi fan.Hitting recommend because subjectively I'd rank it between 5/10 and 6/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Not the most complicated space sim/spaced RPG I've ever played.  But simplistic does not equal simple.  I'm only about two hours in and there's depth here.  You spend all of your time on your ship.  The times you do dock at stations, these are static scenes that you use menus to navigate.  That said, it's functional.My one complaint is that the game isn't 3D.  Yes, it's 3D rendered but you can't move across all three axis.  You're stuck in a plane and this is space. Come on, you couldn't have provided some damn height to the systems?That doesn't take away from the fun I've had so far.  Definitely worth the sale price.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												Fun indie/open world/action RPG set in space.  Any old gamers who remember Escape Velocity series will enjoy this, as will any fans of Firefly who want be an independent captain operating on the fringes of legality in the vein of Malcolm Reynolds.The combat is good, but I did find it became tedious after a while.  The main quest will become challenging if you don't take on side quests but none of them are particularly interesting ("Fly to X system and deliver cargo" or "Destroy pirates at Y coordinates for a bounty"), just repetitive radiant missions.  Nor did I find the main quest story particularly compelling, and I wish the roleplaying element and world-building were stronger.  The ship models available for upgrade also felt a bit constrained, although the amount of customization for equipment is outstanding.The soundtrack really makes the game, reminiscent of Cowboy Bebop at its best.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												Like Sid Meier's Pirates in space.  (Though I haven't completed it yet.)Pros:Great graphics.  All the fancy post-effect stuff from AAA titles.  Very cool ship design, from concept to greebling.  And lots of them, too.A surprising amount of ships to buy and play with.  You can trade to a different hull anywhere it's sold, just so long as you have enough money.  You get full price for your trade-in.  Which means you can tradeout your hull for a mission than trade it back.Interesting ship components with meaningful effect on gameplay, diverse weapons.  No one weapon setup is optimum for all situations.  Ships range in size from small corvette's to large dreadnaughts, but everything still has a role to play.  (Tradeoffs between size and power vs. agility and speed.)Excellant economy, trading, and mission based shipping.  Easy trading.  The market value of goods on a planet is auto updated each time you visit it.  Very exciting too, what with scripted rebel and pirate attacks during shipping missions.  And roaming pirates and rebels you can run into just trading on your own.  You definately must keep your ship well outfitted for tougher shipping missions.  Lots of money to be made!Missions of all types vary in difficulty according to your current ship and rig, but you can see a dynamic difficulty rating before accepting it.  Easier missions are always available, if you find yourself up against a wall.Lots of things to buy and upgrade for your ship, or tradeout for an alternate rig to complete missions.  Different races sometimes require different tactics. Cons:There are a few vague ratings and descriptions for ships and components.  But you can usually find the info you need on the Community Hub.Relatively small galaxy compared to more hardcore (and expensive) space trading sims.TL:DRA casual naval game set in space.  The focus is on fun, and zappy pastel deathrays.  Space looks pretty, which is important if you have to spend alot of time staring into the starry depths.  Trade is better than viable, it's an important way to advance and upgrade your ship.  And anything that isn't clear in game is usually on the Hub.I hope they make a sequel!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys arcade-like space-themed combat.  The player pilots various capital ships that are locked into a 2D plane, so if 3D space combat is your thing you probably won't enjoy this one.  The equipment is varied enough that there is some variety and entertainment is trying out various ships and builds, and the game features broadside main guns, turrets, and dumbfire slots on every ship.Pros:Fun arcade mechanicsDecent amount of ships and equipmentCons:Can get very repetativeTrade and mining mechanics are dull

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												3rd person view of what is essentially a tabletop game.  (You can steer left or right, but not up or down.  It's not "space," the whole game exists on one flat disc surrounded by  a space background.)Text flash tutorials don't really do a good job of explaining what you need to do, or what you should expect from combat.  That being said, combat (once you get the hang of it) is really well done despite being on the previously mentioned flat surface.Extremely imbalanced difficulty levels may discourage some players.  Each solar system, including the first one, starts off very difficult.  Avoid fights, do some cargo hauling missions to upgrade your ship before attempting combat or progressing the story.The story starts pretty shallow, towards the middle it stays shallow, and it ends shallow.Once you get the hang of the combat in this game, and if you're ok grinding cargo hauling missions from place to place - it's a lot of fun.  Objectively I don't think it's a very well polished game, but it's definitely worth the ten bucks on Steam Sale if you're a big sci-fi fan, and only if you're a big sci fi fan.Hitting recommend because subjectively I'd rank it between 5/10 and 6/10

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Love the game. If you played Freelancer back in the day this game has alot of similarities. You can play the campaign at your leisure. In fact the game is very much like an rpg in that you have to "level up". Buy better ships and accessories. The controls are easy to learn and the capital ship combat is fun if a bit fast paced for larger ships. It's unfortunate you can't fly in a true 3D space like in freespace but I soon forgot about it and was sucked into the gameplay and universe.It's hard to believe that this is an indie game. Freespace is still the standard for mouse driven space action games. But until Microsoft decides to release it to steam or gog, this game will most certainly scratch that itch. Definitely worth a play if you are a fan of Privateer, Elite, or Freespace.
