number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Well, I bought this on a whim, but it turns out, money was never better spent.All in all, I would defintely recommend it to anyone who's wanted to fly their own starship in a mostly lawless zone. If you've ever played Tachyon: The Fringe, you're going to love this game.I know that quite a few might be turned away due to the thing's lack of vertical flight. Put simply, the lack of a vertical axis isn't a drawback - it's a feature. The kind of ships you'll be in charge of, you won't need a vertical axis.I'll list out the good stuff and the bad. Hopefully that'll help.The Good:-1) Low-cost title that plays like a AAA game.2) Fast-paced and simple to learn.3) Quirky in many aspects.4) Great soundtrack, with an obvious inspiration from Firefly.5) Very nice ship design, and a used-up feel that's surprisingly cozy.The Neutral:-1) Star-systems aren't particularly unique, but the graphical detail and insanity offsets that to quite some extent.2) Trading and Mining are viable alternatives to a kill-em-all blitz, but it can be boring or tedious after a point.3) Fairly interesting characters, but their full potential was never realised.4) Cash is something weird - either so much that you don't know what to do, or too little, resulting in you getting outgunned.5) Mercenaries are a nice touch, but again - like the main characters - not realised to their full potential.The Bad:-1) Some missions can be hilariously broken, and tougher than they look, which can cause hair-pulling at times.2) Rather short single-player campaign.3) Can be slightly boring after a certain point, though not too bad.4) No further development on this title, it would seem. Hopefully there'll be more on this after some time.Definitely give it a try. You won't regret it!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												a laconic and easily enjoyable psychadelic spaceblastemup.  the soundtrack fits it perfectly, and there's immediately plenty of visceral action with a very uncomplicated interface and easy learning curve - quite refreshing for a spaceship game.  within an hour I was actively seeking fights with the local gangs just to unload perfectly timed broadsides of hot plasma death whilst lazily unleashing a cloud of flak on ne'er-do-wells amidst volleys of akimbo laser death while blitting deflector shields at perfect timing in response to inbound missiles without having to perform any kind of keyboard calesthenics.  with a couple of hours play it's the polish on the details that stand out:  the gnarly warp effects, the way your ship sways and groans when adjusting warp trajectory, the automatic camera and the timing of the music as it changes to the scenario all fits together beautifully to form an immensely satisfying experience.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												I give it a cautious thumbs up. If you enjoyed the naval combat in Assasin's Creed: Black Flag, get ready for that exact same experience except with better music and laser beams.Pro's:Excellent soundtrack and if you get tired of it, the game makes it really easy to swap in your own at start up.Combat is simple, but can be challenging at times depending what sort of mess you fly into.The ship design is interesting and the different weight classes make each class pilot differently enough to keep them distinct. That said, it'd be nice to have a few more ships to choose from or mod support so we can make our own.Con's:Eventually the whole game gets repetitive. The music repeats after a bit, the systems start to look the same with the only real difference being the color of the core and the enemies are more or less interchangeable as far as faction goes.Characters are forgettable and the story won't suck you in, but for $20 bucks you knew there was going to be a trade off and the narrative is it.If you can't wait to play Star Citizen and Elite:Dangerous seems to complicated and in depth or requires too much patience, than this might be your cup of tea. You could do worse for $20 dollars (20 tacos at taco bell?). If you catch it on sale for $10 or less, I'd say go for it without reservation, at full price you might want to ask yourself what else that $20 could buy you.If the game ever gets mod support then buy it without hesitation and see what kind of hijinks you can get up to.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												A very enjoyable, even if a bit short and light on content side space combat sim/exploration game.Pros:+ Fun and often surprisingly complex combat, with decent weapon variety and high emphasis on manouvering+ A lot of ships to choose with often real trade-offs (firepower vs manouverability) and a decent amount of customization.+ Short, but enjoyable story+ Unique climate, with voice-acting and sountrack properly supporting the "Wild West" vibe.+ A universe full of random stuff happening+ Nice looking and well optimized graphicsCons:- Short main story- Somewhat generic and repetetive side missions- Not that much content - in my playtime I've bought the strongest ship with best modules and basicly saw everything the game has to offer- No endgame or super-rare stuff worth finding- Trade and mining are somewhat limited, there is no industrial aspect in the game like in Elite: Dangerous or X3This game definitly turned out to be much better than it had any right to be. If you're looking for a somewhat casual space sim that will give you an engaging universe and freedom to choose your own style of playing, look no further. It won't last forver, but will give you 20-30 hours of very solid experience.I just hope they will come up with some expansion packs or a sequel that will expand on the formula. They have most of the basics done right, giving the player some far-reaching goals, like conquering stations and building an industrial empire would make it absolutely awesome.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a fun game, that get's repetitive in the later parts.I really enjoyed most of my time with the game, it doesn't have much variety though. There are not many different quest types and it feels like the music loops through the same few songs over and over. These things are no problems in the beginning. I had a blast just trucking through space, retrieving and delivering cargo to different stations, outrunning or shooting bandits, earn money and upgrade you ship. Once I was ready to leave the first system I realized it doesn't really change.It doesn't help that you have to do the "grinding", side missions between the main story to earn money, to buy better parts for you ship or a different ship altogether so you can survive against higher level enemies.I have an alright tolerance for this but got fed up after about 30h and just wanted to finish the game. It's possible I spend to much time in the first system(s) and maybe could have been more efficient to go to different systems earlier for more lucrative quests. Your mileage may vary.If that isn't a problem for you, this is the perfect game for you!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												Fantastic, absolutely worth the $20 I paid for it and then some.It's the gritty, space cowboy vibe of Starcraft and Firefly with some deep combat that you [finally] won't want a friggin' flight stick to enjoy.+Soundtrack is almost worth the price alone. Hint: use an .ogg file converter.+Cool ship design and some fantastic depth to the gear+Simplicity of movement thanks to no verticality (you don't need to fly up or down, just left, right, or forward)-Combat is satisfying as all hell but some of the nuances could be explained better. It took me a while to figure out how flak cannons work, for instance.-Some kinds of gear, such as engines, have more of a bland linear progression than a matter of preference and variety.-Game only saves at space stations-Some achievements are busted. (ex: my achievement ticker says I've killed a space pirate lord or whatnot, but the tracker for killing 10 says I haven't gotten a single oneTLDR: It's the space sim you want without all the complicated crap that would push you away.

												How is this supposed to freely support various growth path? Story is non-existant, trading is weird and underwhelming at best, mining is an awful/dull experience (and the mining laser is awkwardly hidden at the bottom of a weapon list somewhere you'd never check if not told). This leaves you with combat as the only real way to get ahead, and there are better (free) space combat games. I'll admit the graphics are good (most space games are since it's relatively easy to do) and the music is interesting. But that will keep you going for less than 2h, which is - thankfully - how long you have to ask the refund.

												This game is Grindy, ok. But grinding in this game is SO MUCH FUN.you take command of a capital ship here, and engage with broadside type of engagement. You get to kill ships in dozens, broadside or not (turrets&missiles are available)Simply get this game if you like capital ship solo-like west gun blazing game.

												Things I absolutely love about Rebel Galaxy:1. Broadside Combat2. 4x (light) Space Sim with tight controls on a controller3. Excellent graphics, gameplay, and a decient story4. Impressive amount of content for the asking price.Things I absolutely despise about Rebel Galaxy:1. Scaled EnemiesReally this is the only thing keeping me from recommending the game. It has so much going for it, but the deeper I got into the game, the more it gave me this overwelming hatered of grinding for gear and ships that perform the same since the enemies will automatically get harder. I felt like I will never beat Rebel Galaxy and it would only allow me to finish it... at some point, and that makes Rebel Galaxy feel like a waste of time.You don't even realize that this is a problem until it is too late and now you have to "game the system" in order to play it the way it wants you to.2. Saving at portsThis last point would not anger me so much if the game didn't have Scaled Enemies.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Do you like Firefly? Do you like flying around in a ship and blowing stuff up? Then buy this game.Play as a pirate, smuggler, merchant, miner, mercenary, soldier or any combination you like!The story is nothing to write home about, but this is mostly a space sandbox anyway. The game itself is absolutely gorgeous and an incredible pleasure to play. There are many different ship types to play around with and different weapon combinations to keep you interested for a good while. The little dinky tugboat you start out with isn't much, but it won't take you too long to throw some bigger guns on it and start slugging it out with the bigger ships.Ship flight is arcade-style and takes place in faux-3D space: that is to say smaller ships like fighters and bombers (which you don't pilot) fly around in 3D, but the bigger ships, from corvettes to dreadnaughts, stay on a 2D plane. Ships have turrets and you can pick up a hireable strike-craft to help you out, but most of the firepower is concentrated in naval-style broadside weaponry.Difficulty is mostly linear and is determined by the tier of your equipment, not the size of your ship, so you're not forced to play a huge, sluggish battleship if you don't want to (or don't want to save up for it.) Some people have complained about the "risk estimate" for certain missions being a little inaccurate, but I haven't really had any issues with it provided I upgrade my equipment properly and am not afraid to bug out when the going gets tough.Default soundtrack is great - a pleasureable selection of hard rock music that fits the tone of the game. You can add your own music, or replace the whole soundtrack altogether if you want. Controls are smooth, with the occasional futzing required with overlapping cargo containers (protip: use your targetting scanner to lock onto the container you want.) Graphics are absolutely stunning and the sound effects are top notch.Definitely worth picking up this gem!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												The game gets boring pretty quick. It starts out fun, but it turns in to a terrible grind real quick. After awhile you are forced to take on the same missions over and over just to get enough cash to upgrade. Even then, the upgrades don't offer much variety. It's mostly going from MK I to MK II to MK III etc...After that, it's more grinding for more cash. The missions aren't even all that fun or memorable.The combat doesn't even require a whole heck of a lot of tactics, especially since the game only allows movement on 1 plane in what should be a 3d world (outer space and all that).It's a good game if it were cheap, but I wouldn't spend more than 5 space bucks.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Playing the original Wing Commander as a kid, I can say that this game is at least less aggravating than that flustercuck of getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥in space, thanks to this game's native third person view, nice targeting systems, and limiting player movement to an invisible, flat "surface" in space. In other words, you can't point your ship "up" and fly that way. You drive through space like in a car, only turning left and right. This might be a point of contention to some, but in combat and while exploring, I found this to get on my nerves in Wing Commander, so I honestly prefer Rebel Galaxy's handling of this.The music in this game is pretty darn cool. Just watch the trailer on Steam if you want a taste. It works really well and keeps comabt and exploration more enjoyable. That said, it's "more" enjoyable thanks to the music; never really enjoyed the gameplay myself. Everything feels like a big fetch quest, even when the missions aren't fetch quests. You go to a space station, spend money to upgrade your ship, talk to an alien, get a mission, and go to another nav point which requires a couple of minutes of flying in one direction with nothing to do, before reaching a fight that involves whittling down enemy shields and hull, one by one, until they're all dead. Then you fly back to the space station again and repeat. I only played for 3 hours, and I got bored during that length of time.What's worse, if you die, there is no quicksave or checkpoint system while you're away from a space station, so be prepared to repeat lengthy 2-3 minute space travel segments and 5 minute combat segments all over again, just to get to the part you died on before. Everything has a grindy feel to it: earning money, upgrading the ship, the combat itself, etc. I cannot recommend a game that appears to require many more hours to complete, but which left me bored and wanting to play something else within 3 hours' time.

The little dinky tugboat you start out with isn't much, but it won't take you too long to throw some bigger guns on it and start slugging it out with the bigger ships.Ship flight is arcade-style and takes place in faux-3D space: that is to say smaller ships like fighters and bombers (which you don't pilot) fly around in 3D, but the bigger ships, from corvettes to dreadnaughts, stay on a 2D plane. Ships have turrets and you can pick up a hireable strike-craft to help you out, but most of the firepower is concentrated in naval-style broadside weaponry.Difficulty is mostly linear and is determined by the tier of your equipment, not the size of your ship, so you're not forced to play a huge, sluggish battleship if you don't want to (or don't want to save up for it.) Some people have complained about the "risk estimate" for certain missions being a little inaccurate, but I haven't really had any issues with it provided I upgrade my equipment properly and am not afraid to bug out when the going gets tough.Default soundtrack is great - a pleasureable selection of hard rock music that fits the tone of the game. You can add your own music, or replace the whole soundtrack altogether if you want. Controls are smooth, with the occasional futzing required with overlapping cargo containers (protip: use your targetting scanner to lock onto the container you want.) Graphics are absolutely stunning and the sound effects are top notch.Definitely worth picking up this gem!

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												This game seriously came out of no where!!  Last I heard about the devs was back when they parted ways from Runic soon after Torchlight 2 released to form Double Damage just over a year ago, then they fell off my radar and now BAM! they're back with a pretty solid space sim in a really short space of time. I'm so impressed by that, well played indeed!As a space sim enthusiast,  I have to admit I was initially a little put off by the fact there was no 3D space flight and it was all naval style combat but soon after I got into the game I found broadside combat to be really engaging and a lot more fun than I originally thought it would be. I'm not very far into the game yet but I've been enjoying mining, trading, fighting pirates, the typical space sim activities and apparently, it's possible to join the pirate faction with its own storyline, pretty cool. Rebel Galaxy is easily worth the full $20 price tag.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												If you like the idea of EVE / Elite:Dangerous but tried playing both and thought... I can't be arsed. Then play this instead.Basically it's like an Indie Freelancer, this would be the closest game you could compare it to. Yes it is not a 'space simulator' but what it does give you is turrets that you can just give targeting orders to... which i think is awesome and a suedo tactical battle if you use the scan function to effectively pause the game and think out a strategy. I have played this game for several hours and have many more hours of gameplay left. Mining is... well mining but it has been done quite well. Battles are fun but it is a bit of a 'I have bigger guns and better shields' fight more than anything. Trading actually works!Basically if you enjoyed Freelancer buy this, if you are drawn to 'Elite' type games but ultimately you've tried things like X, Elite:D and EVE and just couldn't be bothered with the time investment and complication then buy this. If you like to wear a long brown jacket and insist that your girlfriend calls you Mal... buy this.I personally would just plain recommend you buy this!9/10 - Could be more variation with stations and objects. Music is great but repetitive. Wish I could have a fleet not just one ship.

												Massively under-rated game. Basically, this is a much more approachable version of Elite: Dangerous and the X:Rebirth series. Yes, the fighters are going to swarm around you from all angles, but you don't aim your broadsides up and down... the computer does the up and down for you. The broadsides take a little getting used to, but once you do you'll be blasting fools in no time.Super highly recommended

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												What a blast! Didn't know I was craving Rock'n Roll in space. Now I need more of that ludicrous alchemy: Dubstep Gothic, Minimal House Fantasy, NewRetroWave Sword and Planet...Rebel Galaxy profits from some tightly focused game design that does exactly 2 or 3 things really well without resorting to needless filler. Consequently its approach is very much arcade, so don't expect a lot of simulation here.The missing vertical axis works surprisingly well and I didn't feel restricted by it. Presumably many people will be put off, though.+Flair: Like an issue of HeavyMetal magazine.+Soundtrack: +150% cool. Also easily replaced with your personal flavour, if needed.+Action: Fast and Fun.-Exploration: Nice visuals but basically just background for some gunfights.-Variation: After a certain point it's more of the same².

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												This game IS awesome! The game is quite fun. In this game you are a nephew looking for your aunt. Pretty much the story summed up in a single sentence.... from where I am. This game is kinda like how people play fallout 3 or 4.... you explore and forget what you are doing. Soundtrack- Its a mix of country music and rock and its just awesome! When you first go into warp the music start getting faster then right when you warp the music kicks off and you feel like a total badass! 10/10Graphics- This is an extremely pretty game. 8/10Story- The story is pretty decent but its just a way( this is how I feel) to get more money and such also to get you to explore other systems. 7/10Gameplay- Its like a 2D game set in a 3D world. While you cannot go up or down the AI can. Its very world of warships stle but is very different. You get broads sides and the AI on your ship actually fires by itself or you can control them yourself. 9/10Overall- Its a very fun game and is very addicting when you go around being a kickass bounty hunter and mowing down hundreds of fighters and capital ships. If you love spaceships and rock & roll then you'll love this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												I really like the Idea of this game. Battleship combat in Space witha variety of weapons and enemys. Solving Missions as Mercenary for hire or Merchant or whatever.The game IS fun, at least in the first 15 to 19 hours. Thus i still would recommed this game, even for it's full price. However, after 19 hours the gameplay really runs thin on me and is still the same as it was at the beginning, just with a little bit different and statistically better weapons.If there is more variety further in then that iks bad because after 19 hours the game should have put on it's best gameplay pants.  Overall it doesn't really do variation that well.These are the reasons why i coulödn't keep going any more.Equipment/Upgrades are more or less superlinear: There is no sense in choosing a weaker weapon because you perhabs like the look or how it's mechanic works, if it's of a lower damage and a shorter range then what you actually can get you won't bother because of it's downsides.This counts for every aspect of the upgrades, everything is rather a linear upgrade because the best things to get will be (numerical as well as trough testing them) only the best Broadsides, Turrets, Shields and so on.On top of the the lack of variation also comes from the game having not enough actually usefull or rewarding... well rewards. drops of items or weapons. In my 19 hours with the game it dropped maybe 5 Items one of wich i then actually took on till i stopped playing because it was just the best. Or at least i think it were drops because the game sure as hell didn't really tell me.All the thiongs that the enemys let fall is really boring loot that is also really cumbersome and stupid hard to collect. Because for some reason you can lock on to dropped cargo but if the Tractorbeam just doesn't want to collect the more viable ressource and instead insists on picking up the♥♥♥♥♥♥Nuts and Bolts then there is nothing you can really do about it aside from collectting the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ thing drive it elsewhere, throw it into space over there and then come back to repeat the same thing until... NO THANKS after a short while i just didn't bother with most of these drops. Good equipment and weapons you only get in stations. That is not a bad thing per se but it hurts the gameplay fun. Why don't we have a slvage mechanism where we can salvage broken enemy ships?Samey and thin Mission/Story: The Story is okay. Nothing really to write home about. It gives you a direction to go for but much more then thin context for the mission it ain't. Not even the Main Ones. Every Mission is more or less the same. No matter what the description or story behind the Mission. You go somewhere, bla bla happens, enemys are there or turn up, you shot stuff, perhabs you have to deliver something and that was it. Go there, pewpew, done. Well, there WAS one mission that was a escort mission. But that was an instant death of mission target thing. Not that i really could have done something against it. Wich incidentally feeds into the next problem.The combatsystem is flat: And i don't only say that because in stead of real space you actually just move on a single layer, an invisible "surfeace" in space. That in itselfe i don't mind at all.The promisse of the combat system is really interesting at first. You have braoadsides, like a battleship should :-) , and with growing ships you own more and more turrets on top of it. In the Pause menue you can then give the different turrets commands like, only attack fighters , or that rocketturret is only suppossed to shoot at Capital ships. You can also take control over the different turrets youself but that doesn't really make much sense. With increasing Equipment you get the feeling your tactical possibilities grow. But they don'tAside from limiting missille turrets for the bigger ships the best strategy is to give all turrets the commando only to attack what you actually lock in with the trageting system. THIS is thousand times more effective then let different turrets do different tasls. You then skirt around the edges of the battlefield picking of the enemys piece by piece because it makes no sense to charge in and do risky stuff. That will just get you killed or addled with immense reparicosts. It doesn't bring you really much to use cover. You can hire ONE additional mercenary but those aren't much more then the turrets you already have. There is nor real strategy to the combatAnd that is a problem because it is boring as hell. Okay that's a lie, it is fun in the beginning, i wouldn't had spend 19 hours in the game otherwise, and testing the different weapons did that. But in the end it is always the exact same. And that very same lack of real strategy was also was cost me that one Escort Mission.With no viable tactics that i could have stopped the different enemys from attacking my charge. There are no weapons that do much beyound damage. There is no REAL variety.But instead of hammering on that point i will tell you what i WISHED it had:First off, give me more bigger ships that i can hire with different real gameplay roles (Give me a tank, a repairiship, a ship that can confuse or disrupt(e.g. debuff) enemy systems with AOE Explosions.Let me give them a strategy and a DIRECT choice of target or missionparameters. Like the repairship´is to reapair (du) us but keep away from capital ships. The tankships is to stay close to me to catch the really heavy incoming fire in my flank. Do the same for the enemys and that would give me an incentive do actually dive into enemy ranks and aim for their specific ships.Do the same for the weapons. Gve me a variety of functions. How cool would i have been if i could use point defence flak against missilles, streams of bulletts flying away into the sky with a chance that they miss one and some get trough. How about those same guns don't just affect missilles that attack me but an area around me. Or that ramming shield, make that actually DO SOMETHING. Because as far as it stands there is no real gain from ramming your ship into others with it, the name is totally useless in that case.In a escort mission i would stay close to my charge together with a Tanking ship and my possibilitys would have been much greater.It also would have given far better tools for the overall mission variety just by playing with the enemycombinations.  It would have had the chance of getting me much deeper into the frau riskl something, drive me to the edge and i imagine how i in a last bit for taking down that pesky Carrier how i ram my ship into his and win day...or something.As it stands the game is good for the first ten to fifteen hours or so then it becomes really samey same and uninteresting.From the fact that i unasked loose my ship when i buy a new one over the mission to the weapons and gagdgets it simply lacks the depth to carry me further. Wich is sad because i feel this could be more. Perhabs next time. :-P

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												Overall a really good, polished game.  The mechanics and controls are simple enough to master, but equipment is varied enough to pose interesting choices.  The story is not a bad one, and you do get options at certain points to do things your own way.You probably won't play through more than once, but I felt satisfied that one enjoyable playthrough was worth the price of the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												This is a very well made game. An almost Freelancer style game with simple mechanics that make learning quick and fun. The missions you take can be legal or illegal - bounty hunter, merchant, smuggler, miner, thief, and so forth. Combat is satisfying and engaging, though a bit over the top at times and occasionally downright impossible until you have had further equipment upgrades. Once purchased though, the difficulty lowers.The commodity system was great! This was one of the most satisfying games for being a merchant I've ever played. Watch for starvation and run them food from an agrarian planet. Take water from one system that is rich in it to a more barren system and earn 200% or more than what you bought it for. Took a little getting use to, and I still don't understand it all, but the overall mechanic is satisfying once you get an idea of it.My only gripe is it needs more content. After the main story is over, you have the biggest Dreadnaugh, and you are fully upgraded, doing missions is a little pointless. The devs should open it up for modding. More ships, weapons, equipment, systems, etc., etc., and this game would be more than a hoot.Definitely worth the $20. The game is great and a definite recommend, even if it's for a few story runs only.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy was initialy hard to play, the controls felt wierd and until I got my settings right the framerate wasn't great, but after fixing the settings and about two hours this became one of the best games I have ever played. Top five for sure. Basicly think of what it would be like if Empire at War's space battles weren't RTS, or if Battle Star Galactica Online wasn't for wallet warriors and wasn't unbalanced. The locked plane and broadside combat keeps the game simple and exciting and totally un-clunky, although sometimes the menus can be a bit difficult.The ship designs are great too, especially the underated Sorcerer dreadnought (my personal favorite ship, by far) although sometimes the AI targeting gets confused due to the ship's geometry, which was fixed with the sorcerer for the main part but makes the McKinley my least favorite ship so far.Aliens in this game also have good design by being Lovecraftian fish people or rad badger dudes and they all feel Star Wars inspired and combined with the hailing system also add a sort of Star Trek feel.Overall, the game is initially daunting and difficult to get used to, but after you've given it a chance it is absolutely great.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												This is the game I've been looking for since Freelancer. Combat takes place on capital ships, so don't expect to be pulling off sweet manuevres or Luke in the Death Star trench stuff. The whole premise of the game is that you're looking for pieces of a puzzle first introduced by your enigmatic aunt, along the way you undertake missions and♥♥♥♥♥♥off all the pirates in the sector to the point you can't dock anywhere any more. I came to this off the back of Elite Dangerous, and have been completely satisfied. High risk missions pay more money (hauling huge munitions cargos into the middle of a siege is immensly rewarding), and you have full freedom to do whatever you want and explore the galaxy. Combat is usually pretty fluid, though learning to balance your weapons and deflectors takes a little practice, and the broadside based combat may not be everyone's cup of tea.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												What a blast! Didn't know I was craving Rock'n Roll in space. Now I need more of that ludicrous alchemy: Dubstep Gothic, Minimal House Fantasy, NewRetroWave Sword and Planet...Rebel Galaxy profits from some tightly focused game design that does exactly 2 or 3 things really well without resorting to needless filler. Consequently its approach is very much arcade, so don't expect a lot of simulation here.The missing vertical axis works surprisingly well and I didn't feel restricted by it. Presumably many people will be put off, though.+Flair: Like an issue of HeavyMetal magazine.+Soundtrack: +150% cool. Also easily replaced with your personal flavour, if needed.+Action: Fast and Fun.-Exploration: Nice visuals but basically just background for some gunfights.-Variation: After a certain point it's more of the same².

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												This game IS awesome! The game is quite fun. In this game you are a nephew looking for your aunt. Pretty much the story summed up in a single sentence.... from where I am. This game is kinda like how people play fallout 3 or 4.... you explore and forget what you are doing. Soundtrack- Its a mix of country music and rock and its just awesome! When you first go into warp the music start getting faster then right when you warp the music kicks off and you feel like a total badass! 10/10Graphics- This is an extremely pretty game. 8/10Story- The story is pretty decent but its just a way( this is how I feel) to get more money and such also to get you to explore other systems. 7/10Gameplay- Its like a 2D game set in a 3D world. While you cannot go up or down the AI can. Its very world of warships stle but is very different. You get broads sides and the AI on your ship actually fires by itself or you can control them yourself. 9/10Overall- Its a very fun game and is very addicting when you go around being a kickass bounty hunter and mowing down hundreds of fighters and capital ships. If you love spaceships and rock & roll then you'll love this.

												I really like the Idea of this game. Battleship combat in Space witha variety of weapons and enemys. However, after 19 hours the gameplay really runs thin on me and is still the same as it was at the beginning, just with a little bit different and statistically better weapons.If there is more variety further in then that iks bad because after 19 hours the game should have put on it's best gameplay pants.  Overall it doesn't really do variation that well.These are the reasons why i coulödn't keep going any more.Equipment/Upgrades are more or less superlinear: There is no sense in choosing a weaker weapon because you perhabs like the look or how it's mechanic works, if it's of a lower damage and a shorter range then what you actually can get you won't bother because of it's downsides.This counts for every aspect of the upgrades, everything is rather a linear upgrade because the best things to get will be (numerical as well as trough testing them) only the best Broadsides, Turrets, Shields and so on.On top of the the lack of variation also comes from the game having not enough actually usefull or rewarding... well rewards. drops of items or weapons. In my 19 hours with the game it dropped maybe 5 Items one of wich i then actually took on till i stopped playing because it was just the best. Or at least i think it were drops because the game sure as hell didn't really tell me.All the thiongs that the enemys let fall is really boring loot that is also really cumbersome and stupid hard to collect. Because for some reason you can lock on to dropped cargo but if the Tractorbeam just doesn't want to collect the more viable ressource and instead insists on picking up the♥♥♥♥♥♥Nuts and Bolts then there is nothing you can really do about it aside from collectting the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ thing drive it elsewhere, throw it into space over there and then come back to repeat the same thing until... NO THANKS after a short while i just didn't bother with most of these drops. Good equipment and weapons you only get in stations. That is not a bad thing per se but it hurts the gameplay fun. Why don't we have a slvage mechanism where we can salvage broken enemy ships?Samey and thin Mission/Story: The Story is okay. Nothing really to write home about. It gives you a direction to go for but much more then thin context for the mission it ain't. Not even the Main Ones. Every Mission is more or less the same. No matter what the description or story behind the Mission. You go somewhere, bla bla happens, enemys are there or turn up, you shot stuff, perhabs you have to deliver something and that was it. Go there, pewpew, done. Well, there WAS one mission that was a escort mission. But that was an instant death of mission target thing. Not that i really could have done something against it. Wich incidentally feeds into the next problem.The combatsystem is flat: And i don't only say that because in stead of real space you actually just move on a single layer, an invisible "surfeace" in space. That in itselfe i don't mind at all.The promisse of the combat system is really interesting at first. You have braoadsides, like a battleship should :-) , and with growing ships you own more and more turrets on top of it. But they don'tAside from limiting missille turrets for the bigger ships the best strategy is to give all turrets the commando only to attack what you actually lock in with the trageting system. THIS is thousand times more effective then let different turrets do different tasls. You then skirt around the edges of the battlefield picking of the enemys piece by piece because it makes no sense to charge in and do risky stuff. That will just get you killed or addled with immense reparicosts. It doesn't bring you really much to use cover. You can hire ONE additional mercenary but those aren't much more then the turrets you already have. There is nor real strategy to the combatAnd that is a problem because it is boring as hell. Okay that's a lie, it is fun in the beginning, i wouldn't had spend 19 hours in the game otherwise, and testing the different weapons did that. But in the end it is always the exact same. And that very same lack of real strategy was also was cost me that one Escort Mission.With no viable tactics that i could have stopped the different enemys from attacking my charge. There are no weapons that do much beyound damage. There is no REAL variety.But instead of hammering on that point i will tell you what i WISHED it had:First off, give me more bigger ships that i can hire with different real gameplay roles (Give me a tank, a repairiship, a ship that can confuse or disrupt(e.g. debuff) enemy systems with AOE Explosions.Let me give them a strategy and a DIRECT choice of target or missionparameters. Do the same for the enemys and that would give me an incentive do actually dive into enemy ranks and aim for their specific ships.Do the same for the weapons. Gve me a variety of functions. How cool would i have been if i could use point defence flak against missilles, streams of bulletts flying away into the sky with a chance that they miss one and some get trough. How about those same guns don't just affect missilles that attack me but an area around me. Or that ramming shield, make that actually DO SOMETHING. Top five for sure. Basicly think of what it would be like if Empire at War's space battles weren't RTS, or if Battle Star Galactica Online wasn't for wallet warriors and wasn't unbalanced. The locked plane and broadside combat keeps the game simple and exciting and totally un-clunky, although sometimes the menus can be a bit difficult.The ship designs are great too, especially the underated Sorcerer dreadnought (my personal favorite ship, by far) although sometimes the AI targeting gets confused due to the ship's geometry, which was fixed with the sorcerer for the main part but makes the McKinley my least favorite ship so far.Aliens in this game also have good design by being Lovecraftian fish people or rad badger dudes and they all feel Star Wars inspired and combined with the hailing system also add a sort of Star Trek feel.Overall, the game is initially daunting and difficult to get used to, but after you've given it a chance it is absolutely great.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												This game likes to stretch itself out. Normally i don't mind a game that takes me a long time to complete. I like feeling as if i got my money's worth. Good games (like Witcher 3) do this by giving you hours upon hours of enjoyable content and interesting plot. Rebel Galaxy stretches itself out by creating a vast emptiness between everypoint and making your speed very very slow. I get it, it's space, there is supposed to be an emptiness, vast distances between places. So what's the point of giving me a warp drive (one that no matter how much you upgrade still seems slow as hell) if it's still going to take me two minutes to reach anywhere i want to go, and that's only if i'm lucky enough to not get stopped by a group of pirates or an asteroid field. I've spent 17 hours playing this game, the majority of it was spent in transit. All the tension this game gave me was not from space battles or plot development, but instead the worry of wether or not i would reach the next objective anytime soon.If you want to pretend to be a space trucker hauling cargo for days on end, just to afford better gear to slowly move the story forward. then this game is for you.If you're looking for fun, and excitement, look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												First important note: This is not a sim! It looks like a sim in many ways, very customizable ships, sandbox gameplay, in the end though it is not a realistic sim-type game, if for no other reason than lacking an X-axis.What it is though is accessible yet deep, full of options and freedom, an optional story line, surprisingly high production values and a really great sound track. Just overall a very solid game, you'll probably get your moneys worth just in the first system, I know I have!

number of helpful: 14 of 30 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												A game without any need for a player. You make no decisions- just follow a waypoint indicator to the next mission. You don't aim, your weapons autoaim and some of them autofire. There is no terrain, occassional asteroids dot the map but they don't effect combat much. Every set of enemies feels identical - there is no variety whatsoever. The game is played strictly on a 2d plane. The only tactic I ever had to use was kite enemies from long range if I was overwhelmed (which was very rare).  Weapon variety is low and upgrade progression is linear. The music quickly becomes dull, mostly twangy country music. Not a lot of variety. The graphics are nice and ships show damage decalls when hit. There is a big variety in ship size and appearance. It would be nice if a ship 10 times my own ship's size was intimidating at all I guess.Perhaps most telling is the components present in the game. There's a lot of opportunity here, perhaps there could be a part that doubles your speed and halves your shields. Instead all of them give marginal benefits to your ship (like a 10% increase in turning speed). These components are all expensive, requiring more than a dozen missions of farming to get. The entire game is a grind with no need for a player. Why couldn't you find something for me to do Rebel Galaxy?

												The lack of autosave after completing missions makes playing this game tedious and obnoxious. There's no way to run a string of missions and save in between each finished mission. You either have to dock at a space station, which could be very far away, or you have to exit and then restart the game. Do yourself a favor and play a different game that won't constantly rollback all of your progress.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												First game in 11 years on Steam that I've requested a refund.Contrary to what you may read from the starry-eyed youngsters spamming out blue thumbs, this is not a scion of Privateer.  This is a fourth generation knock-off of Privateer designed for the ADD crowd.  The combat is simplistic, mindless, and confusing.  The map scale is tiny.  The... well, if you loved Privateer, you know where I'm headed here.On the bright side, the developers do understand something that most designers of modern free-form space combat/trading games often miss entirely:  Privateer was a huge success because of its atmosphere and "you are there" feeling.  They nailed that part.  Too bad the rest of it sucks skunk sacs.Rather than spend cash on this thing, just give it to Chris Roberts to work on his latest game.  You'll get a far better return on your investment

												Was really excited about this, and feel a tad let down. At it's heart is an ok game. Just...  ok. A few good moments strung together with lots of crappy travelling around (I would love to hear the designer's view as to why asteroid fields stop warp speed.... seriously. It sucks). Samey missions, more travelling, and more than a few ropey balancing issues (you often get whacked as the step ups between enemy levelling is steep. It's not a big deal.. it just means, yup.. more travelling.).  Overall, it's not the new sliced bread, or Freelancer or Elite, or.. You know, actually, it's just a ok-ish game. One to pick up in the sales.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												Naval style combat is good and fun, and it works... if you have a top down view. Unfortunately with Rebel Galaxy it's not a top down view and you can't ever seen where you are aiming or where the enemy ship is. So you never get a hit, you always miss. And by the time you realise you wasted money buying this game, your ship isn't a ship anymore, it's space debris. So fun! Not. Simple design mechanics are overlooked by the developer of this game. They clearly didn't test the game before they went into it and are trying to break even before anyone who doesn't own the game yet realises it's too hard to succeed for a casual game to be fun.

												Runtime Error. a new game of 10-20 minutes from double damage. in this game, if you can, you will encounter subpar voice recording; a map system that you cannot search because consoles don't have keyboards; and random game crashes [in existance since release] that affect a lot of people.seriously, this game crashes for tons of people; you get a runtime error and your graphics drivers crash. but before that happens you'll enounter voiceovers that buzz from low quality microphones, others that echo from being recorded in rooms with little, to none, sound baffeling. you may even get to use the poorly ported games map system which leaves tons to be desired from.got problems? well double damage is so poor they have no forum, so clicking on any links steam provides won't take you anywhere so you'll have to search google and find their page which redirects you to steam after it redirects you from double damages unexistant studio page(yaye for godaddy placeholders). you will find that the dev mostly engaged in futile redirections for your issue, and sure enough, failed to fix the issues probably because his little nestegg was designed to farm consoles for a quick buck and he has no real skill at diagnosing the problem; indeed the game doesn't even file error reports.i'm sure loads of you will have no problem, you'll most likely neg my review; but i can't recomend a game i can't play for more then 20 minutes, one that only saves in stations, one with poor quality sound, an epic level of underdesign(freelancer, yeah, right), and one in which the dev obviously is another indy wallet farm. there is plenty of games from active developers, i'm just going to get a refund. but if you're feeling lucky, go ahead.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												The control scheme and game mechanics for combat and controls are very cumbersome.  This game is not a first person simulator but forces your camera view to behave like one.    You can't exactly lock your camera to a top down view  and still hope to actually do any fighting at the same time since it is heavily dependant on your camera to be swerving around to the sides of the ship to enable attacking/aiming/shooting.The 'rpg' adventure aspect is very shallow/empty.  It's just one big fetch/delivery/grind with no depth to the world.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												So I've had this game for a couple of days and have a dozen hours on it or so and my overal impression is 'meh' with a side of 'boring'.I found the start of the game very infuriating, the controls didn't work on a laptop (although they were fine when I reconfigured them). But combat is still a pain, many of the actions you can perform while flying demand the camera to be facing a certain direction and you can't steer you're ship while simultaneously aiming a broadside. But that's kind of OK, it just means that the game is aimed at beginers of this genre. It does do somethings well, like having shields and armour go down on different parts of the ship independently. Would be nice if they could also be upgraded independently.Which brings me to my biggest gripe about the game. Upgrading your ship is dull. You have only a handful of options per part, which then go from Mk1 to Mk2 to Mk3, etc... Doesn't feel like an accomplishment to have my top speed under boost increase by 10%. Add to that that every battle feels the same (unless there are some unseen possible tactics I haven't come across) and the world is bland.Basically, when ever I played this game only one thought crossed my mind "Why am I not playing X3: Terran Conflict ?". It's not a perfect game by far, but it has all the depth that Rebel Galaxy lacks. It's not that it's a bad game, it just isn't interesting enough for me to make it fun. Perhaps the plot could have rescued it, but after 10h it is also boring and repetitive

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												The vast majority of reviews are quite decieving for this game, in that they paint a picture for this game that makes it seem like more than it really is.The 2D naval combat and the camera that's way too close makes the game feel extremely small and claustrophobic and makes combat a nuisance at best, and on top of the terrible camera, the heavy amounts of aim assist make it very dull, tracking your shots hardly matters since your shots effectively home in on the target so long as you're in range and have charged your broadside shots and the turrets are literally an autolock and fire themselves when you're in broadside mode.The controls and functionality are very off-putting as well, this game was very obviously made for consoles and wasn't properly ported to PC, there are no options in game, only a settings launcher that pops up before you enter the game so if you want to change anything at all you have to restart the game before you can. Keyboard and mouse controls feel pretty slip and slide too.Finally there's all the comparisons to Freelancer I want to put to bed.I played Freelancer for hours, probably hundreds of hours, I absolutely ADORED Freelancer, it was the ideal space sim for a plebian like me, nice and simple and really pretty while still feeling like it's in space.This however is no Freelancer.The combat is way too basic, the movement is way too restricted, the world is far too claustrophobic. Everythings packed and squeezed into this tiny 2D space where the concept of up and down are alien to the player character.Sorry Freelancer fans, you're gonna have to keep going without.Overall this game's pretty naff.It should have been a Naval game.

In the beginning, there seems to be very little variety to these missions. Maybe the odd colletion job, more yawn...All the positive reviews seem to come from players whi have played this a number of hours, while the opposite seems true for the negative ones? Is it the intro \ early game which is so poor? I will try to give it some more time.

												A shallow main story coupled with repetative side missions make this game a stinker. Side mission types: take this here, take this guy here, kill that guy there. Bigger ships just get more turrets, broadsides, and nigh useless, expensive and selectable components. A small corvette feels the same as a giant cruiser. There is about 15 different weapons with more expensive "Mk" versions offering slightly higher damage or cooldown buffs as the game progresses (Blaster Mk.1, Blaster Mk.2 ... ad nauseum). You get stuck on story missions due to enemy difficulty; go grind so you can do the next main mission. Repeat. The limited ship customization, boring weapon choices, and repetative tasks make this game a snoozefest. There may be life out there in a galaxy far, far away, but it isn't this one. grindfest/10

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Stay AWAY from this one.  Yep it's only 10 bucks most of the time, but the save game system on this title is ABSOLUTELY the WORST one that could possibly be implemented.  Simply put...this game does NOT know when to automaticly save a game that you can recover from.  It's that simple.  Get blasted to smithereens in a battle and need to restart....yep, thats right...your autosave restarts you as blasted to smithereens.  What could these Developers have possibley been thinking to have implemented such a piece of junk?It's easier to completely restart the game from scratch, than to recover from an autosave when you're first starting out - thats just how stupid this save game system is.  It makes playing the game SO damn frustrating, that whatever good points the game may actually have is completely overshadowed by the inability to recover from an autosave.TL;DR  Save's suck so pass this game by.

BUT...I was not able to play the game due to the clunky "Broadside"/action sequences. I would have liked an option to turn on an A.I. "Gun crew" to handle all combat as an RPG player. Even the Broadside. As it turned out, after I bought Rebel Galaxy, Steam had a "similar game" recommendation at the bottom.  It is a free game that was more of what I was looking for playstyle-wise. So now I play that and Rebel Galaxy sits untouched. I rate it 2 stars out of five for potential I was not able to tap.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Stay AWAY from this one.  Yep it's only 10 bucks most of the time, but the save game system on this title is ABSOLUTELY the WORST one that could possibly be implemented.  Simply put...this game does NOT know when to automaticly save a game that you can recover from.  It's that simple.  Get blasted to smithereens in a battle and need to restart....yep, thats right...your autosave restarts you as blasted to smithereens.  What could these Developers have possibley been thinking to have implemented such a piece of junk?It's easier to completely restart the game from scratch, than to recover from an autosave when you're first starting out - thats just how stupid this save game system is.  It makes playing the game SO damn frustrating, that whatever good points the game may actually have is completely overshadowed by the inability to recover from an autosave.TL;DR  Save's suck so pass this game by.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Probably the closest thing to a Firefly game we'll probably get. One of the most remarkable things is how much freedom you have. Wanna be a roaming lawbringer helping traders and the local Militia? You can do that. Wanna be a smuggler sneaking contraband under the nose of the local authorities. Go right ahead! Hell, do you wanna make money shrewdly analyzing market prices system wide and raking in the profit. Then take it its yours! Granted you will sometimes run across enemies that can spank you from here to the end of the galaxy and have to run and to be honest I'm just fine with that. It makes you feel like you're really part of this larger galaxy, you're not the end all be all, just another spacer wandering the galaxy. See you later space cowboy.P.S- That soundtrack is baller as hell.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												I am actually surprised that a low buget game like Rebel Galaxy can have so much content in one go. Trading, Pirating, Distress calls, Even random events that affect the local markets or station access. The world is yours to toy with but you still need to pay attention to what is going on. You dont want to slam straight into a space station where there is a invasion going down. (Unless you are planning on clearing it up of course)The combat is different that in other space oriented games. As you are flying Capital grade ships you cant fly UP or DOWN. Sounds bad but hang on. Fact is you dont need to. With some work your ship becomes a flying fortress. With plasma !BROADSIDES! and enough turrets on it to wipe out a fleet.As for valuing defense and offence its your call. Personally i like being up close so i took some fast acting cannons for close quarters. More damage, less range. The game is FULL of tradeoffs when it comes to arnament. So you need to pick your method carefully. Personally i HIGHLY recommend this game to any game progression enthusiasts with a limited budget. The game is cheap, VERY long if you want to play all the way, and there are enough tactics and explosions around for a great experience. 10 out of 10 in my book.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												First mission, with tutorials - controls: E/Q for engines up/down, W/S for speed boost/brake, A/D for turning left/right. So how do you change your pitch? You don't. That's right, this space sim is completely 2D. Everything is in the same plane - tars, planets, stations, ships. You can't even roll your ship. That's because combat is "naval" style - with broadsides! With the freedom of 3-dimensional space and with the technological possibilities of a spacefaring civilization, the best solution is to fire your guns from the sides of your ship, in the general direction of the enemy. Like sailships.Why didn't you make an actual sailship game? If you wanted alines, you could have made it in a fantasy setting, rather than Caribean, but your battle mechanics would make sense. Here, they just suck.Also, what good is my sensor system? I can scan other ships for cargo and battle strenght, but only after I'm so close that they actually attack. So scan that ship, see that it's too powerful, take a wide detour? Not happening. This is not a space simulation. Don't know what it is and don't want to know.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												Does not start on Mac OS Mavericks. Many people who do not want to upgrade to Mac OS ElCapitan for valid reasons have reported about this problem since early October 2015 and until now, 8 months later, this is not fixed. There are some hacks in some forums that helped some people but not all of them (including me). This is really bad service, as the problem seems to be quite simple to fix from the producers' side (make their launcher start in full screen without using the most fancy ElCapitan methods to do so). It is just about the launcher, not the game itself. This should be a simple task. However, without the launcher to set the game options, the game itself starts only in not-playable configuration. A catch-22 for the end user who has paid money for playing it. So, thumbs down from my side.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												This game is everything I had hoped Elite Dangerous would be. Structurally, both games are very similar: you hop round the galaxy trading, mining, exploring, bounty-hunting and doing various missions, all the while earning credits so you can upgrade your ship and equipment. The main difference being this game removes all the tedium that ED insists you go through repeatedly and infinitely. Elite's station docking was fun for an hour or two, but after the 1000th dock, you just wish they'd just remove it...Rebel Galaxy removes this and you just insta-dock! Elite's 5 minutes with absolutely NOTHING to do while you warp to another station was never fun, and RG condenses this to a 10-30 second jump where you actually have some dodging and janking to do. Design decisions like this might make RG a more casual game than ED, but for me it also makes it 1000% more playable.This brings us to the combat. Purists will frown on Rebel Galaxy for it's 2-D implementation of space versus Elite's glorious 3D, but at the end of the day the combat is arcadey in both games, and RG's combat simply manages to be much more FUN. And certainly more epic. 30+ ship battles while you blast fighters with your short range turrets, broadside their capital ships and unleash homing missiles at everything else are far more epic than anyting Elite managed to throw my way.So my final description is that Rebel Galaxy is Elite with all the tedium removed, an actual story added, way better missions, and with considerably more fun combat. Which is what I've wanted in a space game since I racked up hundreds of hours of the original Elite on my Spectrum sometime back in the 1980s.TLDR: 8/10* this game is everything Elite Dangerous should have been* I would give this game 9/10 but for one annoying feature....you cannot view the local station map while docked. This means that you cannot easily plan the best cargo to buy or the best missions to take because you cannot see the optimum routes around the sector without seeing that local map. It's a quality of life thing that proves more frustrating than it might sound. If they fix that, this is a solid 9/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												This is a game that starts out incredible and quickly becomes repetitive and boring. The more I played it the less I enjoyed it. I was immediately pulled in with a fantastic soundtrack and interesting gameplay. However I realized very rapidly that the bit I got at the start was basically all there was. There's retrieval, protection, and shipping and those are your main mission types. You can mine for some ore to trade and you can buy low and sell high based on random events in the system you're in. It very quickly feels hollow because who cares if planet z is having problems so they need more of y item that you can buy elsewhere. None of it matters at the end, the issues resolve regardless of what you do. The main quest seems interesting enough but the quests are the same "blow up the bads retrieve mystic object" nonsense that the side quests are.Overall an interesting idea but not deep enough.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Although I can't recommend this game, I did not hate it. It was all right and the price is fair. The main problem in my opinion is that every combat situation is basically the same. While the combat is OK it gets old really soon.The main story is hardly the centerpiece, as everything else in this game it's (just) OK. The last mission was quite dissapointing, as a matter of fact I didn't even realize I was in the last stand off against the main baddies until it was over.Even though finished the main story I only visited 1/3 of all solar systems, partially bacause the story didn't take me there and parrtially because there was no reason to go there. In fact all systems are basically the same (the third I saw). The second biggest problem after the staleness of combat is that the ship design isn't varried enough. There is little reason to buy the smaller faster ships. You basically buy the biggest "mobile weapons platform" smack a bunch of guns on it, park it in the middle of an eneny fleet and light them up.Buying defensive upgrades soon is the best investment, esspecially an early mk5 shield and plating. Unfortunatelly it makes the combat even more drab, because you bassically cannot die (for most of the game).

												2d space combat?  What a joke... 3 dimensions are always better than 2.  Graphics are pretty iffy... controls are even worse.  Combat is slow and painful. It's been a long time since I have played a game that hits that special spot of enjoyment that makes me just want to keep playing. I love this game...--UDATE--Having finally made it to the second system, I can say that I am absolutely pleased with this game. Unfortunately, I was totally unprepared for how much herder that new system was, so I had to go back.Man! This game is awesome!I haven't played it for a very long time, but what I have played, I certainly like. The ships all feel different, the progression feels substantial, and getting new weapons and systems for each ship makes everything feel a lot more visceral. One of my favourite things about the game is that you can fit up your ship with some new gear and truly feel a difference in power, making you feel like a real space bad@ss. Certainly worth the asking price, in my books.

content:
Posted: January 7
												The game starts out as a kind of Southern Rock response to Firefly - which sounds awesome! If you like space sims with a variety of play options, you may enjoy this. I gave it a thumbs down for two reasons.First, everything is a grind. Getting a ship strong enough to compete and survive beyond the first sector costs millions of credits. You'll spend hours of gameplay chasing bigger ships, which do not seem to significantly change or develop play. Missions, trading, mining, piracy, pirate hunting... it's all the same thing over and over again. The story is alright, but not good enough to warrant a game that is all grind.The main reason I gave it a thumbs down is that there's a line in one of the main songs that loops over and over again that is EXTREMELY sexist (talking about a woman who is a "sleaze" and not worth a man's time). It's really gross that they decided to include something like that in an otherwise ok space sim.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												This is a wonderful open-world space game with a lot to offer, but my hours are low and I'm giving it a thumbs-down because I just can't get past the horrid UI.The UI for this game is very obviously designed for consoles and not for PC, but even after plugging in a controller and trying it that way, I found myself getting frustrated.  Some things that I don't like, roughly in order of most irritating:Waiting for information to cycle.  When looking at commodities, whether on the commodities screen or on the map, instead of having a scrollable list, pages/lines will cycle every 4 seconds or so.  This creates a) a lot of waiting and b) you can't stop the cycle when your item comes up and actually read it.All scrolling lists and menus move one item at a time.  You can still select something with the mouse if it's on the screen, though, assuming you can see it or figure out what it is while it's grayed out.No way to display the sector map while docked.No way to create multiple waypoints, meaning you can't plan out routes that navigate around hostiles or asteroid belts.No way to zoom your camera in/out, resulting in a lot of screen space always being occupied by your (albeit gorgeous) ship.No speed indicator on the HUD, for you or your targets.If the UI gets fixed, I'll likely dump countless hours into this game and come back and rewrite my review, but until then, I can only say that it feels like a really clunky console port.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
 Interested in No Man's Sky? Dissapointed in No Man's Sky? Just get Rebel Galaxy.  It has pretty much everything that that game has, but it also has a lot more. Here's a list of features: More world types (Sand, gas, etc... Can't land on 'em though) Large battlesA jobs boardShip renaming, Distress signals, Mercenaries, Bigger ships, Exploration bonuses Unique factions Faction affiliation, Randomly generated worlds You can be a trader, mercenary, pirate, soldier, miner, etc... You can actually negotiate your way out of battles! Space looks lovely, and the lighting and sound design is epic. Battles are absolute chaos, but awesome.  And all this paired with some great music! Whilst it is singleplayer, and is on a 2D plane (with 3D models, think Assassins Creed Black Flag Ships), it is much better than this game. You can travel across multiple star systems (not a whole galaxies, sadly), and each planet is randomly generated. Each planet has their own specialities (Mining, war-like, trading, prison planet(!), etc... Some are gas planets, some are barren, etc...You can't land on them, but that is pretty much my only gripe with this game. I bought this before I heard of No Man's Sky, so I was not dissapointed. But the game is still pretty as f###Raiding a trade ship can actually ruin the prices of a planet's economy, which you can then exploit. Selling munitions at a planet that is at war can get you more profit. There are multiple factions. Pirates, civilians, the militia, the mafia/crime bosses, or just be a merc! Small note to Angry Joe: You can scan any ship you want, see their race, freight, ship name, etc... ;) Also, it's 20 F###### DOLLARS.﻿

												Excellent potential, but the save system is hands down the worst implementation of saves i have experienced.  Without the ability to manually save the game, if you make a single mistake and getting into deep trouble and the system auto-saves you in that state, your game is ruined and you have to restart.  I played for nearly two hours and lost everything because a red marauder team caught me and I couldn't escape.  A no win scenario that effectively destroys your save game isn't a 'challenge', its a game killer.  I refuse to devote more time to a game that doesn't give you the ability to protect your progress with a manual save option.  Until then, this is a game wiating to frustrate you to the point you uninstall it.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												I understood this game wouldn't have the real kind of depth I was looking for, but felt it would be good enough as a simple time killer.  I like the 2D plane naval style battles.  What I don't like is not owning multiple ships with different setups.  Mining is really more complicated than it should be for this type of game.  If my mining laser is on the bottom of the ship, good luck hitting an asteroid above your ship.  Scanning for asteroids gives no information of what you are mining for and as far as I can tell there is no item that does.  Certain weapons seemingly fire through your ship even though vision is blocked.  Really it's not a terrible game, but it's not a particularly good one.  Galaxy On Fire has more depth than this game.  The combat is good and interesting, the story is good and even the voice acting is good.  Graphics are fine.  Some small details were missed and the game was dumbed down more than it needed to be.  If you are looking for something really simple, then this game is for you.  It's on Galaxy On Fire's level.  If you are the type who likes the X Series or was into Eve Online and you were looking for something kind of in between in the single player realm, you will be slightly disappointed.

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												I wanted to like this game.  I really did.  Reading other reviews and watching videos reminded me of Escape Velocity: Nova, a great Ambrosia game from oh so long ago.  I thought that this game could capture the same magica that game possesed but with the updated flare of almost 20 years of gaming advances.Unfortunatly, I was wrong.Combat in Rebel Galaxy feels dry, leaving you endlessly flying in circles trying to keep fighters on screen.  Capital ship combat, while entertaining for the first 20 minutes, comes down to trying to land as many broadsides as possible which, once again, leads to flying in circles.The 2-d movement that was great in a top down space trading game like Escape Velocity is restrictive and unnatural.  At no point could I suspend my disbelief and imagine that I was piloting a space ship.  Any sense of immersion is ruined by this element.With all that said the game isn't bad looking and the price is pretty low.  That might be enough to make this game an enjoy able experience for some but it didn't make it worth it for me.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												(Review based on preview copy provided by developers)Rebel Galaxy is a Space Opera with some pretty legendary names behind its creation, and it definitely shows. There's no question that it's worth the asking price of $20 USD - though it does have its pros and cons worth considering if it's the perfect fit for you, as well as some gameplay aspects some people will enjoy more than others.----Important Notes:- This game involves trading, mining, and most of all - combat. - Combat is based on Naval combat, not standard 6-degree space combat, you will be using broadside cannons, ramming, and turrets for your capital ship on a horizontal plane (non capital ships use the full 6 degrees of freedom, but you don't get to fly those :P). This leads to interesting, yet still very satisfying, combat.- You have access to a lot of control with your ship, a lot of choices, including what tools you employ and how your weapons behave in battle - and they definitely have an impact on how you play.-You also have the ability to toy with alliances and factions, to change the system (improving/destroying your relations with different factions changes how you play the game)- Combat, either through Bounties, Missions, or Random Encounters will be your fastest way to gather resources and progress - though Trading/Mining are definitely still somewhat viable options.----Pros:- Good visuals, with satisfying explosions, weapon fire, etc. And visible damage on your ship.- Amazing audio assets (and the ability to customize the audio if you want). Voice Acting is "good", not stellar, but the explosions, music, etc. are insanely well chosen.- Combat caters to both the casual captain and the aggressive player ( you can hang out on the fringe of battles, letting the automated turrets do the work, or you can dive in ramming/blasting with your broadsides, while ducking and dodging through swarms of bullets)- Solid story, while it won't win any awards, it's on par with Blizzard storylines ( "Okay" campaign story, Great universe )- Lots of freedom of choice... and travel. Aided by procedural generation of the sectors - so no 2 playthroughs are the same.- Fairly well optimized (sad that I have to note this, but compared to a lot of other games with similar visual fidelity lately - this one barely taxes my system at max settings)----Cons:- Can get repetative after a while (go to point a, Kill stuff, get money, repeat) - but this tends to happen after the 10-20 hour mark for me. It does follow a formula similar to Diablo/Torchlight/etc. in that regard. - Can be slow paced at times, especially when a mission spawns more than 5000-6000 sm away, there is no fast travel within a sector, and while warp is fine for medium length trips, you will sometimes run into the issue of "staring at the back of your ship twiddling your thumbs". - "Out of Game" options menu... each time you launch you have the choice of changing the options, but you can't really change them in-game - so you might be restarting a few times to find the settings perfect for you.----Works well with a controller or mouse & keyboard, despite their recommendations.

			Rebel Galaxy, a space opera and a crazy adventure into naval style combat in space - beautiful graphics and engrossing music. Rebel Galaxy shows the experience of its developers (among them the legendary Erich Shaeffer...
