content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												[HUGE VALUE - Buy This Game!] To relate this to another game - It's like that new Mad Max game [Sandbox Game with Huge Amounts of Sidemissions along with a Story to Push the Game Forward] - but in space and with naval combat. Your ship has turrets - one on the port side which you typically wanna aim with and the rest automatically shoot at what you want them to shoot at. The game is way big and you'll find yourself grinding missions and being immersed in the experience. Devs have worked really hard at making this the best game it can possibly be. Give them some of your money and your time. You won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												The game balance is all kinds of drunk. The side missions, of which you'll do a whole load, have Risk estimates next to them. These estimates are entirely useless. You can get face melted in a Normal, and never even notice your shields getting touched in a Very High. The power boost between gear levels is also really large, more than 50% boost usually. This means you're going to get melted often when heading into a new area whilst you try to scrape together the money to make your ship competitive. This power difference pretty much kills the immersion as well. Why are two systems, right next door to each other, at such differences in weapon tech? Why doesn't a single ship from the high area go to the low area and just take over? They'd be completely untouchable?

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												I was hoping for Mount and Blade meets Firefly. What I got was neither. This game has so much potential, but is hugley hurt by a number of things.(If you're wondering why my play time is so low its because I plan to get a refund and because the glaring problems are obvious from the start.)Firstly the thing I noticed first that bugged me was that, you ARE LOCKED TO A SINGLE PLANE OF MOVEMENT!(sounds small but it is SO annoying) Now if this were top down, this wouldnt be a problem, but the view is thrid person, making it painfully obvious how limited you are. What makes it worse is that other ships (including those you fight) can fly freely, making combat confusing and disorienting.Second, the graphics, nice enough at first (tough not at all cutting edge) but the problem there isn't poorly done graphics, it's OVERDONE graphics, I am being entirley honest when I say that the lens flare/ lighting effects during (one dimensional)'flight' actually HURT to look at.And finally, parts of it just feel....off. Little things, like a cramped UI in stations with loads of wasted space, or dialogues with characters (which are admittedley quite nicley done) feeling far too zoomed in and with no ability to use the keyboard for dialouge choices (up, down, enter or even 1,2 and 3).It's a nice idea that wasn't done badly, but its just not quite 'right' to play. I cant honestley recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12
												Space exploration game. It's like a super dumbed down Elite: Dangerous, which would be amazing EXCEPT combat is impossibly frustrating. Why? The whole combat system is based on side cannons, like a pirate ship in space. Only thing is, you cant move in a 3D space. Not so bad, except for your enemies can. Still not the worst, seems like it's ok, until you realize you can't aim your side cannons up or down. So the whole time, if you have unguided cannons, you're missing. You get 3 hits on a guy, deplete their shields, and then they fly below you. You can't aim at them, your turrets miss majority of the time, and by the time you can hit them again their shields are refilled. Awful combat system, making the game so frustrating that large fights become impossible.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												I quit the game right before being destroyed, just to save a few seconds and avoid the respawn at last checkpoint. But it autosaved there.So now my save game only goes to a place where I get blown up, and can't escape.I think it's telling of my feelings about the game that I kinda decided, "oh, well, I guess that's the last time I play this game." and shrugged my shoulders.I was 37 hours into that game. I'm sure when I was younger I would have burned down the developers. But really, my apathy towards never being able to play that game again probably is as harsh a burn as I'm capable of delivering at this point.The first dozen or so times you do each mission are fun. Then it's just endless grinding. I'm not going to ever play this game again, because I'd have to start a new game, which would be a ton of grinding to get to where I was, which was a part of the game that involved grinding. I think the price is fair, but I can't say that it's actually worth all the time required to beat it. If you play it for a dozen or more hours and have a good time, just stop when you don't like it any more. It will not change or get better.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Just a few minutes into the game and i'm telling ya, its so worth it.I love almost everything about this game. The soundtrack is dope, the voice acting is fitting, the controls are good enough. Though nothing beats the combat style in this game. Classic naval style combat! First hostile ship i ran into felt a few volleys of my broadsides and he legged it, though not before letting his puny shields and deflectors soak some of it up. And i was like, "Wow, really?" as i finished him with a few scatter laser shots. Heh, good times.Makes me wonder how 2 blokes managed to come up with something like this. It would take a helluva lot of effort to come up with this, even for the big time developer companies. Its quite astonishing that they managed it, enough to make me feel like i should pay for the full price of this game.So far, i haven't found anything bad about this game. So as for now, i'll give it a 10/10.Also, get the soundtrack once it comes out, if you want. Just think of it as a gesture of gratitude for the developers.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												I've logged 34 hours into the game as of writing this review.The game has been nothing short of an exceptional experience. From the very moment you start the game, you get a good sense of what you're getting into. The music sets the tone to this sort of grungy, rockabilly space Western. It's full of character has a good sense of "space". All this despite playing like a sort of "World of Warships meets Elite: Dangerous" hybrid between space exploration and naval combat. I highly recommend buying this game.Pros:Full controller support (including optional Playstation layout).Tight Mouse&Keyboard controls.Very pretty graphics and effects.Visible modular ship damage.Many graphics settings in the launcher.Superb soundtrack.Optional custom soundtrack to replace OR supplement the original soundtrack.Fluid combat mechanics.More lasers than I sometimes know what to do with.Unique and lively NPC interactions.Moderate learning curve.VERY attentive and responsive developers constantly patching reported issues.Cons:Enemy dialogue is sometimes repetitive.No vertical travel (2D movement only).Objects (like Cargo) sometimes block docking or other actions.Slaves (Cargo) have no clear way to be saved other than forfeiting to Militia (-4 rep penalty).Single-player only (for now).

number of helpful: 12 of 31 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Game is fun, but limited. This game is Sid Meier's Pirates LITE. You have no major interaction with any factions, and can not partake in major game map changing ways. It's essentially the combat of Sid Meier's in Space, with nothing close to SMP's metagame. It's the very definition of shallow. Everything will one way or another end up with a blaster in your face. You want to trade or mine? Good luck. You'll be needing a good turret.Ultimately I don't recommend this game despite the fact that I know a lot of people may enjoy it. I respect it's sea-naval intentions, but I just am TOO much of a fan of proper scifi stuff and not arcade based games to enjoy this.My ideal Scifi games are along the lines of Nexus, and Homeworld. I find this to be very simplistic, to it's own detriment because it gets CLUSMY quickly with combat. It's not hard to stay oriented, but it is HARDER than it should be. Camera + controls (really, gamepad optimal, who are you kidding) + enemies + lack of distinct options controlling your own weapons makes this game a hassle. Added on top of it, that it's a big ol'grind fest in a single player game, and you lose my interest quickly.That said, there aren't a lot of good scifi options these days, so a lot of people will find the 20$ entry fee to be acceptable for the amount of entertainment within.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												Save your money..... worst of the space sim group.PROSCool music and easy to navigate, ship upgrade path straight forward. Overall game had promise, until...CONSTERRIBLE combat broadside junk aiming mechanic, ruins the game play. It takes literally forever to hit anything with the lazy aiming system. Hold right mouse until you get a yellow path to aim, left to fire.  Misses everytime or does little damage. I really can't say enough bad things about how poorly thought out this part of the game is. Funny, that most of the game is about combat interactions and this part failed so badly. It's a shame because otherwise it seemed unique, but is unplayable due to this frustrating design idea. Sailing ships in space, no thanks!Overall a waste of $20The solid reviews must be rigged from devs. Too bad Steam doesn't give refunds on this trash indie stuff. Fix your broken core mechanic and allow weapons to hit something and maybe the game could work.Starpoint Gemini 2 is 1000x times more playable.

Posted: October 22, 2015
												The game is pretty fun but lacks much content to be a $17.99 game. There needs to be more complexity with ships, turrets, etc. Large annoyances include being pulled out of warp when coming into contact with unavoidable things like asteroids. I havnt put much time into the game but from first impressions these are my thoughts. I think the game should have been released as an alpha game due to the lack of content. What is put together now is bug free but there isnt much here. One example is that in all 6 hours i played I saw maybe 3 unique avatar/voices of enemy ships. There are a total of 3 turrets for broadside, 6 if you include the 2nd tier which is the exact same just more speed and damage. Id be happy to pay 17.99 for a game with alot of content but this seems like a sub $10 game in its current form.

												This game starts with a fantastic promise: Getting something between Wing Comander Privateer and X³. Checking the Settings turns out: This game is a 2 dimensional space shoter.The idea of space is to have 3 dimensions but here there is only a third dimension for the blow-flies. What distroys any immersion from this point on is, that there is no reasonable explanation for this 2D-space-fake. Why?

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												OS X review below:--Game is nice, especially soundtrack – sets the mood perfectly and is very pleasant to listen to.There is however a major problem on OS X – XBox controller is not supported. Game controls and menus are clearly optimized for gamepads, but mouse look is laggy and has too much inertia. Lining up broadsided are a pain (inertia is OK with analog sticks, with mouse it is annoying as hell), turret control is just horrible (see above).FOV could be wider (or adjustable) – your ship taking 1/4 of screen at all times is very annoying, especially on ultrawide screens. And it's not pretty on big screen, textures are console-quality and look muddy.P.S. Regarding gameplay – warp! It is boooooring. You undock, you warp, you watch distance decreasing for 2 minutes. You fight, you win, you warp, you watch distance decreasing for 2 minutes. Rinse, repeat.I won't recommend this game to Mac users – game is designed for gamepad, gamepad is not supported.

number of helpful: 9 of 28 people (32%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Disappointing to say the least, basically its similar to Eve but without any p2p or pvp. Very vanilla economy. Super generic quests, you can literally have multiple instances of the same quest. You can go ratting. You can go mining. Would not recommend going trading. Single pane (no up/ down) essentially no 3d movement in a space game??? Why???  Pretty I'll give it that. Broadsides are nice but its gimmicky. Sound track is good but it is a short soundtrack. So after the first hour or less you will hear the same songs again and again and again. Pointless. Targeting sucks. to interact with anything you have to get pretty darn close which is just dumb. Travel between quests takes too long, you can upgrade your travel speed but it’s still pretty darn slow.  I want to like it but meh boring...

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												This game evolves from games like Star Flight, Star Fleet and Freelancer with the interface and game play being most like Freelancer(almost a re-write).  I liked Freelancer and must've played through 3 or 4 times.   The graphics and UI from this game most resemble Freelancer.For me the whole broadside pirate style of battling is confusing enough that this game likely has not much time left on my hard drive.  No story line to speak of, no character developement, same 4 options to get a mission on each planet/station/location.  I can live with everything except the battle perspective issue, it would've been much better to have a♥♥♥♥♥♥pit view of battle like other flying games.  It would also be nice of while flying around you could choose between first and third person views.  Also annoying game play plot issues like can't pick up debris cargo withpout a tractor beam but you have to run earand missions to earn enough to get one, should be part of the base ship configuration, same with weapons, start with nothing being the target for every bandit who wants to shoot you down.Had I played a demo of this game I would not have purchased.  I wish I had gotten the new Defender instead of this game.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												This is just bad. I was excited about this game leading up to launch but after playing it... wow. I kept telling meself "well, this isn't great but maybe it will get better".  It feels like someone had an interesting idea for a game and perhaps pulled together a working prototype of a concept and then proceeded to paste minimal elements of a game around it. Menus, models, story... all seriously lacking.The space physics don't feel good at all. You can bounce your ship into things and well.... and nothing, it just bounces off. I don't mind that it is on a 2D plane but the models for ships, asteroids, space stations... all look like they were made 10 years ago.And the story is awful. really really awful. Again, it feels like the bare minimal to move the player forward into... something. I would like to say these feels like beta but that would be too generous. This feels like a early access alpha build. shame.

number of helpful: 14 of 75 people (19%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Disliked that there is no manual or much of a tutorial in the game so good luck with all the controls.  I learned in the forums after a kind soul let me know that there are videos/links to videos in the game if you press esc/start button and look for them in the menus there.   Never would have thought that the equivalent of the manual? i guess would be in the menu.Most of everyone else was busy saying the equivalent of 'man up', so not the greatest community if you are looking for any kind of help.The game might be fun but you will have to put up with non-intuitive controls until the developers improve them or actually give more information to the players.  So at this point the game seems more to be in EA state rather than released state.  I say EA because games in those states are the ones that I expect with no manual/minimal explanation of controls when control scheme is not intuitive.Also becareful since some of the reviews mention that it reminds them of other games space games like freelancer/(insert awesome space game) but they fail to mention that the game movement/combat is in 2D like Starpoint Gemini.So TLDR; Gamble: might be good but be warned that controls aren't the best and community not the most helpful.  This game is more like an enhanced Starpoint Gemini.Edit:The review mentions community as since the 'tutorial' to basic keys is lacking then it means that the users have to rely on 'community'. On the plus side though the developers seem to be good though so there is a future.CONS:- Controls not all intuitive- Tutorial, according to other players you have to play > 15mins before you actually get to it.- Aweful community (don't expect help from 90% of it and have a thick hide when asking).- Universe is 2D like Starpoint Gemini (some people like this so if you are ok with it then you good).PRO:- Devs seem to nice and involved so a few weeks or months the game might become much better.- Possible gem in the future, so maybe hold out until later.

Posted: March 15
												Rebel Galaxy is pretty addicting but is painfully short.  My first, and likely only, run through was brief.  You don't need to max out your ship and equipment to beat the game.  It's nice that anything you buy you sell for the exact same amount.  This really means you can try out everything without consquence.  But because of that there is no real need to play through more than once.I had considered going again just to try out being a pirate but the main story just wasn't interesting enough.  The side missions are a grind for money and they aren't that fun.  You either can win a fight or there is no way to win it  till you get a better ship or equipment.The economy is pretty easy to figure out and that can allow for you to earn money way to fast for the game to be a challenge.  I'm glad I played it but I'd be pretty mad if I had paid more than $10, which I didn't.Wait for a sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												This game tries hard to emulate Freelancer or Privateer, but sadly fails. 1. The look and feelLooks ok, especially considering this is an indie title. Especially the spaceships have a cool touch to them.2. ControlsInstead of freelancer or even EVE controls, they decided to do some strange console like UI navigation & flight controls on a 2D plane orientation (in space?!?). They felt clunky and unintuitive to me.3. Combat and space gameplayThis is in my oppinion the biggest issue - the broadside combat might be a good idea in theory, but not how it is applied here - since the ships often behave more like fighter craft than behemoth ships shooting broadsides at each other, it is highly annoying to control. And most of it is strangely semi automated with snapping auto aims etc. - I get the feeling this was "consoled" down.Why not just do something classic like freespace or freelancer? Free movement and skill aiming in a full 3D environment, not on a 2D plane with strange autoaim and clunky movement?4. Strange camera behaviorReally annoying was the camera, which would zoom in and zoom out during screen switchens (and interpreting this as a warp)5. Story I guess 15 years ago, it was quite ok to receive storyline quests from some shady guys in a spaceport bar.  Transfer it to today in a slighly better 3D look instead of pixel characters, and it no longer is so cool. Especially since the writing does not hook you. 6. Who put the afterburner on "W" and not on "tab" - seriously :)FacitSeeing all the positive feedback, there are defenitly pilots who will like this game, and it is probably not a bad game. From the previews I thought i would like it too. But after really playing it - it just doesn't feel right. Guess waiting for a reboot of freelancer then.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												The game play is fun. After awhile, I got used to the 2D/Broadsides combat, and it doesn't feel like I'm missing as much as I feel I should. But, it's not as fleshed out as it could be either. Otherwise, it's a great modern freeform space sim that lets you live the life of a spacer with a clear mission to work on in the meantime.The best thing for me, though, is the soundtrack. It's rare to find a game that completely nails it to the point that the soundtrack becomes so crucial to the game that without it, it starts to fall apart. I made the mistake of trying to customize the soundtrack... I thought I could mix my own flavor of dirty-guitar, bluesy rock, etc, and I should have just left it alone. When you hear friends talk about how great the soundtrack of Fallout 4 is and how well it helps define the game... that's the level of audio immersion in atmosphere that comes to mind here. Parallels to Firefly have been drawn a thousand-times over already, and the soundtrack is as responsible for that relationship as anything else. I rarely care about game music, and often turn it off, but here... I'll never listen to a space sim the same way again.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												The men who built Rebel Galaxy, Travis Baldree and Erich Schaefer, have a damn good record when it comes to making enjoyable games. Diablo, Fate, Torchlight; these guys seem to make games for gamers. With Rebel Galaxy they have proven to me that they just flat out understand how to make a good game. The sci-fi atmosphere is a mix between Star Wars and Serenity and the ship pilot gameplay fits in perfectly to the overall feel of the game. The story missions are interesting and voice-acted pretty damn well, though you can ignore them for the most part if you wish and start your own trouble within the local system until you're ready to get back to it.The ship buying and customization is implemented in a way that everything you do is working towards your next upgrade, so you do not feel like you are wasting time or money on anything. Your upgrades either transfer over to your new ship, or can be used as credit towards better weapons and ship parts, so your progress actually feels great the entire time. The trading and smuggling aspects of the game are well made and rewarding with a lot of care and attention put into them. The combat feels like a naval combat game and serves its purpose well. While primarily taking place on a 2D plane, the combat mechanics certainly takes advantage of the 3D environment with action and attacks happening all around you. The weapon variation is nice and even some of the basic weapons feel heavy-hitting, so I am sure that the badass factor on the later weapons will be awesome.If you're looking for a fun space sim with satisfying progression and rewarding mechanics, Rebel Galaxy will scratch that itch. For $20 it is definitely a steal.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												This game is like a beautiful koi pond: Full of wonderful, graceful behemoths swimming beneath the surface, distracting from the  shallow, muddy bottom.Pros:-Fun Combat, lots of naval pew pew. The effects of having capital ship grade weapons blasting all over the place, dodging lasers, photon torpedos, and whatever; Pretty awesome. -Beautiful visuals: OooooOOOoooooh-Great Atmosphere: Everything felt great, I felt like a space cowboy the whole time for better or worse. -Plenty of quests with multiple factions.Cons:-The quests are inconsequential:They exist only to get mechanical advantages in bigger, badder ships. Which would be neat if the different factions gave  additional things to do but as they stand, it is a grinding quest for rep for a big ship which is comparable to the civilian models. -Shallow, uninspired story.-Illusion of character influence.-Only one reliable way of getting large amounts of cash with any speed.The Trading and Pirating actions are garbage. Even if you destroy every single ship you see, you'll only get something worthwhile once in every ten ships. Stations rarely have enough goods for a trader ship to make worthwhile runs for any reason.For the same amount of time, you can just get "Destroy X" or "Protect Y" quests to get four times the amount of money you'll make for even the most advantageous trade. From ANY station. The game is pretty and boring. Unless you played EV nova just to grind for hours to get the big ship and swing your massive dreadnought wang around, you're gonna have a bad time. I give it a 6/10, mostly for visuals and atmosphere. Being forced into a very specific playstyle due to the economics of the game is annoying and takes the tiller fully out of quality's gentle, warm hands, and into the dead fish limp fist of neutrality and disappointment.

												Rebel Galaxy is the space sim that many have been waiting for, allowing them to live out their Firefly fantasies out on the edge galaxies. In that regard it delivers much of what is expected of it having all the trimmings that is expected from a game in this genre. The combat is unique however it suffers from a few key problems which quickly turn the challenge into tedium. content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Just think Firefly + Cowboy Bebop = Rebel Galaxy.Didn't know what all to expect when watching the trailers, so I thought "What the hell, I'll give it a shot."  Then I gave it another...and another...and another, and before I was done, pirate fleets were torn asunder and floating lifeless in the cold, empty void of space.Overall:+ Put in close to 12 hours so far and still in the first system.  In many AAA-titles released these days (I'm looking at you CoD), the main part of campaigns can be completed in 5-20 hours, depending on how much content there is.  For a $20 game to beat out $60 games is a damn shame. It shows that bigger studios often care too much about profit, and not enough on a great experience like they used to.+ Sometimes takes on that addictive "just one more mission" quality+ Tight, responsive controls+ Again, for $20, the AI can be surprisingly good+ Like many have said, it's not a space sim, which, for me at least, was a good selling point.  No need for ultra-realism after seeing pretty pew-pew lasers and lots, and LOTS of explosions.+/- The soundtrack can be kind of a mixed bag.  It isn't terrible by any means, but after hearing the same 6-7 songs repeated over and over again in some sequences, I disabled the music in the settings and began listening to music downloaded from YouTube.  Yet if the developor can periodically update the game with new tracks, it'd be an added bonus. + Got to name my ship the Cowboy Bebop10/10 - See ya later space cowboy!

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Great game, especially for the money. Enough RPG elements with ship upgrades and lots of ships to choose from. First, there are some negatives: the late game doesn't offer much in the way of excitement, one you have the best gear, there isn't much that puts up a challenge anymore. It's fun to feel godlike when firing 20 broadside cannons and killing ships that used to give you trouble in a couple of shots. This wears out pretty quickly though and I find myself wishing they would throw more at me to match the level of my ship. Once the storyline is finished I don't feel there is a lot of replayability, there's no real "other" way to play the game except as maybe an outlaw, which will severely limit the number of stations you can visit and missions you can take. The positives, I think, far outweigh the negatives. As I said above there are plenty of fun customization options available to you and each battle needs to be approached with tactics in mind: lots of fighters?  Stay back and let your turrets work and fire some well-aimed broadsides. Big badass dreadnaughts? Take down their shields and get in close so you don't have to charge your cannons up and take them down fast. I haven't played a game with this much value for dollar in a long time, not being able to travel on the X axis isn't a bother as the game still feels big. Worth the $!

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												It's good. Really, it is. It's not, however, amazing. The short: The storyline is... cursory, at best. The game would lose virtually nothing if it weren't there at all. There are some annoyances in missions and travelling, and you need to be comfortable with the need to grind for gear, but all in all it's a very enjoyable space shooter.The long:As I've seen mentioned in other reviews, there's an almost consistent misrepresentation of the mission risk. Low? It could be, then again you could also barely make it out with an inch of hull left. Other times you end up against a ship you literally do not have the damage output to even touch the shields on. High? It could be. It could also be a milk run. It just doesn't make any sense.You do learn to recognize them, though. Some mission types seem straight forward, but will always end with you having to deliver something to a station that's under siege. Skip those. Escort missions are a pain, as in pretty much all games, Fancy waiting 2-3 minutes while your ship lines itself up for the escort? Fancy doing that numerous times as the journey is interrupted along the way? How about inside an asteroid field, where your ship keeps getting stuck on rocks, adding another few minutes. At first, I learned this was a perfect time to go fetch something to drink. Or check email. Or read a page or two of a book. Later, I learned to just save my sanity and skip them. Eventually I did learn a set of mission types I could reliably predict the difficulty of, and I just stuck with those and ignored everything else.There's a fair amount of travelling required, which is to be expected. Space is big, after all. What isn't fine is how often your travels are interrupted. There are countless asteroid and junk fields littered about, and odds are you'll be pulled out of warp a handful of times on most journeys. Which means you then need to crawl along to the edge before you can get back up to speed. If you pay attention you can spot some of them and go around. Not going in a straight line from one place to the next, also seems to help. Then there are the random enemy encounters, which have the same effect of slowing you down. You can spend time fighting them (if they are ship types and numbers you can handle), for loot worth next to nothing most of the time, or turn your tail and boost out of there. In most cases that'll have you on your way again in 30 seconds or so.So why the heck am I recommending it? I guess I must really like spaceships. And lasers. I had great fun, despite the above mentioned drawbacks. Enough so that I put 40 hours into it. After finishing the story, I kept going until I had the best ship fully upgraded. I then went back in a few more times to just fly around enjoying being invincible. For entertainment value, it was a bargain for the price.

												This game is great fun!The graphics are really well done, without it being particularly strenuous on your system. The game play is sound, offering an augmented version of a space flight sim that primarily uses 'broad-siding' as its main form of combat. There is a fair amount of progression to be had in the game upgrading ships and weapons. Even when you get to the point of maxing out your character, you will still find it a challenge taking down the end game enemies. The soundtrack is also awesome!You can easily put between 30 to 40 hours in a single play through, and because of the faction reward system you will have a quite a different experience choosing an opposing path.The only negative I can think of is that is heavily optimised for a controller/gamepad. *sigh* You can try with a keyboard and mouse, but you will find the experience a little skittish!Overall, I can thoroughly recommend this to anyone who is looking for a semi-casual space adventure!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												This game was a huge surprise for me, and I only ended up getting it after watching a favorite streamer of mine play it for an hour or so. For me, this game is like the perfect marriage of complex space battle/trading games like Freelancer and old simple quest-based space games like Solar Winds. I was able to easily start playing this and get a grasp for how to survive and have a blast within a couple hours. I was originally turned off by the fact that you are pretty much on a 2D plane and it isn't full 3D navigation, but the game hides it well during battles and it really makes it a lot easier to figure out exactly what is going on in any situation without needing the added complexity of a 3rd dimension. It took me awhile to get used to the limited information provided by the HUD, but I definitely enjoy the fact that my screen isn't cluttered with useless information all the time. If you have bandwidth restrictions, this game is a surprisingly small download, and the soundtrack is fantastic and really makes you feel like a Space Cowboy. Two thumbs up!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Picked up this game while it was on sale, I probably wouldn't have bought it full price. I definitely would've missed out. This game is easily work 20 bucks, but if it's on sale definitely grab it. It kinda feels like if you mixed Firefly and Star Wars. The atmosphere and music screams Firefly, but the space battles definitely feel like Star Wars. I've only put 5 hours into at this point but I can easily see myself sinking over 40 with repeat playthroughs. The soundtrack is awesome but I do think it might get repetetive after a while, but the devs have it set up where you can play your own music through the game. Or you can play pandora in the background like everybody else. It's kind of a bummer that you can't fly up and down, only side to side. It's kind of good though, the devs did it to keep the learning curve for flight low so you can focus on shooting in battles. The actively changing trade markets at the different ports was a really nice touch. You can literally do almost whatever you want. Wanna be a space miner? Go for it. Wanna be a pirate and attack the innocent? Do it big. Wanna be boring and just play the story? Waste your money. The game isn't too hard to pick up and beat, but it's not a cakewalk either. You don't have your hand held in this game, if offers tips but doesn't stop you from running into high level pirates if you're not careful. That being said, it isn't too hard to earn money and upgrade your ship or buy a new one. Overall, I highly reccomend this game to anybody that's ever wanted to pilot their own space ship.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												I have no problem giving a thumbs up on this title.  A lot of people say it has a "Firefly" feel and they are right.  The soundtrack, universe and choices you make are what gives it that feel.  Will you stop for that distress call?  Or is that cargo too important for you to be a big damn hero.  The games story has been decent so far.  Combat feels like "Star Trek Online" where space is....flat.  Naval style broadside battles make you manage your sheilds as you try to stay on an enemies weak side.  Mercenaries are waiting to be hired at every space station for a price.  They'll fly with you until you dismiss them or faithfully until they die.  You can outfit your ship with a fair amount of upgrades or buy bigger ships.  Each ship has its own benefits depending on what you want to do.  Do you want to smuggle and run trade routes to make money between missions?  You'll want cargo space and speed?  You want to hunt down bounties?  Better go with weapon hardpoints and hull strength.  It's pretty open.  The game has an economy that is ever changing so goods might be cheap here but are selling higher on the otherside of the system giving you a chance to make a buck.    I've read people giving a thumbs down because it takes too long to travel from A to B on occasion.  All I can say to that is "Flying through hyper-space ain't like dusting crops, boy..."  My only complaint is that the pirate dialog is pretty skimpy.  You hear the same "well, well.  You most be lost..." quote too many times. If you're a sci-fi junkie and want a space game that's not overly complex but still has substance then pick this up.  $20 you can't go wrong.  You'll get your $ worth.  You can be a leaf on the wind too!  Just watch how you fly...

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												tl:dr: If you are looking for a simple, fun space game with loot etc in the vain of Freelancer this is the best choice at the moment. The 2D limitation of movement seems annoying at first but it actually simplifies navigation a lot and combat still feels dynamic enough. Voice acting makes the universe feel alive.The main framework of the game consists of typical space sim quests a la "kill those guys" "bring that there" "protect this ship" etc, nicely packed into flavour text and a fully voiced main Storyline which after 6 hours is fun enough to follow while not very original.While most space sims focus around dogfighting and smaller ships this one is all about capital ships and broadside combat. Different sections of the ship can be controlled manually while the remaining turrets fire automatically, mercenary wings can be hired to offer additional support.Aiming is secondary to navigation and tactical ship placement.The universe is made lively and colourful by voiced cutscenes and radio chatter. A nice amount of very nicely designed ships in various sizes is availableAll in all this is a great game for people who don't have enough time for Elite:Dangerous (or simply find ED to be too boring and monochromatic) but still want the Space Exploration experience.Also the soundtrack is very nice and the game makes adding custom music very easy.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy is a great game that has plenty of good balance to it, though granted I had to remind myself it wasn’t Freelancer* with all its similarities. With the constant reminder that your piloting a 2 dimensional ship through 3 dimensional space that makes use of primary functions for broad fire tactic’s while combatting fighter vessels that can fly in any direction was easy to notice the uniqueness Rebel Galaxy Possess in standing out from the rest of the space games to hit the market. One thing that would keep me engaged as a Gamer is the really good work with the Music Que’s between combat and Station Menu navigation. Yes you still get the option to customize your own music to the game, but speaking as an Audio Editor, there was some really good work into allowing the music to que into the combat scene’s. The music is so good that I even had the pleasure to find the list posted by Travis Baldree on the dev’s website Sound Track List**. Granted I enjoy my gameplay and found myself wanting a bit more in the way of controls, but I constantly found the fact of the simplified combat and turret options in ship to ship combat well simplified. I partly wished I could have been able to explore the stations or board the ships that constantly threatened me to get sucked into space, so as only to just see that I could do it, but still we wouldn’t have had such a well-planned out 2 Dimensional controlled 3D Space Combat game. Pro’s:•	Short but worthwhile story•	Simplified Ship controls•	Great Music Selections•	Persistent Markets when selling commodities – even gives a history on the price of the item, and system average for the entire System you’re in.•	Great Map Design and navigation assistance though lacks a little in cross coordination with other implemented features of the game.Con’s:•	Not Exactly Merchant Friendly: Always a hassle trying to find a price for a single item between all known locations that buy and sell commodities of a certain type. Would have like an option that allowed seeing at a quick list of last known prices at all stations for a single commodity.•	Stellar Mass often times stopping warp while not even in the way of the travel.•	Not all ships are available, can’t truly pilot a fighter or gunship.•	Not able to change direction up or down to evade Stellar mass in a direct collision course•	Not able to properly map Cone of angles for the turret systems being applied to the ships. (Kinda handy when attempting to do mining to know where the laser fire can reach.)•	Limitation to the Components that can be installed on all ships.•	Not able to easily pull up the map when needing to make a quick reference to a station or asteroid mining location when getting info or finding merchandise while in space.•	Limited to a single Mercenary Hire, can’t recruit an armada of Mercenaries. Freelancer* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freelancer_(video_game)Sound Track List** http://rebel-galaxy.com/the-rebel-galaxy-soundtrack/

												You have to get this game! $20?! It should be $50! It has an engaging story line, the ability to conduct trade, choose loyalty to different factions through missions, great graphics, and a nice variety of ships. I was certainly not expecting a game of this quality for the price point.Some people might think this game repetitive, in that the frequent combat might be, but learning new fighting styles by changing up your weapons types keeps things fresh. It is derivitive, games like this have existed before, but it has a nice user interface and I know that I'll get more than my money's worth of enjoyment from it.AGAIN: snatch this game up, especially for the $20 I paid!Cheers

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Take AC: Black Flag naval combat... Make it 10x better, stick it in space and add a wicked soundtrack, you have Rebel Galaxy. The combat is action packed, the ship customization system is awesome, it is easy to pickup & play and most of all, if you like the idea of naval combat, it will keep you entertained for a while.The only major drawback is the game is short. The main story line felt short, majority of my playing time was spent on collecting credit through side missions. Another minor drawback was the amount of customization. The way you upgraded the ships was awesome (buying/selling prices were equal, you could easily upgrade or downgrade between ships) however, there are only a limited type of weaponry to choose from.None the less, besides these drawbacks, if you enjoy space & naval combat, this game will give you a good fix. Personally I've spent 60 hours playing and enjoyed it.

												Absolutely great fun, especially for $20. I'm a huge fan of the old space sims like Privateer and Freelancer, and this is the first game in years to really replicate the feeling they gave me. I think part of it has to do with its fun ''space truckers' aesthetic, but it helps that it's also fast-paced and arcadey, as well as beautiful.Also, the fact that things are locked to a 2D plane really isn't a problem. There's plenty of room for tactical positioning, and it makes the broadsides on your ship useful and interesting. If you simply cannot stomach the thought of a space sim without full 3D flight, then give it a pass, but c'mon - open yourself to new things!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												This is a great game and tkaes hours to completely play through it.For 20 bucks I would say that this game is worth the cost and should get a best value award for the content that it brings to the table for the cost.To sum the game up you are a called in by your Aunt to go to the nastiest part of the galaxy and you have to fend for yourself. You find a relic that you repair and eventually you collect parts to repair the AI's memory. The AI then decides to sacrifice itself for the greater good and that's how the storyline rolls.As for the game play you'll find yourself warping throughout space fighting all types of spaceships and different situations which I found really fun to do.The game has a high difficulty curve so be warned, this game isn't for those really really casual gamers and is geared more towards those who can think on their feet and react quickly to different situations. If you need to remember to press your scanning key which is TAB by default to freeze the game and analyze the situation.I did 2 play throughs of the game one as a good guy and one as a bad guy. Both were pretty satisfying but it is really hard to be a bad guy. The storyline gears you toward being a good guy and to earn bad guy rep to actually enter their ports takes a long time. In the meantime you have to not♥♥♥♥♥♥off the civilians otherwise you'll have no ports that you can call your home and all you'll meet there is your end. No worries though missions will help keep your rep up so that shouldn't happen unless you get reckless.The game also does not limit you in what you want to do. I skipped the storyline and worked my way towards the endgame before coming back to complete it. By the time I finished the storyline on my first run through I already had a blackgate that was decked out with MK 5 pulse turrets that decimated anything that strayed within their range of fire. On the second play through I bought a quick ship (the Icarus) and rushed towards the end game areas and did adrenaline rush dead drop missions for hundreds of thousands of credits to reach the end game faster which felt really satisfying to do.Overall I loved the graphics of the game, it has a good soundtrack which you can make your own custom soundtrack as well, and the sound quality of the game is great as well. The only thing I am waiting on now to see if they will release DLC for the game or make a second sequel to the game which I will be more than happy to buy. If you like flying spaceships then give this game a try I promise that it will be worth your money.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												Just think Firefly + Cowboy Bebop = Rebel Galaxy.Didn't know what all to expect when watching the trailers, so I thought "What the hell, I'll give it a shot."  Then I gave it another...and another...and another, and before I was done, pirate fleets were torn asunder and floating lifeless in the cold, empty void of space.Overall:+ Put in close to 12 hours so far and still in the first system.  In many AAA-titles released these days (I'm looking at you CoD), the main part of campaigns can be completed in 5-20 hours, depending on how much content there is.  For a $20 game to beat out $60 games is a damn shame. It shows that bigger studios often care too much about profit, and not enough on a great experience like they used to.+ Sometimes takes on that addictive "just one more mission" quality+ Tight, responsive controls+ Again, for $20, the AI can be surprisingly good+ Like many have said, it's not a space sim, which, for me at least, was a good selling point.  No need for ultra-realism after seeing pretty pew-pew lasers and lots, and LOTS of explosions.+/- The soundtrack can be kind of a mixed bag.  It isn't terrible by any means, but after hearing the same 6-7 songs repeated over and over again in some sequences, I disabled the music in the settings and began listening to music downloaded from YouTube.  Yet if the developor can periodically update the game with new tracks, it'd be an added bonus. + Got to name my ship the Cowboy Bebop10/10 - See ya later space cowboy!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Holy Amazing!Ok so reading all of these reviews may build up a bit of hype and while the game is great, its not necessarily the greatest game ever. It is one of the best game values for your money, some sort of a story line (searching for your aunt?)  is at least present but, most importantly, it really is best described as AC Black flag with space ships.Customization is great as far as equipment and such.  I do wish there was the option to paint your ship assuming I'm not an idiot and didn't miss that.The soundtrack is great with that meaning its along the lines of rock/classic rock which makes keeps your energy up.  My experience comparison is to that of Sins of a Solar Empire... the music alone could make me stop playing the game.  To me its more like, I'm a badass! With a space ship!  Come get some! and lets rock out to that!not, oh hey... could you pass me that mozart cd so I can sit blowing up stuff with some somber tones running in my head...zzzzAnyway, this is as close as it gets to feeling like you're really out in your battlestar galactica or star wars destroyer taking on the skum of the universe.  There is some travelling but the space is populated and plenty of things to run into or die from on your own.  I have a knack for running into red threat levels and practicing reloading the game.The earn money and upgrade your ship works really well, you do need to do some main missions or use your map to find missions.  Flying in a particular direction works too however, you may find you run into near or sudden death encounters with ships you clearly underestimated.  Another way to describe this game is, its like FTL but you dont see through your ship and in order to jump, you best run like hell to reach a safe warp (jump) point!To summerize:Pros:Easy to play and get to the action (and die lol)Thank god its in 2D because handling a 3rd direction would probably make me sick and be overwhelmed (may be a con for some)Very good graphics to the point where it looks great and is playable on lower end systems.It still plays beautifully and perfectly smooth at 4k with a 980 Ti.  Simple but robust upgrade options.  Targeting is pretty easy, the AI can manage some of your guns as well.The universe is alive, even if you did nothing but fly around you run into stuff and/or cool planets with bases.Theres a story at the very least.Awesome sounds and an upbeat sound track.  Your ship makes most of those cool sounds you want to hear when you change directions or power up your warp drives.Great Value/Price makes this hard to beat!Cons:Limited view options (may not be a con but locking the view closer or further would be nice).Just to add in case a developer reads this, if there was a cockpit view I may have to change my pants every time I play.  That would be amazing and with using the broadsides, having the camera switch to whichever side you're moving your view stick to would be an idea.Unable to paint or color your ship.There are a lot of ship choices but I wish there was a variety of each class (not a big deal).While there is a story its not the most elaborate story or intriguing.  Something more along the lines of a mysterious cosmic disturbance was felt among the universe and a new alien race or super weapon is rumored to be the cause.  Among the warring factions and those at peace, spontaneous attacks from a new enemy emerge and along with your journey between the factions in space, do you suddenly run into unexpected encounters from this new weapon or race.  . . . . just my thoughts, some pulled form mass effect which was great up until they ruined it.  There is just more there to be desired but I'm happy to at least have a story.No multiplayer...not a big deal but would be fun to do missions or visit solar systems with a buddy.  Doubling the enemies per additional player would seem sufficient.Final Thoughts:  If the developers are still paying attention (hoping their sales numbers are great or better than expected), this is a great game and starting point that so many others try to achieve and simply fail at.There is a lot of potential here and simply adding more star systems with harder difficulty and additional story would hopefully not be too much trouble if DLC becomes a future ambition.  I was bored or at least overwhelmed with EVE and it really wasn't enjoyable having to basically learn how complex the game was...especially when you only have a few hours to play periodically.  This game strikes a great balance and at the limit of 2D movement however, I think it was a perfect choice because you can focus on battles! and Blowing stuff up!I am very pleased with this purchase and with so much room to add on or improve (even when it is already done so well already) I think it is something worth expanding on.None the less, you will have a blast if you go into this game expecting a space game with simple controls a little travelling here and there (typically no more than 1 minute in the first map), and small battles that grow to epic as the game progresses.Considering fast indoor go karting costs 20 bucks for 10 minutes.... this gives you a whole lot more with some speakers and a subwoofer .... you will be the next Han Solo in your SS Pea Shooter as I named my ship.Enjoy!

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Well first impression is this.  Its in space, sweet, but you cannot manuver on all 3 axis.  only left and right. very planer view.  but its recommended use of gamepad, may mean I'm missing something, but I don't see any options for pitch or roll. Ok so be it.  its not a true space sim in that sence.  It still seems kinda fun.  the first space battle due to story line was very reminecent of Pirates!,  alot of circling and broadside attacks.  the auto turrets take care of those pesky fighters or you can take over and blast those little buggers yourself. kinda fun and the percision mode adds some targeting skill.  the only thing I do not like is the lack of ZOOM.  you cannot zoom out.  so your ship takes up most of the screen. (I was constanly scrolling my wheel trying to get a better view)  so manuvering around objects around becomes a little panicked when proximity sensors pick up something and you have to attempt to steer around and fight at the same time.  due to fact you can only view what direction your pointing the camera this can be a little challanging. but the camera swivels like a top and is very responsive.   kinda curious to see if the scale changes when I can afford the larger ships.  or am I going to have a screen full of my ship. Now this is only my first time playing for approx 30-40 min.  overall graphics,ambiance,and backgrounds look pretty good it looked great on my 40" 4k monitor at full res and high settngs.  I am definently going back in to play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Been waiting for a game like this to scratch my space trading/rpg/combat itch for some time! If you ever loved games like Freelancer or Escape Velocity, this is the game for you!Pros:- The 2D plane gameplay environment works great with the captial ship theme. Naval battles in space!- Said combat is extremely satisfying, and deceptively nuanced. Many types of weapon classes, defence types and equiptment mods provide different ways to go about your battles. Brute force with a dreadnaught with massive broadsides? Stay on a foes tail with a nimble turret frigate? Somewhere in between?- A good story that provides some purpose. More depth than Elite: Dangerous!- Awesome Firefly style space western theme and music!- Beautiful!- Awesome devs that listen to the players and repond to your questions FAST!- It costs TWENTY FREAKING DOLLARS!!!Cons:- Can't change video settings on the fly, uses a laucher where you set them before starting, old school style. Not really an issue for me at all, but I'm sure there are people with lower end systems that need to experiment, and this makes it a little inconvienient.Kinda con but not really:- Mouse camera and aim movement has a negative acceleration issue, where faster mouse movement equates to slower in game response, and vise versa. HOWEVER, as stated above, the devs are AWESOME and responded to my concerns on Twitter within minutes, and even asked me to tell them what I think of the patch with an experimental option for it that came out within hours. Still not quite fixed, but it's obvious that they really care about their game and what people think of it. As a matter of fact, this probably doesn't even qualify as a con! Especially since I imagine most people use a contoller, and its easy to get used to the mouse issue. I'm gonna move it to a "kinda con" category. There we go, much better.In short:The game is awesome. The devs are awesome. The price is awesome. BUY IT!

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												The nice graphics, cool effects, solid story and an awesome soundtrack make up a great atmosphere. Combining a the great atmosphere with a fun combat system with some random systems and a premade storyline, and you get a very fun game.There are elements of ARPG with being able to tweak your ship setup, which alter the way you do combat. All the ships looks cool.The game systems has some depth that you can use to your advantage, as an example I saw some people complain that debris can break your warping speed. But you can actually evade some of them by going around them, or even just shift to the side slightly if you are quick and skilled enough.Combat is fun while not being to difficult to learn. Some people will not like that its not full 3d combat with HOTAS support like Elite Dangerous. I don't mind this as it looks like this isn't aimed to be space flight sim game.I'm at 2nd system and has played ca. 18 hours. Been distracted quite a few times with some trading and mining.EDIT: The game runs SUPER smooth on my i5+nvidia 560. 3 years old system.TLDR; Great atmosphere, solid story, fun gameplay. Yes, you should play it. :)9/10

												I enjoy the game a lot and really appreciate the work the developers have put in post release (Two patches in the two days it's been out).While Linux is not supported (though the developer has mentioned it's a possibility, someday) between patches and trial and error it's pretty stable through Wine and runs wonderfully. The game is extremely scalable, looking great on my Intel HD 4500 work PC and my GTX460 PC at home.The game is a lot of fun as well. If you want Freelancer or Freespace's dogfights and 3D twisting through space combat this may not do it for you, but if you want cruisers and capital ships larger than city blocks to pull along side each other and let off a broadside volley while your flak cannons evaporate fighters buzzing around you this is it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												If your a fan of the t.v series "Firefly", you will adore this game. Space meets the wild west of america. You can pretty much play however you want to really, either as a pirate, a merc, a bounty hunter, a trader, a do-gooder, a member of the system milita or anything else that comes to mind. Factions are present in the game and you can change your relations with the vast amount of them. The milita, citizens, red devil cartel and others are the major "players". There is a lot of replay-ability in this game and each playthrough offers a lot to do. Any valuable free time?, prepare for it to simply cease existing.There are quite the variety of ships to choose form each with their own playstyle and role in combat, ranging from corvettes to huge dreadnaughts bristling with firepower. Also, RAMMING SPEED! is completley viable when you get the right deflector shield. >:DIn terms of preformance, the game is pretty well optimized and I havent experienced any FPS drops nor crashes or glitches in the game so far. The only real issue is with the set up for the graphics being done out side of the game before launch. Other than that the game has rebindable keys for those wanting to change their keyboard set up and is also usable with a game pad as well.Finally lets get some of the "meh" points out of the way: 1) such as only being a 2D plain which really isnt to much of a problem (unless your a 3D space I WANNA GO EVERYWHERE fanatic) but a 3D plain would be nice but the game still works great with just 2D, and 2) being only a singleplayer experience which is great but the concept of playing with friends in co-op or being in a large server with many others effecting the world of rebel galaxy together. The possabilites are pretty big. Think player made factions and guilds fighting wars for resources or player made pirate groups raiding player escorted relief convoys that will effect economys in the game and the major factions relations and standing in the world.Overall I would very much recomend this game to anybody who is a fan of si-fi and or western drama with its beautiful world and fun gameplay with a large choice of options and intense ship on ship combat.I hope to see you all out there in this mad galaxy my fellow starship captains! for profit! for reputation! and for being the greatest badasses that this galaxy's ever seen!

												This game is absolutely off the walls amazing.  If you like the space cowboy theme of shows like Cowboy Bebop, Firefly/Serenity, or even the insane and wild adventures of Space Dandy, Outlaw Star, and Star Wars (specifically Han Solo), GET THIS GAME.  A warning though, YOU FIGHT LIKE A SHIP IN THE SEA which means broadsides and stuff, BUT IN SPACE!  This means no going up or down or even do maneuvers like rolling.  Remember, you're a larger ship and not a light fighter or gunship.  Other than that, you can do so many things that aren't missions, such as cause a food shortage in a station and sell food for higher prices, indirectly cause wars by killing off a diplomatic ship, and other such activities (not going to spoil it).  Yes there is a story to it, but I think this game is better for those who like to make their own as they play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												TLDR: It’s awesome, but I have some nits to pick. I finished the campaign in an Arcturus with level 6 defenses, a mix of level 5 pulse turrets and particle lasers, and level 6 neutron beams in about 21 hours (net worth just under 40 million). My equipment level was such that the final set of missions was pretty easy (I don’t think I lost shields once during the final battle, and the mission itself was listed as low risk).Liked:Combat: I read some comments before purchasing the game lamenting the fact that it didn’t allow full 3-D motion. While I initially held some of the same concerns, I very quickly fell in love with the navel style combat system, which would have been difficult if not impossible to pull off well in a fully 3-D environment. From the carefully aimed long range broadsides to those exhilarating moments when you slam the side of your ship into your opponent and scream “Fire at Will!” as you pull the trigger as fast as you can, combat is an absolute blast.Movement: As an addendum to combat, the movements system in battles, especially when you reach the higher levels of boosters, is amazing as well. The sudden acceleration you see while surging along the side of a much larger ship trying to avoid its broadside feels like it should by squeezing you into the back of your seat. This, plus the broadside mechanic, combine to make combat absolutely enthralling.Ship Design: I really like the types and variety of ships available to captain and kill. From the industrial ships of the common citizen to the more refined combat ships of the militia to the strange and futuristic designs of the alien races, there is a very nice variety of ship designs in the game. There hasn’t been one ship that I’ve looked at and haven’t said “Oooooo, I wanna fly THAT!”Ship to Ship Scale: I really like how ship scale progresses in the game as you earn enough credits to purchase larger and larger vessels. You start off as a small ship trying to make it in the big leagues, desperately firing your boosters in an attempt to avoid a larger vessel’s broadside while keeping him under fire from your own. Later on you become that larger ship, trying to turn fast enough to keep that pesky fly in your sights before his constant fire wears through your shields. Seeing ships I used to pilot seem as gnats compared to my current ships really hammers home the progression I’ve made in the game.The 'Risk' System: It may seem minor, but I really like the risk announcement. Hearing "Threat Level: Red" made my booster finger start to itch almost uncontrollably.Music: Makes it feel like I’m playing Firefly the Game. Enough said.Didn’t Like:Warp Inhibition: Warp inhibition by stellar mass seems to be a bit finicky. I often found myself being inhibited by smaller asteroids when I had a clear path through a field, getting back into warp, and then later in the trip having to jerk to the side to avoid a much larger asteroid whose surface I would barely skim while remaining in warp without a problem. I overall like the inhibition system, but it seems it could use some tweaking.Emptiness: I wasn’t exactly sure what to label this one. Basically, it felt that systems lacked traffic where you would expect it to be, and as a result the game felt a bit emptier then it should have. For example, I never encountered another ship around a jumpgate (except for the last story sequence, of course). Freelancer had a very good system in this respect, in that jumgates always had traffic moving through them, sometimes even enough that the player had to wait in line! Some of my best memories of that game were running from an enemy I couldn’t defeat and hoping that I would avoid the dreaded “entering queue” and be able to complete the jump sequence before my hull failed. Speaking of which…Ease of Escape: I felt it was a bit easy to escape from enemies that outclassed you. Shields recharging under deflectors combined with the fact that broadside don’t fire forward by nature meant that it was trivially easy to escape any situation. I think I died a total of twice in the 20 hours I played, and that was only because I made a conscious decision not to run when I knew I should have. I really feel that there is a missed opportunity in dramatic escapes here.Story: The story had an interesting premise but fell too quickly, in my opinion, into ‘save the world’ mode. I had hoped the story would focus more on “space wild west” type themes, like the conflict between the civilized core worlds and the wild frontier or between an expanding colonial power and those resisting that expansion. I could see hints of the latter in the story, but it ended up feeling more like a mass effect type overarching plot, which I felt fit the lore and feel of the game less well.With all that said, I want to reiterate how much I really like Rebel Galaxy. It’s a fun, fast paced game with an awesome soundtrack and even better combat. I’m really interested to see where the developers take it from here and will almost certainly be purchasing whatever they create next.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I have long been a fan of Freelancer to the point I have spent years lementing the fact that my system no longer supports it. I have played more games then I can honestly count, here I have found some thing of that long lost love. This game gives yopu a huge freedom of movement and choice, an interesting story where you actually effect some of the outcomes, not to mention addicting combat. One of the best parts is taking on random jobs as a no-name Merc trying to build up your ship and reputation. Just when you think your ship is bad♥♥♥♥♥ and your a king of the stars you find out that the Galaxy is a much bigger place then you first realized and that you are little more then a fly in space. Don't be discouraged because this is part of what makes this game amazing, it evolves, it challanges you, it makes you work for what you want without just coddling you like so many games. The learning curve isn't too extreme but starting out you will find sooner then later that you need to make money if you want to survive and it gives you a number of options to achieve this ranging from saving beligured stations, rescue Merchants who are on the short end of luck, There are also the Merchant and Mercenary guilds that give you a huge oppurtunity to expand your reach with jobs, equipment and ships. All the while you have to decide which side of the law you are on. Are you a Pirate? Smuggler? A devil may care merc, or a hero, or are you some kind of mix between. If you want a game that is strangely addicting, well made, with a good sound track (honestly the best I have ever heard) It is like Firefly meets Freelancer. If that doesn't impress you then you have no soul, if it does, strap in for one hell of an inter-stellar ride.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												This may be an odd referene, but when I play this game I think of Sid Meiers Pirates! ... with spaceships and NarcoCola. And that is a good thing!It is a niche game in the aspect that you need to love in order to get hooked;1) Captal Ship gameplay (lots and lots of guns in a 2.5D gameplay)2) Extensive Carrear options (Trade/Pirate/Hunter)3) Telling Aliens where to put their hat (hint - not in a kind place)Having sunk a lot of hours into the game, I have found myself hooked. It has a good wave between getting easy to frustrating and back to easy again, it doesn't fall off either cliff completely and I find the grind to be rather well balanced, which is an absolute must in this genra of game. A good perk to it is that the AI isn't derped or broken like I have seen in simular games (where a ship plants itself into a wall and doesn't get the IQ to turn around).My only big knock against it is that the camera angles are at times borked out pretty badly, and requires its own learning curve to figure out and compinsate for. I would like if the broadside gunner views were pulled back by double to give a better line of sight, or give an option to have a gunners-seat POV.For its price point, it is a must for any Space-sim action game junkie!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												I have no problem giving a thumbs up on this title.  A lot of people say it has a "Firefly" feel and they are right.  The soundtrack, universe and choices you make are what gives it that feel.  Will you stop for that distress call?  Or is that cargo too important for you to be a big damn hero.  The games story has been decent so far.  Combat feels like "Star Trek Online" where space is....flat.  Naval style broadside battles make you manage your sheilds as you try to stay on an enemies weak side.  Mercenaries are waiting to be hired at every space station for a price.  They'll fly with you until you dismiss them or faithfully until they die.  You can outfit your ship with a fair amount of upgrades or buy bigger ships.  Each ship has its own benefits depending on what you want to do.  Do you want to smuggle and run trade routes to make money between missions?  You'll want cargo space and speed?  You want to hunt down bounties?  Better go with weapon hardpoints and hull strength.  It's pretty open.  The game has an economy that is ever changing so goods might be cheap here but are selling higher on the otherside of the system giving you a chance to make a buck.    I've read people giving a thumbs down because it takes too long to travel from A to B on occasion.  All I can say to that is "Flying through hyper-space ain't like dusting crops, boy..."  My only complaint is that the pirate dialog is pretty skimpy.  You hear the same "well, well.  You most be lost..." quote too many times. If you're a sci-fi junkie and want a space game that's not overly complex but still has substance then pick this up.  $20 you can't go wrong.  You'll get your $ worth.  You can be a leaf on the wind too!  Just watch how you fly...

												I love this single-player game to the point I made a video game guide to help new players.Sure the game is repetitive, same could be said of grinding with pokemon.Only instead of leveling up, you buy some cool gear for your ship to the point every enemy in the game can't do anything to stop you. And if you don't like to play the same missions again, you can play as an honest trader, a miner, a bounty hunter, a member of the law or a merciless pirate.The game can also be Moded, expect some cool mods in the near by future.For now the best mod I can recomend is the Miner mod by Philpw99 (changes the prices on the market and improves the cargo crates).The game was made by 2 developers with love, it's cheap and plays like one of the many good AAA titles.Show some love for this game, you won't regret it.[If you hate repetitive gameplay (like pokemon grinds) avoid like the plague.]

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												This game is simply amazing.This game is the natural evolution of a 2d space scrolling shooter like Tyrian or Galactix.  It's a wonderful mix of those games, your standard space-trader game, based on Tradewars 2002, and Firefly all rolled up into one giant explosive ball of awesome.  Many spaceship games now-days require days or even months of tutorials and online reading just to fit your ships properly, position your ship, what you can take on and what you can't, etc.   Rebel Galaxy you can just jump into and be blowing stuff up in minutes.   While i love a good space sim, The attention to detail and realistic physics in those games makes the learning curve incredibly difficult. Keeping this game on a single flat plane, and then creating the game around that plane is a stroke of sheer genius. I've even put down playing Fallout 4 for this.

												I enjoy it because I enjoy space games like this, and that's why I recommend it. If, from the trailers, gameplay videos, whatever, you think you won't like it, don't get it. It's a lot of grinding, with a poor, unengaging story. But there's a lot to be said for making your own stories, even if you have to make up a lot of it yourself and the game provides very little to support that.The gameplay's pretty fun (though it's basically a sea/navy battle in space on one plane) in my opinion. The options and variety of weapons, shields, etc. are nice, though it would be nice to be able to customize your ship to make it more "yours".Overall 7.5/10 for being a solid game, but doing little to distinguish itself from the crowd of other space games. Also grinding. ♥♥♥♥ing grinding.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												Negatives:- Lack of innovation. This is a copy of the (working) Wing Commander Privateer formula, albeit in two dimensions.- Balance issues when it comes to weapon choice.- Minor progression spiking issues. For example, there are times when you find one salvage item that is worth more than your next 10 entire missions.- Lack of end game. Basically once you have Mark 6 shields and pulse turrets the game is over.- The decision to make this a 2D game makes little sense to me. It takes away from the astrobatics experience and simplifies gameplay.- Some tedious game mechanics with warp travel. Finding an asteroid belt with some salvage seems meant to be a nice surprise, but in reality it's just annoying because it drops you out of warp and the only salvages (as far as I know) which give high-credit equipment rather than commodities are the ones you take off of ships. The number of times I had to veer just to the right or left of an asteroid and use thrusters to get back into a safe state to use warp drive was far too many.Positives:- Provides good value for $20, especially if you are a huge fan of the series' that it takes from (Privateer, Dark Star One).- Stable. No real performance issues.I know the negatives list is longer than the positives, but I would still recommend the game if you are a space exploration fan just looking for a remake of Privateer without the daunting depth of X3.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Okay, this is a great game, ive got a fair few hours into it and am far from being bored. However, the game has a lot of things which need to be fixed:- The difficulty system, please oh please fix the difficulty system. For those of you that don't know, when you accept a mission the game tells you how difficult it is based on your ship, which is great. Except it's horrifically broken right now, i have absolutely dominated "hard difficulty" missions and been absolutely rekt on easy difficulty missions, the system, to put it plainly, is pointless in it's current state-Fighter class ships, they are supposed to be these little craft which acompany larger ships to help them in fights. However some missions you get only fighter class ships, and they are hilariously overpowered. In a fight of me vs 7 normal sized ships(roughly my own ships size) i can win if i use tactics, a bit of luck and a lot of guns. But in a me vs 7 fighter class ships? Heck no, i get dominated like a david and goliath fight. Let's not forget that these are supposed to be small, relatively weak ships which fight you AS WELL AS regular ship, it makes some parts of the game completely impossible, such as a mission i went on recently. The mission was simple- destroy a chrono relay and any response squad you encounter. The relay was easy, the response squad? 30 fighter ships surrounding my ships on every single direction. They closed in and there was no way to get through them without ramming through one part of the blockgade they had formed, which i did and i was unsurprised to find my shields and hull drop faster than call of duty's sales. Basically the message is this- NERF THE FIGHTERS FOR MY SANITY'S SAKE PLEASE I CAN'T GO THROUGH ANOTHER FIGHT LIKE THAT-lastly, mercenaries randomly dying is a problem, i'll warp from a civilian base and suddenly the mercenary death sound will play and it will give me the message "your mercenary, sparrow, has ejected" this glitch costs me 30,000 credits every time i get it so i would be very grateful if you could fix itThose are the only major issues i've found so far, other than that, an amazing space game with huge potential

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												Ok, so I generally do not write reviews, because I like what I like and do not expect others to like it. However, this is a game that I would not have initially considered, and it has turned out to be a diamond in the rough.First, it is simple. It is naval combat...in space. Sure you can run cargo missions, or rescue missions, but in the end you will be fighting some faction, and it is simplistic in its approach. When I say simple, I mean it takes away some of the more complex aspects of gameplay and makes navigating and aiming the most important. Everything else is handled automatically or assumed for you. I like not having to think about complex aspects of a game. I like knowing where to go for a mission, and how much to repair my ship, and knowing that when I buy a new ship everything I previously purchased gets moved to my new ship.Rebel Galaxy has done a great job in making a game fun to play, whether you are a hard core gamer, or a casual one.I highly recommend this game.

												Holy crap it is a boatload of fun to explode enemy ships, this is like every naval and navallike combat-game control should be like.
