												Rebel Galaxy brings naval-style broadsides combat to space, alongside a surprisingly deep comodities trading system in a procedurally generated universe. Developed Blizzard alum and industry veterans at Double Damage studios, their decades-long vision of a space game has finally come to fruition. The dirty delta blues sountrack, along with a built-in custom sountrack tool, adds miles to the used-future aesthetic of many sci-fi favorites such as Firefly, Cowboy Bebop, and Star Wars. The devs are also highly engaged with the community here on Steam and on /r/RebelGalaxy, regularly responding to questions, concerns, and balance issues.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I have long been a fan of Freelancer to the point I have spent years lementing the fact that my system no longer supports it. I have played more games then I can honestly count, here I have found some thing of that long lost love. This game gives yopu a huge freedom of movement and choice, an interesting story where you actually effect some of the outcomes, not to mention addicting combat. One of the best parts is taking on random jobs as a no-name Merc trying to build up your ship and reputation. Just when you think your ship is bad♥♥♥♥♥ and your a king of the stars you find out that the Galaxy is a much bigger place then you first realized and that you are little more then a fly in space. Don't be discouraged because this is part of what makes this game amazing, it evolves, it challanges you, it makes you work for what you want without just coddling you like so many games. The learning curve isn't too extreme but starting out you will find sooner then later that you need to make money if you want to survive and it gives you a number of options to achieve this ranging from saving beligured stations, rescue Merchants who are on the short end of luck, There are also the Merchant and Mercenary guilds that give you a huge oppurtunity to expand your reach with jobs, equipment and ships. All the while you have to decide which side of the law you are on. Are you a Pirate? Smuggler? A devil may care merc, or a hero, or are you some kind of mix between. If you want a game that is strangely addicting, well made, with a good sound track (honestly the best I have ever heard) It is like Firefly meets Freelancer. If that doesn't impress you then you have no soul, if it does, strap in for one hell of an inter-stellar ride.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												TL;DR: Space travel, big ships, little ships, weapon customization, trading, mining, pirating, enjoyable broadside combat ONLY on one plane (no up or down movement by your ship). Story is so-so, but not what the game is about. Graphics are beautiful, runs smoothly, 8/10 I would recommend for the 20$ asking price, definitely worth it on a good sale.Rebel Galaxy. Now here's a game I bought on a total whim, thinking if I hated it I could just refund it. Well I put about an hour into it, and honestly, that refund looked more promising that enjoying this game.HOWEVER. On I played, and I'm glad I did.Rebel Galaxy story is alright, but I didn't honestly pay it much attention, and it lost my interest quickly, becoming much more interested in ammassing large amounts of money and upgrading my ship. Yuo start out in this dinky little capital ship that seems hopelessly outgunned when compared to some of the other faction ships. But get enough credits and start upgrading, and suddenly you feel like you rule the galaxy. Your ship can be customized not aesthetically, but through a diverse set of broadside turrets and mounted turrets, as well as thing slike cargo hold space, shiels, boosters, engine, armor plating, etc. Buy bigger ships, they're slower and less manueverable but covered in turrets and a hefty broadside arsenal. Smaller ships have less bang, but move and manuever like a charm, boasting high top speeds to simply work around your opponents.Briging me to the combat. As before mentioned, your weapons consist of mounted turrets and a set of broadside guns, with the number of each depedning on your ship. Different turrets excel at different things, from taking down enemy fighters, disabling shields, or blowing the armor plating clean off a capital ship. Your broadsides are meant to be capital ship destroyers, with you circling your opponent in naval-esque fashion and bombarding them from one side or the other of your ship. Although combat only taking place in one plane, it is very enojyable and rewarding to watch your turrets anihilate enemy craft like mere flies.Now not being able to move up and down may feel like a real let down, being stuck only moving fowards, backwards, and turning. But really, it isn't, once you open your mind to it. Space is still a very big place, and I can understand how adding upwards and downwards movement may be too much for some people.As far as space itself, the races have no real lore or background of any sort, and the game is definitely not one to get you any extra information on any of them. However, there is much, much to do, from pirating, to mining, to trading commodities between various stations that can be in various states such as economic boom or famine, driving various prices of various commodities up, or down. You could also just hunt various bounties in each system, or perform various types of quests for the different factions in the game, such as the militia or merchant guild.Lastly, I greatly enjoy both the graphics and the sountrack. I often find myself staring at the various stars and planets in the game, even being mesmerized by the movements in an ice field. For the sountrack, the twangy rock style fits perfectly into combat or encounters whenever it is triggered, fading in and out at appropriate times seamlessly.Overall, I would say this is an easy 8/10, with my only qualms being that sometimes long journeys in space can be a bit dull, with the only breakups being enemy AI that are far too willing to jump into combat they cannot possibly hope to win, and it is incredibly annoying to be halted from light speed because you came just BARELY too close to a stray rock in an asteroid field. Well worth the money I spent on it, and a truly great deal if you can ever catch it on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Man, eat your heart out Han Solo!  Space adventure and star-RPG action not seen IMHO since the likes of Freelancer.  Great soundtrack, lots of gratutious space battles, arcade-like control, plenty of alien races to blast into the next dimension.  The controls, while a bit awkward at first to me, after a while they became intuitive and better than I'd say Freelancer's was...  And I'm an old sk00l die-hard Freelancer fan.The star systems are beautiful and actually laid out like a real star system, orbit paths shown and all,(via the map mind you) something I always wished Freelancer had done, instead of being static planets laid in a "small" star system.The attention to detail of the ships is great and you can even see "scarring" of battle damage done to your ship in realtime.  These things really give the feel to the game to make it truly a space sim.The dynamic economy and persistant universe features are also great features I loved from Freelancer are well done here also.  There are many many things done in Rebel Galaxy I had always wished Freelancer would be, but sadly it's no where near the depth and "size" of it.So with that said, the game is not without flaws though, It's story line is interesting and engaging, but also very short.  There is only a total of 14 solar systems in this game to explore, last I remember vanilla Freelancer had about 40-50 of them, some mods had an upwards of over 150 systems! (Crossfire 2.0)  Far too small of a universe to explore IMHO.While you do eventually upgrade to bigger and badder ships, sadly IMHO the name of the game is speed in these space battles and most of the big boys are far too slow to stay alive.  To me the only "big ship" to upgrade to is the Blackgate, (the biggest dreadnaught there is!) anything less and if you're overwhelmed, you simply won't be able to weather the assault or run from them.  Your upgrades, defenses and weapons are far more of an important factor in survival here as well as your tactics.(and hire a friggin' Merc fighter pilot!)As far as the BGM, I did enjoy the soundtrack at the beginning it eventually began wearing thin on me and I finally ended up muting the BGM.  Don't get me wrong, I love Blues Sacrenro and the songs are some of the best on a game's soundtrack I've heard in a long time, but listening to it for weeks on end?  Ahhhh, thanks but no thanks... In closing, the game has ALOT of great things going for it and I truly see it as a "spiritual" successor to Freelancer.  However, I can only assume due to the abbreviated schedule of the Double Damage team limited them to  what they were able to cram into the game is that sadly it's nowhere near of the likes of it's predecessors like Eve Online, the X series, Freelancer and so forth.  Therefore I feel you'll get your money's worth, but this is only if you're looking for something "entry level" in a space sim as this game is very approachable to casual gamers I'd say.  Try it for the space sim, stay for it's "arcade-like" action.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												That was a nice 20 hours experience. :-)   Not less, and no more.+ Simple gameplay, nice combat mechanics. You're flying in 2D on a med to large ship. So fight mechanics is like a sea battle. You have broadside weapons you have to aim with, you have turrets / torpedos / mines. You can also ram opponents with a special deflector (buy fast thrusters and a fast ship for that!). It is up to you to change the ship and fight dynamic and distance.+ Nice music (you can set it to your own music if you wish).+ Bright and colorful space. I know that this is unrealistic. But this is just the thing I wanted in X3 and the thing I've enjoyed in Freelancer. You can freely travel among a few systems with a warp  jump drive. Driving during a warp jump within a solar system is cool!+ The space exploration is a nice part of gameplay. Although, it's not very rewarding. You'll find some bounties, stations to be hacked, save a lot of miners from pirates (or the other way). But you won't be able to find any true gems / hidden space stations (the thing I've enjoed in Freelancer).+ Trading looks nice. However, never tryed that. Just like the feeling that I could. Newsboards, station switching states. Lively (not very lively, still nice).+ Pirating ability and "change the side" possibility is also a nice part of the game.+ Something original world setting. Looks a bit like Warhammer (edge of it) - you're trading with religious tracts! It's shame that they didn't say more about it.- Few (only one) side quests. Quests from mission board sometimes challenging (take "hard" and "very hard" only!) but, you'd get dull after 20-30 of them.- You do not really influence the solar system state with your action. So.. No stategy here. I think it would be nice to take stations from one side to another and do some other sort of global things (like in Pirates or in Space Rangers / Seadogs).- Bad keyboard mapping and froms GUI. At least for PC users. At least during first 2 hours of gameplay. You'll get used to it and it would be OK after an hour of gameplay. In general, the fight controls are nice. But....  First, there were no presets for some important buttons, so I had to manually select some buttons. Then I changed the whole mapping since some of the presets were awful. Then I figured out that I am not able to use my Thrustmaster gamepad here (so what is "full controller support"?). it took me 3 minutes to figure out how to close the tutorial message. It took me 2 hours to find the right spot where to click "sell this good" in the commodities market. After 10 hours I've figured out that I can use arrow keys instead (which I set to do nothing in game settings), not with WASD keys (wich I used). After 3 hours of gameplay I've figured out how to use map (press 1 and use the mouse wheel). After 17 hours of gameplay I've figured out that there is a menu when you're in space where you can switch between missions / cargo (here's how one drops the cargo!) / AI turret preset (wow! but still this wheel widjet works strange). And it turned out that I can change pages only right to left. Not the other way (there is "Esc" button assigned to it wich should change the page, but closes the window).- One button to rule them all: collect cargo with tractor beam, warp jump, receive incoming hail, close windows. Everything is done with holding the same button. Most of the time it's ok. But I hate the moment when I want to collect that damn cargo and talk to the pirate instead (for 10 times in a row, having him in a long range). Or want to jump and hear only "the ordinance is full".- Buy the I still do not understand how to sell ordinance. Took something in the beginning of the game and now I cannot collect any more and sell it. I do not use rockets / mines, though.So, this is a nice arcade game. If you like arcade games that took place in space, you'll gonna enjoy it. If you prefer solid-like games (like X3 or Elite) - than you'll probably get bored at one point.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												This game is simply amazing.This game is the natural evolution of a 2d space scrolling shooter like Tyrian or Galactix.  It's a wonderful mix of those games, your standard space-trader game, based on Tradewars 2002, and Firefly all rolled up into one giant explosive ball of awesome.  Many spaceship games now-days require days or even months of tutorials and online reading just to fit your ships properly, position your ship, what you can take on and what you can't, etc.   Rebel Galaxy you can just jump into and be blowing stuff up in minutes.   While i love a good space sim, The attention to detail and realistic physics in those games makes the learning curve incredibly difficult. Keeping this game on a single flat plane, and then creating the game around that plane is a stroke of sheer genius. I've even put down playing Fallout 4 for this.

												Not X5, Not freelancer, much better then most space games. Think Firefly, with bigger ships, minus the ground stuff. Its pretty neat. Its a testament to how a sound track can make a game.I have not finished the game but I am getting there and I love it so far here are my thoughts, maybe updated when I finishPros: Lots of ships- It seems like the two main factions have 8 and then there are a few more. Lots of parts for those ships- All sorts of interesting mods to your standard ship stuff, Cool things like deflectors that make enemies take damage when you ram them!Decent Combant(read in cons)- Cool combat system, it changes up the standard sit and shoot captial ship fightsGreat Sound Track- speaks for itselfOk StorylineCons:2D movement, yea its not a deal breaker but its sucks when  you need to get around as asteroid. I get that it is alot more work to do but it would of helped a lot about the game.Horrible voice overs for some characters, some are great but most are ehh, maybe you should not of gotten your friend. In particular a few of the mercs you can hireCombat can be finicky, things like bad feed back, infinate missles from opposing ships when you can only carry 20 or so and the like is annoying.Artifical scaling, when you get stronger suddenly most enemies do too. It makes it hard to progress as often your upgrades feel a little meaningless.Overall-Get it, for the price it is great. It could be better, I hope it is open to mods as there is a lot more that could be done with this game. Particularly a randomized universe expansion. It isn't X, it isn't a dogfighting game it is its own thing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Prior to the praise, let me say this.  I eagerly await SOME form of update or additional content to bring us...well...additional content.That being said, after spending a few days with this gem, I'm blown away!  This is exactly what I've been craving in a space/flight game.  I have tried and tried to gain proficiency piloting in Elite Dangerous via keyboard and just can't get it down.  With this game, you navigate on a single open plane.  This is a nice simple navigation and "broadside" battle setup that you will not find overly complicated.  If you played Assassin's Creed: Black Flag and got relative enjoyment from the broadside battles at sea, then you should already be downloading this game.Although the battle is not overly complicated, it is by no means simplistic.  There is plenty of strategy to the battle and the biggest payoff is in how you outfit your ship (Black Flag again).  The main story keeps you going, no dullness yet. Also, extra big kudos to the soundtrack.  I could fly around the various systems picking fights and hauling cargo all day long with this music jamming!I truly hope the developers push this a little further with maybe some deeper missions or stories to pursue.  It is, after all, a REALLY big sandbox.  Also, if it's not to much to ask maybe a tad more complexity be invested in the space stations.  It's not a game breaker like some whiners say, but I can see where a little more polishing could help.  Frankly, I'm in and out of stations in the blink of an eye so I don't mind copied and pasted stations.  I'm more eager to get back out there and destroy something!Space Truckin' On    8 of 10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy goes for the western in space vibe, and it succeeds at it. The soundtrack and characters definitely feel reminescent of Firefly. One thing I particularly enjoy is that the game puts you in control of massive capital ships instead of tiny fighters like most games. You start off with a smallish cruiser, but can work your way up to massive dreadnaught vessels that feel great to pilot.The story is nothing special, but I enjoyed it. The side quests can get repetitive, but if you don't mind a bit of grinding then you probably won't get bored of it. I enjoyed the combat, so the side quests remained engaging to me.The combat is quite simplistic for a combat game, but enjoyable never-the-less. It's inspired by naval combat, and takes place on a 2d plane. Every capital ship has an assortment of broadside cannons and turrets. You're turrets are enough to take out most smaller vessels, but for other capital ships you'll want to get along side of them and use your broadsides. There are a ton of different ships, items and upgrades to unlock. There is also a good variety of side grades, allowing you to pick a unique playstyle. As for actual in game activities, there are story missions, delivery runs, dead drops, trading, mining, bounty hunting, and various other mission types.Highly recommend if you're a fan of scifi/space combat games. It's more of an arcade game then a sim, and you can only fly on a 2d plane though.

Posted: January 2, 2016
												So far, i have a really good feeling about this game.Somewhere between an arcade shoot em up and a space sim, i just love the space western cowboy touch. It reminds me of Starcraft and Firefly. Now, i found the music excellent, kinda stoner rock close to QOTSA. Though with a few hours of play, the music gets repetitive so i put it down to 4%.The gameplay is ok, you fight horizonnally so you can't pitch and roll, not like a real dogfight anyway. Broadside weapons, laser beams, mines, flak canons, if you've watched Harlock or Yamato anime you'll understand what it's about =). While you choose one set of weaponry, the others will be auto attacking, i personnally prefer using only turrets with shieldbursters. It gets really strategic at some point, because going melee won't work all the time. You have port, starboard, front and rear shields and hull, so go for a mindful plan of action. You have boosters and speed control for a reason. Also i love those warp animations !You can also mine, trade, hack things ... It's not as complete as Elite Dangerous but it's totally ok for me. This arcade game won't consume your entire life.

												A good Space RPG though a bit grindy. The game looks pretty good on the graphics side and the music fits the game pretty well. The game is kind of like a simplistic version of Elite Dangerous in a lot of ways minus the size and RG has a story/ The story is a bit short and just ok. Though having a fleet of dreadnoaghts rolling with you would have been sweet. Its not a complex space game if your looking for some thing more sim like say the X games or Elite Dangerous but its a fun game and worth the $20 asking price. there is a good amount of content in the game .

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												This game is giving me everything I WANTED from Star Citizen.Heading into an iceteroid (ice asteroid) field at high speed, drop out, surrounded by Double Jack a-holes, with my Trigun soundtrack blazing (it lets you add your own music to  the already excellent soundtrack).  Take out a few small fry, then scream around a giant iceteroid to sneak up on the big gunship, unleash a swarm of missiles in its face, then a couple broadsides and it explodes, taking out the iceteroid with it. My wingman helps clean up the trash.It's 'only' 2D, with 3D graphics, but it works really hard to make you feel so f#@$ing epic.Remember those old Ambrosia games like Escape Velocity (and of course Star Control)? It’s like that except 3d engine and you’re right down behind the ship and that makes things a lot more badass.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												As I look back fondly at Freelancer and how I could spend nights hunting pirates and trading illegal goods in the edges of the galaxy, I noticed Rebel Galaxy hit steam and thought, wonder if this is going to be one of those “trying to hard” games or actually good.Well it’s actually good.Now I’m not going to call it a masterpiece, but I will say it is very entertaining in this day and age where everyone is trying to do something new and innovative. I suppose the kinda new thing is how the combat works, closest example is probably world of warships, but in space and even that comparison is not giving it justice.--Movement and Combat.--The ship that you pilot is on a horizontal axis so you can only move back, forwards and sideways, this makes it easier to pilot the ship and aim your guns to your target. Targeting is automatic in a sense that the target you are directly aiming at is your primary target.The ships you pilot have broadside ports on both sides of the ship and the number of them varies on the ship you pilot, The Broadside is your primary weapon as you can’t set it to automatically fire.Your ship also has turret spots, however your turrets can be set to automatically fire at set targets and you can choose the primary target for each individual turret. You also have access to a secondary armament slot that can be outfitted with different armaments ranging from flak fighter/rocket countermeasures to mines and missiles.--Ships and components.--As you would imagine, you can buy and outfit a wide array of different ships, each with their own unique specialities. This also means some ships are more heavily armored than others, or boast more potential firepower.Most things on the ships can be upgraded to a better variant, like more armor plating, better shields, thrusters, engines, bigger cargo hold and so on, you get the general idea.--Stations and trading.--Each solar system that you can enter and explore has stations and these stations, mostly, can be used as a hub to repair, refill and outfit your ship to your liking. However, that is not all you can do. You can visit the bar to get the latest news from the news board that gives you an idea what is going on in your solar system, this is an ever changing system, some stations might have a tech boom that bumps up the price of technological trade goods, making it more lucrative for traders to sell their goods to that particular station, this mostly means you.You can also pick up different missions from the mission board, that all range from, go and kill this dood, defend this dood from being killed by this dood, pick up this thing that this dood lost and so on, you get the general idea.As you would imagine, one of the easiest ways to earn money is to work the market. Buy a bulk of trade goods for cheap from a back end station and take it to a prime trade port to get the most out of your goods, rinse and repeat.I remember making convoluted trade routes in Freelancer to earn millions in a few hours simply by working the market, flying from system to system, buy goods that are cheap in that system, fly to the nearest highest bidder and sell the goods and repeat the same thing. I can imagine this tactic would work here and even slightly better because of the ability to steer your ship during warp.Like I mentioned earlier, stations are not solely for trading however. Some stations are designated as guild bases, like for example the first system you start in houses a merchants guild that offers unique ships and components unique to that faction.--Interaction.--What I mean with interaction is just the general interaction with other pilots that you come across while flying around in space. Your choices matter, not much, but they matter. The same goes for your story missions, like for example, one mission in the beginning you have the chance to bribe a pirate to make themselves disappear or just kill him like you’re asked to. These sorta decisions keep popping up all along your adventures and even in random encounters while exploring, like for example, you just saved a trader from pirates and scanned his cargo hold to find some very expensive materials, do you kill the guy or let him go?--Verdict.--I would imagine that Rebel Galaxy is very good for what it is trying to do, it’s deep enough to keep people of different moralities happy. Sure it’s not the most beautiful looking game out there, but it’s not a game you want to put a paper bag over either. Combat is nice and simple and offers variety of what weapons you can and want to use, same goes for ships and other components. For people looking for a slightly more casual space sim, Rebel Galaxy is your game.And let’s not forget the bloody music, oh my gawd the music. So Firefly, So Firefly.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												To get it out of the way, this is a great game. It is not without its problems but at its core it is, as I said, a great game.So, what makes this game great?- Great soundtrack- Great combat- Great universe- Do what you feel like. Trade, be a merc, go bountyhunting etc etc. - Big galaxyNow, with that said there are some things you should know. First, this game is played on a 2d plane. Imagine it like a naval game and you are not far off. You broadside enemies and there is no moving up or down, just forwards, backwards and to the sides. This has turned into a big issue for people who bought the game and expected Elite Dangerous, so consider this a heads up. (How in the world you can buy a game "in the dark" today what with Lets Plays and beta reviews being everywhere is beyond me). Secondly, the game has its issues, escort missions for example are horrible due to very odd pathfinding. The friendly AI tends to get itself killed more often than not. Finally its quite easy to break the game early on. There is nothing stoping you from (ones you buy the jump drive) to trade around in the starting system, get a lot of money and then jumping to a late game systemto buy the best weapons, ships, mercs etc. Anyway, if you like Firefly, Star Wars and games like Freelancer and Elite Dangerous be sure to check this game out!

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												Great game. Reminiscent of Starfleet Command (for space & combat mechanics) with a dash of Freelancer thrown in (for trading and reputation mechanics), but with more fast-paced action and fluid gameplay than the first.Highly recommended for those on the fence, with two caveats - one, like the vast majority of sandbox games, it can get grindy. Two, don't expect much in the way of meaningful dialogue choices - there aren't as many of them as trailers suggest. That said, boy is it a fun "grind" and has yet to get old after 10 hours of gameplay for me - that's well worth those 4 lattes."Negotiated" with pirates, militia, aliens, and people who look at me funny. Would "negotiate" again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												If your a fan of the t.v series "Firefly", you will adore this game. Space meets the wild west of america. You can pretty much play however you want to really, either as a pirate, a merc, a bounty hunter, a trader, a do-gooder, a member of the system milita or anything else that comes to mind. Factions are present in the game and you can change your relations with the vast amount of them. The milita, citizens, red devil cartel and others are the major "players". There is a lot of replay-ability in this game and each playthrough offers a lot to do. Any valuable free time?, prepare for it to simply cease existing.There are quite the variety of ships to choose form each with their own playstyle and role in combat, ranging from corvettes to huge dreadnaughts bristling with firepower. Also, RAMMING SPEED! is completley viable when you get the right deflector shield. >:DIn terms of preformance, the game is pretty well optimized and I havent experienced any FPS drops nor crashes or glitches in the game so far. The only real issue is with the set up for the graphics being done out side of the game before launch. Other than that the game has rebindable keys for those wanting to change their keyboard set up and is also usable with a game pad as well.Finally lets get some of the "meh" points out of the way: 1) such as only being a 2D plain which really isnt to much of a problem (unless your a 3D space I WANNA GO EVERYWHERE fanatic) but a 3D plain would be nice but the game still works great with just 2D, and 2) being only a singleplayer experience which is great but the concept of playing with friends in co-op or being in a large server with many others effecting the world of rebel galaxy together. The possabilites are pretty big. Think player made factions and guilds fighting wars for resources or player made pirate groups raiding player escorted relief convoys that will effect economys in the game and the major factions relations and standing in the world.Overall I would very much recomend this game to anybody who is a fan of si-fi and or western drama with its beautiful world and fun gameplay with a large choice of options and intense ship on ship combat.I hope to see you all out there in this mad galaxy my fellow starship captains! for profit! for reputation! and for being the greatest badasses that this galaxy's ever seen!

Posted: October 20, 2015
												You are a young budding pilot who recieved a cryptic message from your Aunt Juno, leading you to strike out and find her. Find her you do, and along the way you will mine asteroids, scavenge wreckages, deal with aliens and battle space pirates. Are you a do-gooder? A shifty privateer? Perhaps a crafty space trader? I'll bet you land somewhere in between.It is easy to see how you could play this game again and again. You are given the option to comply, bribe or even double-cross agents, regardless of their faction. You have the ability to be a good guy, or a despicably seedy character, like you see in so many sci-fi stories. Perhaps you want to replay it and see how quickly you can get through it. Others may want to amass the greatest weapons available, and go pick on squadrons of smaller fighters. There are several reasons you could find yourself coming back to Rebel Galaxy.Check out my full review @ Brutalgamer.com: http://brutalgamer.com/2015/10/17/rebel-galaxy-pc-review/

												Early review. its not actually a bad game, haven't found anything wrong in my opinion it is a great game.. when it comes to space games it can be a hit or a miss. which we all know. and this hits right on the bullseye-_- in my opinion. anyways it a great space game for people that want a little bit more ease when it comes to maneuvering in space.. here its like forward, left and right, and your good. and the weapon system is quite enjoyable its nice to command any gun i want. think of the combat style as a battleship and will be firing on your broadside alot, while having the smaller turrets on the top and bottom taking care of the smaller to hit ships which help alot, but if you want to, you can manually use them yourself. and theirs different factions to go towards to get different quests, different outcomes and ships....YES. so its good to know that once i played it through one time, i can do it all over again, but going to do something different. graphics are really good, the music in the background remind me of Cowboy Bebop which is pretty awesome and the combat is so engaging and fun and easy to learn that no one should have any difficults with. so in this case for this game being only $20 and on sale for $18 is a must buy product, and you will do alot of missions, before the 2 hour mark. so have fun within the two hours then return. or keep it..... its up to you.10/10 would warp speed into a fleet of pirate missile ships and die:(, Again..

												I just beat this after mainlining the last half of the story. It was very hard since my ship fell behind in upgrades and required some pretty fancy flying. I would say a more resonable completion time would be around 30 hours.This isn't an immersive space sim, it's more of an arcadey game than that, but I had a wonderful time and plan on going back in and playing another character. Graphics, music, and the flight model are all great. 2D flying really was the right decision here. The only complaint I have is the lack of variety of non-story quests, but there's enough to do out there to last 20-30 hours for sure.Well worth the price paid. I found it more entertaining than the recent releases in the Elite or X series.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												So, this game is awesome. A really well made title, the graphics are bright, colourful and convey the lay of the land easily. At no point have I felt confused by an overcluttered UI, or even a lack of a helpful one, the UI is designed *just* right as it conveys what you need to know and what is useful to know without hiding important information.The ship design, while by no stretch unique, is striking and follows easily identifiable paradigms, no matter the faction A Frigate is A Frigate is A Frigate, so to speak, which allows for easy identification of targets and thus target priority.Weapons are cool, different types are covered; Projectile, Laser, Pulse, Missle, Flak, EMP, Mines, any combination of them is allowed AND the controls for them are simple (certainly on a controller, which I would recommend.)Overall I've found, so far, that this is a solid game with a nice twist on the Space Sim genre, no longer controlling the fighters and the one man craft, this is the big leagues! Corvettes, Frigates, Destroyers, Haulers, Dreadnaughts, Battleships, Cruisers.My only complaint is the lack of a player based Z-axis, so while the enemy craft and allied ones) dance around you, up and down, you are stuck on the planetary plane, but honestly there could be much worse faults!

												My only regret is that i played this game trough too fast. Story is decent and the game mechanics are fun, if you are ok with two dimension navy space ships. Voice acting is little awkward at times which makes it quite endearing in my opinion (tired of reading 10 pages of quest text? anyone!?) and it's nice change from constant reading (what happened to VOs??? Devs do it more!+++). Finnish alien language sounds too hilarious so +.+ Solid mechanics (turret mode could be better if you like to manually use them)+ Very good music.+ Voice-overs (yes, in my books this is huge plus)+ Some randomness to each playtrough (sector map is random dunno what else)- 'E' does everything, and i mean everything, and it constantly tries to do the wrong thing, "warp away, mmmnope, have a orion slave girl that was floating in space for no apparent reason"- Too fev music tracks (after 40 hours it gets repetitive).- No highspeed collision damage (sublights full to a meteor? Don't worry we have your back with our military grade undestructeablemonumnumnum)- Boring last boss (i literally just stood still in my speedyspeedycorvette, and shot him full of holes)- Could use a co-op for a friend, mercenaries suck :D I hope they expand on how each playtrough is unique, like more trell passive skill choises, which have direct effect on how you build your ship. more weapons, ships, modules, more everything.This was the first game in a long time, i didn't have to grit my teeth just to play it trough, and after the main story, it left me wanting for more, so here's hoping for more content!Random thought during playtrough "if this game and eve online had a baby, i wouldn't stop playing it, even if i would starve" scary...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												Great Game! It's sort of like mixing some of the gameplay of Freelancer with the asthetic of Firefly. It's also a bit reminiscent of the ship to ship combat in Black Flag. This is not a very complex game. It seems to favor simplicity over complexity vs other space games, and focuses on providing alot of fun action that's easy to get into. Similar to other space games, it provides the ability to trade, mine, and salvage (sort of). To me, however, the most fun in this game can be had bounty hunting and doing randomly generated missions, both of which get me into a combat. For context, I usually end up trading or mining in other space games because I usually don't care for the combat. The game provides alot of carrots to chase through ships and equipment upgrades. The story aspect of the game is serviceable but nothing too deep. Personally, I'm kinda ok with that. Another nice plus is the price.It never ceases to put a smile on my face every time I play.

												I can recommend this game for anyone who doesn't mind a space combat game that is actually only on a 2D plane. Posted: October 20, 2015
												After two hours, first impressions are everything and this is very polished for an Indie... In my opinion this is the closest, so far, to Privateer. Bearing in mind I have just started to play it, not very far through but so far it's blowing my mind. What set's it apart from the X games , and what i missed most about privateer, is the whole landing on the station/planet interacting with the bar/shipdealer etc. Combat is pretty fun , the sound track is brilliant, it fits the game so well. I would say if you like Privateer, get this, if you liked the X games with the intense trading and diplomacy etc, might be a little too simplified for you. All in all, for the price this is a bargain. Hope these guys do a squel or similar and spend a bit more cash because this has so much potential. The only thing that may be a downside, is that space is not a 2D landscape, except in this game. Minor gripe , and I can see why the did it with respect to the combat style of the game. Love the whole broadside thing, like oldschool naval ships giving it to each other. Graphics are good without blowing your mind (on ultra), sound is pretty good. Did I mention it was the closest to Privateer that i had played in a long time.... Loved that damn game....

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												I'd say this one delivers the bang for the buck. The random maps and some other things make me think there is probably some good replayability, but I'm thinking even if I just finish a single play through I'll get more than my money's worth.Great production values for a $20 game. The voice work really adds a lot to the game to make it feel alive. There's more depth in just about everything than I expected. Except the actual flight... it is 2d. But that's just fine by me and it may even work to the game's advantage. The broadside naval-style combat works and seems pretty good.I haven't noticed any technical issues in the two hours I spent with it so far. Seems like it might be bigger/longer than I expected. I'm not out of the first system after two hours and I think there were around 10 systems when I looked at the map. I haven't kept the pedal to the metal for progressing the story but I haven't screwed around a ton either. I also see very expensive things to buy I won't be able to afford for quite a bit longer without major windfallsTravel can seem a bit slow, but I have yet to play any space game where more time than I liked wasn't spent just getting where I want to go and it isn't very bad here.The bit of the story I've seen so far is decent. 8/10 - Only because I haven't played enough to *know* it doesn't have any major shortcomings.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Best space\space ship simulation game to come out in a long time! Reminds me of Freelancer with the look and feel and the combat is fresh and AWESOME!! Still learning the game but the developers REALLY put a lot of thought and heart into this game. First purchase I have been excited about in years!!The combat is VERY different than any other space game I have played. Different from ANY other game where you control a craft that fires projectiles except maybe an age of sail game! It is broadsided firing mixed with controlable turrets mixed with system components, like the deflector which absorbs incoming damage on activation, and a bunch of other features. You have to actually ENGAGE in combat, even more so than a typical arcade shooter system!! Its intense and the feeling of popping another ship, even a fighter, is satisfying!!The other features of the game are astounding so far. HUGE systems to explore, random encounters, the feeling of actually EXPLORING space! I cannot wait to get home tomorrow so I can get back into this gem!!Thank you Double Damage, for making a game that takes traits of previous great games, improving upon them and adding a TON of more great stuff to it!! I would have paid $60 for this game and $20 is a STEAL!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												This game is AMAZING! It's a space-faring game that incorporates space piracy, shady dealers, and mercenaries, which gives it a wild west feel. The graphics are gorgeous at the lowest settings, and the soundtrack adds a sense of adventure. The game does away with third dimension travel, which lessens the complexity and doesn't hurt the game at all. The combat is naval style, meaning your main weapon is your broadsides. This is really difficult to master but its super fun. I would recommend this game for anyone with a mild interest in pirates, or anyone who likes to be evil/troublemaking, because in this game you can become enemies with anyone. You can shoot down trade vessels and steal the cargo, or recieve distress calls and destroy pirates. Or both. The only people I wouldn't recommend this game to are players looking for a deep, complex space sim, because that is the one thing this game isn't.

content:

												Very Firefly vibe - what's not to love about this?!While there are some buggy AI behaviors, overall the game feels very well polished. I was very skeptical of the 2D-plane in space mechanics, but it works very well. While I have not played A.C. Black Flag - I can completely understand what other players reference with the Broadside combat mechanic. I fought them at first, but it is - in a sense - what the combat is built around and quickly learned to embrace the combat style (and learned to love it).If you are looking for a solid game with some openness to it - pick up Rebel Galaxy. You know, until that other space-exploration game comes out --- what's it called... No Man's Sky? Will be a great time-killer, but will also likely want to come back for more after the initial play through.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												Great 'beer and pretzels' single player starship game.  If you want something fun, without a zillion buttons to press, and challenging, this is it.Except...the game can lock up your rig; and, game saving is done automatically by overwrite...you get 1 dynamic save per 'character', so it reverts your pc to the status of a console.  On top of that, your save files can be corrupted, and they can disappear...I lost 33 hours of play through losing a save file, and had to restart.Edit/update:After several further restarts, and freezes resulting in the game not recognising the save file (sometimes they disappear, some times the game just doesn't recognise they exist), I gave up and went off to play something else.I still think it's a good game, just that the save system and its' bugs killed it for me.  It's 2016, we deserve better.

												This game is better then Eve online.  1) I don't have to deal with real players that have been playing soooo long that your toast before you set foot into 1 ship.2) I like the fact that it's a single player game and it allows me to progress at my own pace.3) I can finally afford time to play the game and buy a dreadnought in a month vs eve online 6 months to get in and 1 year for max skills. for that ship.4) I don't have to worry about replacing a ship after I get destroyed,.  This game is like the old privateer but better.  I Played privateer years ago and my only thing I wanted is to buy a bigger ship in that game and continue playing with better weapons.  This games offers that.  Even tho once I max out, I will have an issue with what ship to use.  I am hoping that even at end game that mk 7 weapons drops out in space or found in distance part of the galaxy while scanning or flying around out in untravel areas of the star system.  We shall see.One last thing, my thanks to the game makers for not removing game play from youtube.  Without watching those game play, I would not have gotten this game at all because of the uncertanity of what this game is about.  Trailers are good, but watching gameplay is better.  In addition, please allow the sites to play the music.  You may find having other players show a game play of your game may bring in more buyers.  I did and I like the way it played so I bought it.I did get blown up a few times but I was able to start up where I left off from the stations.  Kudos thanks.  At least I do not have to start all over again or that far back.  I am very happy about that.  I did learn from it. I do have a request if your reading this,  Can we get a trade computer.  If its already there then I must of missed it.I hope to see future expansion of this game further into the galaxy.   If you need help with idea, just ask the community.  We have plenty of idea.  I even have a nasty idea in fighting around a black hole...

												What a great game! I really found it quite addictive even though its a little repetitive, there is nothing like getting the biggest guns you can and annihalating every enemy on the map. Word of advice though, I found it much more challenging to stick with a corvette ship (the faster the better) and complete the full storyline in that. When you get to the end of the story you should have it pretty much fully kitted out and as the kit you buy stays with you when you swap ships the hard work will have been done. I then amassed some cash and got the largest ship I could just to have some fun and see what trouble I could get myself into.(The main reason for doing this: when you get the really large ships they are really OP which in my opinion takes a bit of fun out of the main storyline).Again the game is well worth the money, its very easy to play, really good fun and you get many hours of enjoyment from it. I'm looking forward to any expansions these guys may bring out too.Have fun!

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												So, this game is awesome. A really well made title, the graphics are bright, colourful and convey the lay of the land easily. At no point have I felt confused by an overcluttered UI, or even a lack of a helpful one, the UI is designed *just* right as it conveys what you need to know and what is useful to know without hiding important information.The ship design, while by no stretch unique, is striking and follows easily identifiable paradigms, no matter the faction A Frigate is A Frigate is A Frigate, so to speak, which allows for easy identification of targets and thus target priority.Weapons are cool, different types are covered; Projectile, Laser, Pulse, Missle, Flak, EMP, Mines, any combination of them is allowed AND the controls for them are simple (certainly on a controller, which I would recommend.)Overall I've found, so far, that this is a solid game with a nice twist on the Space Sim genre, no longer controlling the fighters and the one man craft, this is the big leagues! Corvettes, Frigates, Destroyers, Haulers, Dreadnaughts, Battleships, Cruisers.My only complaint is the lack of a player based Z-axis, so while the enemy craft and allied ones) dance around you, up and down, you are stuck on the planetary plane, but honestly there could be much worse faults!

And honestly, the enemies and such go up and down above/below you so it's not like the game is on a grid or anything. It is done really well.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												Its Firefly meets Cowboy Bebop meets Battlestar Galactica. Rebel Galaxy is a good-looking and fun space action game with a kickass soundtrack. It plays more of an arcade game rather than a space sim so for those looking for the latter might want to look somewhere else. What this game has is a procedurally-generated, sandbox solar systems set on a 2D plane where the player can explore right from the start.For starters, the player's ship can't roll, pitch, or yaw (sorry, no Crazy Ivan manuevers here) - only forward movement, and left/right turns. This is because the game’s combat is designed around the broadside naval engagements similar to Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag. Basically, you line up your ship (think of it as a space boat) against the enemy ship for a firing solution, and then unload your armaments to see some fireworks. It might sound easy but it has its share of tactical positioning and maneuvering - each side of your ship (front, rear, port, and starboard) has a hull and shield rating. After you eat through a ship’s shield face, you start hitting its hull to do some serious damage. You can spin that damaged side out of the line of fire to regenerate your shields and retaliate or simply retreat and fight another day.The game has a decent selection of weaponry, ships, and ship upgrades. You can also choose to align with different factions but sadly, they have no personalities to speak of outside of the nicely animated talking avatars they have.There is a main quest you can follow, or ignore it and set out in any direction you want and be a trader, a miner, a bounty hunter, or space pirate. You can get missions from space stations that can earn you currency to buy ships/weapons/ship upgrades, as well as alignment points to factions. The said missions can get pretty repetitive after a while, but the gloriously huge space battles keep me coming back for more. Exploration in this game is fun and is rarely dull. It has the same relaxing feel as doing cross country delivery jobs in Euro Truck Simulator 2. There are asteroid fields, floating space junk from the ruins of some old battle (which may contain some sweet loot and military grade weaponry), nebulae of different swirling colors, planets, moons, and of course, stars. It will take a few minutes to fly from point A to point B, but there’s usually some unidentified signal, a distress call, or just a random fleet of space bandits to keep things interesting. The game’s soundtrack is really good. It exudes the same vibe as Firefly with its guitar heavy tracks with twangs. The devs also included the most phenomenal custom music support I have ever seen in a game. There’s nothing like Want It All Back from Cowboy Bebop kicking in as I enter combat. I have Cage the Elephant, Clutch, Johnny Cash, Darren Korb (Bastion OST), Queens of the Stone Age, Yoko Kanno (Cowboy Bebop), Vitaminless (Cowboy Bebop), and Bear McCreary (Battlestar Galactica) on my custom playlist. You can sort and assign them as combat, idle, or title music. Your custom music can also be merged with the game soundtrack for more variety.I definitely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												This game is the sandbox space sim we've been waiting for since Freelancer. Elite: Dangerous too fiddly for you? Loved AC: Black Flag for the ship combat? Enjoyed Firefly? Tired of waiting for Star Citizen to get to a release?Then you're gonna love this game.You fly a capital ship in a somewhat open universe. Trade, pirate, privateer - the choice is yours. Fighter pilots? Pah! I fly a ship that launches broadsides, son, and obliterates your little X-wing knockoff with my Flak.The country and western soundtrack and Southern accents for some of the characters bring the Firefly references in so nicely and casually without explicitly resorting to Firefly-like dialect or setting, making it a subtle, valued tie-in.The game suffers from the procedurally generated fault of being a 'lifeless'-feeling open world. There's also some minor Quality Of Life issues with trying to be a trader - finding out (last known) prices is a bit fiddly. Free trade is also unfortunately not very lucrative, compared to the Mission Boards (which will post trade missions that ironically make FAR more than you could shipping the goods without a contract, after you've gone into the game a bit). But at least the mission boards make the Trader path remain viable along with the plainly-intended Privateer path.You also navigate and fight solely along each systems ecliptic and ignore the third dimension, to a much larger degree than Freelancer or its other wannabe successors. But let's be honest with ourselves - this genre was never about the third dimension.This game is also very well optimized for the technical side.Get this game. It's the game we've been waiting for, and it came with no fanfare.

content:

												Like Space? Like Assassin's Creed style Naval Combat? Like Grungy Country Music? Then this game is a pretty good bet.The levels are procedurally generated and the visuals are fantastic, but this isn't Elite Dangerous. While set in space, the combat functions on a 2D plane, similar to naval combat. It works similar to Black Flag, with broadsides being your main form of defenceWhile set in space and with similar mechanics, this is not a space sim like Elite. Elite is a massive, slow grind, and while R.G. offers tonnes of replayability and endgame content (that I haven't gotten to yet) the game is nowhere near as big or complex as Elite. I do think the combat is more fun, but that's probably just because I'm better at it than Elite.It's definitely not going to live up to Elite, Star Citizen or even No Man's Sky in terms of scope, but it's a pleasant and worthwile investment with a fun gimmick.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Great music! Good concept. Good graphics. Crucially flawed gameplay. The key problem is the mouse interface. Whenever you touch the mouse (I tried several), to do things like aim in a firefight, it automatically zooms in to a top down view of the ship, so you can get a closeup of your ship taking damage and do nothing useful to change things. To get the view up, you must scoot the mouse about four feet with max sensitivity to see who is attacking you and keep scooting the mouse to aim or get a glimpse of the object you're about to run into. It's basically a FPS where it defaults to looking down at your feet and you have to scoot like mad to glance at the enemies.  I can't believe they actually released a game where the mechanics of gameplay fundamentally don't work.Addendum: I'm on a Mac. The fix to the mouse control largely fixed the issue. Broadside aiming is still quite difficult because the camera still pans down automatically, although it is much, much easier to compensate for and the ship still often obscures the view of the target. I find I'm still guessing where the enemy is and firing blind, although often accurately. While clunky, it is now playable.

												First things first.I like this game. The pricing is fair and alright.But stop saying this is Freelancer. It is not. Star Systems and trade are a common in any space game. It has a random quest/mission system and a main story line like Freelancer and this is were they start to differ. The broad fighting system makes this a whole another experience.Another thing are the drops like shield boost you got in Freelancer. Ships in Freelancer were Dog Fighter, fast turning, front fire arc and you had to fire them manually.This game doesnt have this concept. Anyway some pros and cons:Pro:CombatGraphicMusicRandom SystemsWingman/woman/xeno/robotCon:Gameplay elements (will explain further down)2D (fully aware when buying, will explain futher down)One Button for: Docking/Warping/Looting/Acceleration (Context sensitive)So the two cons for me, which happen to drag down the fun quite a lot are this.The gameplay elements i dont like are enemies with missiles/mines/torpedes.See, you have a limited amount of them. Limited like under 24 for the first you can buy. The enemy isnt limited. They will spam this♥♥♥♥♥♥like no tomorrow. I am not exaggerating. I tested an enemy frigate, after i shot down all of the smaller fighters. Five minutes into the fight it was still spamming Hornets and Heat Seeker. The complains about 2D ties someone into gameplay. See, there are fields of debris and asteroid everywhere. The systems are rather big, but while "warping" (Fast Travel, has to be engaged after a build up time of 3-5sec), you will be dropped out by enemies, debris, asteroids. And because its 2D , you have to fly around them, if you want your warping. I dont mind it happening sometimes. But it gets old rather quick. Warping, dropping out, killing/avoiding stuff, build up time, warping, dropping out...you get the idea. Tl;drGood naval space game for time killing with some unlucky gameplay decisions.

												So this wil be the first time i will be writting a review so bear with me. The combat in thisgame is pretty good for a spacecombat game, i particularly like the fact that they try to not make it overcomplicated, Then there is just the feeeling of freedom that you get. You get to go anywhere you want at any point. The feeling of vastness of space is also beautifully achieved, without making the travel times to long. All in all this game is one of the more enjoyable games i have played lately and i would definetly recommend it for everyone.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												This is pretty much the space game I always wanted to play.  Not overly complicated with way too many systems to learn, just having fun flying around a beautiful galaxy, trading materials, destroying space pirates, and listening to an awesome Firely-esque soundtrack! The game takes place on a 2D plane, with an emphasis on broadside combat, but the option for other forms of attack such as turrets, lasers, mines, etc. exists.  Basically, if you've ever played Assassin's Creed IV, the game plays very similarly to the boat sailing and combat, only more responsive and more entertaining.  There are 21 ships available to purchase and fly, as well as many items for customizing them, including weapons, defense, and more!Pros:-Runs perfectly with little to no slowdown.-Beautiful graphics with plenty of options to change.-Great music, with an easy option to add your own music in a number of areas, such as battle music, ambient music, etc.-Big universe.  While not nearly as big as other space games out there, it's still plenty big.  I've played six hours so far and haven't even left the first galaxy that you start in, and there seems to be at least 10+ to explore.-Price: $18 at launch ($20 later) is a steal for this game.  It runs smoother and I haven't encountered any bugs so far, which is more than I can say for many of the AAA games that I've payed $60 for recently.-Most importantly: FUN! Cons: -One of the only cons I would say is that there doesn't seem to be much in the way of a damage model for ships.  If you ship is severely damaged, you may see a few minor explosions and fire going on around it, but you aren't missing any chunks of your ship or anything like that.  Pretty minor in the long run when compared with all the pros.-Possible con is that many of the side missions are similar, so you could get burned out after a while.  The positive is that you can do the story missions which offer a bit more variety, or take a break and play something else for a while!-Not really a con, but you can only save when you dock at a space station, which can be a bit annoying if you need to leave suddenly, but there are plenty of space stations, usually less than a minute away, and the game offers an easy option to find the nearest space station.Overall, if you're looking for a fun game with a cheap price, look no further than Rebel Galaxy.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												I must say I am a bit surprised i'm giving this game a go. I found myself at the 30min mark having a bit of fun then stopped to play something else. Come back to it now at the 1hr mark and I realize something.....this game seems to be getting a bit tedious. I stop again to resume another game and come back later. Looking at the Rebel desktop icon I come to the realization that even at this early of a start I can already see how this game will get boring quickly. Without even feeling bored I can already see it coming. I pause and think and decide to give it the ol college try and make it past and still nope. Combat was "eh", mining I swear was going nowhere (and still don't care for it), trading wasn't a very good option since at the start if you so much as pebble your mighty ship was full in an instant and it all seemed so....not that epic? can't think of a good word. Literally came up on the 2hr mark and the time to decide if it refund or keep. I literally stopped playing for a day and pondered it because the game seemed like it had things going for it. Was absolutely lovely once I got the graphics settings right (gave a different resolution for some reason), combat was simple but effective, everything was flashy, the music and sounds were nice but it just didn't click. But I decided to take the leap and just go with it, and I don't regret it. I believe it was completely my thinking of the game. It's a relatively small download seeming more arcady and simple then anything so maybe I came in with a "rush, rush, faster" mindset. Once I put that aside (and a bit bored) I just pushed through and the game opened up for me. Combat although really simple can be as deep or remain as simple as you want it. With ships having multiple turrets areas it's completely possible to play it smart or just brute force a lot of things.  Set some of the turrets for specific enemies or bigger ship armaments with targeting priorities. Play the smart way with shield specific turrets to take down protection then batter them down with the heavy guns. Get extra protection with deflector shields and anti missile armaments because lord knows there will be lots of missiles being shot at you. Outmaneuver enemies and separate them for easy pickings. OR do like me and just go in guns & lasers blazing allowing anything to target anything in a blaze of bullets, lasers, explosions while taking control of certain ones when needed. Now this may all seem glorious and may be revving your engines and fingers to buy but as I said before, combat can be as simple or deep as you want. There's mining but I mean it's mining so it's not rocket science. Although there are ways to help produce better results but I have personally not dipped too much into it. I will say blowing up space rocks is flashy and hasn't gotten old yet though. Trading is simple and straight forward, buy low sell high with different possible events happening to effect said prices.At some point depending how fast you are you will be somewhat at the top of the food chain in not that long of a time but you can still get stomped at times if you get reckless. There are quite a few ships to get some feeling different then others and some unlocked later by doing or becoming apart of...things. Random map events, battles etc and small touches and details that I won't ruin. Overall I think this is a good game that hopefully gets better and in all honesty at some point will wear thin. This is no surprise as the space warrior can only go so far BUT the time getting there has been enjoyable for me at least. Getting that next ship, getting more turrets, better fire power, being able to go right into the fray just tanking everything and watching your lasers just shoot, blow up and just rip apart many a small ship as you focus on the big ones is a beautiful thing. Or just cruising paying no mind and seeing a kill happen all because an enemy got too close and looked at your turret funny.I believe this game is good and worth a buy and what can ruin it is coming in thinking or expecting something it's not. This game isn't ultra deep requiring big management nor is it as shallow and simple as it seems at 1st. The best way I can think of this game is it's like the "Civilization Revolution" of the lot. Just deep enough to seem familiar and can get you to think a bit but not so overwhelming to put off more simple people like myself (although I do enough a deeper game at times). Do you research, watch a few vids, take it out for a quick spin cause i'm sure some of you will enjoy it.ALSO! whatever you do, do NOT do swarm missions or things with the words "swarm" in them. If your not coming in prepared those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s will rip you a new ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ within another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥~

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy is a game about space ships, shooting, economics, exploration, and more shooting- but I expect if you saw the trailer you probably already knew that. Here's how I have reacted so far to the game in general:What I like:-Battles are an intense and addicting affair with a good deal of variety to them-Controls feel very solid and responsive-Music fits the game really well-The economy of the trading system is both rewarding and highly dynamic-Quality character modelling and voice acting-Random encounters and discoveries when using the warp drive keeps travelling interestingWhat I don't like:-Little to no lore or interesting background details on any of the stations you visit-The universe in general feels empty at times, as if nothing interesting happens when you aren't directly involved-Most of the "new" items you can purchase as you progress are just duplicates of weaker items with improved stats-Escort missions are incredibly slow and frustrating due to stupid AI-Enemy fighters at close range are difficult to target due to how much of the screen is taken up by your shipOverall, Rebel Galaxy is hardly a perfect game but has that magical charm which made me a fan of early space exploration games like Escape Velocity. The fact that I haven't grown bored at all despite the endless barrage of missions required to progress speaks a lot about how fun the combat in this game is. I'd definitely recommend trying this out if you're a fan of the genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												This is one of those very rare games that gets EVERYTHING right. It's an instant recommendation to anybody with even a passing interest in space combat/trading games. 10/10.Gameplay: Starting out with a peice of junk spaceship/peashooter, you fight and trade across a number of solar systems, buying upgrades & better ships as you go. Combat is really good fun - like Sid Miers Pirates! on steroids. Configurable turrets, loads of cominations of weapons with different stats, shield arcs, subsystems damage, free for all and group battles. Basically everything. Trading is really fun too, with supply/demand, random events, and smuggling. You can get hidden weapons and ships by joining guilds. The controls also deserve a mention - perfect with an xbox pad. Presentation: The game is gorgeous, both technically and in design. The devs have nailed the space cowboy/western trope. The ship and station design has a good rugged industrial feel to it, and the space environments are spectacular. Beautiful blue nebula, fading atmospheres extending up from the surface of planets, and searing white heat from stars have all been rendered perfectly. Charachter models in stations/via-comms are excellent too, which is nice considering they're not the main focus. The devs clearly know their way around the graphics API because all the shiny bells & whistles are implimented to good effect and in the right places.Sound: This should be under "presentation", but it deserves it's own catagory because it's so good. SLIDE GUITAR. Good grief I love slide guitar. If there soundtrack were an album, it's one I'd actually buy, which is something I've never thought about a game before. It changes dynamically on the situation too, which is great. The music really cements the feel of the game and it's a big contribution to the success in nailing the space cowboy theme. Content: I'm 20 hours in and I'd guess I'm around 1/3 of the way through the game. That's plenty of content for the price. The placement of stations and missions are procedurally generated too, so there will be some variation if you want to have more than one playthough. You'll get your moneys worth out of this game.Technical: I run the game on max settings on 3 year old hardware, with no issues. The devs are actively pushing out patches and post on the forums. Good job.Overall: 10/10. The devs nailed this one and they must be delighted. Buy it.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												First review, mostly because I'm all about some space sims these days and I think this is an interesting game that needs some clarification.So first of all it's not that deep.  It does get grindy.  The missions, while there are a few variations, do find pilots (captains?  Do you pilot a Dreadnaught or captain it? Whatever.) doing basically the same few things repeatedly.  You can't get out of your ship, you can't walk around your ship, you can't go down to planets, etc. etc.  You can't even fly up or down.  Yeah, true.  But you won't really notice after an hour, I promise.What you CAN do is blow stuff up.  A lot.  And it's pretty damn fun about it, too.  You can also put in your own music that plays in game, which is better than just having a music player on in the background because the in game music fades when you need it too, and if you have a large list of music added you get moments when the perfect song plays for the perfect fight, and it's awesome.  So I recommend this game, especially at the 17-ish bucks I bought it for.  It's pretty,  the combat is quick paced and fun, and if you're like me and waiting for even the beta of Star Citizen or for Elite Dangerous to actually have sand to go in its massive sandbox (Right now Rebel has more variation and more fun moments than Elite, but Rebel is not getting expanded for the next 10 years, so), this will scratch the pew pew itch.  Not going to be spending months and months on Rebel, but it's a fun game that might warrant a couple play throughs if you want to try going through with different factions.Almost forgot:  This is not a starfighter type of game.  You fly naval style big ships with broadside cannons and auto turrets (you can control them, too) that you angle in and open fire.  And when you unload full broadside and watch that other ship explode...I gotta say it feels good.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy is not a simulation, nothing like Elite Dangerous or Starpoint Gemini 2 (both great space-sims); if you want to compare it you best go with Freelancer. The story, tone and visual presentation are very different from Freelancer; where the good old piece of gaming history served a more serious tone and a sci-fi-thriller plot Rebel Galxy offers more upbeat space-western; mysterie and discovery are still here but it feels nothing like what Freelancer showed.Yet Rebel Galaxy is very coherent; no matter if it`s the main storyline or the world your traveling in it all breathes Firefly.Visual presentation is top notch and despite what images and movies might suggest not very demanding, i`m running the game on an older rig and it looks and runs like charm. The whole galaxy your exploring, ships, effects, planets, stations, etc. are just filled to the rim with detail, colors and a unique art-style. Sound-design and music are some of the best i`ve ever seen, the soundtrack (western, space-rock) just hits the nail on the head, voicework is fitting, weapons, ship engines sound impressive. Just like Freelancer you`r free to do what you want (with more options); -explore and find valuable cargo, minerals, equipment-pirate trade-convoys (including a news-flash in stations giving you hints)-trade-bounty hunt-do countless randomly generated missions for various factions (tons of different missions types: escorts, deadrop pickups, breaching blockades, getting certain trade-good and the list goes on)and than there`s a mainplot which starts of rather boring but gets traction very fast and serves the space-western picture perfectly.the game offers tons and tons of different ships to fly, gear to put in your loadout (weapons, shields, engines, subsystems and and and), mercenaries to hire (one at a time) and as a unique twist: your flying the "big ships"; starting with corvettes, frigates you soon hit capital ships like destroyers, etc. .the game is not centered around smaller fighter/bomber craft vessel dog-fights, but on you sitting in a massive turret filled capital class ship ditching out broad-sides (similiar to naval combat) while turrets and your mercenary do the busy work).....and it feels and plays amazing!the games does not offer the whole 3D space, but a 2D plane your flying in, which takes some time gettin used to, but it enhances the arcady gameplay by alot.controls and interface are very very slick and tight, especialy with a gamepad the whole UI and control-scheme feels spot on; it`s hard to describe, but every simple action (from hailing other ships, docking, pulse-scanning, scaning, operating different weapon-systems, to shield managment, etc.) goes just natural. Rebel Galaxy is a very polished, colorfull, space-western, sporting freedom and content...great visuals, amazing music and very non-simulation fun gameplay. the price is very misleading, this in no way feels like a low-budget, indie game, but more like a big-release tripple A game offered for a real bargain.

												If you are a fan of Firefly or Outlaw Star or Cowboy Bebop, you will find yourself right at home on this game.  I have enjoyed it greatly so far.  Why?  Well, let's talk about that.Pros:Fun, hectic combatDifferent ways to tackle a problemTrading system is funThe solar system feels livelyDifficulty; some missions are rather challenging at pointsHigh production quality.  SFX(including VA's) and GFX are both spot on.  Good soundtrack as well.Naval style combat is fun and well doneThe feeling of being an outlaw(or not, if you so choose)Cons:You really make the best money by killing stuff.  By a considerable margin.  This in itself is not a con but if you wanted to do something other than blow stuff up be prepared for the cash to flow in slowly.Difficulty; the difficulty ratings for a mission can be rather ambiguous.  I found myself flying into dire situations thinking it was going to be easy.  Maybe that's just me... I don't know.The entire game is 2D but fighters(non-Capital ship class vessels) and missiles move in a 3D space.  This makes sense but is a con for me as I do prefer three dimensional ship combat.Story could have been delivered much better, especially in the onset of the game.  Suddenly you are given a near derelict craft from a relative but I guess you graduated from flight school or something cause apparently you're a natural and know exactly how to handle this vessel.  Now go kick some space outlaw♥♥♥♥♥All in all this is a very fun game with a unique flavor and at this price point is a good choice for the sci-fi naval combat fan to have some fun.Bang!  See you, space cowboy.

												Recommended, with some caveats. While very pretty, the game feels to lack a lot of polish. My turrets almost destroyed a ship I was supposed to be escorting trying to hit a target on the other side of the escortee. The menus were very obviously designed for consoles, with no work put in for them on PC. Mouse has little functionality in the menus, and you are forced to use the keyboard for all inputs. There are plenty of ships in the game that you won't be able to actually fly, which is a shame because they're some of the best looking ships. It doesn't matter what your reputation is with them you can't buy them, and there's no ship capture mechanic. The really disappointing thing about not having a way to capture ships is that you are forced to do very repetitive missions over and over in order to upgrade. Ultimately, its a "blonde" version of Starsector: pretty and fun, but, in the end, a shallow experience.

												Having just finished off the main quest, I have to say that I fell in love with this game over the past few days. Now? Well, it's still a good game, but its starting to wear a little thin. I'm glad the main quest ended when it did.If you've ever played any of the Escape Velocity games, you're in for a treat here. This is basically what you would get if you threw Escape Velocity into a 3D world (though you can only move in a 2D plane, hence the comparison).In Escape Velocity you had turrets and spinal weapons. Here you have turrets and broadside weapons. I would prefer the option to mount weapons along the spine of the ship, but broadsides are what the developers were going for, and they did it well. The combat in this game is good. It's really damn good. It's challenging and exciting and didn't feel like a chore over the past 23 hours of gameplay.My biggest complaint is actually a pretty small aspect of the game. Mission indicators felt like they were getting in the way of my UI. If I could perhaps turn off the main story's mission indicators, I would have taken this game a little more slowly.
