Posted: October 26, 2015
												If you liked Freelancer, you wil love this.Take on missions, fight enemies, upgrade your ship, jump into about 14 large sectors. It is only one plane of movement (left and right, no up or down) but this helps to keep things simple enough, as during battles, you have so much to do and keep an eye on, that you'd be grateful for it! Having separate AI for separate weapons is fantastic, allows you to preserve your more precious ammo for the important things, and to focus your smaller/ammo-less weapons on the smaller guys.I am loving this game and highly recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												This game is the sandbox space sim we've been waiting for since Freelancer. Elite: Dangerous too fiddly for you? Loved AC: Black Flag for the ship combat? Enjoyed Firefly? Tired of waiting for Star Citizen to get to a release?Then you're gonna love this game.You fly a capital ship in a somewhat open universe. Trade, pirate, privateer - the choice is yours. Fighter pilots? Pah! I fly a ship that launches broadsides, son, and obliterates your little X-wing knockoff with my Flak.The country and western soundtrack and Southern accents for some of the characters bring the Firefly references in so nicely and casually without explicitly resorting to Firefly-like dialect or setting, making it a subtle, valued tie-in.The game suffers from the procedurally generated fault of being a 'lifeless'-feeling open world. There's also some minor Quality Of Life issues with trying to be a trader - finding out (last known) prices is a bit fiddly. Free trade is also unfortunately not very lucrative, compared to the Mission Boards (which will post trade missions that ironically make FAR more than you could shipping the goods without a contract, after you've gone into the game a bit). But at least the mission boards make the Trader path remain viable along with the plainly-intended Privateer path.You also navigate and fight solely along each systems ecliptic and ignore the third dimension, to a much larger degree than Freelancer or its other wannabe successors. But let's be honest with ourselves - this genre was never about the third dimension.This game is also very well optimized for the technical side.Get this game. It's the game we've been waiting for, and it came with no fanfare.

												Its like assassin's creed black flag without the assassin's creed. You pilot a flagship, trade, take contracts, hunt pirates or militia or a number of other different faction, mine, and all that good space stuff. Here's the special part about Rebel galaxy, you move on an X Y axis, no up and down here. This really tightens up the game in my opinion. your ship has turrets, and broadside weaponry, which is why it is comparable to the naval combat. So if you loved the sea faring and could do without the on foot part of black flag, go ahead and grab this game, you will love it. Also the sound track is bomb as hell!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												If you're like me, you might have looked at this and said, "Hmm, could this be like EVE Online?" The answer is yes and no. While it certainly is easier to pick up than EVE, there are some aspects that could really use more explaining, such as "If I switch weapons, does that mean the AI will handle my broadsides while I plink away on turrets?" It also can be rather difficult to concentrate on aiming boardsides, piloting, keeping an eye on shields, and trying to figure out if you should break off your current target and take on the guy plinking you from "behind" your camera. A scrollable camera would be quite helpful for that, or a larger HUD radar. Despite that, it's been rather interesting so far.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Okay, so I just finished the main quest and feel like I'm ready to give my 2 cents. First impressions are good! Great soundtrack, the early space battles have a nice intuitive rock-scissor-paper-feel (probably got them in the wrong order). Mid-game, I'm kind of grinding for credits. I need so and so many million to reach tier 6-weapons and to maybe fight the big battles and come out on top. I don't know if I made it too easy, but I went for the fast "Barracuda" so I could out-maneuver and out-run my enemies and then pick the fighters of off in bite-size chunks and move in to the "blind spots" of the capital ships and just wear them down with ma lazers..  Where was I.. yes the grind! It came to a point where my strategy was sound, but I still didn't feel ready to further the main quest. Lots of grinding later I had my weapons and went in to the much to short late-game and now I'm the hero. And still don't feel like I care about my aunt! I mean, for a game that has the plot-hook, that I want to find my aunt and help her, then they should have focused more on the story-line and flesh out the characters of the game. Most of the missions where fun the first 25 times I did them, except for the escort missions, they NEVER became any fun. While you're in the middle of fighting capital ships and fighters, your escort-buddy up and killed himself. Poor form! The funniest side mission was when a discreet gentleman needed my assistance to reacquire lost items. When I get to the pick up, the cargo is pin-up monthly magazines! The gentleman was shipping dirty magazines and suddenly I understand why I was under oath not to tell his wife. Those kind of quirky side-missions makes me smile. I don't know who that man is, but I instantly like both him and his wife and I'm curious about their relationship and his business enterprise. It's like the developers have good story-writers but they are put on writing up side-missions instead of making sure the follow-through for the main story is solid. If you want 10+ hours of fun, go get it! If you another 10 hours of grind look no further! It's good enough game and I give it my dubious thumbs up. =)

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												CLICK BUY RIGHT NOW!  Rebel Galaxy is a VERY good game.  Fun to play, surprising in its depth, and overall a great value for the money.Gameplay is pretty simple, the story is there and some of the fights can be very tough.The only negatrive thing I've seen so far relates to the mercenary guild.  The mercenary guild (which has a station in each system after the first) gives out random kill/protect contracts - just as the merchant guild does.  After playing through several of these to rank up my standing with the mercs so I could buy a new ship, I noticed that I get a lot of missions that pit me up against system militia and other 'good guy' factions, with no warning in the briefing whatsoever.  On one mission in particular in the second system, the enemies generated for my mission were also mercenary's guild - which resulted in a huge net loss for faction for completing an assignment from that guild.  This makes ranking up the mercenary faction very difficult and frustrating - after tweeting the devs on this, I heard back that it's working as intended, and the only option to get around this is to abandon the mission, fly all the way back to the source, and get another one - which may or may not present the same problems.So I would wholeheartedly recommend Rebel Galaxy - but with the caveat that if you do pick it up, save yourself the frustration of trying to rank up with the mercs and just go with regular civilian or merchant class ships instead.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												Hello SteamersAfter giving the storyline a fast once through i decided to give my review of Rebel Galaxy.  First off great work to the creators of this little fantastic space game.  Finally these guys had the balls enough to put Rock Music in a Space Game and it really ramps up the excitement , I got all the dust cleaned out of my Bose speakers on this game and nothing but a big smile on my face when the explosions started from my missles  firing out the sides of my ship.  Sure there are some things that an older player might sqeem at as far as the cartoonie characters you meet but it's not a far trade off from Jaba.  The ships are superb in design and id have to say they look better than a few of the top rated space sim games on the market.  They give you plenty of mounting options for Lasers,Rockets,Missles,Mines and Mining Lasers that can be used for fighting aswell. There is a Storyline to the game and it's good...... I'm glad there is a storyline here some of the bigger space sims decided to leave out storylines and there games feel like there is somthing always missing even in the missions they have.  Rebel Galaxy seems to understand this and always has some npc in the game coming on screen to talk to you about your next mission or a character trying to make a deal with you.  You are not alone in rebel space there is always someone around to greet you rather if it's good or bad.  This i'm sure is a trail space game by Double Damage to see how it does and all i can say is please give us more we like it.  Well i do any way, this is a great space game to play for a few months and you can't beat the price.  score 86/100

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												Its Firefly meets Cowboy Bebop meets Battlestar Galactica. Rebel Galaxy is a good-looking and fun space action game with a kickass soundtrack. It plays more of an arcade game rather than a space sim so for those looking for the latter might want to look somewhere else. What this game has is a procedurally-generated, sandbox solar systems set on a 2D plane where the player can explore right from the start.For starters, the player's ship can't roll, pitch, or yaw (sorry, no Crazy Ivan manuevers here) - only forward movement, and left/right turns. This is because the game’s combat is designed around the broadside naval engagements similar to Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag. Basically, you line up your ship (think of it as a space boat) against the enemy ship for a firing solution, and then unload your armaments to see some fireworks. It might sound easy but it has its share of tactical positioning and maneuvering - each side of your ship (front, rear, port, and starboard) has a hull and shield rating. After you eat through a ship’s shield face, you start hitting its hull to do some serious damage. You can spin that damaged side out of the line of fire to regenerate your shields and retaliate or simply retreat and fight another day.The game has a decent selection of weaponry, ships, and ship upgrades. You can also choose to align with different factions but sadly, they have no personalities to speak of outside of the nicely animated talking avatars they have.There is a main quest you can follow, or ignore it and set out in any direction you want and be a trader, a miner, a bounty hunter, or space pirate. You can get missions from space stations that can earn you currency to buy ships/weapons/ship upgrades, as well as alignment points to factions. The said missions can get pretty repetitive after a while, but the gloriously huge space battles keep me coming back for more. Exploration in this game is fun and is rarely dull. It has the same relaxing feel as doing cross country delivery jobs in Euro Truck Simulator 2. There are asteroid fields, floating space junk from the ruins of some old battle (which may contain some sweet loot and military grade weaponry), nebulae of different swirling colors, planets, moons, and of course, stars. It will take a few minutes to fly from point A to point B, but there’s usually some unidentified signal, a distress call, or just a random fleet of space bandits to keep things interesting. The game’s soundtrack is really good. It exudes the same vibe as Firefly with its guitar heavy tracks with twangs. The devs also included the most phenomenal custom music support I have ever seen in a game. There’s nothing like Want It All Back from Cowboy Bebop kicking in as I enter combat. I have Cage the Elephant, Clutch, Johnny Cash, Darren Korb (Bastion OST), Queens of the Stone Age, Yoko Kanno (Cowboy Bebop), Vitaminless (Cowboy Bebop), and Bear McCreary (Battlestar Galactica) on my custom playlist. You can sort and assign them as combat, idle, or title music. Your custom music can also be merged with the game soundtrack for more variety.I definitely recommend this game.
